petition.title: Vietnam Veterans
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) that US, Australian and allied forces used huge amounts of toxic chemicals for military purposes, such as Agents Orange, Blue and White, in Vietnam during the war there;
(2) many of these chemicals were, and are, known to be highly dangerous to human health;
(3) Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families are suffering many severe problems which may be due to their exposure to these chemicals; and
(4) the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has been seeking a Royal Commission for well over two years to ensure an independent investigation of these matters.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will
(a) express its support for the Royal Commission; and
(b) urge the Federal Government to establish the Royal Commission immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Commonwealth Home Loans
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the special privileges bestowed on the Deputy Prime Minister Mr Anthony M.P.--

(1) That in 1964 a Liberal/Country Party Government granted Mr Anthony M.P. a Commonwealth Government Home Loan Mortgage of $17,964 for a period of 45 years at a fixed interest rate of 4.75% and that at 1.9.82 the amount of principal had only been reduced by $3,354.06, since 1.10.81 leaving a balance of $14,609.94.

(2) Your Petitioners therefore request that the Government immediately make available similar generous terms to the many thousands of home buyers in Australia who are at present suffering undue hardship and financial embarrassment due to abnormally high interest rates.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth: That
The Great Barrier Reef is unique and is included on the World Heritage List.

Although the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act was to create a marine park to provide for the proper protection and management of The Reef, only 14% of the total area defined in this Act as the Great Barrier Reef Region has been declared marine park.
The only insurance against an oil drilling blowout in Reef waters is to prohibit oil drilling in the Region and its vicinity.
This can only be effected by declaring the whole area of the Region a marine park under the above legislation.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to take action to hold a referendum together with the next Federal Elections on the question that: 'The entire area of the Great Barrier Reef and its surrounding waters, defined as the Great Barrier Reef Region in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, as amended 1978, be immediately declared a marine park under the provisions of that Act.'
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Telegram Service
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Victoria respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Telecommunications Commission to withdraw public telegram facilities and downgrade telegram standards by:-
(1) planning to withdraw the 24 hour telegraph service at the Chief Telegraph Office in each capital city and in Canberra and Darwin
(2) closing country telegraph offices
(3) increasing telegram charges whilst downgrading the service
(4) withdrawing telegram operating facilities from a large number of suburban and country post offices
(5) generating serious delays in telegram delivery by reducing standards of service through centralisation of the network and reduction of operating and delivery staff

will reduce an available means of communications in commercial enterprise, deny the opportunity for people of Australia to make contact with family and friends in times of emergency, and civil or natural disasters, particularly for the 30 per cent of Australians who are not telephone subscribers.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will take measures to ensure the maintenance of an efficient, effective public telegram service to meet the needs of the Australian people socially, publicly, commercially and in times of emergencies and civil or natural disasters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Tasmanian Wilderness Areas
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that we the undersigned citizens of Tasmania accept and support the State Government's decision to construct a new power scheme in the South-West of Tasmania.

Your petitioners most humbly pray to the Senate in Parliament assembled that there will be no intervention by the Commonwealth Government to override the decision of the Tasmanian people and Tasmanian Parliament to construct this scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: Aircraft Manufacturing Industry
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
The Australian Aircraft Manufacturing Industry has suffered serious setbacks since its creation, because of the lack of a coherent Australian Government Policy for the Industry, as illustrated by:-
(a) Reduction in R.A.A.F. flying hours.
(b) Cut backs in the Grumman Tracker.
(c) Delay in the introduction of new tactical fighter.
(d) Delay in the introduction of the trainer project.
(e) Cut back on the production of the Nomad aircraft from 200 to 170.
This will further destabilise the industry and many jobs and vital skills will be lost.

We deplore the Government's decision to proceed with the proposed retrenchments and by so doing ignore the resolution passed unanimously by the Senate ''That no compulsory retrenchments of employees should take place until both houses of Parliament have debated the joint committee's report on this reference.''
The decision to go ahead with retrenchments has been made without proper consultation with employees and unions in the industry.

Your Petitioners therefore, humbly pray that the Government will reverse its recent decision to retrench initially 38 employees, followed by further retrenchments in the new year, until both houses of Parliament have considered the finding of the present Senate inquiry into Defence matters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

petition.title: National Heritage
petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Australian people have an irreplaceable heritage-built and natural- that is decaying before their eyes.
2. That the 1982-83 Federal Budget is the eighth in a row in which there has been no increase in funding for the preservation of Australia's heritage.

3. That the States and Territories were granted a total of only $2.2 million for an urgent program of works that is awaiting at least $20m to complete and that most of these projects will be in ruins before enough money is available.

4. That there are conservation projects in Queensland alone valued at tens of millions of dollars which have been postponed or abandoned due to lack of funding and that $3 million is needed immediately to complete restoration of properties owned by The National Trust of Queensland.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government approve an urgent supplementary grant of $800,000 for 1982-83, plus a forward commitment for a total allocation of $8m in the 1983-84 Budget.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

speech.speaker: Teague Sen B.C.

talk.start.para: â€”I give notice that, on the next day of sitting , I shall move:

speech.para: That the Senate is of the opinion-(a) That the South Australian Labor Government's exploration of new taxes and increased levels of State taxation is, in a matter of only a few weeks from the election, a gross denial of Mr Bannon's pre-election promise that the Australian Labor Party 'will not introduce new taxes or increase existing levels of State taxation during our term of office' and (b) That this rejection of election undertakings indicates that the ordinary people of South Australia will now be forced by the new South Australian Government to pay the price for the manner in which the ALP, with false promises , bought government at the last election.

speech.speaker: McLaren Sen G.T.

talk.start.para: â€”I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

speech.para: That the Senate-

(1) Calls on the Government to take immediate action to relieve the serious unemployment crisis in the lower south east of South Australia where, due to the Federal Government's policies of extraordinarly high interest rates, which have had an adverse effect on the home building industry, coupled with imports of New Zealand and North American timber, workers are continually being retrenched from the forests and mills in the area.

(2) Reminds the Government that one form of immediate action is to make a 'no strings attached grant' to the State Government to enable work to commence on a sewage treatment works at Finger Point where at present the raw sewage from Mount Gambier is discharging directly into the open sea and is causing grave concern to the local lobster fishing industry.

question.speaker: Tate Sen M.C.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 23 November reporting the return of the Minister for Defence Support, Mr Viner, from a visit to Indonesia, Singapore, the Philippines and Thailand, and reporting him as saying:

question.para: Australia's policy of not selling 'sharp-end offensive weapons' will remain.
He went on to say that he could see three levels at which Australia could do business with the Asians, including this comment:
In one country where practice bombs had been supplied, the only bombs that exploded were Australian bombs.

My question is: Since when in the history of modern warfare have bombs been classified as not being sharp end offensive weapons? Will the Prime Minister take control of this absurd situation and give an assurance that Australia will not trade in offensive weapons, as that term is generally understood by everyone except Mr Viner, particularly not with military dictatorships such as that of the Philippines where such weapons are likely to be used against those seeking a just, fair and equitable social and economic system? In short, will the Prime Minister ensure that the Minister for Defence Support does not go on a frolic of his own throughout South East Asia selling bombs?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: â€”The Senate can be assured that the Minister did not go on a tour of South East Asia selling bombs. He had significant Australian duties to perform. The question appears to be directed to the Prime Minister rather than to Mr Viner. I have not seen the article. I have not seen the alleged statements. I will refer the question to the Acting Prime Minister and seek his response.

â€”My question is directed to the Minister for Education. Is it a fact that the Australian Capital Territory Teachers Federation, at page 30 of its 1982 members handbook, exhorts all members to support the campaign against racial exploitation and the Australian Capital Territory Trades and Labour Council ban on contacts with the South African Embassy and to introduce this ban at the school level? Will the Minister ensure that school children are made aware of the Vienna convention and the courtesies, privileges and immunities it affords to envoys from any country, regardless of their political philosophies? Has the Australian Capital Territory Teachers Federation imposed similar bans on Soviet bloc embassies whose countries' abuse of human rights of minorities and the enslaved peoples of the Baltic States is a matter of public record?

â€”I would hope that the concern for human rights which might be expressed by any group would be even-handed and that, if people are going to be judgmental about one group, they will not ignore any abrogations of human rights by another group. Having agreed with Senator Reid, if the Teachers Federation is going to draw attention to one country whose practices it finds less than satisfactory, it should also be even-handed across the board. The honourable senator mentioned the Soviet bloc and the Baltic States people. Of course, it is entirely proper that she should do so. I understand that South Africa has diplomatic relations with Australia and that its Ambassador is in good standing here. I assume that he would be treated with all due courtesy by Australians because of that fact. It is, of course, free for any person to decide whether he or she will choose to have social contact with any person or any group in Australia, but I think that should be done with due regard to diplomatic courtesy. The honourable senator does well to draw our attention to the provisions of the Vienna convention in this matter.

â€”My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, concerns the world heritage listing of the national park in South West Tasmania while at the same time the Federal Government refuses to take any action concerning the construction of a dam in that area. I ask the Minister: How does this affect other areas of Australia which are on the World Heritage List? Does this mean that in future when State governments wish to construct dams or other projects in these areas the Federal Government will ignore the World Heritage List and allow the State governments to go ahead under the aegis of States' rights? Does not this situation make a farce of this country nominating areas such as this for the World Heritage List in the future?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: â€”It is to Australia's great credit that she has had listed with the World Heritage Committee a significant number-some four or five- of major areas. It is to the Government's credit that it has succeeded in getting the South West Tasmania wilderness area listed. Kakadu National Park was listed in the full knowledge that mining would not be totally prohibited in the future. Strict rules regarding the management plan have, of course, been imposed upon those concerned-both the Northern Territory Government and the Commonwealth Government. Incidentally, we appear to have been honoured in that our own representative before the World Heritage Committee, Professor Ralph Slatyer, one of the most distinguished Australians, has I think become the Chairman of that Committee for the time being. He will be coming back to Australia. The Government will be having discussions with him as to the full implications.

answer.para: I think the more specific details sought by Senator Grimes need a more precise answer. I accept that the question is of significance and that it needs to be answered in specific detail. I will seek to get that answer. It may well be that we will have to wait until Professor Slatyer and his party return home to realise the full significance. But as I understand it under treaty powers there is a best endeavours clause. I do not want to pose as being precise. Anyone who pretends to understand--

talk.start.para: â€”Very wise in your case.

â€”It is very wise because the Solicitor-General holds views that the Australian Labor Party does not hold on this treaty power. That point ought to be made very clearly in this situation. As I understand it, the treaty power calls upon the nation state to make its best endeavours to see that the particular resource listed is maintained. Of course, that imposes some difficulties and restraints within a federation. I will get the whole matter looked at. I will see whether we can get a more precise statement than that which I am able to make to the Senate at the moment.

â€”I wish to ask a supplementary question. The Leader of the Government referred to the strict rules and regulations which must be adhered to by the Northern Territory Government in maintaining Kakadu National Park. When seeking the information I requested, can he also obtain for the Senate the strict rules and regulations which the Commonwealth Government insists that the State Government of Tasmania apply in its development of this area?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: â€”I will certainly get the information concerning Kakadu National Park. My understanding with regard to South West Tasmania is that the Commonwealth Government has indicated its willingness to co-operate with the State Government in discussions and indeed, if necessary, to co-operate in general practical terms in the management of the national park. No doubt, in terms of some financial commitment in that regard it has made its good intentions clear. Discussions are yet to be held. No doubt, when Professor Slatyer returns home those discussions will take place and the details of management will emerge. I will take the honourable senator's question on board, together with his earlier question.

â€”My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. I draw the Minister's attention to the recent claim by Mr John Mabey, Producer-In-Chief of the Australian Film Commission, that there will be serious doubts about the future of Film Australia , the production arm of the Australian Film Commission, unless it receives an increase in Federal Government funding. In view of the severe financial problems still being faced by Film Australia, despite its use of the amendments made to the Income Tax Assessment Act and its efforts to raise further funds through private investment, I ask: First, will urgent consideration be given by the Government to making sufficient funds available to Film Australia to enable it to meet its present $1.2m budget deficit and secondly, what future action will be taken by the Government to ensure that the vital work performed by Film Australia is not jeopardised in any way?

â€”In the context of forming the Budget, the Government gives careful consideration to the amounts of money needed by bodies for which the Commonwealth has responsibility. I believe that that would include Film Australia. I understand that the Minister whom I represent is aware of the statements that have been made by Mr John Mabey. He is aware of what Mr Mabey asserts in relation to the viability of Film Australia. The Minister is investigating the matters which have been raised and commented on by Mr Mabey in case there is further action that the Government needs to take. Really there is nothing else that I can say at the moment. But I assure the honourable senator that the statements have been noted. They are being investigated. At an appropriate time the Minister will take action depending upon the result of those investigations.

â€”I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs a question concerning a report that Australian aid money totalling $185,000 raised to help the massive social problems in Lebanon has not yet left Australia . Can the Minister confirm that the money raised under an appeal, of which the Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, was patron, has not reached the people it was intended to help? Is it true, as reported in the Arab newspaper El Telegraph, that factional differences with the Lebanese community are responsible for this lengthy delay?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: â€” The information that I have on this matter that has been raised by Senator Chipp is that the article referred to appears to relate to the Australian Aid for Lebanon Committee appeal. The Chairman of the appeal committee, Mr Reuben Scarf, recently reported that since the time of the official launching $190,000 has been raised. He is confident that by the time the appeal officially closes in late December over $200,000 will have been raised. Funds raised by the appeal have not yet been distributed in Lebanon. The appeal committee is assessing needs and recommending ways in which the appeal funds can most effectively be spent in order to help the greatest number of people. I think the Senate would be aware of the rapidly changing situation in Lebanon which makes such assessment difficult. The Government is confident that the appeal will distribute its relief assistance fairly and efficiently.

answer.para: The appeal committee Chairman has made it clear that the appeal is neither political, racial nor sectarian. It will provide relief strictly on the basis of humanitarian considerations. The Government has been assured that the Committee is working to this end in association with the Lebanese Government and the International Committee of the Red Cross. The major religious faiths of Lebanon are represented on the appeal committee. In the Government's view the Australian Aid for Lebanon Committee appeal represents an effort by responsible individuals in the Australian Lebanese community to help to meet the need for relief assistance. I note that Senator Chipp is concerned that this aid money may not yet have been distributed. I will see whether any action can be taken, particularly as the appeal closes very shortly, so that is is expedited and distributed as soon as possible.

talk.start.para: â€”I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer to the announcement by the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, threatening the complete closure of its steel making division unless it is granted certain concessions-the main ones being a guaranteed 85 per cent of the domestic market and the ability immediately to write off capital spending. I ask the Minister: Firstly, can a great deal of the blame for the company's present difficulties be of its own making because the Board failed to maintain the plant and facilities and allowed its steel making to become more inefficient by world standards? Secondly, given that its steel making facility needs upgrading could this be financed from its other lucrative interests in gas and oil and thereby preserve the more labour intensified steel industry and the jobs of hundreds of Australians?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: â€” I saw an announcement along the lines mentioned by Senator Bonner but I have had no response from the Treasurer or any other Minister on that statement. It could be argued that one section of the company which is not profitable could be subsidised in a general sense by other more profitable sections. But I think we need to take into account the demand for steel on the world or domestic markets at present and perhaps the somewhat more limited range of options that may be open to any company including a company such as BHP. I will forward Senator Bonner's question to the Ministers concerned and see whether there is any response which they wish to make. I think that ultimately many decisions taken commercially by our corporations are decisions which rest within their own jurisdiction. Whilst we may regret changes in employment opportunities, very often the Government is not able to take active participation in such decisions.

question.speaker: Button Sen J.N.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and it follows the question asked by Senator Grimes and the Minister's answer in which he referred, at some length, to the distinguished Professor Ralph Slatyer who represented Australia at the meeting in relation to the World Heritage listing of South West Tasmania. I ask whether he heard Professor Slatyer say on AM this morning:

question.para: If the dam is built and floods the area, a large part of the world heritage is lost.
Is that the essence of the advice the Government has received from our delegation?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: â€”I heard Professor Slatyer say not only that, but also say some much more important things. He said that, quite apart from the area of the dam, there were likely to be resources of such world significance in the other area not touched by the dam that, in the longer term, the World Heritage Committee might regard the area as being part of world heritage. One ought to take the whole--
â€”I too heard all that.

â€”I am grateful to the honourable senator. This dam is of such importance that I think we should look at this matter as a whole. Professor Slatyer is, as I have said before, one of the most distinguished Australian scientists. During my term as Minister for Education he was the Australian Ambassador to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation and, in that regard, had a worldwide reputation, as he does in his own discipline. It is very important indeed that we should wait for him to come back and get a precise report from him.
â€”I hope he says something different.

â€”One would hope that he would amplify both the part Senator Button quoted and the part I quoted from what I heard this morning. It is quite impossible, as every honourable senator knows, for a precise statement of national importance to be communicated in the space of, say, a hundred words or so on a program such as AM, however much one may try. We will be making our best endeavours, as a Commonwealth Government, to ensure that the natural resources of the area are maintained. I repeat that the Commonwealth Government took the initiative and is delighted--
â€”You were asked by the Tasmanian Government to do it.

â€”Yes, indeed, we were invited to do it and we were happy to do it. But I remind Senator Button that in 1975, in policy statements before the election, we identified the area and we identified our interest as a Commonwealth in assisting towards its preservation. Long before the Lowe Government, this Government had given the lead in this regard. We are delighted that the action which has been taken by this Government should have succeeded. I hope all Australians are delighted. We will be awaiting what Professor Slatyer and his committee say when they return home. Steps will follow from that.

â€”My question is also to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. If honourable senators bear in mind, as the Leader of the Government has said, that Professor Slatyer, the leader of the Australian delegation to the current meeting of the World Heritage Committee, has been re-elected President of that Committee, does this not make nonsense of assertions by Senator Chipp and others that the Government decision not to attempt to prevent the building of the Franklin Dam has brought Australia into international disrepute?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: â€”I think everyone would agree that it is a tribute to Professor Slatyer and his outstanding international qualities as a scientist, in the first place, and also a tribute to Australia and a recognition of Australia that he should be reappointed. The fact is that, instead of our being brought into disrepute by our actions, the Committee has done the very reverse. The Committee has listed South West Tasmania in the knowledge that one of the factors involved is that the State Government proposes to build a dam. In fact, the listing has occurred on that basis. The many Jeremiahs who said that it would not occur have been proved wrong.

â€”My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. It refers to the Northern Territory Government's refusal to register Yipirinya Aboriginal School at Alice Springs and to the application by the Yipirinya school council for special funding to challenge this refusal in the Northern Territory Supreme Court. Will the Federal Government grant special aid to Yipirinya for this purpose? Does the Federal Government's refusal to make education grants available directly to Yipirinya indicate that the Federal Government's policy in favour of choice in education applies to only some sections of the community and does not extend to poverty stricken Aboriginal parents?

â€”It really does not help to have Senator Ryan ask this question in the way she has. The support of non-government schools by the Commonwealth extends to all schools which are registered in the States and Territories. In order to ensure that we are giving our money and our support through recurrent funding to schools which are appropriate there has been a requirement that the schools be registered by the appropriate State or Territory . The requirement that any school be registered is one that extends across Australia. The fact that the school to which Senator Ryan referred, Yipirinya school in Alice Springs, has not been able to obtain registration from the Northern Territory Government is a matter which needs to be resolved between the school and the Government. We stand ready with funds for recurrent support of the school when it is registered. It will get its funds when it is registered, like all other non-government schools. Senator Ryan is suggesting that for some sections of the community registration should not be necessary.
â€”No.

â€”Well, the honourable senator then might accept that our policy requiring registration is one which is educationally appropriate and sound. The first part of her question-the part that was not attempting to score some ideological point-sought the provision of legal aid to help the people involved to appeal against a particular decision. I will refer that to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Wilson, who will be required to make the decision. I will get his advice and let Senator Ryan know whether legal aid is being or could be made available to this group of people.

â€”Has the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs become aware of rumours that the Australian Government is placing obstructions and delays on applications by those citizens of Zimbabwe who wish to migrate to Australia? Is there any truth in these allegations or are the citizens of that country treated on a basis of parity with those from all other countries?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: â€” I will need to refer that question to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs for a response from him on any conditions that are placed on immigration from Zimbabwe. I am not aware that any differences exist but I will seek advice on the matter from the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

â€”My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is it a fact, as stated in the Canberra Times on Monday, 13 December, that the President of the Young Liberal Movement, Mr Mark Birrell, has called for major reform of Australia's electoral laws? Does the Government agree with Mr Birrell that the main areas for change include eliminating any possibility of gerrymandered electorates, making it easier for people to vote and lifting the media blackout laws? In view of the disgusting gerrymander and malapportionment of Western Australian State electoral boundaries, and State laws which have institutionalised barriers to enfranchisement, will the Commonwealth use its foreign affairs powers under the United Nations International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights in order to achieve electoral justice in Western Australia, or if this course is repugnant to the Government, will the Liberal Party bring moral pressure to bear on its Western Australian branch to adopt democratic principles of one vote one value and universal suffrage as espoused by the Covenant?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: â€”I did read somewhere in the Press that the Federal President of the Young Liberals, Mark Birrell, who is a very able young man, made some comments about the desirability of electoral law reform. I noticed that he made comments about gerrymander and a number of other matters. Let me simply say a couple of things: The Commonwealth Government has under survey the whole of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. We hope that we will be able to bring amendments to the Act into this place in the autumn session. The Government would reject gerrymander by any political party. The two most outrageous gerrymanders ever committed in Australia were, firstly, that maintained by a Western Australian Labor government over the years where electorates had a few hundred people, if that, and, secondly, that instituted by a Queensland Labor government.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting--

talk.start.para: â€”Mr President, is it not a fascinating situation that as soon as the facts are put before members of the Australian Labor Party they raise their voices to try to drown them out? I have said that the Government opposes gerrymander wherever it may be.
â€”But will do nothing about it.

â€”In the whole of the time that this Federal Government has been in office the electoral laws-that is, the drawing of Federal boundaries -have been absolutely fair. Nobody can say that the Federal boundaries have been other than fair. If that were said, let me say very carefully that it would be a reflection upon each of those electoral Distribution Commissioners, senior public servants whose integrity this Government would protect to the nth degree. Our record as a Federal Government in terms of eliminating gerrymander is first rate. The boundaries have been absolutely honest and first class.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting--

talk.start.para: â€”Honourable senators opposite can shout, but I will give this answer. The next part of Senator Giles's question becomes extremely embarrassing for members of the Labor Party; so they try to distract the Senate by interjecting. The Labor Party senator asks whether the Federal Government will use its foreign affairs powers to intervene in State laws-to override State laws to alter the electoral laws and to alter the boundaries. In other words, there is an advocacy by the Labor Party of an intervention using foreign affairs and centralist socialist powers to destroy the State governments. Yesterday I made the point that if there is one thing that the Labor Party does not want exposed in Australia today it is its terrible mistake, in fact, its lethal mistake-it was a mortal wound to the Labor Party-when it decided that it was willing to use foreign affairs powers to override State sovereignties. It was willing not only to seize property in the States but also to tell the States whether they would have industries and what they would do. Now the advocacy is that the Labor Party is to tell the States that they do not have the power to make electoral laws, that the Commonwealth will make electoral laws. This is the same Labor Party that had the worst gerrymanders in Australia's history in Western Australia and Queensland. It is important to understand that what was called the Murphy law, when former Senator Lionel Murphy was here-that is, the Labor intention to use foreign affairs powers to destroy the States-is becoming more and more exposed. I am grateful for the question.

â€”My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Recognising the undertaking of the Commonwealth to assist in the management plan of the South West of Tasmania, will the Government give consideration to financing the additional cost of constructing roads along the valleys so that when the dam is completed the roads ultimately will be flooded, thereby minimising the visual impact of construction roads?

â€”The Government has stated that it will be consulting with the Tasmanian Government in the development of a management plan for a national park of world significance in South West Tasmania and that that park will include a substantial wilderness component. I think Senator Watson's question takes account of the fact that the park will have a substantial wilderness component. The honourable senator's suggestion is one that I welcome. I will bring it to the attention of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, so that when he undertakes and initiates the discussions with the State of Tasmania that suggestion can be among the propositions which are considered and which may be taken up in those bilateral discussions.

â€”I again draw the attention of the Minister for Social Security to the continuing retrenchments of timber industry workers in the Mount Gambier , Millicent and Tarpeena areas of the lower south east of South Australia. As unemployment in Mount Gambier alone now exceeds 10 per cent, with a great number of families now experiencing serious financial problems, will the Minister give an assurance that there will be immediately a replacement social worker for Mr Leon Rowe in the Mount Gambier Regional Office of Social Security who has served in that capacity with great distinction and compassion but who is shortly to leave to commence studies for the Anglican ministry? If necessary , will the Minister give consideration to placing a second social worker in the Mount Gambier area if the crisis worsens, which now seems most likely as predicted yesterday by the Government's Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry?

answer.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: â€”As there are some 14,500 people working in my Department, I must confess that I am not familiar with the movements of all of them. If a social worker is leaving Mount Gambier I am sure that the Department will be giving high priority to arranging a replacement. In respect of the unemployment position in Mount Gambier, it might be worth the honourable senator's taking on board the fact that over the last week the Commonwealth has offered to the State Government several initiatives which may be of assistance to his constituents and of course to the people of South Australia generally. We have within this last week offered to South Australia additional housing money which I understand it is anxious to take up. That should give rise to at least some increase in building activity in that State.

answer.para: I have also within the last week offered the State governments the opportunity to participate in a series of community work projects which, on an experimental basis at least, will test the use of funds which would otherwise be expended on unemployment benefits, plus additional moneys, to see whether some useful social and economic result can flow. Quite apart from the replacement of social workers-I understand the role they play in bridging the gap which sometimes exists between my Department's programs and the people who need the assistance they provide-and the measures which I have outlined, positive things have been offered to the South Australian Government within the last week and may be available to assist the people of Mount Gambier and the region.

talk.start.para: â€”I refer the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General to his reply on 10 November to part of a question I asked on 15 September where the Acting Attorney-General asserted that children born at less than 25 weeks gestation were unable to survive. I ask: Was the Director of the National Perinatal Statistics Unit of the Commonwealth Institute of Health consulted on this matter? Is the Minister aware of the work of the neonatal intensive care unit of Crown Street Hospital in Sydney where, as was recently reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 27 November, a baby born at 23 weeks' gestation was expected to go home-alive-early next year? Is the Minister aware also that there are at least two other mentions in recent medical literature of children apparently surviving at gestational ages of 23 to 24 weeks? In view of these facts I ask the Minister: In the interests of accuracy and truth will he have his previous reply to me revised?

â€”The information which was provided in answer to the previous question and which appeared in the Hansard of 10 November 1982 was provided by the Capital Territory Health Commission. I have made inquiries and I am informed that this information represented the knowledge of the Commission at that time. I will draw the report of 27 November 1982, referred to by the honourable senator, to the Commission's attention and let him have a reply as soon as possible to the specific question that he has raised. Obviously one would need to be bold indeed to make too positive an assertion in this area. I am grateful to the honourable senator for drawing this matter to the attention of the Health Commission.

â€”My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Is the Government aware of plans by an American group to attempt to salvage Captain James Cook's ship, the bark Endeavour, which has been lying under an earth fall at Newport, Rhode Island, in the United States of America since 1793? Whether or not the Government is so aware, will it investigate the possibility of having the Endeavour returned for restoration and preservation in Sydney as the major and best known symbol of Australia's history and culture? Will the Government make it known to the Government of the United States that, if any significant portion of the Endeavour can be retrieved, it would make a welcome and very appropriate gift from the people of the United States to the people of Australia on the occasion of our bicentenary?

â€”I am interested in the matter which has been raised by Senator Mason. I am not aware of plans to recover the Endeavour which was covered by an earth slide at Newport, Rhode Island, in 1793. It may well be that the ship is still in some reasonable condition. I will pass on to Mr McVeigh the proposition put up by Senator Mason. I think it would warrant the most careful consideration. I must say in relation to the last part of the question, however, that if there is any question of a gift of the Endeavour from the United States to Australia it may not be up to us to suggest that that should occur.

â€”I direct my question to the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General. I contrast the difference in deportation procedures between the centralised, speedy British Home Office operations and what I would call the legal roulette in Australia of people alternating between the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the Federal Court of Australia and elsewhere. The problem is compounded because people of British origin have access to one Tribunal while people of non-British origin do not. Does the Minister think that in the light of endless and costly litigation the Commonwealth Government could consolidate the appeals system as happens in the United Kingdom?

â€”It is undoubtedly true that the extension of rights to appeal against administrative decisions is complicating both the administration and the law in Australia. Many honourable senators have, of course, taken a very active interest in the extension of citizens' rights. As in all changes there are, of course, both advantages and disadvantages. The honourable senator in drawing attention to the complexity of this area has pointed to what we might regard as some of the more untoward or unfortunate effects of changes which basically have been made to protect the rights of individuals against peremptory administrative action. The matter is one which I think is of some complexity. It involves both the responsibilities of the Attorney-General and the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I will see that the question is referred to them. I will also refer to the Acting Attorney-General for his consideration the particular point about the possibility of a simpler appeals mechanism.
â€”I ask a supplementary question. I wonder whether the Minister would hazard a guess whether legal aid is utilised in some of these cases.
â€”I have yet to see a prize awarded for guessing in the Senate. I will withstand the temptation, if the honourable senator does not mind.

â€”My question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Support follows Senator Tate's question. I remind the Minister of the Senate Select Committee on the Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories on the future of the ordnance factory in Bendigo which was set up as a result of the combined vote of the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party. I refer the Minister particularly to two minority reports handed down separately by the Democrats and the ALP. I ask him whether he is aware that both those minority reports called for the retention of the factory, further exploitation of its capacity, increases in its capacity in respect to the manufacture of 500 lb bombs which, by any definition, are of a sharp point, and the further manufacture of guns. The minority reports stated that this extra capacity would be maintained as a result of the sale of that equipment-those bombs and those guns-to South East Asia.

â€”I recall those two minority reports that came down at the time of the Senate's examination of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. I recall the points made by those minority reports. I remember that it was Senator Siddons and a Labor Party senator-I have forgotten the name-who presented those reports. Those reports were aimed at increasing the capacity of the ordnance factory at Bendigo --
â€”Are you against it?

â€”Of course not. The objective is to increase the opportunities overseas for the sale of ordnance and, of course, the provision of ordnance for our defence forces. The point that Senator Crichton-Browne makes is a very important one. It is the objective of the Department of Defence Support to increase Australia's capacity to defend itself. To some extent fulfilment of that objective may rely upon the expansion of markets overseas. But, naturally enough, all factors would need to be taken into account in the negotiations of sales contracts in respect of strategic materials such as those outlined by Senator Crichton-Browne.

â€”I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a statement by Mr John Wruck, a senior Vice-President of the Utah company, that he 'could not rule out the possibility of retrenchments in the New Year'? Has the Government had any discussions with the company over this matter? Does the Government agree that an overseas-owned company which operates in Australia and which has an annual profit of over $100m should do everything possible to retain staff when the unemployment level in Australia is so high?

â€”I will have to ask the Minister for Industrial Relations whether he has been at all involved in the matter raised by the honourable senator in his question. As far as the obligations of overseas companies are concerned, I think it needs to be remembered that the obligations of employers generally have to be seen in the light of the fact that, if labour cannot be profitably employed, it is not possible to employ labour. I make no judgment on the position with respect to Utah. I do not have any facts before me. Certainly, one would hope that all employers would exercise a responsible attitude with respect to maintaining people in employment as far as is possible. I simply make the side point that it is essential that if we are to maintain private employment in Australia-private employment is, of course, the bulk of employment-we should maintain also the profitability of Australian industry. That has implications for actions by trade unions as well as by management and company ownership.

â€”My question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport is about the report of the Australian National Railways Commission which was tabled this week in Parliament. The report makes only one mention of industrial disputation, that is, a loss of revenue of approximately $3.5m due to industrial action. I ask: Is it a fact that consideration is currently being given to the withdrawal from service or, in any event, major reductions in the service of the Indian Pacific, one of the last long distance passenger trains in the world and a popular international attraction? Is it a fact that the 9 per cent reduction in passenger traffic mentioned in this report is due to inefficiency in marketing of the product and the fact that passengers are frequently informed that no seats are available on the Indian Pacific when, in fact, the train leaves the station half empty due to over-allocation of block bookings to travel agents? Is it a fact that 152 train journeys were cancelled between March 1979 and 5 December 1982 due to industrial action? Finally, I ask the Minister whether the new Ghan is being exposed to difficulties similar to those being imposed on the Indian Pacific railway by industrial disputation and inefficiency.

â€”Senator Lewis has asked a number of very detailed questions and I hope that he will accept that I will need to refer some of them to the Minister for his direct comment. However, on the general question of the problems presented by industrial disputation-he drew our attention specifically to those confronting the Indian Pacific railway service-I make the point that in recent times there has been considerable disputation that would not have been covered by the Australian National Railways Commission report to which he refers . There was, of course, virtually a total shut-down of ANRC operations until about a week ago. I understand that the Indian Pacific railway is still out of action due to the activities of the South Australian branch of the Australian Railways Union. Consequently, that railway is not operating at present and there will be a considerable drop in transport and passenger revenue as a result. I did note in the ANRC report the references to marketing problems. I will seek specific information from the Minister on those matters and will direct his attention to Senator Lewis's suggestions in that regard.

â€”My question, which is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, follows his frothing and raging earlier in Question Time on the subject of the external affairs power. I ask: If the Government is so irrevocably and unequivocally hostile to the use of the external affairs power to override iniquitous State laws or otherwise interfere in State affairs, why did the Fraser Government intervene in support of the scope and reach of the external affairs power in the Koowarta case, heard recently in the High Court, when the Racial Discrimination Act, based primarily as it is on the external affairs power, was under challenge by the Queensland Government? I ask further: If the Government's attitude has in fact changed since then, will it now be moving to repeal the Racial Discrimination Act?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: â€”Nobody except Senator Evans can manage to confuse an issue so well. That is no doubt due to his professional training. The fact is that what I have said is that the Federal Labor Party, both in the period of the Whitlam Government and now, is seeking to abuse the Federal treaty powers and the foreign affairs powers. It is seeking to make a much wider use of them than even the courts themselves have said is warranted. I remember Senator Lionel Murphy standing here and arguing that what it should do was use them as widely as possible and then let anyone who wished to do so come along and challenge them. The fact is that it is not a question of preventing iniquitious State laws . Let us not forget that in Western Australia a Labor government had created a Labor gerrymander and another Labor government was being asked to intervene. That, in itself, is absolute nonsense. As I understand it, it is not the intention of the Federal Government to change its mind on the question of the Racial Discrimination Act. The High Court decision in that regard will of course be interesting and will be studied. The real point is that the Fraser Government would not intervene to take over electoral laws in Western Australia or elsewhere. It would not intervene to force itself upon States and destroy their sovereignty. It would use its powers in the most discreet and careful way possible and it would respect, as far as it is humanely possible, the sovereignty of the federal system.

answer.para: The Labor Party, by its very platform, is opposed to the federal system. It wants a centralised system of government; it wants to destroy State and local government. On the other hand, philosophically we stand to strengthen State and local government. We believe that the people in the States, by the ballot box, have their right to determine what is right. We do not believe that any Federal government-Labor or Liberal-is all-wise or all-knowing. That is the difference between us and the Labor Party, and that is the issue that will destroy the Labor Party.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Would the Minister care to describe, simply and concisely, what is the difference in principle between the Commonwealth acting at the expense of the States to preserve Australia's international reputation in the context of race relations and, on the other hand, the Commonwealth acting against the will of the States to preserve Australia's international reputation in the context of preserving what is universally acknowledged to be part of the world environmental heritage? What is the difference in principle?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: â€”Honourable senators would know the old rule of pleading: When you are strong on law and weak on facts thump the law; when you are strong on facts and weak on law thump the facts; and when you are weak on facts and weak on law thump the blooming table. We have just seen a classic example of that. The difference is this: The philosophic liberalism principle of the Liberal Government was tested internationally only in the last 24 hours as regards our reputation.
â€”You are a hypocrite and an incompetent drone.
â€”Order! I ask the Leader of the Government to resume his seat. I ask Senator Evans to withdraw his remarks, which, as he knows, are most unparliamentary.
â€”I withdraw 'hypocrite' and 'drone' but not 'incompetent'.
â€”I ask Senator Evans to withdraw unconditionally.
â€”I withdraw unconditionally.

â€”I could not want more helpful opposition in this matter. Yesterday an international committee of great prestige recognised the national status of Australia, paid tribute to it and accepted the Federal Government's application to have a wilderness listed on the World Heritage List. The difference between the Liberal and Labor parties is that we do it in the liberal way. The Labor Party would use the bulldozer of very dubious Federal powers to destroy the States. It would say to the Tasmanian Government: 'You have no right to make your own determination even though the people, through the ballot box in a referendum and a State election, believed they had the right to elect a government to make a decision about a dam and led you to believe that you had the right to make that decision and even though 33 of the 35 members of the State Parliament including the Labor Party, voted for the decision'. If the Labor Party does not believe in State sovereignty why does it not repeat to the States the advice Mr Whitlam gave them? He said about the best thing State members of Parliament could do in the interests of Labor socialism was to destroy themselves. That is on record in a speech written by Mr Whitlam. Incidently, the Labor Party is seeking to achieve the same result indirectly by the brutal use of power, and no reponsible government will ever let it do that.

â€”I direct a question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I refer to the successful listing of the South West Tasmania region on the World Heritage List, which apparently will ensure the protection of 98.3 per cent of the national park. Is the Government concerned that due to the drought and other environmental problems, such as salinity, the River Murray could become an endangered river? Having regard to the threat posed to the River Murray and as it is the lifeblood of South Australia, as it is an important Australian and international tourist attraction and as rural producers living in the Murray Valley area in three States depend on this vital resource for their survival, will the Government consider applying to have that important resource included in the World Heritage List?
â€”And then dam it.

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: â€”The only people who are damning their cause are in the Australian Labor Party. It would be fair to say that the Murray-Darling system is Australia's greatest natural resource. It is the only real river system of any size and consequence and, of course, it feeds through three main States and is vital to them. For those who talk about damming it, let me say that it was a Liberal government which recently brought about the River Murray Waters Agreement, which aims to preserve the environment of the River Murray by insisting on the upgrading of the quality as well as the quantity of water and by insisting on proper environmental controls along the length and breadth of the Murray-Darling system.

answer.para: If one were looking for further examples of the conservation measures of the Federal Government, one could look at the River Murray. But in a continuous and aggravated drought the River Murray could become endangered. It is only because of the building of the Dartmouth Dam-I heard some people were opposed to the dam -that we had the capacity, because it was 70 per cent full a few months ago, to put a flush down the river through the Hume Reservoir to keep the salinity level relatively low. Had the Dartmouth Dam not been built, today the River Murray would be in danger.

talk.start.para: â€”What about the Snowy Mountains Scheme? You wouldn't have it. It was boycotted by Menzies.

â€”Probably today the honourable senator would be one of those who would not allow the Snowy Mountains Scheme to go ahead. The Kosciusko National Park is a great national resource and a great wilderness. Indeed, the wilderness itself has been managed and preserved, despite the building of a hydro-electric system in the park. If that had not been built the supply of electricity to New South Wales and Victoria would not exist today and the River Murray's salinity would be causing problems. It so happens that because of the Dartmouth Dam in particular, and because of anti-salinity practices, we have lower salinity levels that we might otherwise have had. I had not thought that the River Murray might be listed on the World Heritage List. I will see whether such a diverse scheme over such a diverse area could be listed. I will seek advice from the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment on the matter.

â€”My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Did the Australian delegate to the United Nations General Assembly vote yesterday against two resolutions calling for a freeze on the production of nuclear weapons? If so, can the Minister either explain or justify the Australian Government's attitude to both of those questions?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: â€” I will seek that information from the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

question.block.title: INDONESIAN CENTRE FOR STRATEGIC AND INTERNATIONAL STUDIES

question.speaker: Teague Sen B.C.

talk.start.para: â€”My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the quasi-official conference between Indonesians and Australians in Bali last week, sponsored by the influential Indonesian Centre for Strategic and International Studies. Is it true that these Indonesia-Australia discussions fit into a recent pattern of developments to provide real evidence of overcoming what has been for too long a handful of irritant problems which in recent years have diminished our neighbourly relations? Has the commendable editorial of yesterday's Australian Financial Review been drawn to the Minister's attention? That editorial, in particular, states:

question.para: . . . judgments need to have an element of realism, and they need also to be well informed on the basis of honest reporting and truthful assessment of real situations. This has not always been the case on the most significant item of contention, East Timor.

Finally, I ask: As the Indonesians have made it very clear that they want to open a new chapter in sensible, mutually beneficial relations between our two countries, will the Australian Government respond positively and with a fresh appeal to all Australians to participate in this reconciliation with realism and good sense?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: â€”The Australia-Indonesia symposium was arranged by the Indonesian Centre for Strategic and International Studies which arranges similar meetings with other countries on a regular basis. An Australia-Indonesia symposium arranged by the Department of Foreign Affairs was held in Canberra in 1979. The recent symposium provided an opportunity for expert and interested people, both officials and non-officials, to review matters of international and regional interest that affect the two countries. The Australian delegation considered the symposium to be most successful. As the delegation has only just returned, the Minister for Foreign Affairs expects to receive a report in due course. He does not wish to comment on Press items until he has had a full report from the delegation. The questions raised by Senator Teague, in a more general sense, can await the response that the Minister will make after he has had a report from the delegation. I will see that any information forthcoming from the Minister is made available to Senator Teague.

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: â€” On 1 December Senator Tate raised a question with me with regard to our aid to the Philippines and the programs in which we are involved. The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided an answer to the matters raised by Senator Tate, and as the answer is a page and a half in length I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

answer.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to Senator Tate's question of 18 December:

At a dinner in Manila in honour of the visiting Australian Defence Minister, Mr Sinclair, on 2 August, the Philippine Defence Minister, Mr Enrile, made the following remarks on Australian aid to the Philippines, according to the text provided to our Embassy in Manila:

''The historical bond between your country and ours, our shared democratic ideals, and the confluence of our individual concern for regional and international security and stability, our quest for peace have combined to accelerate the remarkable growth in the programs of cooperation between Australia and this nation, the Republic of the Philippines.

The increasing contribution of Australia to regional and world security is a development that is welcomed by the Philippines as a member of the Association of South East Asian Nations, since ASEAN is at the forefront of preserving and promoting the peace and stability of our Asia-Pacific region.

Of special importance to us in the region, of course, is Australia's intensified participation in regional economic development which is a vital component of security and stability. The Philippines regards itself as fortunate in working closely with the Australian Government and its people in development programs in the Philippines which are aimed at the development of some of our rural areas-Zamboanga, Samar especially. And these are directed in those places where we continue to face pockets of insurgency.

These programs, I must say, have proven to be very effective in upgrading the living standards of our people in the areas affected, and, thus, have helped us in the Ministry of National Defence and in the Armed Forces of the Philippines in abolishing the root causes of our problem in those areas.

I would like to take this opportunity to express the gratitude of our people for these significant end-results of Australia's assistance to these particular development programs. I'm therefore very optimistic, your excellency, that your visit with us at this time will further solidify the programs of cooperation between our two nations.''

I have no objection to the tabling of the full text as made available to the Embassy by the Philippine authorities. Mr Sinclair spoke extempore and without notes and no record was taken of his remarks.

I do not believe that the text of Mr Enrile's remarks justify the interpretation placed on it by the South China Morning Post article of 3 August under the headline ''Australian Aid helps Manila Subdue Rebels!'' There is no question of our aid helping the Philippine Government to monitor the security situation in the area. It is an unfortunate fact that social tensions, political problems and insurgency activities are generally greatest in areas such as Northern Samar which are most depressed and economically deprived. Australia's program of development assistance aid is thus intended to help remove the poverty which is one of the basic causes of unrest. Mr Enrile has rightly drawn attention to this role for Australian assistance. He has not sought in his remarks to associate Australia with specific anti-insurgency activities. I see no need for the Australian Government to reconsider its program of civil aid to the Philippines nor to suspend its program of defence cooperation with that country as proposed by Senator Tate.

answer.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: â€”Earlier during this session the matter of expenditure on welfare housing has been raised, and on a couple of occasions I have incorporated in Hansard a table showing expenditure over the period 1973-74 to 1982-83. Some recent updates of statistics provided by State housing authorities slightly change those figures. In the interests of accurate and full information--
â€”Up or down?

â€”The adjustments are upwards. They also do not take into account the additional expenditure of $100m which was announced early this week. I seek leave to incorporate this table in Hansard for the information of honourable senators.

answer.para: Leave granted.
The table read as follows-
FUNDS FOR WELFARE HOUSING
Commonwealth funds (a)
State and internal funds
Total funds
Actual prices (b) Actual prices (b) Actual (e) prices (b)
(a) Includes Northern Territory after 1978-79. Excludes Australian Capital Territory.
(b) Implicit Gross National Expenditure (GNE) deflator. The 1982-83 estimate is based on the Budget forecast of 11 per cent increase in the non-farm product deflator.
(c) Based on informal estimates provided in 1978 by State Housing Authorities.
(d) Estimate, including $137.4m nominated by the States and the Northern Territory as additional funds for welfare housing in 1982-83 out of their Works and Housing programs, (but not yet approved).

(e) In addition to the welfare housing funds included in the table, a further $39.4m is available in 1982-83 for mortgage and rent relief and a further $3.8m ($1.9m in 1981-82) for crisis accommodation.

answer.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: â€”On 25 November Senator Coates asked me a question without notice which dealt primarily with uniformity of procedures between the various Social Security Appeals Tribunals in each State and Territory. In my reply on that occasion I indicated that this was a developing area in the activities of the Department of Social Security and that I would take up with my Department the points which the honourable senator raised with respect to uniformity. I have a supplementary answer which is a little over a page long. Rather than take the time of the Senate I seek leave to incorporate that answer in Hansard.

answer.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

At present, there is a degree of general uniformity between the procedures adopted by Social Security Appeals Tribunals. Each Tribunal seeks to ensure that its procedures are such as to ensure that, within its advisory role, the best consideration is afforded to the merits of each case. To this end, Tribunals seek to ensure that an appellant is aware of all factors relevant to his appeal and is afforded an adequate opportunity to address the Tribunal on those factors.

The detailed procedures of the various Tribunals do however vary. This is a matter on which my Department has been consulting with Tribunals with a view to drawing up detailed uniform procedures. These would include pro forma correspondence, information leaflets etc. as well as standardised procedures, all of which would be designed to be of maximum assistance to people appealing to Tribunals and those advising or assisting them. This consultation will take some time yet to reach finality but should be of great benefit.

So far as legal representation before Tribunals is concerned, the initial practice when the Tribunals were created in 1975 was to allow lawyers to be present only in very rare cases. This practice has been progressively liberalised in recent years and the currently prevailing principle is that an appellant to a Social Security Appeals Tribunal may be represented by whomever he pleases, whether a lawyer, welfare worker, relative, neighbour or friend. All Tribunals are aware of and apply this principle. At the same time, it is hoped and expected that lawyers will appreciate the non-adversary nature of proceedings before the Tribunal and not adopt the more formal demeanour appropriate to Court proceedings.

Finally, Senator Coates raised the question of providing to appellants a statement of the Department's case before the hearing. The standard practice is that Tribunals provide to appellants in advance of hearings a copy of the submission made to them by my Department.

In conclusion, I would stress again that the operations of Social Security Appeals Tribunals is an area of developing refinement, the aim of which is to improve the effectiveness of the appeals system. As part of the process of identifying areas in need of attention, I would be grateful if honourable senators would draw to my attention any areas of perceived difficulty.

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: â€” I can provide information for Senator MacGibbon with regard to his question relating to immigration from Zimbabwe. Applicants in Zimbabwe are considered for migration to Australia in the same way as persons in other parts of the world. The following statistics are supplied in relation to immigration from Zimbabwe. These show the arrivals by category in the years 1980-81 and 1981-82. They are as follows: Family reunion, 82 and 107 respectively; general eligibility, 683 and 852 respectively; and special eligibility, 24 and 47-giving totals in 1980-81 of 789 and in 1981-82 of 1,006. As I think is known, the present immigration policy is non- discriminatory. It is applied consistently to all applicants regardless of race , colour, nationality, descent, national or ethnic origin, sex or religion.

debate.title: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

speech.speaker: Missen Sen A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I present the twentieth report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, concerning the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill 1982, the Cotton Research Bill 1982, the Customs Securities (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1982, and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill (No. 2 ) 1982.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: â€”On behalf of the Committee, I lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills , Alert Digest No. 18, dated 15 December 1982, and a copy of a submission received in relation to the Customs Securities and Customs Tariff Bills.

debate.title: BANKS AND FINANCIAL CORPORATIONS (OVERDRAFT AND LOAN CHARGES) BILL 1982

proctext.para: Motion (by Senator Chipp) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to regulate the charges to be made by banks and certain other corporations in respect of overdrafts and loans.
Bill presented, and-by leave-read a first time.

speech.speaker: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

talk.start.para: â€”by leave-I move:

speech.para: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Anyone paying off a loan or an overdraft will have realised, sometimes to his or her surprise, that the 'interest' charged is, in effect, somewhat higher than anticipated: There are 'establishment fees', 'service fees' and other euphemisms for changes which add to the cost of the loan and which at least in the case of overdrafts are debited automatically to the borrower's account. This Bill is designed to bring out into the open these additional costs which can add .3 per cent, .5 per cent, 1 per cent, even more to the interest bill of a loan in any one year by providing that banks and financial corporations may not make any charges in respect of loans and overdrafts except interest. There is a good case for saying that banks and institutions should be able to cover these administrative costs without raising the interest rate.

The year 1980-81 was a particularly good year for banks. The Bank of New South Wales announced an increase from $124m to $165m, a record profit and an increase of 33.3 per cent in that one year. The Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Limited increased its profits from $136m to $175m, an increase of 29 per cent. Other banks reported increases of similar magnitude: National Bank of Australasia Limited: up 33.7 per cent; Commercial Banking Company of Sydney Limited: up 27.1 per cent; the Commercial Bank of Australia Limited: up 19.3 per cent. During that same year, 1980-81, interest rates on home loans and small business overdrafts increased sharply to around 17 per cent to 20 per cent and building starts declined dramatically. For many young couples the dream of owning a home became a mirage. Families who were locked into paying off a housing loan were put into a squeeze: They had to use an ever-increasing proportion of their income to pay off the loan and go without in other areas.

The year 1981-82 was not quite the bonanza for banks and financial institutions as the previous year but the basic trend continued: On 22 September 1982 the Australian Financial Review carried a report headed: ''Commonwealth Bank says profit gain 'just above inflation'''-allowing for some changes in accounting procedures the bank had shown an 18 per cent profit improvement. The ANZ Group showed a profit of $180.47m for the year to 30 September 1982, an increase of 2. 9 per cent on the previous year, but others had done even better: For the same period Custom Credit Corp. Ltd., the finance subsidiary of the National Bank of Australasia Ltd, increased profit by 2.62 per cent to $30.8m and CBFC, the Commonwealth Bank Group's finance arm lifted profit by 31 per cent to a new record of $14m. By absorbing administrative overheads in the interest rates charged the banks and financial corporations covered by the Bill will be obliged to present a clear picture of the obligations a borrower faces. Incidentally, it should also enable them to compete in the market place on the basis of the services offered-I note the bill-paying facility offered by some institutions- and more importantly by reducing the interest charged on loans and overdrafts and thus to introduce some degree of competition which would benefit the customer rather than the banks and financial corporations. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Messner) adjourned.

debate.title:
BANK ACCOUNT DEBITS TAX ADMINISTRATION BILL 1982
BANK ACCOUNT DEBITS TAX BILL 1982 ADMINISTRATIVE DECISIONS (JUDICIAL REVIEW) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 9 December, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Bills be now read a second time.
(Quorum formed).

speech.speaker: Grimes Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: â€”If we progress at this rate I would say that we will be finished by this afternoon.
â€”What is wrong with that?

â€”There would be nothing wrong with that at all. The bank accounts debits legislation is composed of three Bills which, in fact, are the legislative result of the Government's Budget decision to levy a tax on debits to cheque accounts. It is a revenue raising measure which, I must say, is typical of the type introduced by this Government in that its impacts will be inequitable as between both institutions and individuals and it bears no relation to ability to pay. The legislation will also, incidentally, add to the cost of business in the community. As a side effect it will encourage the cash economy, thus assisting tax avoidance and evasion, which the Government allegedly wants to avoid. Hence, we will be moving a second reading amendment to this legislation. Failing that, we will not oppose it. The Government will be judged on its actions in this regard, as it will be judged on its actions in regard to the rest of this disastrous Budget.

speech.para: The tax, which is to commence on 1 January 1983, if that is possible, will be levied at the rate of 10c for amounts up to $99, 25c for amounts from $100 to $ 499, 50c for amounts from $500 to $4,999 and $1 for amounts above that level. Quite clearly, in these circumstances the proportionate impact of the tax will be much higher for smaller transactions and, as such, it is regressive. Bank cheques are exempt, as are debits to accounts of banks held in other banks. Institutions exempt from the tax include benevolent and religious bodies, hospitals, schools and government departments. Foreign diplomatic and consular personnel will also be exempt. The liability to pay the tax will rest with the banks, except in very special circumstances, but the banks will recover the taxes from their customers. Thus this is, in fact, a tax on individuals and business people who will eventually pass it on to the consumer. The mortgage payers, those who pay by having money taken out of cheque accounts, and those who have regular payments removed from their cheque accounts for other purposes will bear the heaviest burden if they continue to carry out these procedures as they have in the past.

The tax discriminates unfairly between financial institutions. Savings banks, being exempt, will have an advantage over credit unions and building societies. The credit unions claim that their losses will be between $5m and $7.5m. I am sure every honourable senator in the chamber has received information from the credit unions expressing their concern in this regard.
