The revenue to be gained- if Budget Paper No. 1 can be relied upon, in view of the repeated variations of figures that have come out since this Budget was introduced-is estimated to be about $80m this year and about $200m in a full year although, for some reason, this fact was omitted from the second reading speech of the Treasurer (Mr Howard ).

An extra point which I believe should be made in this alleged States House is that this is an area of taxation, through stamp duties and charges, which has been left to the States, but I suppose we will not hear the scream from the States rights people concerning this revenue-raising matter that we heard concerning other legislation in this place. There has been considerable confusion among the States. Many honourable senators will have seen the letter written to all Western Australian senators from the Liberal Premier of Western Australia expressing his very real concern about the effect that this legislation will have on States' revenue. I will return to that letter shortly.

Nothing could be more calculated to drive people into the cash economy than this legislation. Businessmen have already suggested that they will in future make one cash withdrawal and make many small payments, or enter completely into the cash economy, to avoid the difficulties created by this legislation. What greater stimulus to tax evasion and tax avoidance could this be? What administrative structures will be needed to cope with the situation which will arise? The Treasurer of this country has made a considerable number of speeches in recent times expressing his concern about the effect of the cash economy in the avoidance of taxes in this community. Yet here we have a measure which will have the inevitable effect of driving people into the cash economy. As I have suggested, the tax is inequitable. It is ill-conceived and administratively clumsy, as has been pointed out by my colleague in another place. But it is part of the Budget bed. The Government has made that Budget bed and we believe it should lie in it if it persists in opposing our second reading amendment.

I return now to the letter which was written by the Premier of Western Australia to Western Australian senators from both sides of the House expressing his concern about the matters in this legislation. I hope that at some stage the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), who is at the table, will answer some of the points which are raised by that Premier. He said:

I am deeply concerned about the proposed introduction of a tax on debits to certain bank accounts announced by the Federal Treasurer in the 1982-83 Budget. I understand that the two Bills which introduce the proposed tax, the Bank Account Debits Tax Bill 1982 and the Bank Account Tax Administration Bill 1982, have been passed by the House of Representatives and will shortly be considered by the Senate.

As I understand it, the proposed tax would generally be applied to debits to accounts with banks that are subject to operation by cheque or like payment instrument except those accounts which are specifically exempted.

Of particular concern is the specific exclusion of Government business undertakings from the institutions listed to be exempt from this tax. In my view , a move to apply the tax to transactions by State Government business undertakings is completely against the spirit of the Australian Constitution.

I believe that is not fact. I believe the Premier, on my reading of the legislation, is wrong under those circumstances. This is just a demonstration of the difficulty that has arisen because the Treasurer has trespassed into what has previously been a States area and has therefore created confusion not only amongst the community in general but also amongst the State Premiers, his own party colleagues. The Premier goes on to list his concerns and doubts about the efficacy and equity of this legislation. I believe it would be worth while to incorporate this letter in Hansard. However, I have not yet shown it to the Minister. I will hand it over to him, hoping at the end of my speech that I will be able to have it incorporated.

As I said, we believe that this tax, because it is regressive, inequitable and administratively clumsy and because it discriminates between individuals and, in particular, between institutions, is an unwise form of revenue raising. We are particularly surprised that a Government which so often in this place, as it did this morning at Question Time and last week during debates, relies on the States rights argument as a defence for its actions, should now introduce a measure in an area which is traditionally within the purview of the States-an area which it apparently has entered into without any consultation with the States-hence leaving the States in great confusion. It is for this reason, therefore, that, on behalf of the Opposition, I move:
At the end of motion, add '', but the Senate is of the opinion that the tax proposed by the Bill is inequitable, discriminatory, inflationary and counter- productive because-
(a) it is proportionately greater on small bank debits and will therefore bear more heavily on less affluent persons;
(b) it discriminates unfairly between financial institutions by bearing more heavily on customers of some non-bank financial institutions than those of savings or trading banks;
(c) it will add to costs of all businesses and will thereby add to inflation; and
(d) it will promote the cash economy and the consequent spread of tax evasion by discouraging the use of cheques''.

talk.start.para: â€”It remains only for me to seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the letter from the Premier of Western Australia.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
PREMIER OF WESTERN AUSTRALIAPERTHWESTERN AUSTRALIA 6000
5th November 1982
Senator R. N. Coleman
The Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA, ACT 2600
Dear Senator Coleman,

I am deeply concerned about the proposed introduction of a tax on debits to certain bank accounts announced by the Federal Treasurer in the 1982-83 Budget. I understand that the two Bills which introduce the proposed tax, the Bank Account Debits Tax Bill 1982 and the Bank Account Tax Administration Bill 1982, have been passed by the House of Representatives and will shortly be considered by the Senate.

As I understand it, the proposed tax would generally be applied to debits to accounts with banks that are subject to operation by cheque or like payment instrument except those accounts which are specifically exempted.

Of particular concern is the specific exclusion of Government business undertakings from the institutions listed to be exempt from this tax. In my view , a move to apply the tax to transactions by State Government business undertakings is completely against the spirit of the Australian Constitution.

This move follows the recent Commonwealth Government action to alter the previous exemption arrangements for diesel fuel used for off-road purposes. This move had the effect of taxing State business undertakings such as Westrail and the State Energy Commission. The effect will be to increase transport costs to farmers and other country people and to increase the costs of electricity generation in remote country areas. Overall, the additional cost to the State Government of the lifting of the excise exemption for diesel fuel used off-road is estimated to be in the vicinity of $12 million per annum.

These decisions follow unilateral changes to the tax sharing arrangements imposed by the Commonwealth on the States in 1981 which cost the States a total sum of $374 million in 1981-82. Translated into 1982-83 terms, the amount which the Commonwealth has appropriated from the States and absorbed into its own budget would amount to $770 million this year.

One wonders when this type of action by the Commonwealth will stop. First the changes to the tax sharing arrangements, then the removal of the diesel fuel excise exemption and now the proposed tax on bank transactions. All these changes were made without any consultation with the States. Moreover, I protested, in writing, to the Prime Minister on 26 August regarding the tax on bank transactions and he has not even had the courtesy to reply.

The Commonwealth Government's actions on the tax on bank transactions, the diesel fuel exemption and the tax sharing arrangements lead me to strongly question whether we really have a co-operative Federation in any meaningful sense of the term. The situation has now arisen whereby the Commonwealth is not only failing to consult the States on matters which significantly affect State finances, but is now turning to implementing taxes directly on State Governments using its powers over excise duties and through the proposed tax on the bank transactions of State business undertakings.

Recent studies have shown that the Australian taxation system is already highly centralised by comparison with other OECD countries. The proposed tax on bank transactions would result in an even greater centralisation of taxation power in Australia with the Commonwealth.

As representatives of the States I would ask that, when the Bills associated with the proposed tax on bank transactions are debated in the Senate, you consider the effect that the imposition of such a tax would have on the States and their business undertakings. It is not so much the cost to State business undertakings of the proposed tax but the principle involved. While Section 114 of the Constitution states inter alia that the Commonwealth shall not 'impose any tax on property of any kind belonging to a State', the Commonwealth proposes to effectively tax business undertaking transactions, no doubt using the view that the tax is imposed on bank transactions and not property as such.

I urge you to ensure that amendments are suggested to that legislation to ensure that the debits made by State and local government business undertakings are within the definition of excluded debits so that their accounts will be exempt accounts.
Yours sincerely, R. O'CONNOR,
Premier Senator GRIMES-I let my arguments rest.

speech.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: â€”These three banking Bills seek to impose a tax on debits to bank cheque accounts. Debits resulting from cheques drawn on accounts, such as for periodic transfer of payments, and the charging of interest and bank fees will be subject to the new tax. The prime target is debits to current accounts held with trading banks. These Bills can be seen as a small but significant step towards the broadening of the tax base. In that respect, the Australian Democrats endorse enthusiastically the principle of broadening the tax base. However, we are not so enthusiastic about these Bills for a number of reasons, which I will shortly outline. I wish to make it plain that we endorse the principle of broadening the tax base. We believe that the burden of income tax on both companies and individuals is far too high. We strongly support the moves to bring to justice those who do not pay their fair share of tax. Anyone who is not paying his or her fair share of tax is increasing the burden of tax on other taxpayers.

speech.para: However, in these Bills several principles have been violated, which principles , we believe the Government ought to keep in mind. Ideally, a tax Bill ought to be equitable, cheap to administer from the point of view of both the Commonwealth and the individual or company involved and, above all, should not distort the financial system or affect the decisions made by companies or people . In the words of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System, 'Any tax should have a neutral impact'. We cannot pretend to live in an ideal world. Few taxes could perfectly meet these criteria. However, I put it to the Senate that this tax, as it is presently envisaged, is not equitable and will not be cheap to administer from the point of view of either the banks or the Government. Most importantly, it will seriously distort the financial system. These Bills will impose a tax ranging from 10c for debits of less than $100 up to $1 for debits of $5,000 or more. I put it to honourable senators that this is extremely inequitable.

I give an example which I admit is an extreme case. If I were to draw one cent from my cheque account I would have to pay a tax of 10c as well as stamp duty and bank charges. The tax alone, however, would amount to 1,000 per cent. On the other hand, if I were fortunate enough to win $1m in a lottery and deposited my winnings in a cheque account and then wrote a cheque for that amount, the tax payable would be $1 or 0.0001 per cent. Can any tax which varies from 1,000 per cent to 0.0001 per cent be described as fair? They are the facts of the matter.

talk.start.para: â€”That's not a typical example.

â€”I admit that it is an extreme example. But it illustrates the point that the tax varies dramatically. Further-this point touches also on the aspects of neutrality-the tax will be inequitable in its operation. As presently proposed it will discriminate against non-bank financial institutions. Financial institutions such as credit unions and building societies are major customers of banks because, by law, only banks can provide cheque account facilities. This means that non-cash withdrawals can be made only from non-bank financial institutions if an institution draws a cheque on its bank account. All such withdrawals, including periodic payments made on a member's behalf, would be taxable under the proposed legislation. But all withdrawals and payments made from savings bank accounts other than cheque accounts would be exempt from the tax.

speech.para: An amount in the order of $1.6 billion is held at call with credit unions and building societies across the country; funds which, by their very nature, tend to be used in most instances for transaction purposes. But the Government's policy, in the absence of implementation of a sensible recommendation made by the Campbell committee in this area, is that banks shall have the sole right to facilitate the use of such funds for transactional purposes through the provisions of cheque accounts. Thus, if we pay bills with bank cheques drawn on our savings accounts, the transactions will not be subject to the new tax. But similar services offered by non-bank institutions will attract the tax. Banks will also be exempt from tax when paying their normal operating costs, including salary cheques. That, of course, is a substantial saving to the trading banks.

Many, if not all, honourable senators will have received a letter dated 10 November from a Mr Peter Timmins, the Chief Executive Officer of the Australian Federation of Credit Unions. In that letter Mr Timmins informs us that he discussed several issues with the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and that Mr Howard's concluding comment was that he agreed with the logic of many of the points made by Mr Timmins. Mr Howard said, however, that the Government was not inclined to amend a revenue Bill in the Senate, although he would keep the matter under close review. Mr Timmins accused the Treasurer of refusing to discuss Bills before they were introduced and said that Mr Howard later rubbished what the non -bank financial institutions were saying.

In the interests of brevity I will make one final point. I understand that the banks are having so many difficulties integrating the tax into their computers that the Treasurer has put back the planned date for the introduction of the new tax from 1 January to 1 March of next year. The Government amended the Bill in the House of Representatives to remove the 1 January date and leave the date of effect to be announced by proclamation. If the date is put back to 1 March there is more than adequate time for the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations to report on the Bill in terms of the amendment that I have circulated. We are not proposing a marathon investigation. The Treasurer admitted that there are problems with this piece of legislation. The Australian Labor Party has also pointed out-its amendment sets this out-that it is strongly critical of this legislation. Although it is part of the Government's revenue raising strategy announced in the Budget, we believe that that is not sufficient reason for the Senate to carry out its allotted task to review legislation and, if it is found wanting, to amend it and send it back to the House of Representatives. The Australian Democrats do not adopt the attitude of the Australian Labor Party that any Bill that has a dollar sign attached to it should not be looked at by this chamber. I therefore urge honourable senators to support the motion that I shall move at a later stage that this Bill be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. The Democrats will be opposing the third reading of this Bill but we do have some comments to make during the Committee stage, assuming that the Bill gets that far.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: -The Bank Account Debits Tax Administration Bill was due to be discussed by the Senate some two weeks ago. It is a most unfortunate situation that we are discussing this important measure in the dying stages of this Parliament. The only reason we are doing that is that the Australian Labor Party gave a guarantee to the Government that it would not oppose this legislation. I believe that such an action is reprehensible, when the Labor Party knows full well that it, together with the Australian Democrats and myself, is in a position to refer this matter to a Senate committee. In fact , it is selling down the drain many thousands of members of credit unions and co -operative housing societies and building societies throughout the whole length and breadth of Australia because those members are the ones who will be discriminated against by this legislation.

speech.para: Because of the time constraints that are now imposed upon us, it is not for me to canvass or go over the matters that have already been raised. In support of the move to send this matter to a committee for further consideration, I quote what the Treasurer (Mr Howard) said in answer to a question by Senator Bjelke- Petersen. At page 2240 of the Senate Hansard, under the heading 'Credit Union and Building Society Cheques' Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle had this to say:

On 26 October 1982 (Hansard, pages 1789-90), Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice regarding claims by credit unions and permanent building societies that they are disadvantaged under the bank account debits tax arrangements by comparison with banks.
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

It is a fact that 'cheques' drawn by banks (including savings banks) will not give rise to a liability to bank account debits tax while 'cheques' drawn by credit unions, building societies and, where relevant, other non-bank financial institutions will do so. To see this position in proper perspective, however, it is necessary to have regard for the general context of the tax and the operating modes of all the institutions concerned. I have given assurances to the credit union movement that the Government does not wish the tax to cause serious disadvantage to credit unions (or, for that matter, to other non-bank financial institutions). The Government accordingly will be closely monitoring the situation and keeping the legislation under review.

What sort of basis is that on which to introduce legislation which, credit unions have indicated to all honourable senators, will seriously disadvantage them, as it will other non-banking institutions? If what Senator Siddons has said is correct-I have no reason at all to doubt what he said-and if the scheme cannot be introduced until 1 March next year, there are added reasons why the Senate ought to refer this matter to a standing committee for examination so that non-banking institutions can have an opportunity of giving detailed information to the Senate as to how seriously they will be disadvantaged. After all, one of our major functions is to ensure that information supplied to us from the electorate is made available to the whole of the Senate. As part of that function Senate standing committees gather information, distil it and provide it to us. I believe it would be in the interests of the Senate and of equity to support the reference of this Bill to a committee. I will be supporting that proposition. I hope that other honourable senators, even at this late stage, will do so.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talker.name: Senator MESSNER
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

talk.start.para: â€”Many issues have been canvassed in this relatively short debate in relation to the bank debits legislation, but I would like to mention a number of things before attempting to answer those issues. First and foremost, it was pleasing to note that Senator Siddons supports the Government's ambition to seek a wider-based tax which will lead to reductions in income tax. It is significant that the Budget of August this year increased some indirect taxes and introduced new ones, of which the bank debits tax is one, and of course was able, by virtue of the revenue raised in that way, to provide tax savings for families. That started on 1 November. We know the benefits of the home interest rebates scheme, the increase in the spouse rebate and the reduction in the slope of the rates of tax applying to lower and middle income earners. For that reason the Government's objective is to continue its program of broadening the tax base to achieve further income tax reductions and to provide more incentive.

speech.para: I turn now to some of the issues that were raised in the debate. Both Senator Siddons and Senator Harradine concentrated on perceived inequalities or inequities that may arise for building societies and credit union activities. The Government's position is that those assertions are by no means clear. In fact the proposed tax may or may not discriminate unfairly against the non-bank financial institutions such as those mentioned by honourable senators. The point is that it is probable that, if action along the lines taken by this legislation were not taken, there would be clear discrimination against trading banks. As we know, credit unions and building societies which provide cheque-paying facilities in conjunction with trading banks would otherwise be exempt, to the disadvantage of trading banks. For that reason, it is reasonable that this tax apply to debits being arranged in that way. Most transactions which occur via credit unions and building societies are cash transactions and will not be touched by this legislation.

As to the activity known as the use of bank cheques by trading banks to pay accounts-I think this was alluded to by Senator Harradine-I think it is pertinent to note that charges are made by trading banks for that facility. It might cost 50c or more each time such a cheque is used. It is not a free facility. It is not as though the building societies and credit unions will be unfairly disadvantaged in that respect in that they otherwise would be able to provide a cheaper facility.

talk.start.para: â€”The credit unions and the building societies carry that cost. The banks refuse to do so. They are competitors. It is a free enterprise.

â€”That is the point I am making. This works to the advantage of credit unions and building societies. Further points were raised in the debate, particularly by Senator Harradine. A copy of an amendment with respect to credit unions which Senator Harradine plans to move has just been put in front of me. The Government will oppose the amendments to be moved at the Committee stage by both the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine. Senator Siddons proposes to move a motion after the second reading of the Bill. The Government will oppose referring the Bills to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for the reasons I have outlined. The Government notes that the Australian Labor Party has indicated that it will not support that move either.

speech.para: The Labor Party has moved an amendment to the motion for the second reading of this Bill. Indeed, it draws our attention to alleged discrimination between financial institutions. Again, I refer to my earlier remarks when answering points raised by Senator Siddons and Senator Harradine. Specific questions relating to the efficiency, equity and practicability of the proposed tax are raised in the motion the Australian Democrats propose to move following the second reading of the Bill. I point out, first of all, that it is very doubtful that there could be a more efficient tax than the one which is proposed in this legislation. It will involve a very small number of taxpayers. Of course, once the banks have amended their computer programs and their systems to provide for the tax there will be clear administrative savings to the Government. The whole tax should operate very smoothly. In relation to equity, I think that Senator Siddons drew our attention to a rather fanciful example of drawing a cheque for 1c and being charged 10c. He concluded that that represents a tax of about--

talk.start.para: â€”One thousand per cent.

â€”Senator Siddons says that it represents a tax of about 1,000 per cent. He compared that with a tax at the other end of the scale. I have to say that one could draw on any number of examples to support that kind of argument. But, of course, it is very unlikely that that sort of situation would arise. Anybody who put himself in that situation clearly would not be acting in his own best interests. Obviously, people will not undertake that kind of action . Furthermore, as regards equity I think Senator Siddons would acknowledge that the sliding scale as proposed in this legislation is clearly in favour of a more equitable approach. It differs from that of the States with respect to stamp duties on cheques and other bills which, of course, are applied usually at ad valorem or flat rates of duty on each cheque. To follow Senator Siddons's argument, nothing could be more inequitable than the stamp duties that are applicable to bank debits imposed by States in that respect.

speech.para: I refer now to the practicability of the proposed tax. Consistent with the Government's aim of broadening that indirect tax base which we spoke of earlier, this will be a relatively low tax. I believe it will be a most efficient tax to collect. It will have a minimal overall effect on the banking system in the long run. For all those reasons, the Government will oppose the amendment moved by the Labor Party, the motion and the amendments to be moved by the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine's proposed amendments.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Grimes's amendment) be added.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

speech.para: Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
Reference to Standing Committee
Motion (by Senator Siddons) proposed:

That these Bills be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for report on the first sitting day of the Senate in 1983 and that the Committee have particular regard to the efficiency, equity and practicability of the proposed tax.

talk.start.para: -For the same reasons as I gave in the second reading debate, I support that motion. I am only sorry that the Australian Democrats did not support the last reference under Standing Order 196A which was before the House.

â€”Just briefly, the Australian Labor Party does not support the referral of this legislation to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. This is revenue raising legislation which is part of the Budget. I agree with the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine that it is likely to be inefficient. It is certainly inequitable and certainly places an uneven burden on various individuals and institutions. The tax is due to start on 1 January. We believe that the tax will be seen to be inequitable by the whole community, but it is part of the Budget. As I said, the Government has made that Budget bed and it must lie in it.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”In the course of my remarks in the second reading debate I argued against the points set out in this motion. I do not want to repeat those arguments. I just draw the attention of honourable senators to Hansard. The Government opposes the motion.

speech.para: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Siddons's) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

proctext.para: BANK ACCOUNT DEBITS TAX ADMINISTRATION BILL 1982
The Bill.

speech.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: â€”by leave-I have two amendments which I move together:

speech.para: (1) Page 2, clause 3, sub-clause (1), after definition of ''Board of Review'', insert the following definition:

'' 'building society' means a society incorporated under a law of a State or Territory which has the objects of assisting its members to acquire or erect homes and to acquire freehold or leasehold property and of making loans to its members upon the security of freehold or leasehold property;''.
(2) Page 3, clause 3, sub-clause (1), definition of ''excluded debit'', paragraph (a), after sub-paragraph (v), insert the following sub-paragraph:
''(va) a building society;''.

The amendments will have the effect of excluding building societies from the tax . Building societies are very important financial institutions in our society today. We can see no reason why they should be discriminated against in favour of the trading banks. Literally millions of people are involved with deposits with building societies. This tax will discriminate against those people who have their money at call with building societies. I do not want to go over the ground that I went over at the second reading stage of the Bank Account Debits Tax Administration Bill, but the comments of the Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Senator Messner) have not in any way explained the inequity of this piece of legislation. We have moved these amendments in an attempt at least to solve one of the glaring inequities of the legislation.

talk.start.para: â€”I foreshadow that I will seek leave to move two amendments to clause 3. Quite obviously, having regard to what I said at the second reading stage, I will be supporting Senator Siddons's amendments.

speech.speaker: Grimes Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I briefly say that the Opposition, although having great sympathy for both Senator Siddons's amendments and Senator Harradine's proposed amendments, will not be supporting these amendments. This is a revenue raising piece of legislation; it is part of the Budget. The legislation is inequitable. It is everything that was said about it at the second reading stage. These amendments remove what may be considered two anomalies, but there remain many other anomalies. There remains the fact that the distribution of the levy which is placed on debit transactions in banks is grossly inequitable going as it does from 10c for debits of up to $99 to $1 for debits of up to $5,000. What needs to be done, if we are going to do anything, is to change the whole of the legislation to remove all of those inequities.

speech.para: The Government has made this decision to raise revenue in this way. On one hand the Australian Democrats say they believe in broadening the tax base, in making the tax collections much broader in this way, yet on the other hand they want to pick out specific exclusions of this type. Although we agree and have said that the building societies and the credit unions are treated unfairly compared with the savings banks, we are faced with the fact that this is a revenue-raising measure which is part of the Budget. As such we will leave the Government to face the difficulties and opprobrium. If the Government and the Australian Democrats want to come back with a complete re-wording of the legislation, removing all anomalies, that is a different kettle of fish. At the moment we will not support the amendments.

talk.start.para: â€”Before the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Senator Messner) replies on the amendments I ask him whether the Government has made an estimate of a flat rate tax on debits to raise the same amount of revenue? I put it to him that that is an alternative .

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talker.name: Senator MESSNER
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister assisting the Treasurer)

talk.start.para: â€”I will give a quick reply to Senator Siddons. I understand that the Government has calculated the equivalent of a flat rate of tax in order to raise the equivalent amount of revenue and that the rate applicable would be in the order of 20c a transaction. I do not want to reiterate the arguments I put during the second reading debate in respect of these matters but I just say once again that if these amendments are carried and incorporated in the legislation there would be discrimination against trading banks operating in this situation.

speech.para: Amendments negatived.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: â€” by leave-I move:

speech.para: (1) Page 2, clause 3, sub-clause (1), after definition of 'company', insert the following definition:

'' 'credit union' means a society incorporated under a law of a State or Territory which has the objects of the raising of a fund by subscriptions or deposits of its members and the making of loans from that fund to its members;'' .
(2) Page 3, clause 3, sub-clause (1) definition of ''excluded debit'', paragraph (a), after sub-paragraph (vi), insert the following sub-paragraph:
''(via) a credit untion;''.

The effect of these amendments would be to exclude credit unions from the operation of this tax Bill. A credit union is defined as 'a society incorporated under a law of a State or Territory which has the objects of the raising of a fund by subscriptions or deposits of its members and the making of loans from that fund to its members'. There are over 600 credit unions in Australia. They have some 1.6 million members and assets of about $3 billion. So far as the State of Tasmania is concerned, some 65,000 members of the Tasmanian community are members of credit unions. These people will be adversely affected by the Bill. I am concerned about the fact that they have not had an opportunity of expressing fully to the Government or to the Senate the dramatic effect that this legislation would have. Admittedly they have seen the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and they have done a very good job in providing information to us. Nevertheless, I believe the full ramification of this Bill is not yet realised by the Government. That was indicated by what the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Senator Messner) said in reply to Senator Bjelke-Petersen.

Without canvassing the matters that were discussed before and in view of the time constraints that are on us in the dying stages of this Parliament, I wish only to express my disappointment that this measure was not sent to our Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for examination because not only these matters but also the matters that have been raised in the debate could have been given more attention. The Standing Committee could have made certain recommendations which I am sure would have been satisfactory to all concerned. I propose the amendments and hope that they are carried even at this late stage.

speech.speaker: Georges Sen G.

talk.start.para: â€”I am obliged to say a few words on this matter. As chairman of a credit union in Queensland I find the provisions of this legislation concerning credit unions quite iniquitous. I take the view that has been taken by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Senator Grimes, that we are in a bind in that this is a revenue raising measure and although some changes need to be made to the legislation there are no means by which we in this chamber can bring that about.

speech.para: I put it to the Committee that the imposition on credit unions in Queensland is more substantial perhaps than it is in other States. Not only are cheques involving withdrawals subject to duty but also the State Government imposes a stamp duty on such transactions. Now there is to be a further charge. Transactions made by members of these community organisations will now be subject to a triple charge.

It is my view that the legislation is an imposition on credit unions. I will not go into the other areas covered by Senator Grimes except to say that it is unfortunate that this legislation has been introduced without a proper investigation being conducted into its effect on credit unions. Nevertheless, the Opposition finds itself, as Senator Grimes has said, unable to support the amendments. I feel obliged to make these comments because the credit union movement in Queensland and throughout Australia is substantial and the difficulties faced by members of credit unions as a result of various impositions have not been properly recognised.

talk.start.para: â€”I would like to make some very brief remarks. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) mentioned that if building societies and credit unions were excluded other areas affected would be left without any redress. We agree with that. For that reason we suggested that the matter should go to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. Of course, one other very big sector of the community will be seriously discriminated against; namely, local government, particularly local government in Queensland. We draw the Government's attention to that factor.

talker.name: Senator MESSNER
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

talk.start.para: â€”For the same reasons as we opposed Senator Siddons's earlier amendment, we oppose Senator Harradine's amendments.

â€”I cannot allow the comment to pass that there is no means by which this chamber can bring about the wish of the majority of senators to exclude, for example, building societies and credit unions from this measure. After all, that was the purpose of the amendment moved by Senator Siddons in respect of building societies; it is the purpose of my amendment in respect of credit unions. We have the ability, the power and the numbers. Let us use them.

speech.speaker: Grimes Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I will speak very briefly.
â€”And the logic, I might say.

â€”Of course we have the numbers and of course we have the desire to exclude building societies and credit unions but in doing so we would create other anomalies in what is already an anomalous piece of legislation. To do so without altering the regressive nature of the imposts which would result from this legislation is quite wrong. As I said, this is a revenue raising procedure of which we do not approve. However, this measure will raise $80m this year and $200m in the next Budget year. I think it would be quite wrong of us piecemeal to pick out organisations such as credit unions and building societies without giving this matter much more consideration. This legislation is part of the Government's budgetary strategy. It is typical of the budgetary strategy in that the impost falls inequitably in this way. It is for that reason that we do not believe piecemeal amendments to this legislation are justified.

speech.para: Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bank Account Debits Tax Bill 1982 and Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review ) Amendment Bill 1982-by leave-taken together and agreed to.
Bills reported without amendments; report adopted.

proctext.para: Motion (by Senator Messner) proposed:
That the Bills be now read a third time.

speech.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: â€”The Australian Democrats are absolutely opposed to this legislation. We do not propose to call a division on the motion that the Bills be read a third time, as we would like to do, because of time constraints. However, we ask that the Australian Democrats be recorded as being in opposition to this legislation. I seek leave to have our names recorded in the Journals of the Senate.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: â€”I say finally that the position of the Australian Labor Party amazes me. Members of the Labor Party have admitted the gross inequity of this legislation. They have admitted the problems that it will create for small depositors of building societies and credit unions. But they have not attempted to have these matters looked at by a Senate committee. It is obvious that the Senate Committee on Finance and Government Operations could have looked at the matter and not delayed the legislation. We could have had an objective report. We could have had the attitudes of the community recorded.
â€”By 1 January?

â€”We could have had the report by 1 March. It would be impossible for the banks to impose this tax by 1 January. That has been admitted by the Treasurer (Mr Howard). For the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) to say that there would be a time constraint on the Committee to decide by 1 January is just incorrect. The Committee would have had at least until 1 March. It will be 1 March before the banks can sort out their computer programs. It is not an easy tax to administer, as is apparent from the difficulties that the banks are having in correcting their computer programs to impose the tax. It will be an extraordinarily difficult tax for the Government to administer. It is extraordinarily inequitable. The position of the Labor Party in this matter, I think, deserves very severe criticism. We have done what we can about it. Our position has been made clear. We will have to leave it at that.

â€” Briefly put, the attack that Senator Siddons has levelled against the Australian Labor Party is not justified. In fact, it was made quite clear that this was a budgetary measure and that the Labor Party did not want to take it upon itself to delay in any way, which in itself would be an obstruction, the passage of the legislation. Nevertheless, I intend to take an initiative which, if it is successful, Senator Siddons may wish to support. The legislation that is now in the process of being passed can be referred to one of our standing committees. I believe that that is the course that we ought to take; we ought to allow the relevant Senate committee to invest the ramifications of the legislation. That is an initiative that I intend to undertake within the Party room, to ascertain whether the legislation can still be referred for the investigation that the honourable senator desires.
â€”The question is that the Bills be read a third time.
â€”Pursuant to Standing Order 168, I require that my name be recorded in the Journals as voting against the third reading of the Bills.

debate.title:
COTTON LEVY BILL 1982
COTTON RESEARCH BILL 1982

proctext.para: Consideration resumed from 25 November, on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle:
That the Bills be now read a first time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a first time.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
COTTON LEVY BILL 1982

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the imposition of a levy on cotton produced in Australia. The levy has been requested by cotton growers and is intended to be used in financing a research scheme. The related Cotton Research Bill 1982 contains provisions for the collection of the levy, its payment into a trust account to be created for the purpose and all the measures necessary to implement the research arrangements. The levy will apply to all raw cotton produced. For this purpose, leviable cotton is the cotton fibre separated from the cotton seed in the process of ginning.

The operative rate of levy is to be initially $1 per unit of 225 kg which, in industry terms, is $1 per bale. The levy rate may be changed by regulation up to a maximum of $3 per 225 kg. Changes may be made only after consideration of a report from the growers' organisation, that is, the Australian Cotton Growers' Research Association. On behalf of all growers the Association has requested that the leavy apply to cotton production from the start of the 1983 harvest. The Government accepted that request and it is for that reason that the Bill provides for the levy to be imposed on all cotton produced on or after 1 March 1983.

The levy is payable by growers but in practice will be paid on their behalf by the processors, that is, the three organisations which gin all cotton produced in Australia. They are, in Queensland, the Cotton Marketing Board and, in New South Wales, the Namoi Cotton Co-operative Ltd and Auscott Pty Ltd. It can be expected that the amount of levy collected in 1982-83, that is, on cotton ginned in March, April and May 1983, will approximate $200,000. This year, in an exceptionally favourable season, cotton production is close to 600,000 bales. The indications are that production is not likely to expand significantly in the next few years. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
COTTON RESEARCH BILL 1982

The purpose of this Bill is the implementation of a cotton research scheme along the same lines as other rural industry research schemes. Its provisions include necessary arrangements for the collection of the research levy imposed under the Cotton Levy Bill 1982. It brings into being a Cotton Research Trust Account from which cotton research will be funded. It establishes a committee which will recommend research programs and the disbursement of funds from the research account.

The Bill should be read as one with the Cotton Levy Bill 1982 and is to become operative on the same day as it. The levy is intended to apply to all cotton produced from the start of the next harvest season in March 1983.

Cotton growers have sought the implementation of the research scheme and have signified their agreement to payment of the levy. For practical and administrative reasons, however, payments to the Commonwealth will be made by the processors, that is, the three organisations which own the cotton gins. The processors will be entitled to deduct the amounts of levy from their payments to cotton growers.

Levies will be payable in the month following the month of ginning. As they are received into revenue like amounts will be paid into the Cotton Research Trust Account. The Government has undertaken to match on a dollar-for-dollar basis expenditure of industry moneys from the research account. Any expenditure for research from the account will be subject to ministerial approval on the recommendation of the Cotton Research Committee to be established by the Bill.

The Research Account will have in it two separate accounts. Into one will be paid amounts equal to levy received plus Commonwealth contributions. The other will be credited with interest on investments, proceeds of sale of assets and produce, donations and, if any, penalty incurred because of delays in levy payments. Such moneys will not be matched by the Commonwealth. Their disbursement will be subject to the same conditions as the industry and Commonwealth contributions.

The Cotton Research Committee will have 10 members of which five will represent growers and the others will represent, respectively, the Department of Primary Industry, as Chairman, the Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, Australian universities, the New South Wales Department of Agriculture and the Queensland Department of Primary Industries.

As is customary, membership will be subject to ministerial appointment. The Bill provides for grower representatives to be selected and appointed by the Minister from a list of names submitted by the growers' organisation. It is intended that the five appointees will include at least one member representing the growers who deliver seed cotton to each of the three processors. In Queensland the sole processor is the Cotton Marketing Board. The others, in New South Wales, are the Namoi Cotton Co-operative Ltd and Auscott Pty Ltd. The Bill provides for the appointment of deputies. There are customary provisions requiring disclosure of interest by members and deputies. Remuneration entitlements of both are to be determined by the Remuneration Tribunal. The Committee will have the responsibility of formulating and submitting to the Minister for Primary Industry recommendations as to a program of research and levels of expenditure from the Research Account.

As is the case with other research schemes operative for a number of rural industries the purposes for which moneys may be expended are scientific, economic or technical research and associated activities. These include research training and dissemination of information. In carrying out its responsibilities the Committee will be expected to establish effective means of determining cotton research needs and priorities in all the detail that is necessary and, in the course of time, no less effective arrangements for review of its own activities and the conduct and outcome of research funded on its recommendation.

The cotton research scheme which is being implemented reflects established policy of the Government in fostering research funded jointly by the Commonwealth and industry which will help overcome problems, raise productivity, contain costs or improve quality to the benefit of the industry and of the economy as a whole. The cotton industry has contributed voluntarily to research for the past nine years, starting with a levy rate of 25 cents per bale, which has been increased to 50 cents in 1975, to 70 cents in 1979 and the present maximum of $1 per bale in 1980. That in itself is acknowledgement of the value growers have seen in augmenting from their own resources research carried out by CSIRO, two State departments and tertiary institutions.

There are continuing challenges in coping with problems of seasonal conditions and the incidence of pests and diseases. Continued success in selling to selective markets influenced by rapid technological change in spinning machinery requires increasing attention to fibre quality. The scope for additional research is indeed considerable. Cotton has become Australia's fifth largest agricultural export crop, shipments in 1981-82 being valued at $117m. The industry's production and export potential will undoubtedly be enhanced and the industry will be helped to use its resources even more effectively as the benefits of further well-directed research become available. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

talk.start.para: â€”These Bills establish a levy fund and research scheme for the cotton industry in the same manner as those which exist in most other rural industries. For the past nine years a voluntary scheme has operated without government involvement. This is an attempt, belated though it may be, to bring the cotton industry into line with other industries and make provision for the Commonwealth to match the levies on a dollar for dollar basis. The Bills also provide for the establishment of a Cotton Research Committee and a Cotton Research Trust Account and contain a miscellany of other provisions such as normally relate to the establishment of such a scheme. The Opposition does not oppose the Bill.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I thank the Opposition for its support and wish the Bills a speedy passage.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment, requests or debate.

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 16 September, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen G.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The Bounty (Ships) Amendment Bill 1982 is designed to correct an anomaly which was detected by the Opposition spokesman, Mr Hurford, some 2 1/2 years ago whereby fishing vessels which are over 150 tons and over 21 metres in length get a bounty but fishing vessels which are over 150 tons but under 21 metres in length do not. To correct that anomaly is undoubtedly a worthy enterprise and I make only two points in respect of it. One is that this has not been the world's speediest legislative performance, taking 2 1/2 years to produce a three line amendment. The second point I make is that the drafting of that three line amendment, notwithstanding that it took 2 1/2 years to bring to fruition, is something of a masterpiece of opacity. One would not have thought that it would be possible to create even more confusion as to which precise vessels were bountiable, but that seems to have been accomplished with some flair.

speech.para: In order to understand how the Bill actually works and what is bountiable and what is not I have found myself and my staff engaging in drawing diagrams which would rival the anatomical drawings of Leonardo for their complexity. I know that it fashionable to bash parliamentary draftsmen on these sorts of occasions- I hasten to add that it is not a sport in which I usually engage-but for the sheer confusion engendered within the space of three lines I would award this Bill my 1982 Bottom of the Yarra Award for muddy and murky legislative drafting.

talk.start.para: â€”We are told that the Bounty (Ships) Amendment Bill 1982 rectifies a minor drafting error. Whether or not that is true the fact of the matter is that if this error is genuine why on earth has it taken so long for the Government to detect it? The problem was drawn to the attention of the lower House in a speech by an honourable member on 27 March 1980. Here is December 1982-32 months later-and something is finally being done about it. Fortunately, it appears that nobody has been disadvantaged by this error but as Senator Evans pointed out something is radically wrong with the system if it takes this long to rectify a very simple error. Nobody who has had anything to do with this Bill-the Minister, the Government or the staff involved-can take any comfort from it.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I thank honourable senators on all sides for their support of the Bill and wish it a speedy passage.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without requests or debate.

debate.title: DRIED FRUITS EXPORT CHARGES AMENDMENT BILL 1982

proctext.para: Consideration resumed from 18 November 1982.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to establish a new ceiling on the export charge leviable on currants, sultanas and raisins now that the operative rate of the charge has been increased by regulation to the maximum allowed under the existing Act. Opportunity is also taken in this Bill to redefine procedures applicable to increasing the operative rate in the future and to remove from the Act certain unnecessary words.

Moneys collected under the dried fruits export charge are used to finance the operations of the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation which controls the export marketing and overseas promotion of Australian dried vine fruit. The Corporation has been under financial pressure due in part to a poor 1981 harvest, with a consequent sharp fall in receipts in the 1981-82 financial year, but more importantly to steadily rising costs. Action to improve its current financial position has already been taken, with industry agreement, by Statutory Rules Number 100 proclaimed on 29 April 1982. Those Rules provided for an increase in the operative rate of the charge from the $4.50 per tonne which had applied since 1976 to $7 per tonne of dried fruit exported, the new rate being equal to the maximum allowed under the current Act.

The Bill before the Senate seeks to raise the maximun permissible charge from $ 7 to $15 per tonne in order to enable the operative rate to be increased beyond $7 per tonne when this becomes necessary. It is expected that the new ceiling will obviate the need for further amendment to the Act for a reasonable number of years.

The main industry organisation, the Australian Dried Fruits Association, has been consulted in the past on matters affecting the funding of the Corporation, the operations of which play an important role in contributing to the viability of the Industry. It is proposed that these consultations will now be formalised under the provision in the Bill for discussion between the Department of Primary Industry and the producers' organisation on any future suggested change to the operative rate of charge on the export of dried fruits.
This Bill also seeks to remove a provision of the original Act which, I am advised, is unnecessary, The provision in question is sub-section 3 (3) which states:

''All moneys payable under this section in respect of any dried fruits shall be paid on or before the entry of those dried fruits for export to such officers in the respective States as are prescribed''.

I am advised that the words ''to such officers in the respective States as are prescribed'' are superfluous as the identification of the officers to whom the charge is to be paid can be dealt with administratively. Accordingly it is proposed that a new provision be substituted for the existing one.
It is proposed that the Amendment Act will come into effect as soon as it receives the Royal Assent.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

speech.speaker: Grimes Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I indicate on behalf of the Opposition that it does not oppose the Dried Fruits Export Charges Amendment Bill, which establishes a new ceiling on the export charge leviable on currants, sultanas and raisins. The moneys collected in this way finance the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation, which controls the export marketing and overseas promotion of our dried vine fruits. Simply, the Corporation needs the money because of the poor harvest in 1981 and because of rising costs. The levy was increased by regulation on 29 April from $4.50 per tonne to $7 per tonne. This was the maximum allowed under the old Act. The effect of this Bill will be to increase the maximum rate from $7 per tonne to $15 per tonne. As the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) has quite rightly pointed out, there should be no need for further amendment for many years. Our spokesman in another place, Mr Kerin, has described this as an almost open-ended levy.

speech.para: There are difficulties in the dried fruits industry. Production in 1983 is expected to be something like 75,000 tonnes or 27 per cent down on 1982 and a carry-over from 1982 of about 25,000 tonnes is probable. As the domestic market is only about 29,000 tonnes, this will leave in the vicinity of 70,000 tonnes to be disposed of on the export market-a market which is notoriously unstable and hard to predict. It is affected by the quality of our fruit, the policy of the European Economic Community towards Greece's surplus and the size of the Northern Hemisphere crop. In these circumstances, the prospects are not very bright. The new ceiling is very high. It is possible that a huge increase could be applied without adequate parliamentary scrutiny under these circumstances and , for that reason, I am sure that the dried fruits industry and those in this place who have its interests at heart will keep a close watch on the situation as it develops. As it is policy to fund the Corporation in this way and as we quite clearly need considerable assistance to ensure that our dried fruits crop is exported efficiently and that markets are found, the Opposition does not oppose the legislation which apparently is acceptable to the industry.

speech.speaker: Macklin Sen M.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The dried vine fruits industry in Australia is an extremely important primary industry sector and it has been going through some difficult times. Up until the late 1970s, the industry showed a great deal of progress and I believe it could have looked forward at that time to a fairly healthy future. Consumption in Australia has been reasonable and, indeed, has been increasing at the level one would expect in terms of the population. Also in the 1970s, we made some fairly good increases in our exports, and the export price has been reasonable particularly as we have moved into the 1980s. The 1981 -82 season was certainly a lot higher than the previous low season, in 1978-79.

speech.para: However, some points need to be raised in regard to the future. They are of concern right across the board and are certainly of concern to the major dried vine fruit industry areas in South Australia and Victoria. These points apply especially to the recent harvest yields of, in particular, Greece, Turkey and South Africa. Those three countries are our major competitors in world trade. We have traditionally sold most of our dried vine fruit products to European Economic Community countries. In view of the fact that our competitors are Greece, Turkey and South Africa, I do not think that it takes very much imagination to predict what is likely to happen in the immediate future. The entry of Greece into the EEC has already sent shock waves through the industry in Australia. Certainly, the EEC's setting of a minimum import price of about $1 ,000 a tonne means that our current export price of $1,150 a tonne will have to come down and our industry certainly cannot look to the previous high price it was able to get in the last growing season.

Everyone agrees that the impact on Australia's industry could be adverse if the EEC market closes down to the extent which could be predicted. Since our export market takes about 61 per cent of our total product, any failing in our export markets will immediately have dire consequences, particularly in the growing areas in the riverlands of South Australia and the two wheat growing areas in Victoria.

Another point is that our other major competitor, apart from the EEC, is South Africa. South Africa is seeking to develop markets. It was initially successful, particularly in two of our minor markets in which we could have expected some growth. Those markets are Japan and Canada. We had been making some headway in both those markets, but South Africa, in a much more aggressive selling style than we have adopted, beat us in both of them. We certainly cannot look at those markets now, as we could two years ago, as possible developing markets when our EEC export market fails.

Overall, the world DVF industry certainly is suffering chronic oversupply. We cannot look in any sanguine way at our export opportunities. That problem is unfortunately shared by a large number of primary industries throughout this country. The Australian dried vine fruit industry will ultimately have to depend on crop failure in EEC countries, which is not exactly the type of thing upon which we would necessarily want to base our industry. However, on the basis of the upward and downward movements in a number of these areas one can say that we will not get a continual run of good crops. Indeed, the 1982 Californian crop, for example, was a significant failure. That should mean that there will at least be a stabilising of the world over-supply.

I think it is important to raise the points I raised because if one travels to those fruit growing areas, as I did recently, one is struck by the state of almost despair of those growers who went into those industries in times past and based their livelihoods upon them. Indeed, whole towns were based upon those industries. They look towards the future with a great deal of trepidation. When they look at that industry compared with the rest of the economy they are upset and confused. They wonder where they and their children, who normally would go into primary production, will go. They used to look to a reasonable income and a reasonable future, but they cannot do that now. We must look at restructuring this industry, as we have in the dairy industry, for example. We must look at providing support for this industry so that those people who would otherwise go bankrupt may be able to sell their farms at a reasonable price, so that the industry can be restructured and in some way be brought more into equilibrium with domestic demand and a smaller export market that Australia could look to in the future. In these ways, I believe that it is a Government initiative that is needed in these areas, apart from the points in the Bill which were requested, as I understand it-I have no cause to doubt it-by the industry. We would support these provisions, but I do not think that they go far enough and they do not really meet what is likely to be a long term chronic problem with the industry.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I thank honourable senators for their support of the Dried Fruits Export Charges Amendment Bill. I should like to comment on one or two of the matters mentioned by Senator Macklin. Like him, I happen to live in a State that is very much concerned with dried fruits exports. I am aware of the considerable problems of the fruit growing areas, particularly those of my State of South Australia along the River Murray. There are not only the difficulties associated with marketing fruit but also the difficulties with the river itself-the salinity levels and the other questions which have been raised in this place from time to time.

speech.para: Nevertheless, the Bill seeks to address itself to the very considerable problems of marketing dried fruits on the world scene. Senator Macklin has drawn our attention to a number of factors that are present in any consideration of those difficulties, but I believe that this legislation goes a long way to assist the future development of the industry and to create at least some feeling of certainty amongst growers that the Government is doing all that it can within reasonable practical bounds to achieve that. Once again, I thank honourable senators for their support and I wish the Bill a speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without requests or debate.

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 14 December, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Grimes Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: â€”This is the second time around with this legislation, albeit in a different form from that in which it came to this House previously. The Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982 attempts to render invalid the health levy which was imposed by the Victorian Government in July to cover the costs of out-patient services rendered to insured patients in public hospitals in that State. The previous legislation was tacked on to another piece of legislation in the hope that it would sneak through. No announcement was made in the Budget. No warning was given. The legislation was tacked on to another health Bill, and in fact it was rejected by the Senate. The Government then saw the error of its ways and split this legislation so that it is now introduced in separate form. The Australian Labor Party still opposes the legislation.

speech.para: What happens in Victoria, and what would happen in New South Wales and South Australia and what would almost certainly happen in Western Australia and Tasmania if this legislation were rejected, as it should be, is that instead of patients and hospitals having to deal with individual charges and patients when dealing with out-patients, a levy computed on the basis of membership for each fund in the State provides the funds for out-patients services. We agree with the Victorian Government that this is in fact equitable. It is an administratively simple method of funding hospital out-patients. Above all it allows the hospitals to employ healing staff, treating staff, rather than financial staff because it simplifies the system. It also eliminates lags in payments and the delays which have become increasingly important to hospitals, particularly to public hospitals, because of the parlous state of hospital finances at the moment. That is caused by the difficulties hospitals have in collecting both in-patient and out-patient funds. We have the very sad scene of hospitals in various States, because of the new health insurance system, having to employ collection agencies to try to keep their cash flow up.

At least on this occasion the Government has attempted to justify its actions in this legislation in a more detailed way. But I am afraid that those sorts of arguments do not impress the Opposition. I believe that some of the arguments certainly should not impress some of the honourable senators in this place whom we have heard proclaiming States' rights in the last few weeks in so many debates on different pieces of legislation. Most of the argument used by the Minister for Health (Mr Carlton) in another place and Ministers in this place has to do with the Government's almost pathological dislike of the Victorian Government and the Victorian Premier in particular. A lot of the argument is about nit picking, about the size of the levy and about the amount of money that should or would be raised by the levy. A lot of the argument is merely empty exclamations about the alleged efficiency of the Victorian Government. But the crux of the argument which the Government seems to go back to all the time is that the out-patient levy undermines the principles of user pays which is allegedly the basis on which the Government seems to hang all its health legislation in this day and age.

Insured patients throughout Australia-in Victoria, South Australia and other States-in fact, in most cases, do not directly pay for their out-patient services in the manner in which the Ministers in this place and in another place seem to suggest. In most hospitals the patient signs a form and the hospital recoups the money from the relevant health fund to which the patient belongs. In South Australia a system of bulk billing applies. The hospital bulk bills the funds for the out-patient fees. We believe it is nonsense to suggest that the principle of this levy cuts across the principle of user pays at all. In any case, such an argument is irrelevant to the issue of out-patients and out- patient services. We went through all that when the legislation was previously in this place. I think it does not assist us very much in the second reading stage of this legislation to go through the long debate we had on a previous occasion.

But I think it is worth while pointing out that this Government, under the new health system, has firmly and, at times, vigorously in debate in this place and in public statements pointed out that it believes that the public hospitals are the responsibilities of the State governments, having changed the funding of public hospitals to make them the responsibility of the State governments. Yet we have at least three State governments-Victoria, in particular-which have looked at the system the Government has bequeathed them and have said: 'We can now collect out-patient fees in a sensible way. We can collect them in a way which is more sensible for the patients. We can collect them in a way which is administratively more simple so that we do not have to employ so many staff in our finance and accounting departments to go through the various accounts, chase the patients and the accounts and sort out the services. We have a system which is equitable, which collects the right amount of money and which enables us to transfer staff from the accounts department to other departments of the hospital '.

The State governments, having taken responsibility from the Federal Government, said: 'All right, you want us to be responsible for these hospitals. You want us to run these hospitals. You want to absolve yourself from this sort of responsibility.' The State governments came up with this system and the Federal Government said: Oh no, we cannot have you doing that because it will interfere with our friends in the health insurance funds'. Yet I am perfectly sure that my friend Senator Walters and some of the other people in this place who, for the last three weeks, have been haranguing us on this side of the House about States rights and saying what an evil thing it is for the Federal Government to interfere with the States' responsibilities will come into this place and say: ' Yes, but in this case we will do a turnover and say it is our responsibility to tell you how to collect the money in your hospitals. It is not our responsibility to give you sufficient funds for your hospitals. It is not our responsibility to tell you how many beds you should have or the distribution of those beds, but it is our responsibility to tell you how you should charge your out-patient clients in those hospitals.' I just do not see how the Government can sustain that argument at all. We believe that hospital funding is very much a national responsibility and that the Commonwealth should have some say. But, apparently, those on the Government side repeatedly say they do not believe this , except where it affects the health insurance funds, which give so much assistance to the Government during its election campaigns by way of donations, staff and advertising.

I find it incredible that this legislation is back here in this form. If there is to be an argument, as there was last time, about whether the levy is too high , too low or whether the amount of funds that are collected is too high or too low, the Government should conduct it with the States. It is certainly an argument which the Victorian Government is willing to resolve through consultations with the Federal Department of Health and the Federal Government. If the argument is that the health insurance funds will be disadvantaged because they will no longer be able to sit for months on end on the moneys that are owing to the public hospitals while they go through the tortuous process of sorting out out-patients charges, the Government will have no sympathy from this side of the House. For heaven's sake, our health service problems are difficult enough. When a State government comes up with a simple, fair and sensible method of sorting out the problem which faces every public hospital in this country-the problem of sorting out how to recoup the funds which arise from the large numbers of out-patient services which are provided each year-the Government should not reject it out of hand in this way. It should not reject it for ideological reasons but try to support the States in their difficulties, which are largely created by the inefficient and insufficient funding which is provided for State hospitals under this Government.

We continue to oppose this legislation. We prefer to oppose it, as we are opposing it today, in an individual piece of legislation rather than having it tacked on to another piece of legislation in an attempt to blackmail us into agreeing with it. We believe we will defeat the legislation, as we defeated it before, but we are glad that we will defeat it in the present circumstances and not under threats of blackmail as existed during the Budget debate.
Sitting suspended from 1 to 2.15 p.m.

speech.speaker: Walters Sen M.S.

talk.start.para: â€”The purpose of the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) is contained in clauses 4 and 6. It is to preclude application by any State or Territory of any tax based on health insurance. As we are well aware, the Victorian Government has levied 80c a week on every family insured by the registered health insurance funds and 40c a week on every contributor who is single. The Victorian Government has said that that is to cover outpatients' fees. As a result of that decision the health insurance funds in Victoria have had to raise their contribution costs by between 30 and 40c. We now know that the New South Wales Government has said that on 1 January it will implement a levy also. It will levy exactly the same amount as is levied in Victoria-80c a week on families and 40c a week on single people, again supposedly to cover outpatients' fees. But the New South Wales Government is doing more than that. It is also implementing past legislation and next year it will implement an additional levy of 60c a week for families and 30c a week for single people to cover ambulance costs. According to the registered health funds in New South Wales this will result in an increase in weekly contributions not of 30c to 40c but of 90c to $1. We were told by Senator Grimes today and by the Australian Democrats the last time health legislation was debated in this chamber, that this levy was to recompense the States because the Federal Government had not given them enough money to run their hospitals. Senator Chipp quoted Mr Roper, in reference to the health legislation where by the Commonwealth Government was giving the States the responsibility of running their own hospitals, as having said:

speech.para: If the Federal Government's legislation is passed it will mean a shortfall of $ 20m in the State's health funding.

Let us see just what these levies will raise. I find it most interesting that the Victorian Government has estimated that it will raise $44m through that levy alone. Are Senator Chipp and Senator Grimes suggesting for one moment that outpatient departments in Victorian hospitals are down the drain $44m? That is the amount that is being raised-$44m-supposedly to cover outpatient costs. By supporting this legislation, are they suggesting that $44m is the cost to Victoria for its outpatients? The whole thing is too ludicrous. That State is raising a normal tax that it can spend on roads, sporting facilities or anything it chooses. In raising that tax it is discriminating against one group of people who insure themselves in order to cover health costs. It is not imposing the tax on those who insure themselves in health organisations that are not registered- only on those who join registered health funds. A considerable number of people have insured themselves with insurance companies which are not registered health insurance funds. These people are not asked to pay the levy or to contribute to this tax. Other groups have decided to cover their own health costs. Those people will not contribute to this tax.

Let us look at the amount being raised by New South Wales. New South Wales is raising $56m in a full year for its outpatients' services. Is it suggested that it is costing New South Wales $56m for its outpatients' services? That is the amount that it is raising. It says it is raising that amount to cover outpatients' services. It is raising an additional $42m for its ambulance service. Is it suggested that all of that $98m being raised by New South Wales will be spent purely on outpatients' and ambulance services?
