The contributions made by people who insure themselves with registered health funds in that State will rise by 90c or $1. That is what is successfully being done. Again, the States of New South Wales and Victoria are raising taxes at the expense of people who like to insure themselves for their own health costs and look after themselves.

We have heard a lot of rhetoric in the past from the Australian Labor Party and the Democrats. They have said that they are concerned that health contributions are too high for many people to pay. They have made all sorts of claims and have wept tears in this place about this situation. yet now they are voting to increase the contributions in Victoria. As I have said, the rates in that State have already been increased by 30c or 40c in order to cover this levy. An additional 90c to $1 a week is about to be raised in New South Wales early in the new year when these levies are introduced in that State. This is an absolute disgrace. It is being done for one reason only, and that is a political reason. The political reason is this: They want to scupper the health scheme that this Government has introduced. They are willing to scupper it at any cost. They are willing to put people who are paying contributions to a greater degree of hardship. They are willing to put people in New South Wales into a situation where they will pay an additional $52 a year. Let it be clearly understood that the Labor Party and the Democrats are voting to put up the contribution rates in New South Wales by $52 a year. They have already voted to put up the contributions-
Opposition senators interjecting-

talk.start.para: â€”Order! There are far too many interjections from my left. Senator Grimes, you were heard in comparative silence. Senator Chipp, you will have your opportunity later.
â€”I did not speak. I did not open my mouth.
â€”I suggest that the honourable senator who is on her feet be allowed to be heard in comparative silence.
â€”I raise a point of order. For the record, I did not open my mouth . I have played sport for a long time. When I am picked, I always like to have a guernsey. This time I did not even have one.
â€”There is no point of order.
â€”I have been accused of inspiring interjections by stating facts that some honourable senators do not like to hear.
â€”Dishonesty, actually.
â€”Order! I ask you, Senator Robertson, to withdraw your interjection. You accused the honourable senator of being dishonest.
â€”But she is.
â€”With great respect, I did not accuse her-
â€”He is not accusing her.
â€”Order! I ask both Senator Robertson and Senator Grimes to withdraw those remarks as they were accusing the honourable senator of being dishonest.

â€”Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. There is no accusation in that at all; we are stating quite clearly that she is dishonest . There is no implication that she might be otherwise.
â€”It is unparliamentary language and I ask you both to withdraw.
â€”I will withdraw.
â€”Senator Robertson, I ask you to withdraw.
â€”I am quite happy to withdraw. But I did not accuse her of dishonesty. For ease of the matter, I will withdraw.
â€”It is unparliamentary language and I ask you to withdraw.
â€”I have done so. There is no qualification, none at all.

â€”We are well aware that the Opposition is not very keen for these simple facts to be put across. The facts are easy to put across and easy for the people to understand. The increase in health contribution rates next year in New South Wales will be a direct result of the Labor Opposition and the Australian Democrats voting for a Bill to allow that State to increase the contribution rates by $1 for a family. I do not want to hear any more talk in the Senate that they believe that the contribution rates are too high. They will clearly raise them by their vote today. They are clearly raising the contribution rate by $1 a family and I want it clearly understood that there is no other reason for the rise in the contribution rates next year. One wonders when South Australia, the other Labor run State, will join Victoria and New South Wales, because no doubt it will. It will see that there is a nice way of getting a tax which amounts in Victoria to $44m and in New South Wales to $98m and getting it in such a way that the people are not aware that it is being raised. The people in Victoria and New South Wales will look at their contribution increase and say: 'The funds have put up the rates again'. They will not say: 'This rise is the result of the levy put on by the State Government', not unless it is clearly put across to them. The people will be accusing the funds of putting up the rates, not the two States.

speech.para: There is no guarantee at all in the States' legislation that the money so raised will be used for health costs. I would like the Democrats to understand that very clearly. There is no legislation in those States which will ensure that that money will be used for health costs. The States can build roads with it, they can build sporting facilities, they can do as they like with it. They do not have to use it for health funds. They put this tax on a group of people who care to insure themselves for their health costs; not, as I have said, on those people who ensure themselves for health costs in outside areas but only on those who insure themselves with the registered funds.

The Democrats have just opposed a federal tax-raising Bill, the Bank Account Debits Tax Administration Bill. They are not opposing the States receiving this money, even though it is far more discriminatory. During the last debate the Democrats likened this Bill in a most incredible way, to Queensland running the Golden Casket lotteries. I cannot imagine anything more ludicrous, but that is the standard of debate that we are used to from the Democrats. The Democrats say that the tax raised by the levy will be at the expense of only the people who are insured against health costs, except the pensioners and the low income earners. Senator Chipp is pointing to the time. I thought I would be speaking for only 10 minutes, but I have had points of order taken against me-not by Senator Chipp but by the Opposition-and my time wasted. I intend to finish what I am saying. I stress again that it is the group of people who are insured with the unregistered health funds and who carry their own insurance who will not be paying this tax. Senator Grimes talked about States rights and Senator Macklin asked whether I was denying States rights. All States in this country have the right to raise additional taxes. I do not believe they have the right to raise taxes in such a discriminatory fashion. I do not believe they can say to one group of people: 'We want $44m from Victoria and $98m from New South Wales, but we are going to tax only one section of the community. We intend to tax only those people who are willing to look after themselves. We will not tax the others in any way'. This is a discriminatory tax. It is not an honest tax because it has been disguised, it is a political act against the health scheme that this Government has put up.

I said that I would speak for only 10 minutes but roughly five minutes of my time was taken up by interjections and points of order. I will leave the rest of my remarks. This legislation has been debated twice already in this place. If this Bill is not passed by the Senate, every time a member of the Opposition says in this place that people cannot afford their health contributions and whenever the Democrats weep tears of blood because the contributions are too high, we will remind them that they were responsible for raising the contribution rates in both New South Wales and Victoria. The contributors to funds in those States will be reminded that it was not the funds but the States which raised those rates.

speech.speaker: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

talk.start.para: â€”The Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1982 presents to the Senate for the second time a proposition which the Senate has previously rejected. It was rejected because a majority of honourable senators believed it was unjust, that it intruded on States rights and that the system proposed to be introduced by Mr John Cain and now by Mr Neville Wran is a better system. I find it an amazing incongruity that that self-appointed champion of States rights, Senator Walters, should be saying: 'Look, Mr Carlton, Federal Minister for Health, it is perfectly all right for you to go to Victoria and tell Mr John Cain, the State Premier, how to run his health service'. It is incongruity at its most ludicrous , particularly in view of the 14 hours of sanctimonious protesting about infringements of States rights that we heard here this week and last week over the Franklin River. In effect, Senator Walters is saying: 'It is all right to interfere with the way in which the health scheme in Victoria is run, and it is also all right to allow a dam to be built in Tasmania'. My mind is not capable of comprehending such breathtaking logic.

speech.para: What we are debating today is a proposition put forward by Mr John Cain and now I believe by Mr Neville Wran. No doubt it will be followed, as Senator Walters accurately predicts, by all the other States in the near future. It is a most sensible proposition. That is why the Australian Democrats are opposing this Bill. We oppose it not because of any nonsense about States rights but simply because what Mr Cain proposes makes absolute good sense. Let me briefly explain the legislation as I understand it. It deals with out-patients in public hospitals. Under the old system those who attended an out-patients department at a public hospital were charged $20 for each treatment. They has to pay the $20 in cash and then collect a proportion of that sum from their health funds. One could imagine the number of pieces of paper and the amount of clerical work involved. About four different transactions would be involved. The alternative is that the patient, after receiving a bill for $20 from the hospital, could then go to a health fund, fill in an application form, receive reimbursement and then send that cheque-it would probably amount to about 80 per cent of the $20- plus his own cheque to the hospital. The hospital then has to receive it, open the envelope and issue and post out the receipt. Seven or eight transactions would be involved. That was the old system.

The new system that Mr John Cain and Mr Laurie Brereton want to introduce simplifies that procedure. From now on they want out-patient services to be free but in order to reimburse the hospitals for those costs a levy should be imposed on the health funds. The theory is that instead of the health funds being billed bit by bit for hundreds of thousands of patients a year-there would be a plethora of clerical work, expenses and whatever-it would be done in one fell swoop. If Senator Walters or the Government want to argue that a levy of 80c a family or 40c a single person is too high, I would regard that as a reasonable argument. I am prepared to hear arguments on that point of view. Maybe a fairer charge would be 60c for a family and 30c for a single person. I do not know. I do not have the figures.

What we are arguing today is the principle that what is involved here is a simplification of the health system operating in the States. Various State governments have recognised this as a way to economise, a way in which they can reduce administrative costs and redirect the staff resources and funds available to higher priority areas. As a former management consultant, I am appalled every time I walk into a public hospital at the inefficiencies and the waste of money. I would think that Senator Walters would be equally appalled; I know that her husband is in the medical profession.

I think politicians of all political complexions for years have been searching for a way to improve efficiency in hospitals in an endeavour to save this massive bill on the public purse. One State Minister believes he has found a way . As a former management consultant, I can see the wisdom in what the Victorian Government is doing. The Federal Government which is supposed to champion States rights is saying: 'We, from this ivory tower in Canberra which has a monopoly on all wisdom, say to you, John Cain, that you should not collect the fees for out- patient charges in the way you wish. You will do it our way, the federal way'. Mr Carlton, for whom I have an unbounded admiration as a person and as a Minister, has given reasons why we should oppose this levy.

In a strange sentence the Minister for Health said that the levy goes directly against the Commonwealth's commitment to health services based on the 'user pays ' principle. If someone one day were to explain to me that the Government embraces the user pays principle uniformly I would be delighted. I believe it is almost putting a principle to the point of absurdity to say: 'We believe in the user pays principle', when we look at the hundreds of thousands of examples where the principle is abrogated. Mr Carlton also said that an essential element of health cost containment is that people be aware of the costs of medical treatments and this will not occur if insured out-patients make no direct payments to hospitals. I take that point, and I agree with it. I agree that it is an argument but I believe that the weight of argument is on the other side. The Minister also opposed the levy because he said that the lack of direct payments by insured out-patients would lead to an unwarranted increase in the use of those services. I am not persuaded to that view. The Minister should have given evidence that this was the case when he made that assertion. To my knowledge no such evidence has been produced.

Finally-I think this is the crux of the matter-the Minister, who is an honest man, said that it would be possible for State governments to introduce general levies on funds for in-patient services, thus introducing an Australian Labor Party-type nationalised health scheme through the backdoor. If Senator Walters had had the time today she would have gone into that aspect because she is a champion of the private health scheme and is against a nationalised health scheme. I join with her. She and I used to fight battles, if her memory stretches back that far, back to 1975, when we were once in the same political party, against efforts to nationalise the health scheme. She would not have an enemy in me there. But as I understand it, the nub of this matter is a fear of the Liberal Party of the thin end of the wedge to a nationalised health scheme. Again I commend the Minister for his honesty in saying that that is the thrust of this legislation. But I reject the point that that is the thin end of the wedge to a nationalised health scheme.

talk.start.para: â€”You don't think they could do it?

â€”I believe the Labor Party again has been very honest in this matter. It has set out its health scheme; it is there on paper. It would be anathema to the Liberal Party and it would disagree with it. I believe that the Labor Party has been honest as well in stating what its health policy is. Of course, this is a proposition which fits snugly into that health policy. What the Minister is talking about is that this is the thin end of the wedge to a nationalised health scheme. I think that really is a load of rubbish. For those reasons the Australian Democrats join with the Labor Party in opposing this legislation.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: â€”in reply- From what Senator Chipp and Opposition senators have said the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1982 will not receive a second reading. I therefore want to make a few comments. First, I wish to make it clear that the Government has constitutional responsibility for health insurance. Section 51 placitum (xxiiiA) contains the words 'sickness and hospital benefits'. This is an area of Commonwealth responsibility and it is an area where the Commonwealth has a proper desire to protect the interests of Australians. Health insurance is a Commonwealth matter. This Bill seeks to protect contributors to health insurance . My colleague Senator Walters made this quite clear in her contribution. What we are trying to protect them against is a selective tax which is being proposed and imposed by two States under Labor control. The failure to pass this Bill will mean higher health insurance premiums for Australian people in Victoria and New South Wales. The Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats by opposing this Bill are voting to ensure higher health insurance premiums for Australians in two large States. This Bill, if passed, will enable premiums to be reduced. That is the crux of the matter.

speech.para: People listening to this debate should understand that their interests are being put at risk. If this Bill is passed their health insurance payments will be lower. If this Bill is rejected their health insurance payments will be higher. They will have the Australian Labor Party and the Democrats to thank when they have a higher than necessary health insurance Bill. I am grateful to Senator Walters for having made that point clear. That is the undoubted effect that will flow from the Labor Party vote. Labor senators are voting for higher health insurance today and the Australian Democrats are with them. It is not only a higher impost but also one that is quite significant in the way in which it will increase. The New South Wales Government has not only introduced an impost but also has indexed it to changes in prices irrespective of how costs move in hospitals and irrespective of usage. It is indexed to the consumer price index and the impost on contributors to health insurance funds will increase inexorably. I notice that the Australian Democrats are supporting the Labor Party in this matter. I cannot but be reminded of a statement made by Senator Chipp to the National Press Club on 29 July 1981 when he said:
Fortuitously, the ideas of the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party on social and legal and constitutional and electoral reform are almost indistinguishable.

Well, they certainly are. We know from the way in which divisions in this place go and from the voting record in divisions that that is the case. The Australian Democrats divide with the Australian Labor Party most of the time. They vote against revenue proposals to enable the Government to do its job and they vote for most proposals to increase expenditure. On this occasion at least, they are voting for a measure which will increase an impost upon Australian citizens and they are voting against a measure which will protect contributors and keep costs down. There is no way the Labor Party can get away from the consequence of what it is doing.

In the previous debate, I have set out the reasons why we thought these proposals should not be rejected. Senator Chipp was inaccurate when he said they were rejected by a majority in the Senate. They were not. There was an equality of voting. That is a small point. Senator Chipp might as well be accurate in what he said. There was not a majority against this proposal, but the rules of the Senate meant that the Bill failed. So be it. I do not object to that.

talk.start.para: â€”There was not a majority for it, was there?

â€”I notice that I am receiving some assistance from Senator Macklin who has been very vocal throughout this debate. I do not know if he is embarrassed. He can go home and explain to people the effect of his vote. Honourable senators opposite have been talking about State rights. They oppose State rights on the question of the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill and they oppose State rights where there is some doubt that the Commonwealth has the responsibility and power to move as they suggested, and they espouse State rights in an area of clear Commonwealth responsibility. The Commonwealth clearly has the responsibility to look after health insurance. Honourable members opposite are trying to prevent the Commonwealth from carrying out what it is required to do.

speech.para: It has been an interesting week. At the beginning of Senator Chipp's speech we had a reference to the debate on the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill which has been passed. I have only one comment to make on that matter. At the National Press Club on 29 July 1981, Senator Chipp said:
. . . there'll be no gags in future in the Senate . . .

On 9 December 1982, Senator Chipp voted for the gag five times. In July 1981, he said: 'There will be no gags'. On 9 December 1982, he voted for five gags and on 13 December he voted for one more. I suppose we should be grateful for the fact that there was 16 months between his statement and its betrayal. But, after all, Senator Chipp did come here to teach us how to be honest and to keep us honest in the eyes of the electorate.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr Acting Deputy President, in view of the tone of this debate, I wonder whether I could seek your ruling? If a senator in this place was in fact a delegate to the interntional conference of federation of voluntary health insurance funds in 1978 and is closely connected with those organisations, should that senator declare her interest in such funds when she debates an issue like this which is obviously primarily concerned with the voluntary health funds and pushed by the voluntary health funds.
â€”I suggest no point of order arises.
â€”There is no point of order.

â€”Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. With great respect, you are here to protect all senators. I went down to my office for a moment and heard this sneaky Minister use the platform of this debate to go right off the track on health legislation and to talk about my speech to the National Press Club months ago and the use of the gag. I ask you, with ultimate respect: Why did you allow him to do that? He knows the Standing Orders. He knows he is out of order. I would have thought that that sort of protection would have been afforded to me when I was out of the chamber while this sneak carried on like this on a health legislation Bill. It is typical of this Minister. It is the way he plays the game all the time. There has to be somebody in the chamber to expose him when he steps out of line. I would have thought the Chair, advised by the clerks, should have done it.

interject.speaker: Mr ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: â€”I appreciate that the debate has become robust. I could have given the honourable member leave to speak on a personal explanation. He has made his point. I think he has levelled out the aspects of the debate. Everyone is conversant with what was said and what was rebutted.

interject.para: That the Bill be now read a second time.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

debate.title: CONCILIATION AND ARBITRATION (MANAGEMENT OF ORGANIZATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 10 November, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Button Sen J.N.

talk.start.para: â€”The Conciliation and Arbitration (Management of Organizations) Amendment Bill has two main purposes. Firstly, it provides for the disqualification from holding office in an organisation of persons convicted of certain prescribed offences subject to an appeal. Secondly, it provides for organisations to abide by certain rules as to the making of loans and, in particular, for the disclosure of loans and donations by trade unions and trade union officials. The Bill represents yet another contribution of this Government in the field of industrial relations. Not many of the contributions which this Government has made in the past seven years have been very distinguished ones. This Bill will not alter the pattern at all. I want to say at the outset that the Opposition does not oppose the Bill. We see some value in it. Some honourable senators, one in particular, might be surprised to hear that we do not oppose the clause relating to disclosures of donations. That is not a matter which trade unions or the Australian Labor Party , which are sometimes the recipients of those donations, have ever sought to hide. We welcome those provisions and we will not oppose them.

speech.para: I want to talk briefly about the history of this Government in relation to industrial relations matters because it has not been a particularly happy history. There are many reasons for that which lie deep in the ideology of the Liberal Party. This Government has constantly sought to pursue in its industrial relations policies an element of confrontation and a great deal of chest beating about the demons, if you like, that exist in the industrial relations field. The Fraser Government seems to think that if there is some problem in industrial relations that it wants to overcome it need only legislate and everything will be better. The Government has legislated in this area some 15 times since it came to power as a government; yet it still complains--

talk.start.para: â€”And you helped us, too.

â€”Yes, we have helped the Government to legislate; yet it still complains. I would have thought that that scarcely represents success. This approach ignores the very fundamental truth that good industrial relations are achieved, as the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) once said when he was the Opposition spokesman on industrial relations, through co-operation and consultation and not with the heavy-handed approach to which government is sometimes addicted and to which this Government is particularly addicted. Let us not be fooled by this legislation. It has the traditional ad hoc gimmickry approach that characterises the legislation of this Government in industrial relations matters. There is no better evidence of that fact than the statement by the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) in his second reading speech that the legislation was inspired largely by the Winneke Royal Commission on the Activities of the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation.

speech.para: The political background to the Bill is that the Government has tried to make a bit of capital out of problems in the industrial relations arena. The Senate will be mindful of the inquiry into the Builders Labourers Federation and of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union which backfired a bit in terms of its intended purpose. Perhaps it is desirable in that context that the Government should use this to try to recover some ground. What has really happened is that the new Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee) has had to throw a sort of ideological bone to certain elements of the Liberal Party to satisfy--

talk.start.para: â€”Was there any meat on the bone.
â€”That is something on which the honourable senator ought to be able to comment. He is one of the dogs to whom the bone would have been thrown.
â€”As long as there was a bit of red meat on it.

â€”I appreciate the point. The meat would have to be delicately cooked in the case of Senator Withers. I just want to make the point that it is important to appreciate the background and the environment in which this legislation was introduced. We regard the legislation as basically unnecessary. We will not oppose it because we do not see it as doing any particular harm. That is not exactly an epitaph that one would like to see on one's political grave. One would not like to see the epitaph: 'He was never opposed because he never did any particular harm'.
â€”What is an appropriate epitaph?
â€”I would like a minute to think of an appropriate one for the honourable senator.
â€”Order! I suggest the honourable senator stick to the Bill.

â€”Maybe the appropriate epitaph would be: 'He never bit anybody because he did not have any teeth'. What is extraordinary, of course, is that in a situation in which the economy of this country is in dire straits, this sort of legislation is floated up as something of importance. I want to make just one other point about the environmental issue. It is very important to understand that there are more environments than one. We are now talking about the industrial relations environment. As the Prime Minister put it on 30 August this year:

speech.para: . . . high priced lawyers and accountants who have devised and promoted tax avoidance schemes do more damage to the basis of this society than a thousand Gallaghers in this world, or a thousand Builders' Labourers Federations . . .

talk.start.para: â€”Who said that?

â€”That is what the Prime Minister said on 30 August. It is extraordinary that he should have said that on 30 August partly to justify six years of negligence and failure in relation to tax avoidance involving high priced lawyers and accountants. There has been six years of total inactivity except for the Royal Commision on the Activities of the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation which, in contrast, resulted in this legislation being produced so quickly. It is strange that that should happen in that way, but it is part of the way in which politics operate under this Government.

speech.para: I turn to some of the particular objections to the Bill. It is a bad Bill in terms of drafting and so on. It is not well thought out-surprise, surprise! The first point I want to make concerns consistency. By way of introduction we are told that this Bill is aimed at putting companies and trade unions-corporations of capital and corporations of labour-on the same sort of footing. Let us look at the success of that. I refer to the legislation itself, which proceeds on the assumption that there is in fact some sort of basic similarity between trade unions and corporate organisations in terms of financial capacities. The Minister for National Development and Energy made reference in his second reading speech to provisions in the national companies leglislation which place obligations on company directors. It is not true at all to say that trade unions and companies are in a similar position in relation to those matters.

talk.start.para: â€”The tragedy is that they are not.

â€”They are in a similar position in relation to the consequences of the activities of both corporations. I agree with that proposition, if that is what is being put by way of interjection. The functions of company directors are not the same as the functions of trade union officials in any sense, particularly if a company director is running a $10 shelf company or something. The corporate veil is used for very strange purposes sometimes. The penalties provided for that and the administration of that process are not very well carried out. Company directors and officers of companies often have fiduciary duties and obligations to shareholders which are not like those of trade union officials. The concept of a limited liability for a company and the responsibilities which directors have to shareholders ensure that there should be a different standard of conduct for those persons than for union officials.

speech.para: I make the point that it is quite untrue to say that the obligations imposed on officials of industrial organisations by this Bill are the same as those currently imposed on company directors. An examination of the provisions of the Bill indicates that the obligations are likely to be much more onerous than those imposed on company officials by section 227 and section 562 of the Companies Act 1981. I make the point by referring to a number of matters in proposed new section 132F of the Bill which provides that one of the prescribed offences which could lead to disqualification is:

. . . an offence involving the intentional or reckless use of violence towards another person, the intentional or reckless causing of death or injury to another person or the intentional or reckless damaging or destruction of property.

I do not know what that means. Perhaps the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) can help us later on by telling us what it means. The use of the word ' reckless' in relation to a union official, meaning reprehensible conduct punishable by provisions under this Bill, has no counterpart in company legislation. No company director can possibly commit an offence under the Companies Act which is described as recklessness in the generality embraced by that expression. The word 'reckless' in this legislation could cover a wide range of situations which would not ordinarily be thought to constitute behaviour which should disqualify somebody from holding office in a company or anywhere else. For example, one can be guilty of an offence under the Commonwealth Motor Vehicles (Liability) Act or the Crimes Act involving the use of a motor vehicle which is attributable to recklessness in the course of one's employment. This clearly falls within the provisions of this proposed new section. As a result of that a union official under this legislation could be disqualified from holding office.

talk.start.para: â€”Quite right, too.

â€”That may not be the intention. Having interjected 'quite right' if the honourable senator applies that standard to the Dental Board of Queensland or whatever such body covers the honourable senator will he say that he should be denied the right to continue in his occupation as a result of reckless use of a motor car?
â€”They can be far more stringent than that. I am on the British Dental Council register. If I am convicted on a drunkenness charge I get deregistered for life.

â€”With respect, the legislation is not more strict than that. There are plenty of dentists in my State, certainly, who have been convicted of drunken driving who have not been disbarred from their profession.
â€”I am telling you that under the British Dental Council you are.
â€”I do not care what happens under some British legislation; I am talking about what happens here in Australia. In the case of doctors, dentists or anybody else-
â€”Not even judges.

â€”Not even judges, of course, as Senator Withers said. That is true. There have been some shining examples, if I might say so. Not even a judge convicted of recklessness loses his job as a consequence.
â€”I was talking about drunkenness.

â€”Recklessness while drunk, shall we put it that way, Senator? That is the consequence of this Bill. It is either a very bad piece of drafting or a quite discriminatory and unfair provision. I draw the attention of the Senate to that. I must say that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, in explaining that clause in the House of Representatives, said that the courts would be expected to grapple with these issues in a sensible way. That might be so but it is not how one deals with legislation or puts some popularly conceived demon such as Norman Gallagher into the dock to face a drunk driving charge, saying to the courts: 'You have to be very careful about this fellow because he is a union official and if you convict him he might lose his job'. That is not fair. It is an aspect of this legislation that is wrong. One hopes that the Government will re-examine that provision and ensure that it is amended or interpreted in such a way as to be satisfactory, otherwise justice will not be done.

speech.para: The second important point that I would like to make about the legislation is that if a union official has been convicted of a prescribed offence under it and subsequently goes to the court and says, 'I want to stand as a candidate in a union election', then obtains permission from the court to stand, as the Bill would allow him to do, obviously that is not fair under the democratic process. As a candidate he is under a cloud from the start in contesting an election. He is the mendicant candidate, the one who has been to court and been told, 'In spite of your grave errors of character'-or whatever has been found by the court -'when you behaved carelessly,'-or something of the sort-'you are entitled to be a candidate'. That represents a severe intrusion upon the democratic process. In view of the way in which the Bill is structured I do not know how one is to solve that problem, what one does by way of an alternative, but I wonder whether that provision has been thought through. The potential for suffering severe disadvantage is present there.

Again, there is no real parallel in the Companies Act because company directors do not normally stand for election. Another minor point of difference is that the companies legislation probably applies only to offences committed within Australia, whereas the provisions of this Bill apply to offences committed ' under a law of the Commonwealth of a State, of a Territory or of another country '. I do not know why that language has been inserted. Perhaps the Minister will explain it to us later, but it is not on all fours with normal legislation of this kind and one wonders why it is there.

The principal objection that the Opposition has to the Bill-I wish to confine my remarks as much as possible-concerns paragraph (b) of proposed new section 132F (1). That provision sets out as prescribed offences the offences listed under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and the regulations made thereunder. That really involves double jeopardy for officials who are caught up by its provisions. The point is that the Conciliation and Arbitration Act already provides penalties in respect of offences listed in that Act. In a sense people who are caught up by the provisions of this legislation will have to be dealt with twice for the same offence. It seems to the Opposition to be very strange that a trade union official who has been punished under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act should then suffer the additional penalty of being disqualified from holding office under this Bill. The Government really cannot have it both ways in respect of that offence. It is really a matter of beating the cat too much.

talk.start.para: â€”That is true of the Companies Act provisions isn't it?

â€”No, it is not. First, the range of offences here is considerably wider than it is under the Companies Act. If one is convicted, under the Companies Act provision, of an offence prescribed by that Act the pattern of disqualification is not the same as for the offences listed under that Act. They are the same here; they are identical. Double jeopardy is built into the legislation. This is an Act which operates in respect of trade unions for which the Conciliation and Arbitration Act already provides penalties for officials for a prescribed class of offence. The same class is prescribed here. A person is punished under an Act specifically for the purpose of dealing with trade unions and is again eventually dealt with under these provisions by losing his job.

speech.para: I make one other point. A union official might be put in a quite impossible position by this clause. An offence under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act may have been committed in the course of carrying out one's duty as a union official. A committee of management, for example, may have instructed a person to perform certain actions which would result in a breach of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Should a union official obey the instructions of his committee of managment which might lead to a breach of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act or should he disregard that directive? If he went ahead he would suffer a penalty under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and, in addition, find himself disqualified from holding office in a union by virtue of the provisions of this Bill. There is no justification for imposing double penalties in this way and the Opposition intends to move an amendment at the Committee stage of the debate in relation to that matter.

The final matter I want to mention is the disclosure provisions. This legislation provides for disclosure in respect of grants or loans to anyone or to any organisation, not just an officer or member of a union. The Opposition is not opposed to public disclosure of loans, grants or gifts which are made by trade unions or trade union officials to organisations or persons. There should be public disclosure of those things. For a long time we have said that there should be public disclosure provisions in relation to both companies and trade unions. Part of the national policy of the Opposition is that there should be public disclosure. What harm can be done to a society by seeing what donations are given to particular organisations by other organisations? People do not have to make donations if they do not want them to be disclosed. We say that the provisions relating to disqualification of officials are similar to corporate provisions. If the Government insists on that it should admit that there is an overwhelming case for extending disclosure provisions to companies as well. For example, if a particular trade union gives the Australian Labor Party $10,000 for an election we see no objection to that being publicly disclosed. It should be publicly disclosed. The same rule should apply to companies which give the Labor Party or the Liberal Party $10,000 for an election. If we are talking about equality of principle between companies and the trade union movement we have to be fair dinkum about that too. The same standards should apply.

talk.start.para: â€”Does the Labor Party disclose all its donations?

â€”We would if we were asked but we would not disclose donations from businesses because the rules do not apply with equality. However, there is no hesitation at all about disclosing donations given to us by trade unions. If the rules applied with equality across the board we would not worry about donations given to us by companies either. We should not worry about them and neither should the Liberal Party. It may mean that both parties have less money because people may not want to give if their donations have to be disclosed. But when one is operating as a public organisation, such as a political party, there is no reason why there should not be complete and frank disclosure. People can then draw their own conclusions from anything which may follow, as Senator Peter Baume did, with great vehemence, when he discovered that the Victorian Secondary Teachers Association gave a big donation to the Labor Party in Victoria at the last State election.

speech.para: So we say that the disclosure provisions in this legislation should be extended to all individuals and organisations. The Opposition calls upon the Government to follow the force of that argument for public disclosure right through and apply the disclosure provisions to companies as well as trade unions. That should be done. Otherwise, what seems to be the rationale of the Government's approach in this legislation-namely, that the same sort of rules should apply to trade unions as apply to companies-is just not true. The Government does not believe that at all; it believes that only when it suits it to do so. It is a piece of legislative and political hypocrisy which is a quite extraordinary justification for legislation. I now turn to the Opposition's second reading amendment. The most outrageous thing has just occurred. Somebody has passed me a note saying that this is a long 10 minutes. What an extraordinary thing to say!

talk.start.para: â€”Why don't you move that as your amendment? It certainly does seem a long 10 minutes.
â€”If ever it had been agreed to be 10 minutes, I would agree with that, but it was not. I now move:

speech.para: At end of motion, add ', but the Senate calls on the Government to extend the principle of disclosure of donations by organisations and to legislate immediately to require full disclosure by companies of all donations of a political nature made by them'.

Apart from that amendment, the Opposition supports the Bill, with many qualifications and concerns. We do not want to be saying that what applies to companies in general should not apply to trade unions. We think is should and wish the Government thought the same.

speech.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: â€”There are extreme time pressures this afternoon. The Australian Democrats support the Conciliation and Arbitration ( Management of Organizations) Amendment Bill. I will not go into the history of the Bill because that is well known. Nor do I wish to go into the detailed provisions of the Bill because they too are fairly well known. Suffice it to say that as far as we can see this Bill will do absolutely nothing for industrial relations in this country. Whether the Government makes any political capital out of it remains to be seen. We are persuaded that that is the essential purpose of the Bill.

speech.para: I wish to confine my further comments to the various amendments proposed by the Australian Labor Party. The Opposition first wishes to remove sub-clause 132F (1 ) (b). It claims that this sub-clause represents a double jeopardy in that people convicted of an offence under certain sections of various Acts named in the legislation could be subject to a second penalty. Exactly, the same situation applies to company directors who may be convicted of fraud and fined and who may also be debarred from remaining as company directors. If it is good enough for company directors it seems to us to be good enough for union officials. I was not persuaded by the comments of Senator Button in this area.

So we will not be supporting the Labor Party's amendment at the second reading stage. We will be happy, however, to support the Opposition's second reading amendment. I wish to observe briefly that it is a pity that both major political parties do not follow the practice of the Australian Democrats in identifying major donors to political parties. I am sure that we would all be much wiser if they did that. I was intrigued by the wording of the Labor Party's amendment to the motion that the Bill be read a second time, which, in part, states:
. . . immediately to require full disclosure by companies of all donations of a political nature made by them.

Senator Button did not make it clear to me whether that principle would be applied to donations to political parties. I gathered that he was in agreement with that principle. I only hope that when the Australian Labor Party forms a government in the foreseeable future it will adopt that principle and legislate for the public disclosure of donations to political parties.

talk.start.para: â€”We will.

â€”I acknowledge Senator Button's interjection. I am delighted to hear it. Senator Button said that the Labor Party will legislate for the disclosure of donations to political parties. That would be, as far as I am concerned, one enormous step forward in bringing Australian politics to a different level altogether. At present our political system is wide open to legal political blackmail. There is no other word for it. Companies-many of them multinational companies-with millions of dollars to be gained by government favours can legally make multimillion dollar donations to political parties without disclosing that they are doing it. If that is not political blackmail, I do not know what is. If we achieve nothing else in the next few years but the public disclosure of funds to political parties we will have advanced the political process in this country. That is good news from our point of view.

speech.para: I conclude by stating that under this Bill union officials who are convicted of offences will be disqualified for five years only. That does not seem to me to be unreasonable. When this Bill was first mooted in the Press there was talk about disqualification for extended periods. It was argued that officials who, in their youth, may have been convicted for an offence such as pinching some fruit from a neighbour's fruit tree would be excluded from holding office because of that offence committed maybe 40 years ago. I was pleased to see that that provision did not appear in the legislation. We support the legislation. We wholeheartedly support the Labor Party's second reading amendment. We will not support its amendment at the Committee stage.

speech.speaker: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: â€” I support the Conciliation and Arbitration (Management of Organizations) Amendment Bill which relates to an important area of industrial relations; that is, federally registered organisations which apply both to employers and employees. Before I speak to the Bill I should like to take a moment to comment on the contributions to this debate made by Senator Button and Senator Siddons. I looked forward with some pleasure to hearing Senator Button, but unfortunately I did not think he spent much time preparing his speech. His speech had so little factual comment and critical appraisal of the Bill that his 27 minute speech could have been reduced to a 10 minute speech. I will pick up a couple of points he made. I do not agree with the Australian Democrats approach that this Bill does nothing for industrial relations. I think it shows a lack of understanding of the Bill. The Bill is not universally applicable to everyday events. To claim that it is purely for political capital is to show a lack of understanding of what has gone on in Australian industrial relations over recent times.

speech.para: The matter of donations to party funds really is a red herring. We have a belief in this country that people are entitled to the privacy of the ballot box . We do not have public voting, except in some union affairs and so on where people are subject to intimidation. We believe that all the governments of Australia are elected by secret ballot, and it is a quite logical extension of that basic right that people should be entitled to support the political party of their choice without being criticised or investigated by their political opponents. That is a principle which I am happy to defend at any time. This is dealt with quite ethically and adequately in the Liberal Party of Australia by a separation of the fund raising functions within the organisational wing from those of the political wing.

talk.start.para: â€”What a lot of bunkum.

â€”I have never raised any funds in all the years that I have been in the Liberal Party while I have held a political position. I return to the Bill. It relates to both employers and employees. It is very important to stress that it relates to the employers. Listening to Senator Button, one would think that it is applicable purely to employees, but that is not so; it covers the employers. They are both dealt with equally under the legislation.

speech.para: There are two broad areas of concern. The first area deals with the fitness of office-holders to hold office in organisations, or those individuals who aspire to office. The second broad area relates to the use of the financial resources of the organisations with respect to making loans, grants and donations. As to the fitness of office-holders, this is quite a reasonable position to adopt having regard to the position of national importance of office-bearers in these organisations. Similar restrictions or even more stringent restrictions apply in some professional and commercial fields where people similarly have positions of trust and responsibility.

The provisions set out to combat corruption. The Government is trying to ensure a higher standard of integrity-not that the assertion is that union officials, by and large, are corrupt; they are certainly not corrupt. The overwhelming majority of them are absolutely honest. But in any bureaucracy-when I use the word 'bureaucracy' in this sense I am not talking about the Public Service-in any big organisation, there is always the possibility of the abuse of power. This is one legislative way of trying to control abuses of power, particularly where they get into the fields of criminal corruption.

One has to look only at the present structure of Russian society today, in which there is no legislation similar to this, and to talk to people with some knowledge of it to learn of the extent of corruption which apparently now is right through the whole of Russian society, both horizontally and vertically. The provisions are not a prohibition on people who have a criminal record from being office-holders. They can have served their sentence and paid their debts to society, but the requirement is that they must be separated from the event by a period of five years, either the event which led to their conviction or five years after they have served their sentence; so in that sense it does not abridge in any way their human rights.

The second point of the legislation deals with the accountability of the disbursement of funds. This is something about which the debate so far has occasioned most comment. Briefly, the Bill provides that there must not be a decision made by one person or by two or three people in the organisation but by the whole of the management committee; and secondly, there must be provisions for proper repayment. It is designed to prevent loans to relatives or friends, or to prevent donations masquerading as loans, by the requirement that there be adequate repayment facilities. As I have said, there has been great opposition to this. Frankly, it is nonsense. It simply relates to the proviso of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, in Part VIIIAA as it currently stands, and its supporting regulations, which cover all loans, grants and donations over $1,000. That was the recommendation of the National Labor Consultative Council, and the Australian Council of Trade Unions accepted that recommendation. There is no requirement to publish those donations. It is just that they must be within the records of the body approved by the management committee.

It is important to emphasise that this is not anti-union legislation. It applies both to employer and to employee bodies. It is fair legislation, because it protects the vast majority of honest people in both categories from the excesses of a few dishonest individuals. There is no need at all for groups to feel victimised or that they are being placed-without trial-in a category of untrustworthiness with respect to society. After all, managers and company directors, as Senator Siddons has said, accept the provision of the Companies Act which covers their behaviour even though most of them are in ethical companies. But there are also those in the small companies such as the $2 companies which have an horrendous history of failure and, quite frankly, fraud.

It is equally important to realise that the Government does not expect these provisions to be widely used. That is a point I made right at the outset. This is very narrow legislation which will be applied on very infrequent occasions because the great majority of unions and employer groups are absolutely honest. But everyone knows the problems we have had in recent times with the Builders Labourers Federation and the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union of Australia. Quite simply, some unions are not whiter than white. That is the reason for this legislation-to control the few who behave in a criminal way.

Senator Button had quite a bit to say about comparisons with the Companies Act. I do not wish to go down that path because I think it is rather irrelevant to the furtherance of this debate. I would like to talk briefly about offences that will be provided for under this Act and under the provisions of proposed new section 132F (1) (b) which describes the offences. Broadly, they are: Fraud or dishonesty under Commonwealth, State and Territory laws; offences in connection with management problems; and the final one about which Senator Button was so concerned, which is 'the intentional or reckless use of violence'. Senator Button made the case that a motor accident could debar someone from being an office holder. That is simple a facile and incorrect interpretation of the provision. Intentional or reckless use of violence has to be proved. The history of a few unions shows that violence and intimidation have been used to enforce union policy. As a layman I think it would probably be very difficult to prove before a court of law that that violence was intentional. Far from being a stringent requirement, I think the law is rather weak in that we will probably have great difficulty in satisfying a judge or the courts that violence was intentional even though someone might be very badly beaten up or injured. The old story of accidents happening and no one knowing what happened and no one seeing what happened is all too prevalent. Certainly, this legislation is designed to ban those who, in general terms, are unfit to hold office. It is designed quite clearly to protect the organisations from corrupt officials but it is not designed in any way at all to ruin the careers of otherwise impeccable officials.

In conclusion I say that the Act will not have great application. It has become necessary only because of the abuses of power by several unions in the country and the potential, presumably, of other groups to flaunt the law with respect to people's rights. The legislation is not discriminatory in any sense at all between the employer and the employee. It is not anti-union in any sense. It is designed to protect the members of the organisations from a few unscrupulous officials. It is fairly drafted and it is really about accountability for office holders.

speech.speaker: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

talk.start.para: â€”In joining in this debate on the Conciliation and Arbitration (Management of Organizations) Amendment Bill 1982, I commend my Leader, Senator Button, who in his usual way gave a lucid explanation of the legal implications of the Bill. I raise a question of practical trade unionism. I have listened to Government speakers. I was fortified by the remarks of our industrial relations spokesman in the other place, the honourable member for Wills, Mr Robert Hawke, in relation to the capacity of the Australian Council of Trade Unions to put its own house in order . The unions named in the legislation are a very minute section of the trade union movement. Even Senator MacGibbon has conceded that the vast majority of trade union officers do a very onerous job under tremendous pressure. I could reflect on some of the aspects of the Builders Labourers Federation or the Ship Painters and Dockers Union, but I hasten to say that although I may differ with some of the trade union officials in my State-I know Senator Childs will agree with me-they are honest. I refer particularly to Izzy Wyner, the Secretary of the New South Wales Branch of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. He goes to ACTU Labour Council of Australia and Australian Labor Party conferences. He does not often get his way but he fights on, and he is a very honest man.

speech.para: I draw a contrast between the slow processes of the law-notwithstanding some of the aspects of the Gallagher administration-and the activities of Peter Clyne. He has swindled this country out of a million dollars. Nobody stops him by taking away his passport. He is able to go to Europe at will and to return. If the Government wants respect from the trade union movement-

talk.start.para: â€”Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I do not wish to waste the time of the Senate defending Peter Clyne but I understand that he is currently charged with a criminal offence and is on bail and will be proceeding to trial. I remind the Senate of that fact because normally one is a little careful in one's remarks when a man is before the court.

â€”Senator, I immediately retreat because I want justice to be done. Having said that, I turn to the capacity of the trade union movement to deal with their own. There have been cases of bad apples. In the 1950s, when the bus union had lifetime appointments, an official of the union named Bagnall died prematurely-at 47 years of age-and it was found that he had union money mixed up with his own. The union changed its rules and introduced triennial elections. That was its prerogative. The United Kingdom still has not learnt its lesson in relation to security. If one goes to Cambridge or Oxford, one can get away with treason, but if one is from the north of England and has a working class background, one is out on one's bum quickly if one breaks foreign affairs law. Those are the double standards. I know men like Gordon McIntosh say 'Amen' to that.
â€”Amen.

â€”Thank you, Senator. I make these points in relation to the capacity of our society to put its house in order. In my own State, a prominent official of the Rural Bank of New South Wales was sentenced to imprisonment for 10 years for diddling society by misappropriation of certain funds. I fortify what Senator Button has said on the legal side of this Bill and unions putting their house in order. Perhaps I can give an example of the complications for a trade union. Sometimes, if a union's leadership goes astray, the rank and file adjust it. Last night-I do not want to offend my Deputy Leader-I referred to a very fine publication on the history of the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia. The pendulum went from the far Left to the centre Right. I ask honourable senators to note those terms I am using.
â€”You mean far Left to far Right.

â€”Thank you, Senator. Examples of adjustment by the rank and file members of a union are mentioned in the book. The South Coast branch of the Federated Ironworkers Association is well to the left of the national officers, but that problem was dealt with within the union. Nobody had to go to court. Probably the union is all the more healthy for that when Lelli and others put their points of view at the national conference. So many people believe the state can intervene in trade unionism but not in board room battles. These are the problems that are faced today, and the double standard is resented. I think the judiciary should have moved a lot quicker to extinguish the fire in the demarcation dispute at the Omega navigational site in which members of the Builders Labourers Federation were opposed to the FIA and the Australian Workers Union.

speech.para: Sometimes there is State rivalry, regional rivalry and occupational rivalry. I think Senator Childs will agree with me that a trade union official finds it fairly hard to take a stance without first assessing the feelings of the rank and file. After all, for the last ten years editorials and all the pseudo- industrial knowhow on this side and the Government side of the chamber have harped on the rank and file, as though every paid official is being got at. That is just the point. We have inculcated the idea that Jack is as good as his master-that is a lovely term-but sometimes the paid officials know a little more . I can assure the Senate that those officials are hindered by members of the rank and file who do not want to be paid officials, but who like to snipe at the officials. That is why they have to hasten slowly before getting to the party.

They are the real difficulties that the trade union movement has inherited. I suppose it all started with the film starring Marlon Brando entitled On the Waterfront. It gave the impression that every union official was got at. Honourable senators opposite have said about trade unions: 'Get together with the boss and everything will be right'. Sure, we have to have talk around the table, but if a person goes to too many dinners and drinks too many red wines or white wines, that is when seduction can occur in relation to ideas. That is what I always believe. I know that Senator Childs will agree with me that a person has to keep away from such situations. The moment a person declines to participate he is told that he is anti-social. He has to walk a tightrope. I simply say this: The reality of industrial affairs today is that there is always that danger of being enticed into something, into having too many white wines or too many red wines. For all we know the boss could be operating a tape recorder and could play back the tape. These are the things that we have to watch for.

I know that people say that I am too suspicious, but a person needs to be like the dingo in the morning. The dingo walks out in the morning and sniffs the air. He knows a human scent. That is what trade union people have to do. I conclude on this note: I think that in the future Senator Evans will be able to be equated with Senator Robert Kennedy, a dedicated Attorney-General. Senator Kennedy was determined that he would get Jimmy Hoffa. He never got him and neither did his successor. The Teamsters Union does not square up to what I believe in. It does not have socialist objectives; it is a private enterprise organisation. None of my trade union colleagues believe in the private enterprise sentiments of the Teamsters Union. Would any honourable senator on the Government side of the chamber say that the Teamsters Union is an honest union? They know that it is not. To make the message quite clear, we have distinct reservations about the legislation. We believe that the trade union movement is capable of clearing out its own bad apples. There is no need for Federal intervention. Honourable senators opposite may still say that there is. I had better conclude my remarks. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) is looking at me. He knows that I have set a litmus test for honourable senators opposite.

speech.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: â€”I thank honourable senators for their support of the Conciliation and Arbitration ( Management Organizations) Amendment Bill and I thank Senator Mulvihill for making the debate interesting. I shall be brief because honourable senators have co-operated in our attempts to meet a fairly heavy legislative program today. The Bill touches on two areas: First the fitness for office of officers of an organisation or of individuals who aspire to office and; secondly, the use of financial resources of organisations to make loans, grants or donations. As is fully set out in the second reading speech, the matters which have been brought before the Parliament in this Bill largely arise out of recommendations which were made by the Winneke Royal Commission into the Activities of the Australian Building Construction Employees and Builders Labourers Federation. They are matters which have been picked up and developed by the Government, for which we now seek the Senate's approval.

speech.para: There is nothing unusual in having disqualification provisions which render people ineligible for office even though they might have committed an offence which is extraneous to that office. All honourable senators in this place are subject to the provisions of the Australian Constitution. Clause 44 of the Constitution ensures that all honourable senators are incapable of remaining members of the Senate if convicted of, or under sentence or subject to be sentenced for any offence punishable under the law by imprisonment for one year or longer. The broad principle that with respect to elected office there should be some requirement of fitness for office is one which applies equally in this place and elsewhere.

Reference has been made to the companies legislation. This legislation, of course, borrows heavily from the existing provisions of the uniform Companies Act which disqualify company directors from acting as directors for a variety of reasons. Section 227 of the uniform Companies Act sets out various classes of offences which will give rise to disqualification of directors. I note that one of the paragraphs of that section relates to indictment for any offence in connection with the promotion, formation or management of a corporation.

It is inherent in this legislation, as it is in the companies legislation and the constitutional provision, that there is an element of double jeopardy. People commit or may commit offences which render them liable to punishment. They are subsequently liable to the second punishment of disqualification from office. The element of double jeopardy about which some honourable senators have expressed concern is inherent in any proposal of this sort and is not a fundamental objection.

The more serious objection which is advanced by the Opposition-although it says that it supports the legislation, notwithstanding the defects about which it complains-which it has made the subject of an amendment it has moved to the motion for the second reading of the Bill, is that the legislation is not even- handed in that there is not a requirement for disclosure of donations by companies, which are, of course, able to make donations of a political nature without disclosure. I have already said that there is a heavy reliance upon the companies legislation as a model for this legislation.

The matter which is raised by the amendment which has been moved by Senator Button was raised in the other place. Consequent upon it being raised the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee), pursuant to an undertaking which he gave in the House of Representatives, has written to the Acting Attorney-General (Mr N. A. Brown) and raised with him the question of bringing the companies legislation into line with the legislation which is presently before the Senate. In his letter to the Acting Attorney-General, Mr Macphee pointed out that this Bill, among other things, requires three things: That the rules of registered employee and employer organisations or their branches provide for the committee of management of the organisation or branch concerned to approve all loans, grants and donations of an amount exceeding $1, 000; that the committee of management be satisfied that specific criteria are met in relation to each such loan, grant or donation; and that an annual statement giving specified particulars of each loan, grant or donation be lodged with the Industrial Registrar and be available for inspection only by members of the organisation concerned. I stress those last words because this is a matter of making available to the members of organisations, be they employer or employee organisations, advice about what is being done with their funds.

The matter having been raised by the Opposition, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations referred to his remarks in the second reading debate and asked the Acting Attorney-General to ensure that when the policy in relation to the companies provisions was under consideration-it is under consideration at the moment in the context of the planned exposure draft of the companies and securities legislation, a draft which it is hoped will be available for public comment-the question of making the companies legislation compatible with the legislation which is now before the Senate was given consideration. There is nothing either sinister or surprising in the fact that this Bill represents some advance on the companies legislation. The Government will ensure that the question of parity between the two sets of legislation is given consideration in the context that I have just outlined. I commend the Bill to the Senate. I request the Senate to reject the amendment which has been moved by the Opposition.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Button's amendment) be added.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

speech.para: Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

proctext.para: The Bill.

speech.speaker: Button Sen J.N.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: Page 5, clause 4, proposed paragraph 132F (1) (b), lines 14 to 18, leave out the proposed paragraph.

This amendment relates to the question of double jeopardy in that certain offences which are proscribed by the Conciliation and Arbitration Act are proscribed again by this Bill. The list of offences proscribed in this Bill is considerably wider than the list of offences proscribed in the companies legislation. It is not quite an analogous situation, as perhaps the Government would like to say. It is undesirable that there be in any legislation provisions whereby a person should be a susceptible to being charged with an offence-it may be a very technical offence under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act-and then, as a result of that, be eligible for a penalty which could involve losing a job or being ineligible to hold a job. That is the reason the amendment is moved.

speech.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: â€”I addressed this question in my response during the second reading debate and I will not delay the Committee at any length. I referred to the fact that under the companies legislation a disqualification applies in the case of indictment for any offence in connection with the promotion, formation of management of a corporation. So quite a broad category of offences under company law could give rise to exactly the same situation of double jeopardy. As I said before, whether a situation arises under the Constitution, under the Companies Act or under this legislation, it is inherent that there is an offence which is punishable and which carries the further penalty of disqualification.

speech.para: I refer the Committee briefly to the list of actions covered by the sections referred to in proposed new section 132F (1) (b), which is sought to be deleted. The offences listed there are offences in relation to section 45, strike ballots ; the contravention of or failure to comply with a Federal Court order with respect to disqualification from office; a failure to comply with a direction or order of the Federal Court relating to the performance or observance of rules; a contravention of or failure to comply with a direction of the Federal Court made in deregistration proceedings concerning performance or observance of rules; the non-compliance with or obstruction of an order of the Federal Court in relation to certain alternatives to deregistration or the order of the Governor-General in relation to deregistration on community safety, health or welfare grounds, and so on. I will not go through the whole list because I very much doubt whether it will change the views of members of the Committee. I will seek leave to incorporate this list in Hansard because it demonstrates the nature of the offences which the Government is seeking to make relevant to this question of disqualification. In my view and in the Government's view they are matters which demonstrate unfitness for office. As I said, the argument of double jeopardy is one which is really inherent in having a system of disqualification when people have committed offences whether it is under this legislation or other legislation. I seek leave to incorporate that list in Hansard.
Leave granted.
