talk.start.para: â€”I should like to add one point. I am advised that the list was agreed to by both employers and unions at the National Labour Consultative Council. The content of what ought to give rise to disqualification was apparently not a matter of controversy at that level.

â€”With respect to the advice that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) has just given us, I wonder why vice-presidents of the Australian Council of Trade Unions have complained to me about this long after the National Labour Consultative Council met. That may be something peculiar about--
â€”The left hand and right hand.
â€”No. I am making a serious comment. If that agreement were reached it does not seem to be widely known.

â€”So that there is no misunderstanding I indicate that I am passing on the advice of officers, one of whom was present at that meeting. Those present at that meeting went through the list. Some offences were taken out and some were put in. I understand that at the end of that meeting the matter was not one of controversy .

â€”I would like to make the point that some of these offences are in a sense extremely general. I would like to know what the sentence, 'Offences in relation to amalgamation ballot' means. In the list incorporated in Hansard by the Minister for Social Security ( Senator Chaney) reference is made to offences in relation to secret ballots ordered under section 45 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and a penalty of $20. What does that offence mean with respect to a person's capacity to be disqualified from holding office? It is an extraordinary situation if a person is disqualified from holding office on the basis that that person is charged and convicted of an offence for which the penalty is $20. There are a number of offences of that kind. I seek some explanation in relation to them.

speech.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: â€”I am quite happy to go through the sections of the list in detail. I should like to refer to the first section which is mentioned in the clause which it is proposed should be deleted. Section 46 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act states:

speech.para: (3) A person shall not, in connexion with a ballot ordered under section 45-
(a) obstruct the taking of the ballot;
(b) use any form of intimidation to prevent from voting, or to influence the vote of, a person entitled to vote at the ballot;
(c) threaten, offer or suggest, or use, cause, inflict or procure, any violence , injury, punishment, damage, loss or disadvantage for or on account of, or to induce-
(i) a vote or omission to vote;
(ii) any support of, or opposition to, voting in a particular manner; or
(iii) any promise of a vote or omission to vote, or of any such support or opposition; or
(d) counsel or advise a person entitled to vote to refrain from voting.
(4) A person shall not, without lawful authority or excuse . . .
(a) personate another person to secure a ballot paper . . .
So it goes on. It states further:
(b) destroy, deface, alter, take or otherwise interfere with a ballot paper . . .

The first named offences relate to interference with the conduct of ballots. I would have thought that offences of that nature were very relevant to the fitness for office that we are dealing with under this legislation. Of course, it is always true that there can be relatively minor transgressions which might give rise to a technical breach of the law. But I point out that under those circumstances the Bill provides that a person may go to the Federal Court of Australia and seek a waiver or a reduction of the period of disqualification. In other words there is a way out with respect to a technical offence.

I concede that under the sorts of offences that I have just mentioned there may be something of a relatively minor nature. But the general line of these offences is that they are offences which go to the integrity of the trade union operation. They are not unimportant matters; they are matters that go to the honesty, the fairness and proper conduct of elections. If people are convicted of offences under sections such as these then I would have thought that there would be pretty broad agreement in this chamber that they would not be the sort of people that one would want running the trade union movement.

There are a good number of sections set out on this list which has been incorporated in Hansard. If it is the wish of the Committee we can either go through each section in turn or we can simply examine in detail all the offences which can give rise to disqualification. I understand that that detailed examination was undertaken by the National Labour Consultative Council. The list was varied in accordance with discussions at that time. The purpose of the list which I have incorporated in Hansard and have handed to the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) is simply to provide a ready shorthand reference to the range of offences which are dealt with under this legislation.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) has taken the first provision on the list which he has incorporated in Hansard. One of the offences is counselling a person not to vote in a ballot. In the last few years that I have been in this Senate I have seen that done day after day. I have seen it done at Federal and State elections. People say: 'Why bother to vote'?
â€”Violence? Intimidation?

â€”That is not the point. That is one element of the offence. One can be charged and convicted for counselling a person not to vote in a ballot. That is an element of the offence. As a result one then becomes eligible for the treatment under this Bill, the Conciliation and Arbitration (Management of Organizations) Amendment Bill, if it is passed. This means in blunt terms that one loses one's job. If that is so the Minister's solution to that is that there are always provisions where one can go along to the court and say: 'This was not a very serious offence. Therefore my period of exile from the industrial relations arena should be limited'. That is not good enough. That is why I have moved the amendment. It is just not good enough to put that sort of provision in legislation of this kind. The Government is not being fair to trade union officials as against other citizens in the community. The Government is treating trade union officials quite differently.

â€”Nothing could better illustrate the ransom to which the Opposition is held by the trade union movement than the objection which has just been made. Nothing could be more fundamental or more relevant to the decent running of unions than the maintenance of a situation where the fundamental Act under which the trade unions operate has to be honoured by trade union officials. Surely breaches of this Act are most relevant to the question of whether someone is fit for office. I can understand the argument being raised in this Committee that offences which have nothing to do with the running of trade unions ought not to be relevant to a person's fitness to hold trade union office. But when the Opposition's premier objection to this legislation is that it is breaches of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act that give rise to disqualification then it seems to me that we have a very strange situation. I think most impartial observers would believe that the most relevant sections with which we ought to be concerned at having trade union leaders comply are those relating to industrial law in this country.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: â€”I regret that due to circumstances I have not entered this debate thus far. We are dealing with the Conciliation and Arbitration (Management of Organizations) Amendment Bill 1982 as a whole in the Committee stage. I must say that the provisions of the Bill will have limited effect on the industrial relations situation within Australia. When I saw that we were going to deal with conciliation and arbitration legislation I thought that we were probably going to deal with the Conciliation and Arbitration ( Complementary Industrial Relations System) Amendment Bill which will have an effect on the proper conduct of industrial relations within Australia. However, that is not to be, as I understand it. This measure has taken precedence over the other measure in the mind of the Government. The Government needs to be judged on its priorities in this regard. The other measure, which I cannot mention because we are in the Committee stages of debate, had the approval of the States and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), who represents the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, stated that the clause under consideration has the approval of the ACTU.

speech.para: The Minister who represented in the Senate the then Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Viner, said in a second reading speech that a provision in the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill at that time relating to industrial unionism had broad-range support. He said that industrial unionism was ACTU policy. I put down a copy of the ACTU's policy on that matter. It was contradictory to what the Minister said in his second reading speech, which was presumably written by somebody else for him. But if the advice that was given to the Minister on this occasion is the same as the advice that was given to the Minister on the previous occasion, it is incorrect. On this occasion the Minister has said that the ACTU has agreed with this provision. I do not know whether we should report progress to see whether in fact that is the case.

Let us look at the provisions of the regulations on this matter. There are prescribed offences under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and also offences under the regulations. Last night we talked about the principle of double jeopardy. That principle applies also in this case. I am just flipping through the conciliation and arbitration regulations. If the Minister has time, I would like to go through some of the regulations with him now-regulations 140, 146, 146AQ, 146AS, and 170. I ask him, and other senators, to see whether the offences under those provisions would warrant the rather dramatic double jeopardy that is imposed on people who have committed prescribed offences. Regulation 170 states:

Subject to sub-regulation (3) of this regulation, a person voting at any ballot ordered by the Commission under section 45 of the Act shall not show the ballot- paper to any person, or permit any person to see the ballot-paper, while he is marking it or after he has marked it, and a person shall not, directly or indirectly, request, require or induce any other person to show such a ballot- paper to him, or to permit him to see it, while the ballot-paper is being marked or after it has been marked.

One could argue about that. One could say that a person who showed his ballot paper to somebody could be the subject of a prescribed offence under this provision. In the trade union movement, I have regularly been concerned to advise on and rail against the idea of people showing other people their ballot papers. I have also been against those who have requested that ballot papers be shown to them. But the point made in regulation 170 is that a $20 penalty is imposed if somebody happens to show another person their ballot paper. However under this provision such a person cannot be an officer for five years just because he happened to show his ballot paper to somebody.

In respect of counselling persons not to vote, not necessarily in an election for a national official, but in a section election for a particular union, there could be a situation where two people are running for a position and both are equally not acceptable to an official or, indeed, to a member. Another member could come along and ask that member: 'Who will we vote for?'. The member could say: 'I would not vote for any of them in a fit'.

talk.start.para: â€”No.
â€”The Minister is shaking his head.
â€”No, I am sure that is rubbish, Senator. Are you suggesting that somebody would then be convicted under that clause?
â€”I am following on from what Senator Button said.
â€”I am sure it's rubbish.

â€”I have not had an opportunity to look at the regulations. If the Minister likes I could read them to him and find out whether we can come to that regulation. But I am sure his advisers could advise him as to whether, upon reflection, the ACTU as distinct from, perhaps, one of its officials, has agreed to this or whether it has not. The point has been made quite validly by Senator Button that there is a double jeopardy involved here. The point that is being made by me is that I have consistently, by actions within the trade union movement, opposed the breaking of the law and the regulations. I have consistently advised and counselled anyone with whom I have been associated to observe meticulously the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and its regulations. My record stands on that.

speech.para: However, this legislation will have very little effect at all on the industrial relations scene in Australia. It is very surprising that the Government prefers to put this legislation through. I do not object to the legislation, but the Government prefers to put it through rather than put through the Conciliation and Arbitration (Complementary Industrial Relations System) Amendment Bill which would have far more effect on the system of conciliation within Australia than this legislation.

speech.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: â€”I was not surprised to hear Senator Harradine say that he has been meticulous in advocating that people should obey the industrial law. I neither am suprised nor have any doubt that that would be the case. That is precisely why I find the attitude which he is supporting here rather puzzling. It is one thing to point to the variable seriousness of the offences which are listed in the clause and it is quite another thing to say that the offences which can be committed under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act should be those offences which are excluded from the legislation which provides for the disqualification of union officials who behave in an illegal manner.

speech.para: As I said earlier in the Committee, it seems to me that the most pertinent area of activity for assessing the fitness for office is the area of industrial relations itself. If an official has breached the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and/or the regulations it seems to me that that is the misfeasance which most appropriately calls into question the fitness for office. Senator Harradine pointed out that some offences of a relatively minor nature are listed in the clause. That is true. As I said before, that is met by the fact that the disqualification is not absolute. It is a disqualification which can be removed or reduced by an application to the court. The important point is that this legislation is central to the operation of industrial relations, the breach of which, I think, ought give rise to doubts about fitness for office. It is all very well to point to the lesser offences which are listed. As I indicated earlier in the Committee, the effect of this amendment would be that a trade union official who might have breached section 40, which covers serious matters such as threats, intimidation and the infliction of violence in connection with the conduct of ballots, in my view, clearly ought to be within the purview of this legislation. So I regret that there should be a sense in the chamber that in this most relevant area we should exclude the offences from consideration.

I do not think I mentioned directly the Australian Council of Trade Unions in my earlier comments. I mentioned the National Labour Consultative Council on which the ACTU is a key representative. This legislation was considered by the Council. I am advised that the ACTU opposed such legislation and it so said at the NLCC. However, there was detailed discussion by that body about the proposed legislation; in other words, a form of legislation was put before the NLCC for consideration. There was detailed discussion about what it should contain as to offences against the Acts and regulations which ought be caught. Representatives of the ACTU agreed that the sections and regulations which are listed in 132F (1 ) (b) would need to be in the Bill if the Government were to have a Bill of this sort. I want that to be made quite clear. There is a distinction. There was a discussion on the detail of the Bill and there was a variation to the list which was in the proposed legislation.

The point of this legislation is to ensure that, as in other areas of activity, people should not hold office when, by breaches of the law, they have indicated an unfitness for office. In the Bill as it stands at the moment the Government has sought to delineate those areas which it believes are of concern with respect to the operation of trade unions. There are questions of fraud or dishonesty which are punishable on conviction by imprisonment for a period of not less than three months. There are offences in connection with the formation, registration or management of an association or organisation and other offences involving the intentional or reckless use of violence. I think to fail to include in that list offences which go directly to the conduct of industrial affairs and to the affairs of a union is to leave a very strange omission indeed . I commend to the Committee the maintenance of offences against the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and regulations as a central area for potential disqualification.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: â€”I concede that offences relating to the integrity of the conciliation and arbitration system-in other words, offences relating to the integrity of organisations that go to make up that system-are appropriate for consideration for inclusion in the description of a 'prescribed offence' provided that there is some sort of cut-off point. My simple point is that paragraph (a) refers to convictions by imprisonment for a period of not less than three months. That is the criterion in respect of that paragraph. But there is no such criterion in respect of the other offences mentioned in paragraph (b). I make the simple point that some of those offences have penalties of a mere $20. However, in respect of paragraph (a) any offence that has a period of imprisonment of a lesser period than three months is not regarded as a prescribed offence. I just point that out. I realise, of course, that the Federal Court of Australia itself can determine on application by the offender whether or not the offence would prevent the offender from standing for election. I also say that the legislation tends to give a little bit too much power to a Federal Court judge.

speech.para: I rather feel that we should have examined the legislation more thoroughly. We should have spent a little more time examining it. I know that I am being most unpopular by speaking two or three times on this matter because we all want to get away. I raise this matter with the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) in the hope that if there are any injustices in the operation of this Bill the matter can be brought back before the Parliament and dealt wih in a proper way.
Amendment negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

proctext.para: Bill (on motion by Senator Chaney) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 14 December, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen G.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The Opposition is supporting the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982 and the Customs Securities (Anti- Dumping) Amendment Bill 1982, although in the case of the first Bill we will in fact be moving a second reading amendment to reflect our continuing dissatisfaction with the character of anti-dumping law administration in this country. The need for this protestation on our part could have been avoided, of course, if the Government had devoted sufficient resources to enable expedient, quick and effective dumping investigations to be made. But, as a result of its small government philosophy, only now very belatedly beginning to be re- evaluated by this Government, the situation has been in the past that Australian manufacturers have had to wait for over nine months for a dumping decision, in fact, finally to be made. It is that aspect of it, as I say, to which our amendment to the motion that the Bill be read a second time is addressed. I move :

speech.para: At end of motion, add:
', but the Senate is of the opinion that further amendments to the Principal Act and related legislation are required to-
(a) ensure that a prima facie decision concerning dumping is reached within 12 weeks and that the total investigation period is reduced to a maximum of 24 weeks;
(b) shift the practical burden of producing evidence from Australian industry once a prima facie case of dumping has been established; and
(c) enable penalties to be imposed on any additional imports negotiated during the investigation period'.

As will be clear from the text of that amendment paragraph (b) is changed from the form in which it was circulated insofar as we talk about being required to ' shift the practical burden of producing evidence from Australian industry' rather than 'shift the burden of proof'. I will explain that when I come to it later on.

Australia is particularly sensitive to imports being dumped here because of our relatively heavy reliance on tariff barriers as opposed to non-tariff barriers and because of our small domestic market. A shipload of dumped shoes will obviously have a greater impact in Australia on price competitiveness of domestic goods than would be the case in, say, the United States of America. Moreover, unlike many of our trading partners we do not rely on non-tariff barriers to protect our industries. A country, of course, with a sophisticated import licensing system needs virtually no anti-dumping legislation at all. It is, therefore, essential, particularly in these times of massive world over- capacity, that the Government ensures that Australia has an effective anti- dumping system which will provide quick and efficient investigation. It is only under those circumstances that Australian industry can be protected from unfair overseas competition.

The amendments contained in these two Bills go at least part of the way to ensuring and effective set of anti-dumping procedures for this country by removing some obstacles or perceived obstacles to the efficient operation of that system which have been shown up in recent litigation. Just how much litigation there has, in fact been-such as to justify these particular provisions-seems to be a matter of some uncertainty. I am aware of only three actual cases in which the exisiting law has, in fact, been taken advantage of by importers to delay what would otherwise be the effective operation of the anti- dumping measures. But it appears that certain loopholes have shown up. The first of them relates to section 14 of the parent Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act which is sought to be effectively removed by this amending Bill. The Bill removes an obligation on the Minister not to take action which is inconsistent with the obligations of Australia under international agreements relating to trade. At first sight that seems a fairly alarming provision to be removing from legislation, particularly given the way in which ministerial willingness to observe the constraints of international trade agreements has been the subject of so much active debate in the context of Mr Sinclair's performance over Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd and the breach of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade that was there involved.

There is some evidence that this provision, which is really doing no more than expressing in rhetorical form what is implicit throughout the entire Act, is being used as a vehicle for bringing unmeritorious actions to challenge the validity of decisions made at a departmental or ministerial level against importers of goods. This provision has, it appears, been the source of at least one interim injunction which has been granted by the court in circumstances where the merits of the argument have not been terribly obvious but the implications of the injunction being granted have been quite considerable in terms of their effect in delaying the start of the whole anti-dumping investigation process. The circumstance is that a legal appeal in this area can give appellants a period of reprieve in which they can continue to import without the prospect of ultimate financial penalty. It is in that context that this provision is sought to be removed.

Similarly, the Customs Securities (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill-the second element in this package-amends section 42 of the Customs Act so as to remove a doubt which has existed in the past as to whether cash securities can, in fact, be imposed for the purpose of the anti-dumping Act-cash securities being the preliminary way of ensuring that some brake is put on the activities of importers pending the final determination of the validity of the dumping claim. This is another area in which there is some evidence-again, I am not sure just how much in practice-that the availability of a form of judicial review, of an appeal, has been misused and has been the subject of cynical exploitation by importers who have had no great merit on their side but have sought to take technical points about section 42 of the Customs Act not technically authorising the application of these requirements of cash securities.

So it is in that context that recently the regulations were amended, removing the application of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act from decisions to take cash or other securities, the preliminary part of the anti- dumping machinery. What was accomplished in a temporary or preliminary fashion by regulation is now to be accomplished, in terms of formal legislation, by clause 6 of the Customs Securities (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill, which will supersede those regulations.

It is now clear that, as a result of that legislative provision, there will no longer be any opportunity for importers or foreign exporters to frustrate that part of the anti-dumping machinery. Aggrieved parties of course will retain their right to appeal against the final determination that is made under the anti-dumping machinery, but their capacity to seek judicial action is a vehicle for delaying the operation of that system at an earlier stage will be removed. There will still be a check against capricious administrative action, at least in extreme cases, by the vehicle of judicial review of the final determination.

I enter one caveat about all of this: That is as to the way in which these measures, in particular the regulatory change and now this legislation, have been brought forward without reference back to the Administrative Review Council , which is the independent statutory body charged by this Government with the task of advising it as to what sorts of administrative decisions ought to be the subject of judicial review and which ought not to be. These provisions were originally the subject of judicial review because of advice received from the Administrative Review Council that this was an appropriate area for the operation of judicial review.

Everyone has always appreciated that experience may well have shown that some of these provisions were unreal and that the commercial environment might have been such that it would be necessary in future to make some amendments in the area of the decisions available for judicial review. But it was contemplated that any such amendments would take place only in consultation with the Administrative Review Council. Certainly that was the view of the Council as expressed in its third annual report in 1979, in which it recommended that no exclusion from the categories of judicial review should be made without a further recommendation from the Council. It may be that the Government felt obliged to move quickly for commercial reasons in this particular circumstance but it is an unfortunate state of affairs that there appears to have been no consultation whatsoever with those who are extremely expert in this area and on whose advice the Government has hitherto relied.

Let me conclude by indicating briefly what our second reading amendment is all about. I have already moved it formally and have indicated a change of language insofar as paragraph (b) is concerned from the form in which the amendment was circulated here and that in which it was moved in the House of Representatives. Paragraph (b) is directed to the question of who is to bear the burden of establishing what? We believe that the system could be improved if legislation were to provide explicitly that the practical burden of producing evidence as to the case or otherwise for a prohibition order in this area should be on not the Australian domestic industry but rather the importers who are deriving the advantage of the dumping. I appreciate that the point was made in the House of Representatives that we are not talking here about onus or burden of proof in any strictly technical legal sense. But I understand that in a practical sense the process has operated as follows: All the action has had to be taken at the level of the domestic Australian producers with the Department which makes this decision doing some investigative work of its own but really relying on the domestic producer to produce the major material on which its decision will ultimately be made. We say that the whole process would work better and more relevantly to the present economic environment in which Australia finds itself were the burden to be shifted the other way around.

Paragraph (c) of the amendment seeks to impose penalties on any additional imports which are negotiated during the investigation period. The justification for that was well explained by Mr John Brown, speaking on behalf of Mr Hurford in the other place, and there is no need for me to spell that out.

Paragraph (a) is quite important because we are seeking here further legislative change to ensure 'that a prima facie decision concerning dumping is reached within 12 weeks and that the total investigation period is reduced to a maximum of 24 weeks'. At the moment it is conceded by the Government that the time taken for an anti-dumping investigation is of the order of nine months. We feel that that ought to be drastically reduced, particularly in the present very strained economic environment and with many Australian producers going to the wall and with extreme and justified neurosis about unfair international competition. It was said in the House of Representatives that the Government had recently made some resources available to the anti-dumping investigators with something like an 80 per cent staff increase and that it was now anticipated that the investigation and decision time could be reduced to something like 120 days as compared with the present average of nine months. That may be so and we welcome those steps being taken but what we are asking for here in this second reading amendment is not just a statement of aspiration on the part of the Government but rather a legislative requirement that these things be done within a particular timetable.

This is important legislation. It justifies, even in our present circumstances of time constraints, a little attention to its detail. Our feeling is that the Government has never been able to appreciate that in the sorts of economic circumstances in which we find ourselves we do need an efficient and responsive public administration system. We feel and fear that so many areas of public administration have been allowed to run down and become ineffective and that in order for them to be beefed up again we need something more than simply the band -aid patching-up that is involved in these two Bills. Rather we need some fundamental rethinking about the way in which the whole administrative system is to operate. The amendment is a statement in broad terms of at least some of the changes that we believe to be necessary if that administration is to work better in the future.

speech.speaker: Watson Sen J.O.W.

talk.start.para: â€”Dumping of products from overseas on to the Australian domestic market can take three forms-price dumping, freight dumping and subsidisation. Price dumping occurs when the imported price on the Australian domestic market is lower than the overseas domestic price. Freight dumping arises when the transport or freight cost is less than normal. Subsidisation exists when a country gives a financial subsidy to the manufacture of goods which are exported to a foreign country. In Australia there is the additional requirement of proof of material injury or threat of material injury. An improvement would be to transfer the onus of proof to the importer rather than allowing a continuation of the current practice whereby the Department of Industry and Commerce has to have proved to its satisfaction that there is material injury or damage to local industry. In the past, Australian manufacturers in particular have had a great deal of difficulty in proving material damage. In all too many cases we have seen the proof come only at the stage when the company that is subject to dumping difficulties has been in the hands of the liquidator or the official receiver in bankruptcy.

speech.para: Australia is a signatory to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, GATT. Article 6 of this agreement covers anti-dumping and countervailing duties provisions. The codes are international agreements between sovereign states and are not intended to provide personal or individual benefits. They are between one state and another. To date, all the anti-dumping litigation has been in the area of procedures and not on the substantial issues of dumping. In addition to the damage caused to Australian industry by overseas exporters dumping their products in Australia, some use all sorts of devious means to get their goods on to the Australian market. Let me give a few of those examples in addition to dumping. Firstly, goods are invoiced at the correct price but a credit is established in a Hong Kong, Swiss, Japanese or some other bank. Secondly, goods are invoiced correctly but the overseas supplier gives a cost free holiday to the importer.

Thirdly, importers use what is known as the printing by-law, which allows their goods duty free access into Australia. Two problems can arise with that. The by- law specifically excludes printing with markings of any kind that are for identification or distinguishing purposes only. However, certain institutions-I regret to say a number of State hospitals, including those in New South Wales- have allowed their previous narrow identification stripes or other markings to become wide and deep coloured, thus allowing the printer to comply with the words of the by-law if not the intent. Further, some firms have been printing diagonal narrow stripes or other markings on woven man-made fibre fabrics for use as pocketing. As this fabric is printed on only one side, these markings are invisible when it is cut and sewn into garments. A further example is washable dye. On entry into Australia the fabric is printed but it requires only a minor wash for the dye to run out. These are just some of the techniques being used which are having a devastating effect on Australian industry.

When we look at percentage changes in relation to certain tariff or quota protected categories, we find that there have been some dramatic increases over the last year in one instance of up to 135 per cent. These imports are causing tremendous damage to Australian industry. To use a local example, part of the new seven-year agreement included a provision that fabrics weighing less than 120 grams per square metre could come in duty free. We warned the Government that the importers would reduce the weight of their fabrics so that they could come in duty free, that is, at less than 120 grams per square metre. Unfortunately this provision has had a devastating effect on the protection of a local company in Devonport, Tootal Australia Ltd.

A further problem with the Australian economy at present is caused by not only imports but also a lack of demand. The Government has responded in part by developing a package of measures designed to boost activity and employment in the manufacturing sector. That package comprises the wages pause, the restoration of the 20 per cent government preference for local industry in purchasing for its own Government requirements and also an 80 per cent increase in the number of officers in the Department of Industry and Commerce to monitor dumping. This increase in staff is necessary because there has been a substantial increase in dumping complaints in recent months. The processing of dumping complaints are designed to be completed within 120 days compared with 250 days in the United States. In the past in Australia it took a substantially longer period. The Government is seeking to re-examine the general policy on developing country preference. This will be a significant help to local manufacturers. There will be a streamlining and improvement of references to the Temporary Assistance Authority. The overseas aid program is also being designed to provide increased benefits to Australian business. There is a 'buy Australian ' campaign for which $1m is being set aside for advertising in 1982-83.

Manufacturing industries in Australia, including the textile industry, are experiencing recession conditions. I regret to say that in my own State of Tasmania today 96 employees at the Repco company were put off. The reason given was a lack of demand. This is one of the tragedies that the Australian community may have to face in the next 12 months to two years. I regret to say that the textile industry in some sectors is experiencing its worst time since 1930. It is rather ironic that other sophisticated countries protect their industries more stringently than we do. I am pleased to say that through such measures that I have mentioned our Government is increasingly looking to assist in maintaining employment in the manufacturing industry because manufacturing is at a low ebb at present. The Government may have to review the mechanism of what is commonly known as broadbanding in the textile industry to overcome a number of problems in this area. I refer to jean imports. There has been a 117 per cent increase in the importation of jeans under category 107. The problem is the emphasis on the import of jeans at the expense of trousers, et cetera, which are within the quota category.

It is necessary to review the matter of dumping and increase the onus of proof on the part of the importer. Action in relation to dumping is effectively being taken out of the hands of the Government and placed in the hands of the judiciary. This is one of the reasons why it is necessary to repeal section 14 of the Customs Securities (Anti-Dumping) Act to ensure that cash securities may be taken in anti-dumping cases. In these situations it is necessary for the importer to put up cash to an agreed value as an interim measure. If a dumping case is not proved the money is refunded.

The second amendment relates to section 42 of the Customs Act to provide that provisional anti-dumping and countervailing measures are not reviewable under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. It is important to emphasise that the Act and the amendments follow the General Agreement on Tarriffs and Trade code. Essentially we maintain that section 14 of the Act is superfluous and circumlocutive at present. Section 14 requires the Minister, before issuing a certificate against dumping, to issue a notice in the Government Gazette. This states that the Minister has followed all the international agreements -in this case, GATT. The Act itself conforms with GATT requirements. We maintain that it is superfluous.

The measures that the Government is taking by these amendments today are essentially short term and interim ones that do not affect the final outcome. In other words, they are short term interim measures but appeals remain on the results of the final decision. We must also point out that these interim measures are not issued without prior investigation by the Department of Industry and Commerce and discovery by that Department that a prima facie case of dumping exists; and secondly, that there is proof of injury to the Australian manufacturer. As I mentioned earlier, one of the dilemmas is the difficulty in satisfying the departments. I repeat: Section 14 is redundant. I am not aware of any precedent in an Act which requires a Minister to state that he is following certain rules, certainly of an international obligation. For example, even in Australia the Attorney-General does not have to prove that he is working within the light or powers of the Australian Constitution before he brings forth a new regulation, Act as such or an amendment to an Act.

There have been criticisms of these proposed changes principally from importers . These have come principally from three centres-America, China and New Zealand. It is rather hypocritical of New Zealand, in particular, to criticise, because imports into that country are subject to import licence arrangements and under the closer economic relations agreement they do not phase out until 1995. Secondly, New Zealand, unlike Australia, does not have any system of administrative appeals. By this Bill before the Senate we are endeavouring to stop these importers employing delaying devices. In other words, they get an injunction to delay and to frustrate the intention of the employment of fast- track anti-dumping provisions and the taking of securities. Without those devices, it is all very much a farce, because overseas importers can have a once -off dumping situation into Australia and get away with it, and we might never hear of them again for 12 months, two years or even five years.

I also emphasise that this Bill is not, in a sense, a protective device. All GATT signatories are adamant that the products of overseas industry, subsidised or marginally costed, must not be dumped with the effect of damaging the local domestic manufacture. Some people have argued strongly that there is need for rights or compensation to importers, but I suppose that there would be one importer, as compared with 100 domestic manufacturers, who might be injured in some way; so the relativities are very unbalanced. Our first responsibility is surely to look after the domestic manufacturer who employs local citizens, whose jobs are very much at risk at present. Therefore, in the light of our employment situation, this legislation is very significant and very important. I wish it a speedy passage. The legislation makes it necessary that the codes are agreed on a country to country basis, rather than on an individual to country basis. I therefore welcome its submission and wish it a speedy passage.

As the Opposition amendment does not call for action but merely expresses an opinion, and although I agree with its sentiment I cannot see any great benefit being derived from my crossing the floor on this issue. I believe it is significant and relevant but even though it has my tacit approval it is not sufficient for me to cross the floor.

speech.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: â€”These Bills represent the Government's single most important response to the massive dumping of foreign goods on the Australian market. It is a totally inadequate response. Indeed, one might say that it is a shamefully inadequate response. If this is the best my friend Andrew Peacock can do in this area I am afraid that it is just not good enough. Much more could have been done and must be done. In fact, I am not convinced that this Bill is even terribly fair. A firm of lobbyists has written, I think to most members of parliament, about some hair-raising examples of bungling by the Australian Customs Service in this field. It would seem that the heavy handed and arbitrary approach of Customs to quite damaging cases at many times has had the effect of losing jobs for Australians at least in the short term.

speech.para: I have outlined the view of the Australian Democrats on protection many times in this place and in many other forums. The Democrats are not a high protection party. I want to make that very clear. However, we believe that industries which are regarded as strategic and socially necessary for this country ought to be protected when protection is necessary. We are in the middle of a monumental economic crisis, a crisis which, I am sorry to say, has not yet penetrated the ivory towers of Canberra. It is a crisis of monumental proportions. It is absolutely vital that our industries get some protection and get it fast or we will be faced with the prospect of having no secondary industry at all in this country.

Of course, allegations of dumping are made by many firms across the land almost routinely. I admit that it is a difficult task for departments to weed out those claims which are justified and those which are not. Perhaps it is a case of departments accepting a comment that has been made before-that life was not meant to be easy. I believe the Government is gradually coming to the realisation that in a large number of cases claims of dumping are justified. One example came to my attention only the other day. A South Korean firm is dumping certain kinds of steel products at a price which is must lower than the price for which raw steel can be bought in Australia. Similar products are made by John Lysaght (Aust.) Ltd in Victoria. That example shows that we are not being subjected to tough competition. That sort of approach is simply economic warfare .

It has never been an Australian characteristic to stand meekly by and take punishment for too long. I submit it is high time that far more Australian flags can be seen flying outside the company headquarters of our industries in this country. We should be much less concerned with the flags of South Korea, America and European countries. I will give one more example of the problem of dumping to which industries are subjected. This case concerns the Sidchrome tool company , a company about which I happen to have some first hand knowledge. After two years of solid effort it managed to convince the Department tha prima facie there was a case of dumping of Japanese tools on this market. The Department then set about proving the facts, and this is how it did it: An official got on an aeroplane and flew to Japan. He booked in at a hotel and rang up a public interpreter-somebody who was hired without any reference to his ability at all. The interpreter and the Australian official hopped on a train and went knocking on the doors of various Japanese tool manufacturers with the plea: 'I am an Australian offical and I would like to see your books'. This request was transmitted to the Japanese tool manufacturers through the public interpreter. Honourable senators can imagine how much information he got from the Japanese tool manufacturers in that way. This is an actual case. I believe the procedures have been improved since then, but that was the way Australia attempted to prove dumping.

This Bill is a very small step towards some rationality in this whole area. Undoubtedly importers have been abusing the provisions of the legislation right and left. We are aware that some injustices will be left as a result of this legislation, but we can see no alternative to their being borne for the time being at least. In the meantime I give notice that we expect much more from the Government in this crisis through which we are passing. I also indicate that the Democrats will be supporting the Australian Labor Party's second reading amendment. It has been read and I will not speak at length on it. It puts the burden of proof on the importing company and not on the Australian manufacturer. It puts a time limit on how long the Department can take to prove that dumping is or is not occurring. It would be a very welcome step forward in this area if the Government took notice of these requests made by the Opposition and which are wholeheartedly supported by the Democrats. We wish the Bill, with the amendment, a speedy passage.

speech.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: â€”I thank honourable senators for their support of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982 and cognate Bill. The common support no doubt reflects the concern which is felt around the chamber about current economic circumstances and the fact that with world trade in the state it is in obviously we are in an environment where dumping is far more likely to occur; and there is evidence of that in Australia in the number of applications which have been brought to the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs. This legislation represents part of the Government's response to that difficult real world with which industry has to cope. I do not wish to debate this matter at length because that would be unreasonable given the restraint which has been shown by other senators, but I would like to respond merely in a limited way to the points made by Senator Siddons in his general attack on the Government's attitude to Australian industry.

speech.para: Tariff protection is but one part of the Government's approach to industry. I merely wish to remind the Senate of the various actions which have been taken during 1982 to improve the situation of Australian manufacturers. I think that even Senator Siddons might have welcomed the change in the depreciation arrangements which introduced a simplified and, I think, more usable system of depreciation for industry.

talk.start.para: â€”A welcome reform.

â€”Yes. I think he would have welcomed the continuation of the investment allowance, the 2.5 per cent depreciation of new non-residential income producing buildings, the continuation of the Industrial Research and Development Scheme and the upgrading of the Export Market Development Scheme. This debate takes place not in a vacuum but, as I have said, in a world context of very difficult trading conditions and as part of a series of responses by government to the changed reality of 1982. Again, there were changes in the recent Budget to our taxation law with respect to retention allowances and the taxation treatment of company group profits. I think this will have been of assistance to manufacturing industry. There is the question of the employee share issue schemes which are to be made exempt from income tax.
â€”When is the legislation due on that, Senator?

â€”I think that will have to be left to next year. I think we have run our course for this year. Turning to protection, there has been concern with respect to the question of dumping. The Government has already responded to that concern. The legislation is again part of that response. It is clear from the statements made by the Australian Labor Party that it sees the failure to obtain a speedy enough consideration of dumping applications as being central to the need for this legislation. In that regard I would simply draw the Senate's attention to the fact that consistent effort has been made to reduce processing time. Prior to January 1982 processing time was upwards of nine months and sometimes even longer. It has decreased since May 1982 because of improved techniques introduced by the Department and because of increases in staff.

speech.para: We have been asked by industry to reduce the target time to 175 days, that is 25 weeks. We have now arrived at a point at which the delay is about seven months, with four weeks for a prima facie decision, and we have accepted a target of 17 weeks maximum for a final decision. In other words, the Government has in fact accepted a more limited time scale as being more appropriate than that suggested in the amendment. It has taken the necessary staffing and training measures to ensure that it meets its targets. There is no quarrel between the Government and the Opposition in terms of objective or the ideal of having speedy hearings. I am grateful to Senator Watson who indicated to the Senate some of the action which the Government has taken. I should acknowledge Senator Watson's continuous interest in this area. He has raised this matter with the Government on many occasions to my knowledge and, as his speech indicated, he has taken the closest possible interest in the very technical area with which we are concerned this afternoon.

We oppose the amendment which has been moved, in part because it suggests that the Government is not prepared to accept the sort of objective which is contained in the amendment-that is, to reduce the investigation period to 24 weeks-when in fact the government has accepted a target which is less than that. In regard to the second part of the amendment, it is inappropriate to the system under which we operate to talk in terms of 'practical burdens of producing evidence', to use the words that Senator Evans substituted for the burden of proof reference that was in the original amendment. The fact is that complaints are brought to the Department. Under the system we operate under it is then the Department's responsibility to arrive at a decision and to make inquiries and investigations. So it is not a matter of either party being given that onus of proof about which some honourable senators are concerned. In regard to the suggestion that penalties should be imposed, again, that is not an appropriate approach to anti-dumping procedures which do not involve the imposition of penalties but rather the restoration of fair trading conditions.

Although it has not been evident so much in the debate in this chamber, concern has been expressed in public debate on this measure about the possibility that anti-dumping procedures can be abused in quite the opposite direction. In other words, whilst the main focus of debate has been upon the possibility that manufacturers will not receive adequate protection against dumping, some concern has been expressed also that those who are competing with importers may unfairly use dumping procedures to their advantage and to the detriment of people who, by the time the matter is determined--

talk.start.para: â€”You must satisfy that there has been material damage; that is the second component.

â€”That is true. But I wanted to indicate during this debate that the Government has also given consideration to the matters which have been raised in that regard and to the comments which have been made that the Government should introduce a procedure designed to obviate the occurrence of possibly inadequately based complaints from Australian industry about dumped or subsidised goods. The Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act does not make express provision for complaints or requests that may give rise to remedial action under the Act. Action under the Act may be taken by the Minister on the basis that he is satisfied that certain facts exist. It has been argued that there should be some form of constraint against the misapplication of the Act and, in particular , a deterrent against the mischievous complaint which could have a deleterious effect on the importing community.

speech.para: The Government is concerned that the rules relating to dumping and subsidisation should be observed equally by all parties to a complaint in order that fair trading conditions can be restored as quickly as possible. The preferred solution to dumping and subsidy situations is not, of course, the imposition of anti-dumping or countervailing duties but the resolution of the price distortion by mutually agreeable solutions. With a view to minimising the occurrence of inadequately based complaints and further reduce the inquiry time, the Government will now require complaints about dumping or subsidisation to be supported by a statutory declaration made by the appropriate officer of a complainant. The Government believes that this requirement will act as a constraint for more properly considered complaints which are documented in evidence. Furthermore, complaints supported by a statutory declaration can be more readily relied upon in the knowledge that a sanction can be imposed in respect of a false declaration. There is broad unanimity in the Senate that this legislation is necessary and desirable in the difficult trading conditions of 1982. I commend the Bill to the Senate and thank honourable senators for their support of it.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Evans's amendment) be added.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

speech.para: Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without requests or debate.

That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill, the Special Employment-related Programs Bill 1982, seeks the authority of Parliament to enable the Government to fund certain useful programs throughout Australia.

In recognition of the difficult employment circumstances facing many Australians, the Bill is designed to provide worthwhile employment opportunities to a large number of our unemployed, to an extent consistent with the Government 's basic economic policies. As such, the Bill complements other employment- generating measures which the Government has introduced, including, of course, the wage pause.

Honourable senators will be aware that the proposal to establish these special employment related programs was raised with Premiers during the conference on December the 7th. At that conference, the Commonwealth Government indicated its preparedness to spend over the next twelve months the Commonwealth Budget savings resulting from a successful 1983 wage pause. The Bill thus demonstrates- in an immediate way-the important benefits which are available from an effective nation-wide wage pause for 1983.
The exact amount of the savings which will eventually be available from the outcome of the Premiers' Conference is not certain.

Estimates indicate that savings for the remainder of 1982-83 and for the first half of 1983-84 from a national 1983 wage pause could be of the order of $300m. That figure, which is reflected in the Bill, is a gross figure; no deduction has been made for the taxation receipts which otherwise would have accrued to the Commonwealth. The estimate is based on the expected balance of the bulk allowances for wage and salary increases provided for in the Commonwealth's 1982 -83 Budget; an allowance for notional wage increases forgone in the first half of 1983-84; and Commonwealth savings resulting from a 1983 wage pause in Australia's primary, secondary and tertiary education sectors.
Legislation has already been introduced to secure a wage pause for Commonwealth employees. Legislation will also be introduced to ensure savings from the education sectors are realised.

We cannot estimate with certainty at this stage the actual level of savings that will be available as a consequence of the wages pause. Consequently, the Bill preserves flexibility for the Government to spend an amount consistent with the savings actually achieved.

The Bill provides for expenditure by the Commonwealth itself throughout Australia. It also provides for grants and advances of grants to be made to the State and Northern Territory governments-and through appropriate mechanisms, to local government authorities-for the purpose of funding special programs. Such grants would be made either for approved programs or for programs of expenditure where agreement has been reached with the receiving government on matters such as the criteria against which programs would be judged. Where the States themselves take on additional staff for Commonwealth funded programs, we would expect them to use, to the maximum extent possible, the services of the Commonwealth Employment Service. In this manner some preference for employment could be given to long-term unemployed adults.

In determining the allocation of any funds to States, the Commonwealth will take into account factors such as population and the ability of State governments to identify and facilitate work on worthwhile programs.

Where it would be useful, funds could be provided to local government authorities. In such circumstances, further criteria-such as the existence of comparatively high unemployment-would be brought to bear.

The criteria for program funding which would apply to any grant to the States and local government authorities would be essentially the same as those which the Government would apply to funding Commonwealth programs under the Act.

Eligible programs would need to be of high priority, to have high Australian materials and labour content and to be capable of being carried through quickly. Additionally, programs should desirably make a worthwhile or lasting contribution to national wealth, for example, by improving productive capacity, adding to basic infrastructure or reducing future operating costs.

The Government has decided that $100m will be allocated for welfare housing. Other projects which would meet the eligibility criteria include: acceleration of capital works already under construction; repairs and maintenance to existing plant, machinery, roads and building; repairs and readily implemented upgrading of key elements of Australia's infrastructure; and minor works. Thus the Commonwealth will not be funding make-work schemes, or programs of only passing effect.

It is not intended that the Commonwealth would seek matching funds from the States, although reports indicate that a number of State governments will be applying their budget savings from the wage pause to similar employment- generating programs of a worthwhile kind. The Commonwealth will, however, seek to ensure that State governments would not use Commonwealth financing as a substitute for their own funding.

Commonwealth statutory bodies which are not dependent on the Budget will also derive worthwhile savings from a wage pause. The Government expects these bodies to apply such non-budget savings on programs of commercial merit, on reducing the need for wage-induced increases to charges or on improving their longer-run financial structure. It is evident that adoption of these courses by the Commonwealth's commercial bodies would provide at least short-term opportunities for employment generation. The Commonwealth Government has suggested to the States that their commercial statutory authorities-and local government authorities-could utilize the benefits of a wage pause in a similar manner, and elements from the above approach are being adopted by some State governments.

The Government has attempted to estimate the employment effects from the proposals advanced in this Bill. Such estimates are not readily available as programs have not yet been determined, and different programs would have different employment consequences. In any case, it is difficult to calculate a net increase in employment, as account would need to be taken of the alternative uses to which the savings could have been applied (such as reducing the 1982-83 deficit and thus reducing upward pressures on interest rates). A rough estimate, however, suggests that direct employment generation-on a gross basis-could be of the order of six to ten thousand persons. Naturally, second round effects would add significantly to that estimate.

Of course, while these proposals to spend the savings are framed so as to give useful results, the larger employment and economic benefits accrue from the wage pause itself. Acceptance of that wage pause by the community, the States and the Commonwealth Parliament is needed if those benefits, and the benefits inherent in this Bill, are to be obtained. The Government welcomes the community-wide support for a wage pause and acknowledges the support offered by the Premiers on 7 December. The Government now looks forward to the effective support of honourable senators to whom I now commend this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Grimes) adjourned.

proctext.para: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Chaney) read a first time.

speech.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follow-

The purpose of this Bill and its accompanying Bill, the Special Employment- related Programs Bill 1982, is to give effect on the Commonwealth's side to the agreement reached at the Premiers' Conference last week.

As the Acting Prime Minister reported to the House of Representatives on 8 December 1982, at the Premiers' Conference there was general support for the widest and most effective wage pause. The Premiers of Queensland, Western Australia and Tasmania and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory agreed with the Commonwealth Government that this pause, which would apply to both the public and private sectors, should be for 12 months. The Premiers of the other States will be seeking a 6 months pause.
The Commonwealth indicated its intention to legislate for a wage pause in areas of its own employment. The States will be asked to extend the wage pause to their own areas of employment.
The immediate effect of the legislation will be that savings to the Commonwealth Budget of the order of $300m should eventuate over the next 12 months.

The necessary legislative authority for the expenditure of these funds, on employment-related projects throughout Australia of the Commonwealth's nomination, taking full account of the views of the States and the Northern Territory, will be dealt with in the accompanying Bill.

There is no doubt that the international recession has impacted on our economy with a surprising suddenness. As the Acting Prime Minister said our domestic economic performance is being affected by a reduced demand for our exports, rock bottom commodity prices which have reduced the profitability of our resources sector and contracted plans for new resources investment while increased import competition is being experienced as overseas supplier react to the variation in market opportunities facing them.
I have no need to remind Australians that all this is happening during the worst drought in our memory.
These are serious problems. They require positive action by all who are interested in directing Australia back into a sound ecomomic position.
Developments in domestic wage outcomes have been far from helpful.

Average weekly ordinary time earnings rose by about 17 per cent over the year to the September 1982 quarter. This increase is far in excess of the increase in CPI, 12.3%, over the same period, and labour productivity which was virutally unchanged. In addition, reductions in standard weekly hours are not reflected in the earnings figure.

Australian businesses have not been able to compensate for these drastic increases in wage costs, due to weak domestic demand and the world economic recession. As a result profits have fallen by about 13% over the last year and retrenchments have multiplied. Those in employment have increased their real incomes, while their less fortunate fellows have lost their jobs.

For some time this Government has been arguing before arbitral tribunals for the greatest wage restraint possible. The Prime Minister wrote to the Remuneration Tribunal and the Treasurer appeared before the Tribunal in July last. The Government briefed counsel before the Academic Salaries Tribunal about the same time. In both tribunals our submissions asked that the worsening economic situation be taken into consideration and that the tribunals give a lead in wage restraint.

Then, in an unprecedented move, the Government, in view of its responsibility as manager of the economy, argued in the clerical/administrative case before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission that current economic circumstances required there should be no increase granted at all to some 112,000 public servants.

In August the Commission, having taken into consideration the Government's assessment of the economy, awarded percentage rises substantially less for higher paid employees than those originally offered.

Since then the economic situation has worsened and the level of unemployment has risen quite dramatically. It was in these circumstances that the Government decided to call together the Premiers and the Chief Minister on 7 December. Prior to the meeting discussions were sought with the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Australian Council of Trade Unions.
In this Bill the Government is legislating for a 12 months pause in wages and salaries and in reductions in standard working hours in its own employment.

The Bill will suspend for 12 months the powers of certain tribunals, authorities, bodies or persons which could make awards or determinations that vary remuneration funded from Commonwealth sources. The definition included in the Bill will ensure that the Remuneration Tribunal, the Academic Salaries Tribunal, the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the Public Service Board, and a whole range of other remuneration-fixing authorities will not be able to exercise these powers in respect to Commonwealth employees through the prescribed period. The Bill suspends the power of these remuneration -fixing authorities to make or vary any award, determination, decision, order, regulation or contract or to make, vary or certify an industrial agreement, so as to increase the rates, or minimum rates, of any remuneration, or establish a new benefit in the nature of salary or wages payable in respect of Commonwealth employment. There is a similar suspension of powers in respect to reduction of the standard working hours in Commonwealth employment.
The Remuneration Tribunal and the Academic Salaries Tribunal will no longer be empowered, through the prescribed period, to hold or continue any inquiries or to make any determinations or reports.
These tribunals will not be able to make reports on related matters which could include electorate allowances, travelling allowances and other such payments.

Similarly the other remuneration-fixing authorities will be precluded from increasing rates of travelling allowances, expenses of office allowances, and other various allowances payable in respect of Commonwealth employment in Australia.

It will apply in the same way to the remuneration and working hours of Commonwealth employees in the external territories. It will apply to Australia- based staff but not to locally-engaged staff at overseas posts.

The definition of Commonwealth employee is quite wide ranging. It will include those persons either full-time or part-time, permanent or otherwise, in the administration of a Territory, an authority of the Commonwealth, or a prescribed company. The definition includes members of the Defence Force. Over 470,000 persons will be covered by the legislation. Following amendments in the House of Representatives it will also apply to public sector employees in the Northern Territory.

As I indicated earlier, consideration has been given to those, other than Commonwealth employees, whose remuneration was wholly or significantly contributed from the Federal Budget. The Bill provides for suspension of the powers of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal to hold or continue any inquiries or to make or issue any findings. In conformity with this it will deem that the Tribunal is not in contravention of sub-section 98BA (4) of the National Health Act 1953 by reason of the suspension of its powers.
The effect of this will be that remuneration paid to pharmacists for dispensing of certain prescriptions will not be varied during the period of this pause.

The remuneration of members of the medical profession is very significantly affected by the level of approved fees under the Health Insurance Act 1973. In these circumstances the Government in this Bill seeks to continue appropriate regulations during the period of the pause so that the level of fees approved for payment of benefits from registered health insurance funds will be maintained at current levels.

This action obviously cannot of itself stop medical fees from rising. The Commonwealth will be approaching the medical profession to seek the co-operation of all of its members in the application of a pause in medical charges for the next year.

We will also be approaching industry leaders and the professional associations to seek their co-operation in respect to their own incomes to bring about a similar pause in fees and charges during the wage pause. We will be seeking a national effort.
The Government has already announced that the thrust of its initiative is to prevent a new community round developing in wages and salaries.

However it is not the Government's intention to truncate the completion of the current 'community wage round' that was potentially provided for in the National Wage Decision of May 1982. By that decision a broad standard was set as a notional upper limit to increases in wages and salaries from December 1981.

That standard relates to the movement in the metal industry which was, for the tradesmen fitter, $25 a week in December 1981 and a further $14 per week in June 1982. Appropriate proportionate amounts have been allowed for other classifications.

Every offer that has been made to Commonwealth employees since May 1982 has been with the proviso that the rate being offered is tested against that National Wage Decision by the appropriate tribunal.

Most, but not all, Commonwealth employees have received wage movements this year that have brought them to the level indicated by the National Wage Decision . The Commonwealth has determined that no action should be taken which would involve inequitable treatment of employees who have not as yet participated in the current 'community round'.
There is then provision for some exemptions in this Bill.

Where a remuneration-fixing authority has entered into an agreement or taken a decision, on the matters covered by the Bill before the commencement of the pause it may give effect to that agreement or decision under this legislation.

In addition, regulations could be made by the Governor-General which would restore, to a specified remuneration-fixing authority, powers in relation to a specified matter which would be powers that, but for this legislation, would be exercisable by that authority.
These exemptions will not be made lightly. Each particular case will be the subject of examination by Ministers before regulations are put before the Governor-General.

There are a number of classes of employee to whom offers have been made but the required examination by appropriate arbitral tribunals has not been completed. In some cases the examination of claims is still progressing and offers when made could be referred to the tribunals for evaluation against the National Wage Decision.
The Government is prepared to use the exemption powers under the Bill to ensure that all its employees are treated equitably in respect to the current community wage round.

In the matter of reduction of standard working hours in Commonwealth employment I want to refer to the negotiations that have been substantially completed following the Memorandum of Understanding agreed between the ACTU, the Public Service Board and the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations in June 1982.

That Memorandum of Understanding set out the agreement of the Government and the ACTU that negotiations could take place which would identify agreed 'trade- offs' so that standard working hours could be reduced to 38 hours at negligible cost. It was agreed that, when completed, the agreements covering particular departments or authorities would be presented to the appropriate arbitral authority to test against the criterion of 'negligible cost'. Two of these negotiations have been completed, Williamstown Naval Dockyard and the Department of Transport and Construction, and were endorsed last Friday by a Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.
To apply the pause to the other negotiations would be seen as a breach of faith by the Government. That is not our intention.

In the Departments and authorities that have substantially completed these hours negotiations we intend that they should be brought to a conclusion as soon as possible. Each case will be considered then by the Government and, if the criteria have been met, the Governor-General will be advised so that regulations can be made to allow the appropriate arbitral tribunal to examine and evaluate the agreement reached.

One of the requirements before any of these negotiations commenced was that an affirmative decision would not lead to 'flow-on' into the private sector or other non-Commonwealth public sectors. In the circumstances, the Government will not be considering any agreements that would have the potential for 'flow-on'.

In addition, the regulation-making power would be available if in the national interest, it became necessary during the wage pause to have the remuneration of a particular class of employee examined by an appropriate tribunal. It is not envisaged that this will be required except in extreme circumstances.

It is not the intention of the Government to say one thing and do another. It is our intention to prevent a new community wage round further eroding the strength of the Australian economy and to provide a breathing space to allow the economy to digest the large increases in real wages that have occurred over the last two years.

May I emphasise that this legislation is in conformity with agreement reached at the Premiers' Conference for action in the public sector. I ask honourable Senators to examine the legislation as a necessary part of the concerted action that the Government is taking.

The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has already approached the President of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to seek the immediate convening of a Full Bench to consider extending the wage pause to the private sector.
Sir John Moore has agreed and we will make our submissions on Thursday, 16 December.

The Commonwealth will be supported by the governments of Queensland, Western Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory in our submission to the Commission for a 12 months pause. We believe that the Labor States, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia, will support the private sector pause for a period of 6 months.

While this legislation is aimed at a pause in increases in remuneration and reduction in standard working hours for all those on the Commonwealth payroll, it should not be seen as being discriminatory against those in the Commonwealth public sector.
