It is an essential part of our overall thrust, in co-operation with the governments of the States and the Northern Territory, to have in place a wages pause over the next 12 months and to provide the necessary basis for savings to the Commonwealth Budget to provide additional expenditure on employment-related activity of $300m in the course of 1983.

The extent to which this legislation and our submissions to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and the various employer and professional bodies in this country are successful will be of great significance to the future of the economy.
I commend the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Grimes) adjourned.

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 14 December, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Grimes Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The Opposition is pleased that the Social Security Amendment Bill 1982 is being debated in the chamber this afternoon. We welcome the Bill. We do not oppose the Bill, not because of Christmas spirit but because we are very pleased that the items in it have been brought forward, as they are primarily matters which we have urged the Government to remedy for a long time. The Bill is not perfect but it certainly will improve the social services legislation. For that reason, we do not oppose it. For the last two months, in fact, the Opposition has been urging the introduction of a Bill to restore sickness benefit eligibility for people who earlier in the year were excluded from it by a legal opinion from the Department of Social Security. We do not often meet with such success and certainly such rapid success in a response from the Government. Another matter which is included in the Social Security Amendment Bill is one which the Opposition has raised many times in the past. We are particularly pleased at its appearance in this legislation.

speech.para: I begin by referring to the clauses of the Bill dealing with family allowance for school leavers. Honourable senators who were here in 1977 may remember that when the then Minister for Social Security, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, stopped the unemployment benefit for young school leavers over the summer vacation she promised that the Government would continue paying family allowance until the unemployment benefit was payable. The argument for continuing the family allowance was put in both Houses. My colleague in the other place, the honourable member for Prospect, Dr Klugman, stated that, without family allowance:

There may be a sudden drop in income of $11 or $12 for that family, which is probably a very large proportion of the total income. That child then has the additional costs of trying to find a job, the costs of going to the Commonwealth Employment Service office, going to the office of the Department of Social Security, ringing up, buying newspapers which advertise jobs and that sort of thing.

During the debate in this House at that time two Labor senators raised that matter, but not one Government member or senator spoke in support of unemployed school leavers or urged that the family allowance be retained for them. However, at the end of the debate in the Senate the Minister, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, gave an assurance that family allowance for those people would be continued and, foolishly as it turned out, the Senate accepted that assurance. Irrespective of whether she intended that the family allowance should be paid, it just did not happen. Either she did not follow it up or the officers of her Department did not follow it up-they may even have disobeyed her instructions. It was not because it was too difficult; the current Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, and his senior officers have found a way-a way that was open to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle in 1977 and since then.

I am raising the matter of the failure of Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and the Governemnt to honour that 1977 promise for the same reason that I have done so in intervening years: Poor families have had to do without $30, $40 or even $ 50 at Christmas when it was needed for food, clothing and other bills over that time. It has never mattered to families of relatively wealthy people, including all of us here. It has affected, in fact, only parents on low incomes, including pensioner parents who lost dependent children's allowance for the same period. My most recent efforts to persuade the Government to continue the family allowance was a small piece in the October 1982 issue of the Social Security Bulletin, a well known journal on social security in this country which happens to be circulated from my office. It states:
SOCIAL SECURITY POLICIES ENSURE BLEAK CHRISTMAS-UNLESS

In 1976 the Fraser Government, obsessed with its war against so called 'dole bludgers', decided to stop unemployment benefits to school leavers who could not find jobs. They are not paid until six weeks after their final examination or when they leave school, whichever is the later.

But, in spite of promises made by Senator Guilfoyle at the time, family and student allowances are also stopped over this period. This year family allowances finish up on the first or third Tuesday in December.
What are these teenage children to live on in their first six weeks of unemployment?

How are parents supposed to feed grown young people with no less than average appetites when the Department of Social Security, which has paid family allowances to those children since birth, cancels all payments at the very time they need new clothes, transport and telephone money to hunt for work, and food to sustain them for it?
Government members and senior public servants have no problems with the policy. They can manage family holidays and lavish Christmas spending without depending on social security payments.
It is poor families-including unemployed parents in Newcastle and Wollongong- who have to explain to their children that presents and food are scarce.
Can even this Government derive satisfaction in saving a few thousand dollars by leaving teenage school leavers stranded without family allowances?
If not, the Minister should order that payments be made until the end of January so that their families have a marginally less bleak Christmas.

I would not have read from that document but for a subsequent development. The Minister, Senator Chaney, was good enough to inform me that he was bringing in legislation to cover that vacation gap. I am sure that he will accept that he really did not know about the situation until he had read of it in the Social Security Bulletin to which I have referred. He then took immediate action to remedy that neglect. I thank him for it and pay a genuine tribute to his readiness to take such prompt action. However, I am fairly cynical and less than happy about the prominent Government back bencher who has been touting it around his electorate that he was responsible for the campaign to extend family allowances to school leavers and that the legislation is being changed solely because of his efforts. That back bencher is notorious for saying in the past that unemployment was a myth, that the unemployed were overpaid and that if they really wanted jobs they could find them. As it happens, his electorate surrounds the area of Wollongong and is suddenly getting a very long list of unemployed persons. His suddenly found compassion has surfaced only because of the threat of the ballot box. The Opposition has been bringing this matter to the Government's attention for years. Changes which should have been made in earlier years will now cost between $3m and $5m.

I come now to the changes in the legislation regarding sickness benefits. Almost three months ago I, and others, began hearing stories of people who were being ruled ineligible for sickness benefits because of a redefinition of the so -called loss of income provisions following a legal opinion from the Attorney- General's Department. I believe that a legal opinion of this type should not be a private document. Neither I nor any other honourable senator can cast doubt on that document because we have not seen it. But it would not be impossible in such cases for a dubious legal opinion to change administrative practice affecting thousands of people. Therefore I believe that we as legislators should be able to see that opinion. The Hulme-Griffith opinion on invalid pensions was responsible for a massive crackdown on the granting of invalid pensions some years ago. But fortunately that ludicrous opinion became public. If the Government is certain of its legal grounds in changing payment guidelines of this type then I believe it should have no difficulty in making such an opinion a public document so that we can all have a look at it.

I was told, very sadly, of a 34-year-old widow pensioner who was refused sickness benefit, though she had a long-standing illness and was on some eight different drugs. She was able to obtain the special benefit, but because the special benefit carries with it no right to supplementary or rent allowance and no access to free pharmaceutical benefits and because her dependance on these medications did not allow her to manage in society she was forced into a mental home.

We have all heard about Mr Darrell Carthew, a double amputee who was taken off the invalid pension. Because the invalid pension was not defined as income under this legalistic interpretation he was not given sickness benefits. We have heard of the young unemployed lad who had not applied for unemployment benefits because he still had some savings. When he fell from a ladder and broke his leg he was ineligible for sickness benefits because he had no income. Under the amended legislation these people will be eligible for sickness benefits and a health card. I am extremely pleased that this has been accomplished before the end of the current parliamentary session, not next year as we feared.

It is also very satisfactory that none of these people will have to serve the seven-day waiting period before being paid sickness benefits though they will wait some time for payment now that such payments are made in arrears. I believe that the implementation of this legislation-which is not contentious, at least in the view of the Opposition-is a good time to reassess the fairness of the seven-day waiting period. Not all people who fall ill when in the work force are entitled to sick pay. It certainly is the case that many more people than before are working in temporary or part time jobs which have no such entitlement. All we are doing in imposing a seven-day waiting period is exposing them to further hardship. I think it is about time we assessed whether, in difficult economic times such as this, the seven-day waiting period is fair.

The change in the legislation which gives a supplementary allowance to unemployment beneficiaries who fall ill or who are injured under the same conditions as sickness beneficiaries is also a good move. However, we continue to deplore the Government's policy of taxing this very small rent assistance for these people. I am aware that it is a taxation matter and not a social security matter; but I raise it, as I have raised it before, as an injustice because the same payments for pensioners are not taxed. I hope, in this spirit of goodwill, that the Minister for Social Security will now look to this matter with the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and that when we come back we will find that that anomaly has been removed from the social services legislation.

However, as I said, we do not believe this legislation is perfect. I will move a second reading amendment which I hope will be accepted by this chamber. I would have liked to move an amendment in the Committee stage to remove the anomaly, but I am aware that if it were passed the legislation would not be passed, and, as the House of Representatives will not be sitting for a while, we would have been in a situation where people who would otherwise get benefits under this legislation would not get them.

One such disappointment concerns the restriction in section 113 of the Social Services Act, which restricts the amount of sickness benefit payable to no more than has been defined as loss of income. In general, it is a provision applying to self-employed persons and primary producers. In poor seasons or when getting established they often have very little actual income averaged out over the year . If they are entitled in every other way to sickness benefit and have no other income, it seems to me reasonable that they should receive the full rate of sickness benefit. I do not see how it can be considered reasonable to expect a man or woman who suffered a heart attack to support, respectively, himself, a wife and a child or herself, a husband and a child on $67 a week, as occurred in one case which was brought to my attention. It is estimated that the removal of section 113 from the Social Services Act would cost no more than $10m a year. If that sort of solution is unacceptable to the Government, I request the Minister to consider how payments can be arranged to give full benefits to a sick person who has no other income.

The amendment we would wish to move concerns a group of people who have caused controversy in this chamber in the past and, I dare say, will in the future. Although I believe there is a genuine and cogent argument for including them in this legislation, I accept the fact that the Government, with its views of this area, would not do so on this occasion and that certainly we cannot hold up the legislation because of this. I refer to persons who are involved in an industrial dispute. As many honourable senators will remember, the definition of such persons was widened in 1979 to include union members who were laid off as a result of industrial action by members of the same union. The union members can be in another industry in another State and be opposed to or utterly ignorant of the industrial action which put them off, yet they can be precluded by the 1979 legislation from receiving unemployment benefit or sickness benefit during the dispute. The present interpretation of 'sickness benefit' also excludes them from that.

If these people are sick and are entitled to sickness benefit in every other way, how are they to pay rent, to eat, to pay for medicines or to pay for transport to doctors? If they suffer a disabling illness or injury while their works or mines are closed in a dispute they should be able to receive some social security payment even if the Government insists on its present restrictive legislation, as it has done. I really think the Minister has to justify how the Government fails to pay this benefit and how it could even starve people. I know that if such a person is married there is a possibility the wife can apply for a special benefit, but a single person who is thrown out of work because of an industrial dispute to which he is not even a party cannot expect any help under this legislation if he or she suffers an illness or an accident. There may not even be a charitable organisation in the area that he or she could go to in those circumstances. I think the Government should reconsider the appropriateness of the sickness benefit in such a case.

I am told that the probable cost of the changes to sickness benefit legislation will amount to about $2m. It is a very small cost when I consider the hardship suffered by some cases that have been referred to me. On two occasions in the past in this chamber I have asked several questions since the new sickness benefit instructions were put into effect a few months ago. I have put out Press statements. And many members of the Opposition have put out statements-there has also been the article in the October Social Security Bulletin. Except for the injustices about which I have just spoken I am happy that the episode can be laid to rest after what has been one of the shortest and sharpest campaigns we have ever conducted in this area of social security.

My final point-one of which I hope the Minister is increasingly aware-is that variations in conditions and payments of social security pensions and benefits are tiresome and difficult to administer and can be disastrous for persons shot from one to another, particularly when they lose money and additional benefits. The need to settle the social security system so that it is, as far as possible, non-discriminatory, is daily more evident to me and should be daily more evident to Senator Chaney. We have a ludicrous situation where people with identical illnesses and needs in fact receive varying rates of social security benefits, in particular the sickness benefits. Their benefits are not based on need or the nature of their illness but on whether, for instance, they were receiving the unemployment benefit or pensions, what their incomes were before they went on to the sickness benefit. This is a matter we should all take seriously and look seriously at. I urge the Government to do so. Having welcomed the legislation and having pointed out that we do not oppose its passage I move the Opposition's amendment to the second reading of the Bill, which has been circulated. I move:
At end of the motion add:

'but the Senate is of the opinion that the Bill should be amended to extend the payment of sickness benefit without a waiting period to persons who are ineligible to receive unemployment benefits because of sub-section 107 (4) of the Social Security Act, relating to persons engaged in industrial action.'

These people are sick like anybody else. They are frequently in a set of circumstances over which they have no control. We believe it is the duty of the social services legislation of this country to support them like everybody else.

speech.speaker: Macklin Sen M.J.

talk.start.para: â€”As Senator Haines, the Australian Democrats' spokesperson on social security, indicated in speaking to the statement by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), the provisions of this legislation have the support of the Australian Democrats since they are in keeping with the statement and are intent on adjusting existing anomalies. The major provisions of the Social Security Amendment Bill, particularly those relating to school leavers, are especially welcomed at this time, obviously because of the impending problems of many families who receive the unemployment benefit and who are unable to continue support for their children who have left school and who are not, under existing arrangements, eligible for any unemployment benefit.

speech.para: The provisions of this Bill are long overdue. In 1976 the Government stopped unemployment benefit to school leavers for six weeks after their final examination or after the day they left school, whichever was the later. In a number of ways this has caused excessive hardship to many low income families. The Australian Democrats are surprised that it has taken quite so long to get around to discovering this anomaly or, if not discovering it, at least doing something about it. As the Minister for Social Security said in his second reading speech, the budgetary implications of the proposed amendments are relatively minor. If that is the case it is a pity that we have had six years with no action.

We support the amendments concerning the sickness benefit and support the Minister's move to end the anomalies which have placed an unnecessary burden on people who are already disadvantaged in one way or another. We would hope that the Government, having commenced what we hope is a systematic examination of social security in terms of the anomalies which have existed within the legislation, will turn its attention to other anomalies which have been brought to its notice over many years. We hope that in the new year we will see further amending legislation to the Social Security Act which will rid the system of some of the most glaring anomalies. It will be an improvement in what will become, over the next year at least, one of the most hard-pressed portfolios within the Government and one which will have to be sympathetically handled due to the enormous pressures which will obviously be placed upon it by the economic downturn and the enormous number of people who are currently on the unemployment benefit and a range of other benefits. I believe that the Minister will find himself under enormous pressure because of this. We hope that the Government will respond to emerging problems that we have not seen in this country probably for some 30 or 40 years.

The Australian Labor Party has proposed an amendment to the second reading of the Bill. Despite the fact that I have just quoted from an article of the Opposition shadow Minister for Social Security in which he said some unkind things about the Australian Democrats, we still intend to support his amendment because I believe it does point out yet another major problem. Senator Grimes raised a point about which we are concerned. We are very much concerned about the person who is thrown out of work because of industrial action taking place in some other part of the community which is not necessarily directly involved with that person. I think it is unfortunate that that type of situation exists within the legislation. Since it does exist and there is no possibility of removing it in the foreseeable future we believe the worst effects ought to be ameliorated wherever possible by amendments. We would not have liked to have supported an amendment at the Committee stage because of the likelihood of holding up this piece of legislation which will be extremely necessary at the beginning of next year. But we do accept the point that a person who is thrown out of work in a sickness context ought to be able to have a benefit conferred on him as with any other person who did not fall under section 107 sub-section ( 4) of the Social Security Act.

However, I propose an amendment which has been circulated to honourable senators. The intent of the amendment is not necessarily to put what we were looking at in a formal way, but rather to raise again the other area; that is, if we were moving into this area the Australian Democrats would like to see the situation where a person in that context can have recourse upon his normal entitlement from his employer for whatever accrued sickness leave is available to him. We do not believe it ought to be the case that automatically it goes under the social security arrangements. Even if a person were thrown out of work as a result of industrial action we do not think it is beyond the legislative process to be able to devise a method whereby that person can have recourse to his accrued sickness entitlement from his employer before he reaches the point of having to call on the social security system of this country to support him in his sickness situation. The Australian Democrats will be proposing that amendment to the Opposition's amendment. Whether our amendment is carried or lost, we will still be supporting the Opposition's amendment at the second reading stage because I think the principle is worth supporting. It is worth trying to get it into legislative form at a later stage. I move the following amendment to the Opposition's amendment:
After 'persons' (first occurring), insert:
'who have exhausted their entitlement to sickness leave from their employer and '.

talk.start.para: â€”I just wish to indicate that we will accept the Australian Democrats' addition to our amendment. I understand that Senator Macklin said I said some very unkind things about the Democrats. I had better not talk about pedantry and other things. I cannot see that the Democrats' amendment adds a lot or that it takes away anything. Therefore, we are happy enough, in the spirit of Christmas, to go along with it.

speech.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: â€”We are debating legislation which seeks to extend benefits in two ways. First, it seeks to extend for six weeks the payment of the family allowance to the families of school leavers who are unable to get work and are ineligible to receive unemployment benefit. Secondly, the Bill seeks to pick up an unintended anomaly whereby certain people were found to be no longer eligible for the sickness benefit because they have not suffered a loss of income due to sickness. I note that the amendments are welcomed by the Opposition and by the Australian Democrats. That was made clear in this chamber in an earlier debate on the proposed amendments.

speech.para: I suppose one of the joys of being the Opposition spokesman on social security is that whatever is done by the Government there is always something left undone . The spokesman for the Opposition always says that while the Labor Party welcomes what is good it would be nice if we did something extra. I note that the pattern has been preserved in the current debate. In any event, I just want to comment on a couple of points which were raised. Senator Grimes mentioned the entitlement of primary producers to sickness benefit. It is true that primary producers, like other people seeking entitlement to sickness benefit, are required to show that they have lost income due to sickness. If a primary producer is in the position where he is not earning income in any event and cannot demonstrate a loss of income, he cannot obtain a benefit. A primary producer who is disabled by sickness and who is required to hire labour to do the work which he would otherwise be doing is entitled to claim the cost of that labour as loss of income. So, in the circumstances where the labour of the primary producer is actually replaced on the farm by some paid help, sickness benefit is payable.

Another point that I wanted to mention was the rather critical reference to Mr Michael Baume, the honourable member for Macarthur. It is a fact that Mr Michael Baume made vigorous representations to me with respect to the extension of the family allowance to school leavers during any period of unemployment. I regret that the Opposition found it necessary to attack a member who, I think, worked hard to advance the interests of his constituents.

I will be saying something about how ungracious the Opposition is in supporting this legislation of which it is supposed to be in favour. In a very serious vein , I wanted to pick up the comments made by Senator Grimes at the conclusion of his speech on the motion that the Social Security Amendment Bill be read a second time. I think there are lessons to be learned in the amendments which are before the Senate at the moment, one of which is that the system is one of very great complexity. That is true both for clients and for administrators. The fact of the matter is that when one is drawing amendments to the social security legislation one is continually brought up against the difficulty of drawing amendments which will not produce unintended consequences. I say that having discussed the matter both with my officers, who have the responsibility of advising me, and briefly with parliamentary counsel. I, therefore, express agreement with some of the sentiments that Senator Grimes expressed.

I think there is a case for trying to look at ways of simplifying both the legislation and the system. I say that publicly because I would welcome public contribution to what is a quite difficult process. It is very easy to say that things should be simple and straightforward; the actual achievement of that objective is less straightforward. But I think some of the delays which were experienced in our coming to grips with the anomalies which emerged in the legislation which we are addressing today were delays occasioned by a very complicated system in which it is quite easy for things to occur in a way which is not specifically intended.

I refer to the sickness benefit point. A legal opinion was obtained because a difficult case arose which gave rise to an inquiry. That legal opinion indicated that payments had been made not in accordance with the Social Security Act. Very properly, my Department took action to ensure that from that time on payments were made in accordance with the law. At the same time, where there were cases of hardship it was pointed out to operatives in the field that special benefit was available. I believe that we should have come to grips with the policy matters more speedily than we did. But, again, I think that is a function of complexity. It is important that I and my officers learn from that experience, try to ensure that we work towards a simpler system and also respond to difficulties as they arise-not merely ensure that we comply with the law but also make sure that the policy is addressed so that any unfairness in the way things work out is avoided.

The social security system is very important to some two and a half million Australians who are dependent wholly or in part upon it for income maintenance. I again wish to make in quite clear to the Senate and to the public that where there are anomalies, where there are difficulties, the Government would wish to see those speedily addressed to avoid unnecessary and unwanted hardship. I commend the Bill to the Senate. I oppose the amendments which have been moved by the Opposition. I indicate that to save time, since the Democrats are supporting the amendments, we will not divide. Clearly, the Government opposes the amendments.
Amendment (Senator Macklin's) to amendment (Senator Grimes's) agreed to.
Amendment (Senator Grimes's), as amended, agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

debate.title: WILDLIFE PROTECTION (REGULATION OF EXPORT AND IMPORTS) BILL 1982

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 7 September, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Ryan Sen S.M.

talk.start.para: â€”The Opposition supports the Bill. I must say that, as far as it goes, we actually welcome it. The Australian Labor Party is always keen to see the Federal Government accepting its responsibility for the environment, accepting its responsibility to act as a national government in protecting Australian flora and fauna and, as in this case, accepting its responsibility to implement international obligations acquired as a result of an international treaty.

speech.para: The purpose of the Bill is to strengthen Australia's arrangements for the protection of its animals, plants and wildlife generally, by improving the effectiveness of its import and and export controls. So far so good, but this week, having seen the events that have taken place in the Parliament, I cannot allow the opportunity to pass without commenting that is a great shame-indeed, a great tragedy-that whereas the Government is prepared to act as it has in regard to this legislation to protect our Australian flora and fauna by imposing more effective export controls, it has at the same time been prepared to abandon its responsibilities, to resile from its international obligations, in respect of the South West Tasmania region.

I will not traverse again all the issues involved although I do not think it can be said too often that the Federal Government has made the wrong decision, has abrogated its national and international responsibilities and its decision ought to be overturned. There are people on both sides of this chamber and many people throughout Australia who agree with that statement.

However, the Bill before us is a wildlife protection Bill and in this respect the Government is acting properly and we welcome the measure. It has been the intention of the Opposition to move an amendment, the effect of which would have been to include the hooded seal and the harp seal, both of which are seriously endangered species, in the schedule of flora and fauna which gain protection under the Bill. We cannot accept the reasons that the Government has given for excluding the hooded seal and the harp seal. In fact, it has given no sound reasons at all. It says that the matter is under further consideration. It is our view that where you have endangered species, where their slaughter is unnecessary and, in the case of seals, where it has been carried out with appalling brutality, the species ought to be included.

My colleague Mr Stewart West moved such an amendment in the House of Representatives and it was my intention to move it again in the Senate on behalf of the Australian Labor Party. I understand that in the event of our having done so we would have had the support of the Australian Democrats. However, the conduct of the Government with respect to the legislative program this session has made it not feasible for us to move the amendment. Although the legislation has been in the Parliament since September, it has not been brought on for debate in the Senate until this evening. Because of the time that has already elapsed, and the seriousness of the matters dealt with in the Bill, the Opposition-I understand the Australian Democrats accept this position also-do not wish to hold up the legislation further. The Government has itself held it up now for five months, which represents quite disgraceful negligence on its part.

Honourable senators have sat here day after day, night after night while the Government has meandered, wasting time. We have seen filibusters by Government members in regard to two pieces of legislation that they did not want to support . I refer to the retrospective tax legislation and the Australian Democrats' legislation to protect the South West Tasmania region. We have seen Government senators waste the time of the Senate in a most irresponsible and negative fashion, yet here we have, with only a few sitting hours remaining, the Bill before us. The problem is this: If we moved an amendment to protect the harp and hooded seals that amendment, in all likelihood, would be successful. However, the House of Representatives is no longer sitting. It finalised its sittings last night and so the amended legislation could not be returned to the House of Representatives for further consideration by it, as is required under the procedures of the place, until next February. Because there are some electoral implications in the amendment we proposed to move the Government would very likely again put our amended Bill to the bottom of the Notice Paper and several more months could pass before the flora and fauna of Australia received the protection that is provided for in this Bill.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I know that you will agree with me that this is a most disappointing and unsatisfactory state of affairs. We are in a position to improve the Bill in a way that would receive the support of this place but, because of the Government's mismanagement of its legislative program, we cannot proceed with that amendment without holding up a very important piece of legislation for a length of time which is not acceptable to us. As a consequence we will not move the amendment of which honourable senators have previously had notice. There is nothing more to be said about the Bill because we endorse it. We believe that as the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) said in his second reading speech the uniqueness of Australia's flora and fauna places a special responsibility on all of us to ensure that we do our utmost to avoid species becoming extinct. A great deal of damage has been done to our natural flora and fauna. We know that this legislation will prevent an acceleration of that damage and for those reasons we support the Bill.

speech.speaker: Missen Sen A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I support the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill 1982. I recognise the fact that this Bill is coming before us at a very late stage of the sitting. However, I am glad that it has come before us and that it will be passed before we rise. I recognise the force of Senator Ryan's argument in connection with the hooded and harp seals. I hope that it will not be very long before they are on the Schedules and protected. The provisions in this legislation make it easier for the Government to take action. The Schedules can be altered and added to by delarations. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills made a number of suggestions about this Bill. At one stage it was concerned about the fact that the provisions in the Act could be altered by declaration. The Committee took a general objection to what is called Henry VIII clauses by which the legislation can be altered by regulation. I think the explanation for this which was given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) was very satisfactory. There has been a great deal of delay over the years in making provisions to protect wildlife, fauna and flora. Examples were given by the Minister of the fact that the appendices to the existing legislation agreed to by the parties in 1975 were not put into effect until 1981. Therefore the provisions which have been made in this Bill which enable the Government, by declaration or regulation, to amend the Schedules mean that this matter can be very much on hand and there is no reason why we have to wait for Parliament to resume if the Government's investigations on this matter come to a satisfactory conclusion.

speech.para: I think this Bill is very important. Of course the general purpose of it is to put into one Act our obligations under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora-which is known as CITES-and various other international agreements and to protect our native species and ensure that both their import and export is controlled. We have in the past had a number of pieces of legislation on this matter, and that is unsatisfactory. This now puts the legislation into one whole piece, and I think that that is a satisfactory way in which we can protect the forms of natural life which are precious to Australia.

Apart from the importance of the Bill itself and the provisions which I think have been very carefully looked over in both Houses of the Parliament, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee did make a number of recommendations. I am pleased to say that particularly in the House of Representatives amendments were moved which very satisfactorily overcome most of the problems which the Committee raised. The Committee raised those matters by way of highlighting what are seen to be possible difficulties, sometimes in regard to inappropriate delegations of legislative power, and it was also concerned, in regard to the matter of appeals , about approved management programs. But that, too, was handled by an amendment in the House of Representatives. The duration of permits was another matter criticised by the Committee and, likewise, that provision was improved by amendment in the House of Representatives. We now have a Bill which is a better Bill because of the processes which the two Houses have gone through. I hope that it will be used extensively and I hope, along with Senator Ryan, that the particular case that she raised will be dealt with soon by expeditious decision which the Government can make without returning the matter to this chamber. Therefore I have much pleasure in supporting the Bill. I hope that it comes into quick operation.

speech.speaker: Mason Sen C.V.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I want to follow up briefly the comments that Senator Ryan made because it seems to the Australian Democrats that we have in the Senate the iniquitous situation that we have had in the past whereby legislation which ought to have come forward long ago does not arrive until the end of the session, whereupon we are called on to pass Bills such as this Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill and the word is put out that the legislation should not or cannot be amended or it will be held up because the Senate is sitting and the House of Representatives is not. This seems to us to be a form of blackmail which the Senate will have to consider very carefully at some future time. It seems entirely inappropriate that one House of Parliament should apparently be regarded as subservient to the other to the extent that it is assumed that that House will not consider matters and that any amendments it makes are somehow of lesser value than amendments made in the other place. This is a matter of basic significance and it applies with great force to this Bill. I suggest that the management of business in the Senate must become a matter of increasing importance as time goes on.

speech.para: Like Senator Ryan, we regret intensely that it was not possible to move the amendment concerning hooded and harp seals. We would have been only too happy to support that. Indeed, most people in this country would like to have seen the amendment in the Bill because they feel very strongly about this matter. I would like to follow up what Senator Missen and Senator Ryan have said, and say that I hope the Government will use its powers to see that that very necessary and popular inclusion goes into this Bill in any case, since it can do so.

That said, the Australian Democrats do support the Bill wholeheartedly. Its provisions are excellent and we see in it too, a necessary concession to the feeling of the public of this country that not only human beings are important but all forms of life are important and have their values. To an extent all forms of life are dependent on each other-the relationship is symbiotic-and we can go on ignoring wildlife and destroying things at our own peril. This Bill is an indication of a greater strength and significance of that kind of movement. I am not speaking of any fringe group, or of greenies or environmentalists or whoever-although all those terms could be applied to me-because it is now a widespread, almost universal, feeling among the younger generation, especially, of this country that we have great duties towards life of all forms, be it trees , plants, birds, fish or any creature on this earth. We should not destroy those things or commit what I consider to be the unpardonable crime which has been committed so often of completely eliminating species from this planet. That, I think, is a most serious step for any species to take against another, especially a species which calls itself 'rational' and 'humane' and ' compassionate', and all sorts of other adjectives that we like to apply to ourselves.

We agree completely with the sentiments of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr McVeigh) as expressed in his second reading speech but, unfortunately, the Government does not seem to agree with its own expressed view . This concerns us. I find it impossible to understand why the Government did not heed its own words when Cabinet decided not to exert its influence with the Tasmanian Government and stop the needless and appalling destruction of the South West Tasmanian wilderness which is now continuing and will continue until wiser and rational counsels, I hope, can change that. The Minister stated:
The uniqueness of Australia's flora and fauna places a special responsibility on all of us to ensure that we do our utmost to avoid species becoming extinct.
They are very nice words with which we would all agree. The Minister went on to state:
Regrettably, many species of our flora and fauna have become extinct in recent times.
He instances the reasons. He said:
The causes include thoughtlessness, over-exploitation and simple lack of knowledge and understanding. Possibly the most devastating impact has been through the destruction of natural habitat.

I should have thought that the Minister's words could in a sense have been an instruction to the Government on the way it behaved concerning South West Tasmania. Here is an example right in front of us. The wildlife of our nation is at threat for the very reasons that the Minister set down. The Government is condoning thoughtlessness. I think that, if sufficient thought were given to this matter, the Government would see that it is wrong to build the dam in South West Tasmania. I think that more thought may well further change the community view and the Government's view.

talk.start.para: â€”A change of government would be the most efficient way of doing it .

â€”Senator Ryan claims that a change of Government would be the most efficient way of doing it. On the present showing, I can only agree with her because, if the Government is prepared to fly in the face of the feelings of the majority of Australian people and condone and connive at the destruction of something of value, it has at least to consider the electoral consequences. There again, the Minister said that over-exploitation is the problem. What does the Government propose to do but permit over- exploitation of the Franklin River ? The Franklin River is a river, as we understand it, in its natural form. It will cease to exist. It will become a pond-a regulated, controlled pond. The unique wildlife on its banks will be destroyed. If that is not over-exploitation , I do not know what it is. The Minister's third reason-he weeps crocodile tears -is a simple lack of knowledge and understanding. Scientists from all over the world-some of the most eminent archaeologists and biologists-tell us in this country that we will make the most appalling, terrible mistake and, in fact, are committing a crime, by allowing this destruction to go on. If the Government wants knowledge and understanding, where will it go to get it? I suggest not to Mr Robin Gray who has shown no sense of understanding or knowledge in this matter at all and no wish to aquire them. The Government will find that information among those people-scientists, and people of world repute-who have told the Government that it is making a fool of itself and, more than that, committing a crime by allowing this destruction to go on.

speech.para: It would have been a strange irony if those of us on this side of the House were to allow this Bill, the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill 1982, to pass this place without stressing this point to the Government. I have news for the Government but it may not be news to the Government. It has not heard the end of the Franklin issue, not by a long haul. There is much more of it to come than we have had so far. That is saying something because it has exercised the time and patience of this chamber a great deal already. But, if the Government flies in the face of what the people of the country want, it must expect that result. The purpose of this place-and it is certainly the purpose of the Opposition-is to remind the Government continually that, when it goes against the people of the country, it is committing a betrayal of its responsibility and electoral promises. We on this side of the chamber will certainly give the Government no opportunity of forgetting that in the months to come.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: â€”The Senate is debating the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill 1982. I am grateful to honourable senators who have spoken in this debate and who have indicated that all sides of the Senate support the Bill. It is good legislation. The purpose of the Bill is to strengthen arrangements for the protection of Australian animals and plants and world wildlife generally by improving the legislative backing for our import and export controls. That is a good purpose. The Bill deserves the support of this chamber.

speech.para: The Bill will do several things. It will transfer responsibility for the control of wildlife imports and exports to the Minister who is concerned with conservation matters. That seems to be appropriate. The Bill will consolidate existing regulations and ordinances on endangered species and policy regarding exports of Australian wildlife into a single piece of legislation. The Bill will maintain Australia's strict controls on the export of Australian wildlife and it will extend coverage to native flora. The Bill provides for quick amendments to the species listed in the legislation to reflect changes to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora and for penalties consistent with the protection to be made for illegal trafficking. So I am grateful for the support of honourable senators. I am also grateful for the fact that the amendments which were anticipated will not now be moved.

Senator Mason, however, spent some time discussing South West Tasmania in the context of this Bill on the grounds that it concerned wildlife and conservation matters generally. By way of interjection, Senator Ryan indicated that the way to improve the situation was to change the Government. I thought it fair just to place on record a couple of facts about the positions of the major political parties in Australia. I an reminded, of course, that it was a Labor government that first proposed the dam, and the Federal Labor Party did not renounce that proposal at that stage.

talk.start.para: â€”That is untrue.
â€”It was a Labor Premier in a Labor controlled State who first proposed the dam. Federal Labor did not renounce it. A referendum was held , and Federal Labor did not campaign against the dam.
â€”That is completely untrue.
â€”It did not then indicate to the people of Tasmania at a Federal level--
â€”I am forced to say, Mr Acting Deputy President, that that is a lie.
â€”Order! I ask you, Senator Grimes, to withdraw that remark. It is unparliamentary.
â€”I meant to say that it was untrue, Mr Acting Deputy President; but again, it is on the record.

â€”The Tasmanian Parliament met after an election and 51 out of the 54 members of that Parliament, including the Labor Party members in Tasmania, voted for the Bill to build the dam. State Labor in Tasmania is a pro- dam party. I am interested, too, in the contribution made by the Leader of the Federal Labor Party. I have before me an article published in the Launceston Examiner of 7 July 1981. I am not sure, but it may have been during the election campaign. In that edition there appears a story headed 'Hayden petitioned to halt dam row'. The Leader of the Federal Labor Party was approached by a group of Hydro-Electric Commission workers and they called on the Leader of the Federal Opposition to intervene in the State power wrangle. What the story says is interesting. It says:

speech.para: Mr Hayden, while agreeing to discuss the matter with the Premier (Mr Lowe)-
That is, the Labor Premier of Tasmania-
made it clear that it was a State Government concern.
Those were the words of the Leader of the Federal Labor Party-'it was a State Government concern'. That should be on the record. The newspaper report went on to state:
He said he would support a Federal Parliamentary Inquiry into the power needs of Tasmania.
It also stated:
It was not possible, however, for him to play a role in influencing the State Government.

I want to put on record the fact that Mr Hayden, the Leader of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party, is reported in a newspaper article in Tasmania as having said that the dam was a State matter. We have to be sure about who is saying what. The Australian Democrats have taken a consistent line.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I believe we have tolerated this sort of nonsense long enough. I wonder whether the Leader of the Government or anyone else can bring the Minister back to relevance in his remarks on this Bill.
â€”I feel that the Minister is relating his remarks, in a sense, to the Bill before us.
â€”What do you mean by 'in a sense'? We will all get up.
â€”I hope common sense will prevail.
â€”You ask the Minister to prevail. He is lying and he knows we cannot reply.
â€”Order! Senator Grimes, I ask you to withdraw that remark. It is unparliamentary. I ask that out of due respect for the Chair, you withdraw.

â€”I withdraw, but on a point of order I point out that the Minister is deliberately misusing the processes of this chamber on an occassion when we are trying to co-operate with the Government. The Minister knows quite well that we are not in a position to reply to his remarks because he is closing the debate. This is typical of the Minister. As Senator Chipp said today, he is a sneaky, scurrilous character. We will not tolerate this when we have been co- operating all day and are willing to co-operate tomorrow. We will not continue with this co-operation.
â€”Order! Senator Grimes, the language you are using is unparliamentary.
â€”The language the Minister uses is unparliamentary.

â€”It is unparliamentary to say that a person is scurrilous and to use other words you used. I do not want to repeat them. I ask you to moderate your language. If you have a point of order to raise please do so, but moderate your language please.
â€”My point of order is that the Minister is speaking on legislation which has nothing to do with the dam that he has been talking about. In the process of doing this--
â€”Senator Mason did.

â€”The Minister is not replying to Senator Mason. He is aiming his remarks at members of the Australian Labor Party, knowing quite well that he can do this-as he does so frequently-without us having the opportunity to reply. The Standing Orders of this place allow him and the Leader of the Government in the Senate, who is sitting next to him, to blackguard in a collective way, but not in an individual way, people who do not have the opportunity to reply. If we have to tolerate this there will be no co-operation in this place. We do not care whether we have to come back next week. I think it is the Minister rather than anybody else in this place who should act responsibly.
â€”Senator Grimes, I have listened to your point of order.

â€”Mr Acting Deputy President, I wish to speak to the point of order. I understand that certain arrangements have been enetered into with respect to these last few days of the sitting of the Senate. Those arrangements obligate members of the Opposition not to participate in debates. If we are to have time wasting by the Government members and Ministers that agreement, which was reached in a spirit of co-operation between honourable senators with a view to Government legislation receiving-

â€”Order! Senator Gietzelt, I must remind you that a point of order must relate to a contravention of Standing Orders. What you are saying at the moment does not do that. You are talking about an arrangement between the parties. That has nothing to do with Standing Orders and I do not take your point of order. Minister, I ask you to relate your remarks more closely to the Bill before us. I have been rather tolerant and I ask you to confine your remarks to the Bill before the chamber.

â€”I do not want to pursue the matter further. I just wanted to put on the record the newspaper quotation and what was said by Mr Hayden in Tasmania during the election. There is only one other matter that I need to mention in winding up. Some concern was expressed to the Government before the Bill was debated about some of its provisions. Some people had an interest in places like Lone Pine in Queensland. The Government is sympathetic to the intention of the amendment which was to be moved by Senator Ryan, but we did not think it was appropriate to proceed down that road at the time. Senator Martin expressed some concern about exports from Lone Pine. We have considered this and we believe that the Bill, as drafted, will permit exports from places such as Lone Pine in Queensland, which I understand has a long history of this activity, to be considered in appropriate circumstances. The honourable senator is not in Australia at the moment. She is away on other business. Perhaps in the new session, if she wants to pursue the matter I can take it up for her then.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

proctext.para: Clauses 1 to 30-by leave-taken together.

speech.speaker: Martyr Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: â€”I will be very brief. I am told that there has been support for hooded and harp seals and other wildlife. I feel obligated to say just one thing, and it will not disrupt anybody, so I ask honourable senators not to try to gag the debate.
â€”I know what you are going to say.
â€”Yes. I want to support unborn human beings, who are far more important that any flora or fauna. The honourable senator can gag the debate now if he likes.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Clauses agreed to.
Clause 31 (Requirements for permits to export-Native Australian animals and plants).

speech.speaker: Grimes Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: â€”Clause 31 deals with requirements for permits to export native Australian animals and plants. In South West Tasmania there are many native Australian animals and plants.
â€”About to be destroyed.

â€”They are about to be destroyed by the building of the dam in that area. Senator Peter Baume, in his rather inappropriate and scurrilous second reading speech decided to use the debate, on the Wildlife Protection ( Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill 1982 which the Opposition had agreed to support and facilitate its passage through the Parliament, as a propaganda campaign against the Australian Labor Party and, in particular, against the Leader of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Hayden.
â€”Well, blame Senator Mason for bringing it in. He brought in the South West.

â€”Senator Walters interjects and who am I to refuse to reply to her interjection. She has been making great play in Tasmania of the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill 1982, which Senator Mason introduced last week. She said it was an important Bill for Tasmania and anyone who voted with Senator Mason was un-Tasmanian and was working against the rights of Tasmanians. Her colleague, the Minister for the Australian Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman, yesterday wrote a letter to the Launceston Examiner stating that the Tasmanian Labor senators, in supporting that legislation, were voting against the interests of Tasmania.
â€”Why don't you tell the truth? I did not say that.

â€”The honourable senator said that many times. The simple fact of the matter is that of the honourable senators in this place, four Labor senators and one Liberal senator voted for the legislation. Senator Walters and Mr Hodgman are accusing one of their own colleagues of voting against the interests of Tasmania. Senator Walters, in supporting the campaign of an organisation called HEAT, in supplying that organisation with photocopying facilities to photocopy the advertisement which has been distributed around the State and in assisting the organisation to distribute its documents so that they were delivered to me, supported the statement in the advertisement that Labor senators from Tasmania who voted for that legislation were handing over control of South West Tasmania to unknown people overseas. She knows that this is a lie, she knows that it is absolute nonsense, but she persists in supporting people such as this for party political purposes when we have before us a very important issue in Tasmania.

speech.para: The simple fact of the matter is that in the referendum in Tasmania and Tasmanian Labor Government supported the Gordon-above-Olga scheme. The fact is that some federal Australian Labor Party parliamentarians-not all of them- supported the no dams position, as did a Liberal senator. I do not recall Senator Walters ever opening her mouth on the issue. I do not recall any newspaper advertisement with Senator Walters giving her views on that matter.

I just point out that what Senator Baume said today, and what Senator Sir John Carrick said today in Question Time, is untrue. If they perpetuate this sort of untruth I will stand up and deny what they are saying. In particular, Senator Baume, as is his wont, in closing a debate, condemned members of the Labor Party who up until then had absolutely co-operated with the passage of this Bill to the extent that we did not move the amendment that we wanted to move because if we did so and it was carried-it would have been carried-the Bill would not have got through because the House of Representatives is not sitting. If he wishes to act in this deceitful way-there is no other way to describe his actions-I will stand up in the Committee stage of debates, as I have done in relation to clause 31 of this legislation, and point out what a dishonest character he is. I will do it again and again. We will not co-operate with people who come to us, seeking our co-operation, and then slap us in the face in that way. We will not have this chamber treated in that way. If Senator Walters wants to join in and bring about a proper debate we will give her as much as she gives us. Senator Walters this afternoon voted on legislation on which she should not have voted without declaring her interest in that legislation. She is as corrupt as anybody has ever been in this place.

talk.start.para: â€”Mr Temporary Chairman, the honourable senator has said that Senator Walters did not declare an interest in the legislation. She had no interest. She is not corrupt and I believe that it is outside the purview of the Standing Orders so to declare.

â€”Mr Temporary Chairman, Senator Walters was a delegate to a conference concerning the voluntary health funds in Toronto in 1978. She was included on the list of delegates to that conference. She knows she was. She has never denied that she was included on that list of delegates. I therefore have no compunction about answering her in the way that I have if she wishes to sit in the back of this chamber and snipe at me in the way that she usually does.
â€”Order! I think the word to which the honourable senator objected was the word 'corrupt'.
â€”Oh well, if I am not allowed to use that word I will withdraw it . All the facts are there.
â€”I was not listed as a delegate to the conference to which Senator Grimes has referred. Senator Grimes can apologise to me before we leave this stage of the debate.
â€”Order! I do not want to gag anyone. Senator Grimes withdrew an imputation. We are dealing with clause 31. I have to keep the debate in order.
â€”Mr Temporary Chairman, will you let me reply to Senator Grimes' s accusation?
â€”The imputation was withdrawn. I am bound to keep the debate within the ambit of clause 31 of the Bill.
â€”Then the situation is--
â€”Under the Senate Standing Orders you can make a point of explanation but I do not want the debate on clause 31 trammelled with other matters.

â€”by leave-I believe that I have been misrepresented. I would like an apology from Senator Grimes because he is entirely wrong. I was not listed as a delegate to that conference. I represented the then Minister for Health, Ralph Hunt, and at that conference I delivered a message from him. I was representing the Federal Government. I would like an apology from the honourable senator opposite because he is 100 per cent wrong. I gave a message to that conference from the Minister for Health and did not attend as a delegate of any fund. I attended as a member of this Parliament.

speech.speaker: Grimes Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The list of delegates to that conference stated : 'Walters, a member of the Medical Benefits Association for Tasmania'. Immediately under that the list stated: 'Walters, Shirley, Senator'. The title at the head of the page is 'List of Delegates'. If Senator Walters was not a delegate she should have corrected it at that time. She has had three years to correct it. She has never corrected it. It is a claim which has been made ever since by many people in this place. I believe that I owe her no apology at all.
â€”Oh, no; not for being wrong!
â€”There is nothing wrong. The list of delegates is still in the records of the conference.

speech.para: Clause agreed to.
Clauses 32 to 77-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 78 (Co-operation with States and Territories).

speech.speaker: Tate Sen M.C.

talk.start.para: â€”Clause 78 is headed: 'Co-operation with States and Territories'. That is a very important concept which needs to be kept in mind in relation to wildlife protection. That clause refers to 'management programs for the purposes of this Act'. I take this opportunity to comment on the outrageous intervention in the second reading debate by the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume), bringing into this chamber all of his Sydney smart-Alick debating tricks that he has learnt over the years as a schoolboy, in order to resurrect the debate on South West Tasmania in the context of the debate on this Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Bill.

speech.para: I intend to reply to the specific point he made. As I understood it, from listening in my room, he dredged up, in order to make his cheap smart-Alick Sydney schoolboy debating point, from a Tasmanian newspaper of a couple of years ago some remarks attributed to the Federal leader of the Australian Labor Party. The Federal leader is said to have stated on that occasion that whilst he would negotiate and carry a point of view to Mr Lowe, he thought that it was for the State Government to make a decision at that time. As I understand it, that was the tenor of what was attributed to the Federal leader at that time. I suppose the point that Senator Baume was trying to make was that that shows that it is a matter for the State Government and not a matter for Federal intervention.

talk.start.para: â€”No, that is not the point I was making. It is just that Labor's policies are all over the place.

â€”That is the only point that follows. It is well known that the Federal Liberal Party has always seen this as a matter of genuine concern for the national Government. In 1975-this is relevant to the question of national, State and Territory co-operation-the national Liberal Party and the State branches of the Liberal Party issued a joint declaration to the effect that the South West ought to be preserved. To my knowledge, that joint declaration has never been consciously repudiated, or repudiated in any terms. For this national Government to introduce a clause headed 'Co-operation with States and Territories' in relation to management plans for wildlife protection when, in fact, there has been a joint national-State declaration that the South West ought to be preserved-a declaration of the Liberal Party at its national and State level-which has been repudiated unilaterally by the State Government and connived at by the national Government only a few days after the Flinders by- election is the height of hypocrisy. Anyone who could believe that this Government is interested in co-operating with States and Territories is being completely misled.

â€”I rise on a point of order. I think it is about time that the Committee got back to the legislation. I would suggest that we at least debate the Bill that is before us and get on with the business of the day.
â€”There is no substance to the point of order.
â€”I raise a point of order-

â€”Order! I have ruled against the point of order. I know that tempers are becoming frayed but I think things are coming back to an even tenor again. Senator Tate was speaking to clause 78. Have you completed what you wanted to say, Senator Tate?

â€”No, I have not. Clause 78 deals with other things-management programs of a co-operative nature being entered into by the national and State governments in relation to the protection of wildlife. My point is that we had a perfect example of such a co-operative agreement between the national and State branches of the Liberal Party in 1975, as outlined by Senator Peter Rae in the debate on 2 December 1982. I bring this up to show how much faith one can put in co-operative schemes between national and State governments of this political character. Amongst other things, that agreement provided for the Commonwealth Government to make a special grant to assist the Tasmanian National Parks and Wildlife Service to develop a management plan for the existing South West National Park as a matter of urgency. It also recognised, in that joint declaration, that the Australian people will be asking Tasmanians to forgo revenue that might otherwise flow from unchecked development of the area in order to preserve for the nation an area considered to be of immense national significance. In other words, there we had a joint policy commitment to the development of a management plan for South West Tasmania by the national and State branches of the Liberal Party which was repudiated unilaterally by the State Liberal Government led by Mr Gray. As I said it has been connived at in recent days by the Liberal Party at a national level. My question is: Who did the actual conniving on the part of the national Government to destroy that joint policy? Apparently the Cabinet was meeting and, according to Mr Anthony, Mr Fraser, the Prime Minister, was on the telephone and was fully consulted. But was he? Is the decision to connive and agree to the going ahead with the dam on the Gordon below Franklin to be attributed to the Prime Minister? Does he take personal responsibility for that? That is one question that might be answered. I would also like to know whether members in the Liberal party room had a chance to vote on that issue. In other words, I should like to know what happens to joint co-operative efforts in the hands of this particular national Government.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: â€”The first question is not relevant to this Bill, which concerns the export of animals. It has nothing to do with it. As to the second point, the affairs of the Liberal party room are not matters for the Parliament.

speech.para: Clause agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported; report adopted.

proctext.para: Bill (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 10 November, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Grimes Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I speak in support of the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill in the absence of my colleague Senator Walsh who, as honourable senators know, is a wheat farmer and knows considerably more about this subject than I do. I point out at the outset that wheat is not, has not and will not be grown in South West Tasmania under any circumstances as neither the climate nor the soil is suitable for growing it. It seems to me that the main points of this Bill are that it provides for the Australian Wheat Board to indulge in futures trading. It is empowered to hedge wheat and financial transactions on futures markets to secure prices for any unsold wheat, but the details of any such procedures must be published in the annual report of the Wheat Board. It changes the advance payment arrangements. At present growers must receive payment on delivery at the beginning of the season. This amendment will allow payment later in the season if the grower wishes. This is to be an arrangement between the grower and the Board. It makes adjustments to the guaranteed minimum price which may now be paid as a provisional and then as a final adjustment, the present system leading to delays since details of charges such as quality, allowance, handling, storage and some transport costs are not known until the end of the season. The amendment will enable the board to expedite finalisation of the season's pool, which at present is inefficient. In other words, this legislation , which I understand has the approval of the wheatgrowers and certainly comes from the Wheat Board, is acceptable. The amendments result from suggestions made from the Australian Wheat Growers Federation and the Wheat Board.

speech.para: The wheat industry is in great difficulty at the moment because of the drought in particular. The Wheat Board estimates that in November receivals this year will be 7.9 million tonnes with an expected gross income from the wheat crop of about $1,480m, whereas last year's gross income was $2,535m which means that the Wheat Board has been selling off its stock to meet export commitments. The Opposition supports this legislation because it has the approval of both the growers and the Board. As the passage of a previous Bill delayed consideration of this legislation tonight, we will support it without any further cogent, concise and precise arguments which, I am sure, are familiar to everyone in this place. If they are not I suggest that they read the House of Representatives Hansard of the debate on this legislation in the last couple of weeks.

talk.start.para: â€”Before I call the next speaker, I say that the Senate would regard that as heartening news. I call Senator Peter Rae.

speech.speaker: Rae Sen P.E.

talk.start.para: â€”I am not sure that what I have to say will be regarded as heartening. I start by pointing out that the provisions of this Bill were contained in proposals put forward by the Australian Wheat Growers Federation and the Australian Wheat Board. They are part of a chapter of a somewhat sorry history of problems experienced in the management of the marketing of Australia's wheat crop, which I believe is of fundamental importance to Australia,which is of fundamental importance to that large number of wheatgrowers but which in particular is of fundamental importance to our balance of trade and our export income, and which needs to be well managed. The Australian Wheat Board is still having trouble getting out its financial statements. It is still having trouble overcoming the problems which have now continued for what seems like an eternity but is only, I think, about six years. During that time it has not been able to get an unqualified Auditor-General's statement nor has it been able to get statements out on time.

speech.para: Bearing in mind the amount of money which is involved in the function which it fulfils on behalf of the wheat growers of Australia and on behalf of Australia I can only say that I hope that the proposals which are made in this Bill will enable the Wheat Board to be more efficient than it has evidenced itself as being in the past few years. Because of the experience of the past few years I would like to take up a number of matters during the Committee stage and seek answers to them. Due to the problems which exist in relation to the wheat industry of Australia and because of some of the international trading problems that exist I would not be keen to see the Bill held up for a lengthy period. Undoubtedly, it contains a number of measures which will be extremely beneficial to wheatgrowers of Australia and to Australia.

Contained in the Bill are matters which past history would cause the Senate to say: 'Let the alarm bells ring before blithely accepting that this will be an improvement or that this will be in good hands'. I believe that the record of the Wheat Board, including the occasion when the Senate unanimously censured the Wheat Board for its failure to be able to produce its accounts-a matter which it has still not been able to rectify totally-is something which causes the Senate to pay particular attention when amending legislation comes before it in relation to this Board. When it can get its accounts out on time with a clean bill of health I believe that we will all heave a great sigh of relief and say: 'Thank goodness it has been able to produce something about which the wheat growers in Australia will feel a lot more confident than they have in the past'. Mr President, I am sure that you understand what I am saying.

During the Committee stage I would like to raise a number of questions in relation to particular provisions of the Bill. I support the efforts of the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation in trying to improve the system and putting forward suggestions. As a matter of fact, at one stage it told me that it wanted to convert the Wheat Board from being a qango to a tango-from being a quasi- autonomous non-government organisation to a totally autonomous non-government organisation. I said that I hoped it would achieve its ambition. Nothing would please me more than to have a situation in which it can run its affairs without the need for the Parliament to provide legislation to establish it, assist it and govern it and provide a Senate committee to spend an awful lot of time trying to work out where it has gone so hopelessly wrong at various times. With that qualification and also with that commendation of the efforts that are being made by some people to try to overcome some of the problems, I support the general concept of the Bill. I wish to ask a number of questions during the Committee stage.

speech.speaker: Macklin Sen M.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill 1982 has the support of the industry. Indeed the original program of wheat marketing contained in the provisions of this Bill came from the industry itself. Due to the limited amount of time available tonight I wish to mention only one item. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the recommendations of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. I should like to compare those recommendations with the submission of the Australian Wheat Growers Federation to the Industries Assistance Commission in terms of wheat marketing. I think that exercise could be of great interest to honourable senators in comparing the similarities in the deliberations of those two bodies.

speech.para: The only point I wish to make in relation to this matter tonight, among the many that could be discussed, is the point that I raised earlier today regarding the dried vine fruits industry-that is, the emerging problem of the European Economic Community in terms of wheat marketing. I think the figures in this area are as illustrative as those in the dried fruit area. In the 1968-69 growing season the EEC imported 3.4 million tonnes of wheat. If we go through to the year 1973-74 we find that the EEC had turned around that fairly massive import amount to a slight export amount. From there it grew. In 1978-79-10 years after it had been importing 3.4 million tonnes-it was exporting 3.9 million tonnes. In 1979-80 that figure grew to 6.2 million tonnes. The 1980-81 harvest produced 9.6 million tonnes. The advent of such a massive amount of grain on the international wheat market has had a fair amount of ramification on Australia's industry which has been from its earliest years an export oriented industry. If one looks at the EEC in terms of the provision under its common agricultural policy one discovers that it has an enormous amount of latitude in this area to increase further support to its grain growers.

The common agricultural policy in the EEC and its cost to the community have been much talked about. In many cases they are often talked about as though the EEC did not have a great deal of latitude even to increase further that type of support. Grain support takes up the largest area in the EEC-for example, nearly 60 per cent of arable land in the EEC is devoted to growing wheat. In other words, wheat is one of the EEC's prime crops and yet it takes only 0.7 per cent of the gross national product to support that common agricultural policy in transferring resources from the taxpayers of the EEC to the growers of wheat in the EEC. So the EEC has a fair amount of latitude still to increase its support in this area. The projections are that it is unlikely to increase areas under crop. Indeed, it will probably start to pull back in that area.
