When one looks at the projections, particularly going through to the end of the 1980s, one still finds a projection on worked markets of an increase in the EEC's net export of some 10 million tonnes probably by the 1987-88 growing season. Since Australia produces not much more than that in terms of its export market we are looking at a particularly important area that we have to come to grips with and to take account of. I think in this area-I mentioned this earlier today during the debate on the Dried Fruits Export Charges Amendment Bill-we cannot go along with the assumption that the ups and downs of the market will enable us to live through these types of problems. We are in a situation where we will have to fight for every export market that we get; we will have to fight to hold those markets and we will have to fight doubly hard to create new markets particularly in Asian countries.

We have been fortunate in terms of the Australian Wheat Board and some of the gains that have been made from time to time in that area. But I point out that the most spectacular gains that have been made have not been made so much through the ability of the Board and grain sellers to sell wheat as through the failing crops in specific countries, namely, China and Russia. I do not think it is good enough for us to sit and wait for a disastrous harvest in one of those countries so that we can maintain our wheat industry at the level to which it has grown. I believe that we have to go out and aggressively seek markets for our wheat in a way that we have not done in the past.

talk.start.para: â€”We have to find buyers who can pay for it.

â€”It is for this reason that the Australian Democrats support the Bill, Senator. It will give us an added ability in that area and will complement the initiatives that the Government took earlier this year in changing a number of the statutory boards, some of which are in this area, to enable them to become single sellers on the overseas market. This has always plagued many of these areas in that we have sold against one another, against producers within this country, to our own detriment on international markets.

speech.para: The Australian Democrats support the initiative of the Government in this area. We hope that, with the streamlining that the Government has proposed, coupled with the previous initiatives of the Government, we will have the best possible marketing structure and the utmost flexibility with the Australian Wheat Board to undertake a task which will not be easy. I certainly acknowledge that. It is a task which will be absolutely vital to the enormous wheat industry in this country. We wholeheartedly support the Government's initiatives in this area and hope that the Australian Wheat Board will be able to live up to the type of power which it now has under this legislation actually to undertake the growth or the maintenance of our overseas export market.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I will be even shorter than Senator Grimes on the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill. I thank all honourable senators on both sides of the House for their magnificent support of this legislation. I wish the Bill a speedy passage.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

proctext.para: Clauses 1 to 4-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 5 (Powers of Board).

speech.speaker: Rae Sen P.E.

talk.start.para: â€”In clause 5, we have a situation where extra powers will be given to the Australian Wheat Board in relation to trading in futures-which it has been doing for some time-for hedging purposes and also an opportunity to trade in the financial futures markets. I do not dispute at the moment the importance to Australian wheat growers under the present world wheat trading system of there being some capacity on the part of the Wheat Board to be able to engage in what is one of the very risky areas of activity.

speech.para: Anybody who has played the futures markets either in gold, commodities or whatever it may be, knows that, whilst there are possibilities for gains, there are also significant possibilities for losses. I acknowledge that the world wheat trade is a rather different situation with a more limited number of people . Significant risks are inherent in futures trading. The Wheat Board has, to date, apparently been able to hedge to the benefit of the growers. I ask the following question of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner): What would happen if the Wheat Board operated outside the guidelines that are provided and, as a result of its operation outside those guidelines that are provided in the proposed legislation, suffered a significant loss? If it does suffer a loss-I hope that the Senate will acknowledge that futures trading is something which can be subject to losses as well as benefits-who will be responsible for the loss which is so incurred? Would it be the taxpayers of Australia? Let us remember that the amounts we are talking about involve billions of dollars in wheat sales. How much is traded in the futures market will vary from time to time and from year to year, but the total amount of the trade is very large indeed.

Who is being placed at risk? Who will pick up the tab if there is a massive disaster? Will it be the taxpayers or the wheat growers? If the action is taken outside the guidelines provided in the Bill, will the responsibility lie with the individual members of the Australian Wheat Board? If the last is correct-as I understand it there are significant legal opinions to the effect that it is correct-are we not perhaps imposing on the individual members of the Wheat Board a liability which could place them in a most invidious position? I am not opposing appropriate futures trading on behalf of Australian wheat growers and the sale of the wheat crop.

The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, in looking into this, heard evidence about the way in which the futures operation is conducted. The Committee did not make an adverse report in relation to it, but rather expressed some interest and concern that it is a business which needs to be carefully dealt with. I therefore ask: First, what happens if there is a loss while operating within the guidelines; and secondly, and more importantly, if they operate outside the legislative guidelines, who carries the can, who picks up the loss, which could conceivably be quite massive?

talk.start.para: â€”Senator Rae rightly draws our attention to the problem that could arise in a situation in which the Australian Wheat Board operates outside the guidelines. That is a matter of very considerable concern to us all. However, essentially, there is within the guidelines the provision that the Minister would be informed of any breach of the guidelines and the kind of situation that was outlined by Senator Rae. This would lead, therefore, to the intervention of the Minister in the kinds of circumstances which he outlined.
â€”Are you saying that the Minister would be responsible? I am talking about financial responsibility.

â€”Obviously, the risk relies totally on the fact that the producers would be in a position of having to share the loss in the normal course. But the point is: Would it be a catastrophic loss? Would it be the kind of situation which would lead to a major disruption of the industry? It is that sort of point that the guidelines seek to address. I think the proper point to make, which I am sure Senator Rae would be interested in, is that in the end through those guidelines this kind of activity which might be carried on by a statutory body which, ostensibly, might be acting on its own, and any breach of the guidelines would be brought within the ambit of political control. The Minister would be advised of the situation in the event of a breach.

â€”It seems to me that what the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) said in reply to Senator Rae was that the first safeguard was that the members of the Australian Wheat Board would report to the Minister for Primary Industry if they went outside the guidelines and that that was some sort of safety provision. I want to know and I suppose other honourable senators want to know what happens if the members of the Board, as has been known to happen with such boards in this country, go outside the guidelines and either do not notify the Minister or notify the Minister very late and, as a result, suffer what could be a catastrophic loss of money. As Senator Rae pointed out, in the wheat futures trade the risks can be very high and the amounts of money involved can be very high. Under these circumstances, who is responsible for such loss-the members of the Board, the wheat producers who contribute to the Board or the taxpayers through the Government?

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill provides that if the Australian Wheat Board operates outside the approved futures market guidelines and incurs losses those losses will be excluded from the net pool return and be borne by the growers when the net pool return rate for the season is above the guaranteed minimum price.

speech.para: The Bill is silent on who bears the losses. But when the GMP is above the net pool return rate is it not customary to include a legislative provision covering an eventuality which is not authorised by legislation. The remedy would depend very much on the size of the loss and on the circumstances at the time. One possible option is for the Board to draw on the reserves of the organisation for that purpose. That is the point which I sought to make during Senator Peter Rae' s remarks. A further point is that there is regular reporting to the political controller, that is, the Minister responsible.

speech.speaker: Rae Sen P.E.

talk.start.para: â€”If we are to rely upon regular reporting all I can say is that history will cause every alarm bell imaginable to ring in relation to the Australian Wheat Board. Until the Wheat Board can get itself sorted out and have even the good sense to let people who are interested, and who it knows are interested, know when it is yet again having trouble producing its annual financial statements or getting an audit certificate I do not believe we can have great confidence that that system upon which the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) says we can rely can be relied upon. I find it somewhat alarming that the Minister has indicated in effect that if there is a massive loss the wheatgrowers will pay. The safeguard is that if the Board went outside the guidelines the Minister for Primary Industry would be advised. Nothing in the history of not only this organisation but also, as Senator Grimes said, some others would indicate that this Parliament should have great faith that that would in fact happen.

speech.para: I believe this provision regularises something which has been happening for some time, which has happened so far with a history of no known disaster. Before we give it the legislative imprimatur indefinitely I think we ought to signal to those who will operate it that a very careful watch will be kept on how it operates. It may be that this chamber ought to adopt the attitude that after this provision has been in operation for a period one of the Senate committees ought to be requested to look at whether it is operating successfully or whether some legislative amendment is needed perhaps to provide for the point which I have raised about who covers the loss, how risky it is or what sorts of assessments are made as to what we are exposing somebody to. Finally, I ask the Minister quite definitely whether it is not a fact that the opinion of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) is that the individual Board members would be responsible for the loss, and has that advice not been received by the Department of Primary Industry?

talk.start.para: â€”As a member of the Australian Labor Party and a democratic socialist I have no objection to orderly marketing procedures and to organisations such as the Australian Wheat Board ensuring--
â€”That is not the subject matter of the debate.

â€”I know; I am coming to it. I have no objection to organisations ensuring that orderly market procedures are conducted. But when the board which is set up to do that enters into a risky situation such as the futures market in order to hedge the risks, as Senator Peter Rae has said, we are in a very different situation. Under those circumstances we need-I echo the words of Senator Peter Rae-a much stricter and more regular form of reporting than we have had in the past. We simply cannot rely on the records of organisations such as the Australian Wheat Board and other boards which have consistently reported to this place so late that it has been beyond the Parliament's ability to do anything about it in many ways except to refer the matter to the committee to which I am sure Senator Peter Rae was referring. In the future we will have to insist that this Parliament, as well as the Minister for Primary Industry, get regular reports so that we are not beset with a catastrophic loss which leaves us impotent and able only to pick up the tab on behalf of the general taxpayer. To suggest that even the wheat growers or the individual members of that Board could pick up the sorts of losses which potentially exist in this area is in fact nonsense. It gets back to the fact that the taxpayers will have to pick them up.

â€”I think that Senator Rae has raised an extremely important point. However, from what I know and have looked at in terms of futures trading in the wheat market I do not think that necessarily an analogy, with, say, silver, could actually hold as hard as we might think. Grain is involved in a different type of futures market. I am taken by Senator Rae's suggestion that Parliament in some way ought to be advised or have some type of overview of the early operations of this legislation. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) might respond in some way-for example, during the Budget session next year-and make a statement to the Parliament in terms of the operation of this Bill over the year so that we could get an early understanding of how it is running and the types of problems the Australian Wheat Board itself may see as likely to occur. If that initial step were taken the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations might not necessarily be involved in prolonged investigation. After the Minister made a statement the Committee could determine whether it was necessary for it to undertake further investigations. I wonder whether the Minister for Primary Industry will respond to the suggestion that this matter be discussed during the Budget session next year?

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I am quite happy to refer Senator Macklin's comments to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) and obtain a reply to the point which he has raised. I point out both for the benefit of Senator Grimes and Senator Rae that the Act which this Bill seeks to amend provides for a review within two years of the operations of this legislation. Consequently, there will be an opportunity to examine actions which are taken in the next two years and which may result from the issues which Senator Rae has been making very clear tonight. Senator Rae asked a specific question about advice from the Attorney-General's Department. My advice is that no advice has been received from the Department on that point.

speech.para: Clause agreed to.
Clause 6.

talk.start.para: â€”Clause 6 is quite interesting.
â€”Interesting enough at 9 o'clock to justify a major excursion?

â€”After some of the things that have taken place in this chamber in the past fortnight I would have thought that trying to carry out the role of the Senate by looking at the clauses of a Bill and asking some questions about the operation of one of our largest statutory authorities and a major part of our export industry was not unreasonable.
â€”How did we manage without you for the two months you were away?

â€”I am not sure, looking at some of the things that have happened, that honourable senators managed all that well actually. Proposed new section 12A omits some of the words in section 12 of the principal Act and changes others. Would the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) briefly outline the reasons for those changes? When he has done that, I would like to raise the question of the reserve.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”In the course of the second reading speech of the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) when he put the Bill down the point made was:

speech.para: The Bill enables the Board to deduct monies from the proceeds of the sale of wheat and wheat products and create reserves that can be used for specific purposes . . .
The Board will be required to disclose the details of each reserve in its financial statements which will be published in its annual reports to Parliament .
Provisions have been made in the Bill so that the Government's financial liability under the Guaranteed Minimum Price arrangements will not be increased as a result of deductions made for reserves.

I think if we are looking at the management in a prudent way of an organisation of the size and, certainly, the magnitude of the Australian Wheat Board we are looking at a situation where reserves are most important in the continuing operation of the Board. Consequently, policies as to management of those reserves and the manner in which they might be invested and certainly the way in which they are accounted for are tremendously important not only to this Parliament but also to the nation. Certainly, I believe that would be of great concern to the Committee of which Senator Peter Rae is the Chairman-the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. In those events we have a situation where, no doubt, the prudent maintenance of vigilance by this Parliament and by that Committee over the affairs and, certainly, the allocation of reserves by the Wheat Board of surpluses from time to time is a very important question as it touches on the amounts which would be returned to growers on a year to year basis.

The maintenance of reserves and their investment, I must say, are matters for individual concern. They are certainly matters which would be examined from time to time, no doubt, in this place. The accountability is being established by this legislation. Certainly, increased surveillance over the strategies and the policies of investment in this area are matters which are set forth in the legislation. I am not sure what Senator Peter Rae has in mind specifically in the points he seeks to raise but I take the point generally. The clauses of this legislation touch very important issues within the prudent management of the Wheat Board in the future.

talk.start.para: â€”I move then, having received that answer and letting it go by, to some of the specific matters in relation to the power to create reserves. The first point I refer to is that one of the reserves to be created in fact legalises what was the Ceres House reserve which was identified by the Auditor-General as an illegal reserve which had been established by the Australian Wheat Board which, apparently, now is to be legal. Also, provision is made for the import loss reserve. Apparently, both of those reserves are regarded as prudent capacities for the Wheat Board in its overall management. But apparently it has also been accepted that they will be managed without the necessity for prior ministerial approval for the creation of those reserves. I ask: Why is this change being brought about? Why has the change been made from a situation where ministerial approval was required to one where there is no requirement at all for there to be ministerial approval in relation to the creation of this type of reserve? Is it that the Government's new policy in relation to the Wheat Board is to give the Board the utmost autonomy or is this a change where this has slipped by by inadvertence? Is there some other explanation as to why there is now a distancing from the degree of management, including these sorts of things previously questioned by the Auditor-General which the Wheat Board can do without even consulting the Minister let alone getting his approval?

â€”Some of the points which Senator Peter Rae has raised just now are points which I think require further examination. I suggest that the best way to handle this matter is for me to take the issues that the honourable senator raised, forward them to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) and obtain a reply for Senator Peter Rae. I just say, though, specifically on the points of depreciation--
â€”The creation of reserves without ministerial approval including the Ceres House reserve and the import loss reserve.
â€”In the event of there being the kinds of reserves to which the honourable senator is referring, I understand that all new reserves are subject to appropriate ministerial approval.

â€”I do not want to hold up the passage of the Bill or delay honourable senators but I do not want this legislation to go through unnoticed and uncared for. A number of matters of importance need to be addressed. I beleive that when the answers have been given there are ways in which we can look at this legislation again if it is not working properly and the answers are not satisfactory. But if it is suggested that this is to be subject to some form of ministerial approval that is provided for not in this clause but in some later section-the answer might be given that the Minister is required to approve the form of accounts-I can only say that that would be a very weak and inadequate answer. As Senator Messner would well know and accept, to approve the form of accounts is not approve the creation of a reserve. I simply make this point: If, as it seems to me, there is no requirement to obtain approval, why is there not to be? Why has the change been made? What is the safeguard? What is the policy in relation to it? I leave the matter there for the moment.

speech.speaker: McLaren Sen G.T.

talk.start.para: â€”I do not intend to enter into a discussion of the legalities of the clause but Senator Peter Rae has prompted me to rise because, on several occasions, he has said that certain provisions of the Bill should set the alarm bells ringing. I know that Senator Peter Rae has had a deep interest in the Australian Wheat Board ever since I have been a member of the Senate and quite often has referred the annual reports of the Board to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. I would have thought that, given all the occasions on which his Committee has had those reports before it, some concrete recommendations would have gone forward to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) and we would not have been faced with the problem that faces us tonight. Senator Peter Rae speaks about setting the alarm bells ringing. They should be set ringing in the minds of wheat growers--
â€”A number of very concrete proposals have gone forward. Some have been responded to, some are being applied in the Bill and in regard to some we are awaiting an answer.

â€”I accept Senator Peter Rae's explanation. I repeat, if any alarm bells are to be set ringing among the wheat growers it should be because moves are afoot to undermine the Board, and to market wheat outside of its control. That always goes on in times of great shortage such as we are experiencing now. There is never any problem in selling wheat when there is a drought such as we have now, or a bad season in other countries, but when we have over-production, as we often do, the Board is looked to for help by all wheat growers. There is then no criticism of it, except the criticism that it cannot find enough markets for the product.

speech.para: We should take cognisance of the fact that the Act that we are discussing tonight has been in operation for 35 years. It was conceived by the late Reg Pollard, as a member of the Chifley Government in 1947. Surely, if there are any weaknesses in it they should have been found long ago. If we cannot improve this legislation the wheat growers will be in serious trouble.

I take note of what Senator Peter Rae has said and refer again to the alarm bells that he mentions. In the light of what he has said tonight, about this clause in particular, the farmers' organisations ought to be getting very busy making strong representations to the Minister so that when next the Bill comes before the Parliament it will be so watertight that it will be one that will always safeguard the interests of the wheat growers and will not contain loopholes whereby people who are trying to white-ant orderly marketing in Australia will be able to bring about the demise of the Australian Wheat Board. If that ever happens, rather than the taxpayers being obliged to pay out great amounts of money because of the Board indulging in futures, to which Senator Peter Rae referred, they will be faced with very large bills in order to bail the wheat farmers of this country out of their problems. I hope that, the Minister having replied to the questions that Senator Peter Rae has posed, when next amending legislation on this subject comes before the Senate it will be such that no honourable senator will want to stand here and criticise it.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 7 (Advance payment for wheat of season other than last 2 seasons).

speech.speaker: Rae Sen P.E.

talk.start.para: â€”I raise somewhat similar questions to those which I raised in relation to clause 6. Why does it appear that the old principles which applied have been withdrawn and that the Australian Wheat Board , if it so chose, would be free, without having to obtain ministerial approval and without being subject to the direct scrutiny by the Department of Primary Industry that that involves, to make decisions which could-looking at the structure which is being created by the legislation-enable manipulations of payments and funds between payouts and reserves in which a fairly free and liberal situation of management may be created?
â€”Small 'l'.

â€”Small 'l' liberal. Timely reporting is all the more important when those sorts of powers have been given. Giving these sorts of powers, which are not subject to ministerial or departmental scrutiny, to a board that has still not been able to sort out its accountancy situation so that it can produce timely financial statements makes me say that it is something that I believe this chamber ought to have brought to its attention. This chamber ought to take a continuing interest in the operation of such a body.

speech.para: Clause agreed to.
Clause 8 (Final payment for wheat of season other than last 2 seasons).

talk.start.para: â€”I again ask why the amendment is deleting the need for the approval of the Minister? One is almost tempted-with the history of the involvement of the Auditor-General, the work that has been done by officers of the Auditor-General's Office and the battle that has taken place with the Australian Wheat Board, giving the impression of resistance to a lot of the inquiries of the Auditor-General and even the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations-to ask whether this is simply to avoid the Board being subject to the scrutiny of the Auditor-General? If this is the case, would it not be prudent, at least for the time being, for the legislation to require the Minister and the Department of Primary Industry to have some involvement until the Wheat Board has a record of performance which would justify the confidence which is being placed in it by this proposal?

â€”I again acknowledge Senator Rae's interest and the point that he raises on this very important question of ministerial control. I will again refer that issue to the Minister for Primary Industry for his direct remarks. I think we need to acknowledge in this situation that we are talking about progress payments to growers. These are matters of management operations and not specifically of the kinds of things which demand immediate attention by Ministers. Nevertheless, the matter is of importance. Acknowledging Senator Peter Rae's interest in it, I will certainly refer it to the Minister for Primary Industry.

â€”Without stretching my luck or disturbing the peace in any way, I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs whether he could set a timetable for this. There has been interest from other sections of the chamber in relation to these matters. Can the Minister indicate that he will refer these matters to the Minister for Primary Industry and report back to the chamber before the end of the second week of the autumn session? I also ask the Minister : Is that reasonable? If not, does he have some other suggestion?

interject.speaker: Senator Messner

talk.start.para: â€”I am happy to give that undertaking.

interject.para: Clauses 9 to 15-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 16 (Application to Board of Division 2 of Part XI of Audit Act).

speech.speaker: Rae Sen P.E.

talk.start.para: â€”I draw the attention of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) that clause 16, involving a new section 54 ( 1) AA is a matter which falls within the remarks I have previously made and which I will not elaborate on. I draw attention to that provision as part of a group.

speech.para: Clause agreed to.
Clause 17 (Remuneration and allowances of authorised receivers).

talk.start.para: -This clause deals with a matter which has been of some concern in the past. The Auditor-General qualified the accounts of the Australian Wheat Board because of the problem of reconciling stocks and payments in relation to the joint arrangement between the Commonwealth authority and the State authorities; that is, the Australian Wheat Board and the grain handling authorities and receivers in the States. What is proposed here is somewhat curious. A meeting was held at the instigation and suggestion of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations between all of the people involved in this to try to sort out a workable system to overcome the problems which were identified by the Auditor-General. I note from the minutes of the meeting that the problems do not appear to have been resolved at the meeting. The present proposal does not seem to flow from anything which is logical, on the knowledge which I have about the matter. It may be that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) can correct me. I acknowledge that he has been brought into this matter at very short notice tonight. If he is not in a position to answer tonight, will he add this question to the list? Why do we have a position where apparently the remuneration is to be determined by the recipient, by agreement, but it changes the pre-existing arrangement and is, as at the present state of affairs, not subject to any form of audit by an Auditor-General at State level which would enable there to be a determination of the reasonableness of the price being paid to the person performing the services by the wheat growers of Australia? At the moment I cannot understand why this is so. If the Minister is in a position to advise why this has been done, that is okay, but it does not seem to accord with what was agreed to and dealt with at the meeting held in April of this year. It does not seem to be explained by the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill or by the second reading speech, and I look forward to a reply.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The transfer of residual stocks of wheat from one season's pool to another enables the earlier finalisation of pools and reduces the administrative costs of operating those pools. I think Senator Rae would acknowledge that point. Obviously, that would be of significant benefit to producers. As to the financial control and the accountability which he outlines, I acknowledge his point about the management in each State. Of course there are provisions whereby each State makes its own arrangements in relation to rates and what have you. Obviously that would affect the accounting procedures within individual States.

speech.para: As to auditing and the provision of auditors in each State, that is provided for. Senator Rae's question-he should forgive me if I am wrong-relates to the provision of the Federal Auditor-General in relation to those activities. I would like to hear from him specifically how he sees that the present arrangements are not specifically running in any way counter to the way in which he envisages that they ought to run.

talk.start.para: -This is the last point I wish to raise. I hope I can deal with it quite briefly. The Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill is changing a situation in which apparently the Wheat Board was the basic one to determine the payment to the authorised receiver to one in which the authorised receiver is the person who basically determines the remuneration which he will get for his services. That is as though we were putting matters into a market situation in which somebody performing a service could say: 'I will charge a price and if you do not like it you can go somewhere else'. That obviously is not the situation with wheat marketing and the handling of wheat receivals. If my understanding is incorrect I should like the matter explained, but that is the way the legislation reads as it stands at the moment. Further, if the receiver happens to overpay, from whom could there be a recovery if there were a mistake? There was plenty of evidence produced by the Auditor-General of massive mistakes being made in the past in relation to the operation of the wheat marketing scheme. If there were a mistake under this new amendment how could it be picked up? How could the money be recovered? It is my understanding that there is no power to recover an overpayment, as the legislation exists at the moment. If there is a power to recover it I am sure it would be interesting, but otherwise it looks as though the taxpayer may have to pick it up again.
â€”Why didn't you oppose the Bill in the party room, because of all these weaknesses?

â€”I did not see the Bill in the party room. I was not in Australia at the time it was introduced, as the honourable senator probably knows. I have seen it in the past couple of weeks since I arrived back.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I shall deal with the point concerning recoverability. I think Senator Peter Rae asked a very legitimate question. I shall seek to get specific information on that matter. I understand the difficulty to be that this is a question of individual States and their specific legislation in this area. Whilst the means of payment and the arrangements between the people actually making the payment and the receiver is a matter for individual State arrangements, as Senator Peter Rae outlined, the point he made would be well covered by the arrangements between the States in that situation. I would need to get further information on that specific point. I will endeavour to do so and bring down a reply for the honourable senator.
â€”And the overpayment question?
â€”Yes.

speech.para: Clause agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

proctext.para: Bill (on motion by Senator Messner) read a third time.
Proposed Tabling of Papers

interject.speaker: The PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: â€”I have received a letter from the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Anthony). The letter is as follows:

interject.para: I refer to your letters of 25 November 1982 to the Minister for Social Security and to the Minister for Finance. In those letters you transmitted the text of a resolution agreed to by the Senate on that day relating to the tabling of papers connected with tax avoidance and evasion. The letters were acknowledged by the Ministers on 7 December 1982, by letters which indicated that the Government's response would be made as soon as possible.

The Government has given careful consideration to the resolution and to the purported directions contained in it to the two Ministers in their respective capacities as Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General and Minister representing the Treasurer. On behalf of the Government, I am writing to let you know that its position has not changed from that outlined to the Senate by the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General on 14 October and 25 November 1982. I attach the relevant extracts of Hansard.

The Government does not seek, nor wish, a confrontation with the Senate over the tax documents. The responsibility for the investigation and prosecution of possible breaches of the law is vested by the Constitution in the Executive Government. It is an integral part of these responsibiities for the Government to decide what government documents of a legal or investigative character can properly be released in the public interest so as not to prejudice the conduct of legal proceedings that may be brought against alleged offenders against the laws of the Commonwealth. The Government is under the further obligation not to prejudice the fair trial of any alleged offender by the release of information that might reasonably be considered to be prejudicial to his fair trial.

The Senate resolution purports to direct the Government in the manner in which it should exercise its Executive functions. The Government's view is that the Senate does not have the power under the Constitution to determine the manner in which Executive functions are carried out.

The Solicitor-General has advised in relation to all the documents sought ( except the tax investigation report, which he has not seen) that disclosure of their contents would be 'harmful to the administration of justice'. The injury which could be caused to parties in the prosecutions by their release could not in his view 'be avoided by excising names'. Several of the documents sought relate to the Perth matter referred to in the Report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. Criminal proceedings have already been commenced in that matter.

The Commissioner of Taxation considers that the same argument applies with greater force to the tax investigation report, which itself deals with the Perth matter. Moreover, he considers that, given that the identity of the individuals concerned in that matter is now public, 'any information at all provided in a so -called ''sanitized'' version would . . . offend against s.16 (of the Income Tax Assessment Act)'. Because of this, the Commissioner considers s.16 prevents him from handing that document to the Minister for the purposes of the resolution. The result is that the resolution purports to direct the Ministers to produce a document which the Commissioner considers cannot lawfully be given to them.

The Government has demonsrated that it is fulfilling its constitutional responsibility. A Special Prosecutor has been appointed to bring prosecutions in relation to 'bottom-of-the-harbour schemes'. As mentioned above, proceedings have already been commenced in relation to the Perth matter referred to in the Royal Commission report. The Special Prosecutor has announced his intention of investigating the activities of all promoters of 'bottom-of-the-harbour schemes' and of initiating prosecutions as appropriate as soon as possible.

The Government hopes that those Senators who voted in the majority for the 25 November resolution would recognise that under the Constitution the Government has the responsibility for enforcing the laws of the Commonwealth and for determining, in the manner in which it considers appropriate, and for which it bears responsibility, whether the release of documents would prejudice that responsiblity. The Government also hopes that those Senators would therefore not continue to seek to direct Ministers contrary to their constitutional responsibility as members of the Executive.

In the event that a Senate majority seeks to enforce the directions contained in the resolution of 25 November 1982, the Government intends to put the basic legal and constitutional questions in relation to the Senate's powers before the High Court of Australia.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen G.J.

talk.start.para: â€”by leave -I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the statement.

In moving the motion, I state briefly that I find it fascinating that the Government should have chosen to rely not on doctrine of Executive privilege but upon the constitutional high ground that it marked out in its earlier contribution to this debate. I am reminded of the distinction that Jeremy Bentham once drew between mere nonsense, on the one hand, and in the context of natural law, what he described as nonsense on stilts. I cannot forbear but comment that this contribution to the nation's constitutional jurisprudence from the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) satisfies that latter description. The Senate, confronted with a claim of this character, ought to do something that obviously cannot be discussed without some further and better thought. For that reason, I do not seek this evening to set in train any procedures. But I think it might be possible for some appropriate reaction to be given tomorrow. I give warning, if that is the appropriate word, to the Government that we may well seek to bring on this matter for debate tomorrow. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

debate.title: CONCILIATION AND ARBITRATION (COMPLEMENTARY INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS SYSTEM) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

proctext.para: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Messner) read a first time.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Mr President, the amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act proposed by this Bill seek to address aspects of one of the fundamental structural problems of the Australian industrial relations system, the multiplicy of industrial jurisdictions.

The broad purpose of the Bill is to foster greater co-ordination in the work of Federal and State industrial tribunals. This is a significant goal, but it is one which of course cannot be accomplished by means of Commonwealth legislation alone. The wider significance of the legislation is to be found in the agreement of the Commonwealth and the States to enact complementary legislation on the matter. The measures proposed by this Bill provide the response to the implementation of that agreement which is required of the Commonwealth.

The concepts which underly the provision made in this Bill emanate from consultative arrangements entered into by the Commonwealth and the States with a view to finding means whereby a more complementary system of industrial relations might be brought about.

Honourable senators may know something of these arrangements and the background to the legislation. The Premiers' Conference in June 1979 agreed that Commonwealth and State Ministers for Labour should conduct a review on the question of fundamental changes to the Australian industrial relations system, and the Commonwealth/State Review of Industrial Relations Systems was established.

The Working Party set up to carry out this Review put forward a wide range of proposals for consideration by Ministers during 1979-81. These proposals were considered by the National Labour Consultative Council. While consideration was being given by the Commonwealth and the States to a proposed National Inquiry into Wage Determination and Industrial Relations, the review established by the Premiers was suspended.

The Premiers' Conference in February 1982 decided, however, not to proceed with the proposed Inquiry, but agreed that a Working Party of Commonwealth and State officials be established with the following terms of reference:
'To examine and report on steps which could be taken to achieve:
(i) a complementary industrial relations system within Australia;
(ii) more effective liaison between State and Commonwealth industrial jurisdictions.'

The Premiers' Conference requested that the Report of the Working Party be presented to the June Premiers' Conference. The Working Party reported to the Conference of Labour Ministers in May 1982 and the report was unanimously adopted by the Ministers who agreed upon its submission to the Premiers. The June 1982 Premiers' Conference agreed to implementation of the recommendations contained in the Report.

I should say, Mr President, that the spirit of co-operation which was evident at all stages of the development of the proposals now reflected in the Bill, and at the June 1982 Premiers' Conference, gives promise of further co-operative proposals to bring about a more effective industrial relations system for Australia. The officers' Working Party is continuing to meet and I am confident that further proposals of significance will emerge.

I might now turn, Mr President, to consider briefly the character of the industrial problems with which this Bill is concerned. While well recognized in the industrial relations community, they are not generally clearly perceived by the community at large.

The power of the Commonwealth to legislate with respect to industrial relations matters is limited to the enactment of laws for the prevention and settlement of interstate industrial disputes by conciliation and arbitration. Disputes which are wholly within a single State cannot be dealt with by the Federal Commission and not all matters which may be in dispute between employers and employees are ''industrial'' within the meaning of the Constitution. Outside the permissible scope of Commonwealth law the State Legislatures have wide powers. All States have established tribunals to deal with industrial disputes and in each State there are organisations (which may or may not be registered) of employers and employees operating wholly within the State.

Particular consequences of these arrangements are first, that no one tribunal, Commonwealth or State, may have jurisdiction to deal with what is in effect but may not be in law a single dispute or with closely related disputes, and that second, it is difficult to co-ordinate the decision-making activities of the tribunals and to bring about uniformity in the principles and policies applied.

Some efforts have been made in recent years to ameliorate the problems arising from the divided industrial jurisdictions and to bring about a measure of co- ordination in the work of industrial tribunals. The President of the Australian Commission, Sir John Moore, has since 1976 convened meetings of the Heads of Commonwealth and State industrial tribunals. Initially held annually, the meetings are now convened each 6 months and have been widely supported as effective in promoting co-operation and co-ordination between tribunals. Furthermore, to meet particular industrial situations, such as where part of an industry is covered by a State and part by a Federal award, or because one of 2 unions competing for work was covered by State and not Federal registration, the Australian Commission has conducted joint conferences and joint hearings on an informal basis with an industrial tribunal in a State. It is desirable that such a practice be put on a statutory footing.
Mr President, for the benefit of honourable senators, I will proceed now to outline the particular provisions made by this Bill. In short, the Bill provides for:
joint sittings of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and a State Tribunal;
expansion of the powers of Local Industrial Boards (when constituted by a State Industrial Authority) to permit them to exercise Federal jurisdiction;
the exercise, by agreement, of State jurisdiction by the Australian Commission.
JOINT PROCEEDINGS OF COMMONWEALTH AND STATE TRIBUNALS

The provisions made by the Bill are intended to provide a proper statutory footing for the conduct of a joint sitting of a State tribunal and the Commonwealth Commission. In terms of the proposal developed by the Working Party it is envisaged that each tribunal, while it would sit with the other and hear the matter simultaneously, would exercise only the powers conferred by its own constitutive legislation and would make a separate decision (though ideally in identical terms) in its own jurisdiction. The appeal, reference and review provisions applicable by reasons of the constitutive legislation of each tribunal would apply to a decision made in the jurisdiction.

The provision made in the Bill, while guaranteeing the validity of the joint sitting arrangement, does not fetter the discretion of the President of the Commission in deciding to initiate a joint sitting or to respond to a request from a State Tribunal for such a sitting. Similarly the President is not limited in his capacity to determine the timing of a joint sitting such as whether the sitting is to be held at the conciliation or arbitration stage of proceedings-or as to termination of the sitting.

The Government considers that such a provision will be of considerable utility in circumstances referred to above, such as where State and Federal unions are involved in a demarcation dispute or where neither the Federal or State jurisdiction has complete coverage of an industry. In the latter case, a joint sitting could be convened in such circumstances as where:

A Federally registered union makes an application to the Commission for variation of an award and proceedings have commenced in a State industrial jurisdiction in respect of a State award or determination dealing with employees in occupations the same or similar to those in which members of the Federal union are engaged;

A log of claims is served by a Federally registered union, a dispute is notified in the Federal Commission and proceedings have commenced in a State tribunal in respect of an award or determination dealing with employees in the same or similar categories of work to those covered in the Federal log.
POWERS OF LOCAL INDUSTRIAL BOARDS

Under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act as it stands a member of the Commission may refer a matter to a Local Industrial Board for investigation and report. A Local Industrial Board may be constituted by Representatives of employers and employees with a Chairman, or by a State Industrial Authority.

New arrangements proposed by the Bill will permit the President of the Commission to refer a matter to a Local Industrial Board constituted by a State Industrial authority and that Authority will be empowered to settle the dispute by conciliation or arbitration or both as appropriate. In performing these functions the Local Industrial Board will be exercising Federal jurisdiction and will be able to exercise powers under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.

The principal benefits of such an arrangement are twofold. First, circumstances may arise in which a member of the Australian Commission is not immediately available to deal with a dispute but a member of the State Industrial Authority is able to proceed to deal with the matter at short notice. Disputes occurring in remote locations are particularly amenable to such proceedings. Second, situations arise in which a dispute at a local level may affect both State and Federal jurisdictions (such as where employees in a single enterprise are covered by both State and Federal awards) and it is appropriate for a member of a State tribunal to proceed to settle the matter in both jurisdictions.
EMPOWERING OF FEDERAL COMMISSION TO DEAL WITH DISPUTES IN A STATE JURISDICTION

As part of the agreement reached by the Commonwealth and the States it is envisaged that, in appropriate circumstances, the President of a State Industrial authority would be able to request the President of the Commission to exercise the jurisdiction of the State tribunal. In such circumstances the powers of the member of the commission exercising the State jurisdiction would be given by the legislation of the State concerned.

Mr President, it is intended that the powers of the Australian Commission in relation to the Joint Proceedings and Local Industrial Board provision made by this Bill will be exercised only in relation to such State Industrial authorities as are prescribed. As State Parliaments enact legislation to give effect to the agreement as to Complementary Industrial Relations Systems, the Commonwealth will, for its part, make regulations to give force to the amendments proposed by this Bill in respect of particular State industrial tribunals.

As I suggested at the outset, Mr President, the significance of this Bill lies perhaps as much in the fact that it is a manifestation of a co-operative approach by the Commonwealth and the States to the resolution of industrial relations problems as in the specific provision made. The Government is optimistic that this process will continue and bear further fruit.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sibraa) adjourned.

debate.title: CONCILIATION AND ARBITRATION (GOVERNMENT SERVICE) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

proctext.para: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Messner) read a first time.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I move:

speech.para: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This legislation is designed to repeal the Public Service Arbitration Act 1920 and to vest the jurisdiction under that Act on the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

These amendments recognize that the structure and range of Commonwealth Public Service employment and the functions of the Public Service Arbitrator have changed considerably since the establishment of a separate jurisdiction of the Public Service Arbitrator in 1920. Honourable Senators will recall that the Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration took the same view in its Report of 1976 and recommended that action be taken along the lines of this legislation.

What is proposed is a natural progression from the statutory links between the jurisdictions of the Arbitrator and of the Commission (and of the Arbitration Court before it) that were established in the 1950's when the system of appeals and references to the Commission from the Arbitrator was introduced. A further alignment occurred between the jurisdictions in 1972 when the concept of an industrial situation was injected into the Public Service Arbitration Act to give the Arbitrator scope to deal with industrial action in the public sector.
The legislation has been the subject of intensive examination by the NLCC and a special Committee of the Council. The ACTU supports the Bill's objectives.

Mr President, a new Division 1A is to be inserted into Part III of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and this will encompass the areas of Commonwealth employment presently covered by the Public Service Arbitration Act. Certain Northern Territory Government Service employment will also be covered by the new Division.

I should point out here-and it is an important point-that certain areas of Commonwealth activity which presently do not come within the scope of the Public Service Arbitration Act will not be the subject of the Commission's jurisdiction under the new Division but will remain within the Commission's general jurisdiction under Division 1 of Part III of the Act. I speak here, for example, of such enterprises as Qantas, the Australian National Line, TAA and the Postal and Telecommunications Commissions. However, provision has been made in the Bill for the transfer by regulation of Commonwealth and Territory authorities and employees as defined between Division 1A and other Divisions of the Act as appropriate.

In addition, provision has been made for the President to have power to arrange for specific matters to be dealt with by a panel in a Division other than 1A and vice versa to cater for situations where it is desirable that similar matters in each Division be heard by the one panel.

I would point out to the Senate that the jurisdiction of the Fire Brigades and the Prison Officers Tribunals in the Northern Territory will not be immediately drawn into the jurisdiction of the Commission. The relevant unions in the Northern Territory are presently covered by separate Tribunals and require time to make the necessary arrangements which will leave them free to move into the Commission's jurisdiction. The Government is prepared to leave the operation of the process of rationalization as to these tribunals in abeyance for the time being. The provisions of the Bill as to them can be brought into operation by Regulation when there has been further consultation about them.
I now turn to the main details of the Bill.

Clause 9 inserts the new Division 1A into Part III of the Act and it will embrace a number of new sections designed to empower the Commission to deal with industrial disputes and industrial matters concerning Commonwealth and Territory employees. Proposed Section 70A contains relevant definitions for these purposes and provides for the exclusion from the new Division 1A of members of the Defence Force, the Australian Postal Commission, the Australian Telecommunications Commission and the Australian National Railways Commission. Other specified Authorities such as the Australian Shipping Commission, if not brought within Division 1A by Regulation will remain within the general jurisdiction of the Commission. Provision has also been made for the exclusion of certain other employees who are not presently within the jurisdiction of the Public Service Arbitrator.

Proposed section 70B removes the limitations imposed by the definition of '' industrial dispute'' and ''industrial matter'' in section 4 of the Act. The new Section 70C extends the Panel system for the hearing and determination of matters to the new Division.

The purpose of new Sections 70G and 70H is to provide for the transfer where appropriate of the hearing and determination of a matter from the new Division to another Division or vice versa. This is similar to the procedures already in the Act which allow the President flexibility in the allocation of matters to be determined.

Section 70J will effectively carry over to Division 1A the powers of the Public Service Arbitrator under section 12D of the Public Service Arbitration Act in relation to orders made to end or prevent industrial action.
Proposed section 70K will give the Commission power to declare terms of awards to be Common Rules for the whole or a part of Government Service.

Clause 5 of the Bill deals with section 36 of the Principal Act and the right of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to intervene in matters before the Commission. The Minister already has such a right in proceedings involving significant matters before the Commission. That right will now be extended to all matters involving disputes in the Commonwealth public sector. This does not mean that the Minister will enter proceedings in all such cases- far from it. But the Government has decided to reserve to itself the right, as a most significant employer and in the public interest generally, to put views to the Commission in relation to its own area of employment.

The other important elements of the Bill are in Clauses 11 and 15. Clause 11 inserts a new sub-section 132 (5) in the Act to provide for the continuance of the registration of associations of less than 100 employees which were registered under the authority of the Public Service Arbitration Act. The registration of such bodies is not to be cancelled by virtue of sub-section 132 (1) (B) of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act unless their membership falls below sixty per cent of the number of employees in the relevant industry in the Public Service.

Clause 15 makes certain transitional arrangements to enable, for example, determinations of the Arbitrator to continue in force and matters pending under the Public Service Arbitration Act before its repeal to be dealt with.
Mr President, when this Bill was before the House, certain amendments were moved by the Minister. These were adopted by the House. The amendments were made to clauses 3, 9 and 11.

Three of these amendments derived from certain matters brought to the Minister' s attention by the ACOA and the ACTU after they had studied the Bill. They represent a response to what was put to the Minister and in discussions that took place between the ACOA and ACTU officials with Departmental officers.
Let me explain in some detail what the amendments were about.

The Public Service Arbitration Act deems public sector employment to be an industry for the purpose of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act so that an organisation may be registered by reference to that industry.

Although the Government Service Bill classes public sector employment to be an industry, the wording of the Bill before amendment restricted that to the prevention and settlement of public sector disputes.

It was not the intention of the Bill to take away the basis for public sector employment being deemed to be in an industry for the purposes of registration of an organisation under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. The amendments rectified those defects.
In a spirit of proper consultation, the terms of the amendments to be moved in the House were given to the ACTU and the ACOA to inform them of the Government's intentions.
There was then some correspondence on technical points between the ACOA and the Department.
The Department received a letter from the ACOA which said, and I quote:
''Generally speaking the drafting satisfies the substantial point raised about the treatment of Australian Government Employment as an industry for purposes of the Act''.

Then the letter went on to, nevertheless, express some reservations about the amendments. The Department replied to that letter. The gist of the reply was that we could see no reason to depart from what was in the amendments ultimately made by the House. The correspondence between the Minister and the ACOA and ACTU and between the Department and the ACOA is available should Honourable Senators wish to see it.

Another amendment adopted by the House and proposed by the Minister stemmed from the Conciliation and Arbitration (Complementary Industrial Relations System ) Amendment Bill 1982 which is presently before the Senate. That Bill inserts a new Section 44B in Division I of Part III of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 empowering the Commission to refer disputes to State Industrial Authorities. The Bill includes provisions excluding the operation of that section in disputes concerning the Snowy Mountains Authority or Commonwealth projects. The amendment adopted by the House is a consequential one and of a formal nature to ensure that the provisions of the Government Service Bill dealing with Commonwealth Government employment are excluded from the operation of section 44B.
Mr President, as I have pointed out, the proposals set out in this Bill have been the subject of detailed consultation with the Labour Movement and have its general endorsement.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Sibraa) adjourned.

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 22 September, on motion by Senator Messner:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

talk.start.para: â€”The Asian Development Fund Bill 1982 is a very important piece of legislation. Through it we propose to make from our 1982-83 Budget a contribution of $212,332,030 towards the Asian Development Fund . Whilst the Opposition does not oppose the Bill, it does have some reservations about the way in which it is proposed that our contribution shall be used by the Asian Development Bank through the agency of the Asian Development Fund. It is true that the Whitlam Labor Government was responsible for the establishment of this Fund in 1974. The motives behind its establishment were of the highest order. The Bill to establish the Fund and the objectives set forth for that Fund were designed to assist in the proper, orderly development of countries in the Asian and Pacific regions. One wonders whether in subsequent years that objective has been properly realised in the allocation of money by what one might call the more developed countries to assist the underdeveloped countries in our region. To that extent the situation with the Asian Development Fund is critical.

speech.para: The original purpose of the Fund was to provide substantial assistance in the creation of infrastructure for the underdeveloped countries in our region-to provide infrastructure such as transport, communication, power and irrigation facilities, water supplies, urban development and everything that is essential for the orderly development of a country so that its inhabitants can enjoy a standard of living comparable to that of the Western powers. One is therefore entitled to attempt to determine whether that objective has been realised. In recent years a substantial degree of industrialisation has taken place within the countries concerned and, in a majority of those countries, it has not materially improved the living standards of the people.

Our form of assistance has been to provide the sort of public funding that has enabled industrialisation and a vicious form of exploitation of the work force in most of those countries. It seems that much of the money which has gone to these countries has been spent on agricultural development and what is left has gone towards infrastructure. What has been most disturbing this year has been the degree to which the Australian Government has been required to increase it contribution from 5.14 per cent to 7.2 per cent of the needed funds, while at the same time the richest country in the world, the United States of America, has seen fit to reduce its contribution. That has the effect not only of reducing the total sum available to those countries but also of reducing the objectives of the scheme, to which I have referred.

One can therefore understand the critical note of the very eminent President of the World Bank, who plays a significant role in allocating sufficient funds for the development of Third World countries. He said:
For the first time in 50 years the United States is saying that it cannot afford to continue increasing its aid program.

When one considers the mammoth increase in armaments that the Reagan Administration is putting before the United States House of Representatives and the United States Senate in the insane arms race between the super-powers, one can understand why the United States has taken that extraordinary step of reducing its normal contribution. The purpose of the Fund was to have the countries that may be described as haves contribute towards the have-nots. The Australian Labor Party does not quibble with that objective. Australia is in the same sort of conservative or monetarist bind that has plagued countries such as the United States and the United Kingdom. The present Administration of the United States takes the view that the Third World should rely mainly on private capital and market forces to overcome the problems of development. It then exercises its influence through the World Bank and the Asian Development Fund to propagate that monetarist view that market forces and private capital should be the basis of the strategy applied in the development of the Third World countries.

That gives emphasis to the Labor Party's criticism of this legislation. Just as those policies are failing in the United States, the United Kingdom and Australia in the domestic sense they will fail to provide the essential steps that need to be taken in the Third World countries to raise living standards. With the rapid industrialisation that is taking place in our neighbouring countries, whether they be in the Asian region or the Pacific region, we see differentiations taking place. Some of those countries have to contend with private capital invested for the purposes of exploitation and for the development of consumer goods which then have their effect on world markets, the Australian market in particular. It is our funds that are providing the additional public revenues either for agricultural development or for infrastructure to produce the means by which the private sector can carry on its exploitation. Of course, as we know, many of the countries to which I refer have despotic leaders, authoritarian regimes and governments that are not basically concerned with the living standards of their people but rather with assisting the multinational and transnational companies viciously to exploit the cheap labour that is a feature of the countries within our region.

We must have a policy of differentiation in this area because in a sense the countries in our region are now in three different categories. The advanced countries have high technology, microchip and the electronic industries. They are producing consumer goods at a rapid rate with cheap labour, and in a highly competitive world market these goods create difficulties for countries such as Australia. In other countries in our region industrialisation is taking place without the advent of modern advanced high technology. Other countries, particularly in the Pacific region, have economies of a somewhat primitive nature.

The Asian Development Bank and the Australian Government have a partisan approach to the way in which the funds are allocated. I refer, for example, to their refusal to assist properly in the rehabilitation and development of countries such as Vietnam, where Western powers-the United States and Australia- carried out policies of destroying the economy and the countryside. This Government and the United States Government have refused to honour the obligations, to which they agreed at the time of the Paris peace talks and the finalisation of Western intervention, to give that country the sort of aid that is essential for it to rehabilitate itself and establish a more reasonable economy. As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Lionel Bowen) suggested during a debate in the House of Representatives, it is a criminal shame we apply such policies to countries within our region, such as Vietnam, which require the assistance of the developed countries to overcome the ravages of war when it sought only to establish a form of self-determination and found itself heavily invaded, bombarded and partially destroyed by countries such as the United States and Australia. The Development Fund and the Development Bank are being used as instruments to pursue foreign policies which are inimical to the better interests of the region. They follow economic policies which have been proven to be against the best interests of the people in the region.

Honourable senators on both sides of the chamber have raised questions recently about funds from the Asian Development Bank being applied to countries such as the Philippines, which has an authoritarian, martial law type government. It uses money from the Asian Development Fund to provide an infrastructure which enables it to maintain an authoritarian regime which is against the best interests and proper development of that country. The philosophy of the conservatives of market forces and private capital, as expressed by the President of the United States, is the strategy that has been applied to this region. The Asian Development Fund is part of that process. Therefore, the original motivation and strategy behind the establishment of the Fund is being perverted by governments such as those in Australia and the United States, which misapply the principles on which the Fund was originally established. Whilst we see this differentiation within the region and, to some extent, the degree of economic growth surpasses that of some of the developed countries, we are nevertheless making a substantial contribution to the Fund. The Senate should be concerned about this. An amount of $212m in the current financial year is a substantial contribution to the Fund.

We have seen other examples of the way in which funds have been misapplied as a result of the policies being pursued by this Government. Honourable senators will recall, for example, the so-called assistance given to Fiji by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). The Australian Broadcasting Commission exposed how the funds were applied to keep in office a conservative government of the same ilk as the Fraser Government and not to help the people of Fiji. Rather than the noble sentiments and objectives which were the purpose of the original fund, we see this distortion taking place in the way in which the funds are being applied . But having said that, it is better to have the funds applied in the region than to take the negative position of not giving assistance to the countries of the region at all. Even though I believe our criticism of the way in which the funds are being applied is valid, nevertheless some positive contribution is being made. The poorer and least developed countries in the region are being given some assistance, even though we certainly quarrel with the way in which the Fund is operated.

I heartily endorse the very critical note that was taken by Mr Lionel Bowen when this matter was being debated in the House of Representatives. Unfortunately, having regard to the time constraints which we have in the Senate on the second last day of this sitting, I will leave my remarks at that point. I hope that the Government will examine what the Opposition has said in both Houses of Parliament about the operation of the Asian Development Fund and heed our criticism, with a view to improving the fund and making it a much more efficient instrument for improving the living standards of the people in our region.

speech.speaker: Hill Sen R.

talk.start.para: â€”As Senator Gietzelt has indicated, the Asian Development Fund Bill is an important Bill. I find it desirable to speak, because although the Bill is witness to the fact that the Australian Government will not avoid international responsibilities at a time of domestic economic difficulty, the Government nevertheless should continue that policy in the knowledge that it has the very positive support of members of this chamber. Already there is pressure to reconsider our aid commitments. I noticed only a matter of days ago that one State Premier stated that such a move would be a good starting point when looking at our economic woes. In the same mould, in September of last year Ronald Reagan stated:

speech.para: Unless a nation puts its own financial and economic house in order, no amount of aid will produce progress.

That is of course true, as far as it goes. But what he could also have said is that to keep up the aid program will be a little harder for the average American or, in our case, for the average Australian. But nevertheless, relatively, his position remains beyond comparison.

I remind the Senate of portion of the excellent speech given by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) at the University of South Carolina in July of last year on the subject, 'The Third World and the West' in which he said:

According to the World Bank, not a body given to emotional exaggeration, 800 million people are living in conditions of absolute poverty in the Third World. The infant mortality rate in low income Third World countries is 12 times as high as that in Western countries. Life expectancy in them is still under 50 years. Thousands are dying every week from malnutrition and outright starvation.

When the situation reaches that stage, the question must be asked: What does aid achieve? At the very basic level it is humanitarian, keeping people alive, providing basic essentials for life. From there it moves into what John F. Kennedy said in 1961 would contribute to:

. . . move more than half the people of the less developed nations into self sustained economic growth while the rest move substantially closer to the day when they, too, will no longer have to depend on outside assistance.

But as countries reach that stage, they proceed to prove that every nation prospers by the prosperity of others. Over 70 per cent of the Third World trade is with the developed industrialised countries. Over one-third of Western trade is with the Third World. Each strengthens the other. So if humanitarian justification is insufficient, if an economic justification is necessary, then that is it. But there is a further justification that is strategic. The speech of the Prime Minister, to which I have just referred, reminded me of Edmund Burke, who said:
Discontent will increase with misery.

The record of the Eastern bloc in economic aid has been poor. The Soviet Union gives only 0.04 per cent of gross national product in aid. It gives the West a tremendous opportunity to show by example the material benefits that free industrialised nations can offer. With that comes a closer and more meaningful relationship. The average assistance of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries at the moment is about 0.3 per cent of GNP. There has, of course, been a great deal of activity in recent years to bridge the economic chasm between the rich North and the poor South. As we know, Robert S. McNamara, as President of the World Bank, advocated in 1977 the formation of an independent commission on international development issues. The Brandt Commission, as it is now known, was set up to report on-I quote from its terms of reference-the following:

The global issues arising from the economic and social disparities of the world community and to suggest ways of promoting adequate solutions to the problems involved in development and in attacking absolute poverty.

It called for a major increase in the transfer of resources from the developed nations to the developing and undeveloped and a summit meeting of world leaders to enable initiatives and concessions to be threshed out with candour and boldness. The summit at Cancun has come and gone with progress described in the terms of Willy Brandt, the Chairman of the Commission I mentioned, as progress in millimetres. The heads of state representing both the North and the South met for only two days and passed the need to continue global negotiations to what was described in one volume of the Economist last year as that drones' hive of indecision, the United Nations. What progress has been made? At the Versailles meeting earlier this year of major industrialised nations their leaders said:
There is now a good prospect for the early launching and success of global negotiations.

They said that the European Economic Community would prepare a draft resolution based on that circulated earlier by the so-called group of 77 developing nations .
