In other words, drafts are being prepared and that is the degree of progress being made. Global negotiations will be slow. Whether they can ever lead anywhere is questionable. Some commentators are now referring to the Cancun cul- de-sac.

What is of particular relevance to this Bill is that the multilateral development banks-both the World Bank and the regional banks-continue to play a worthwhile role in the development needs of the Third World. One such bank is, of course, the Asian Development Bank. Many of the issues facing the Asian Development Fund, the soft lending facility of the ADB, are the same in a larger way as those facing the International Development Association, the soft lending facility of the World Bank. The most major of those obstacles has been the attitude of recent United States administrations, and of Congress debates, as to whether this kind of lending, the multilateral kind of lending, is in the best interests of the United States. It raises the question of loans going to countries opposed to United States foreign policy. But in doing so it is really pointing to the strength of multilateral agencies. That the donor has less direct influence over terms and conditions upon which recipients receive funds, either in the nature of economic development or in foreign policy demands, might be in the best interests of the developing world. Development needs have a better opportunity of being the principle inducement. It is also the American view that the greatest share of loans should go to countries which have shown an ability to help themselves. In other words, there is better value there than pouring money after poverty.

Also there is criticism that the lending concentrates too much on the public sector rather than encouraging a vigorous private sector. Both these points ignore the fact that building up the necessary economic infrastructure on which an industrial take-off can be based requires large amounts of money to be applied for long periods, especially in the public sector. These problems face the ADF today. The Far Eastern Economic Review, in its 1981 review, considered the ADF to be the most exposed such body to increasing United States lukewarmness to multilateral aid and general budget cuts. That situation of concern has in fact proved valid. There has been a fall in the contribution of the United States, as was indicated by Senator Gietzelt. The annual United States contribution to the 1982 replenishment was $520m, which represented a fall in United States proportional contributions from 22 per cent to 16 per cent . The shortfall was made up by other countries. Japan increased its share from 33 per cent to 38 per cent and Australia increased its share from 5 per cent to 7 per cent. France also increased its contribution. This reduction by the United States is, of course, to be regretted. It indicates that the industrialised nations of the region are going to have to shoulder a larger share of the region 's economic needs.

It is, however, regretted because the Asian Development Bank has played a part in the excellent economic performance of the last decade of the newly industrialised countries of Asia-Hong Kong, Taiwan, South Korea and Singapore. It has also contributed to the strong agricultural performance and rapid industrial progress of the four middle income countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations-Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines and Thailand. Singapore is excluded as being inappropriate to that description. All, excluding the Philippines, were among the 20 fastest growing economies in the world over the past 10 years. Some have moved from the highly concessional loans of the ADF to loans from ordinary capital resources. It is in the south Asian countries such as Burma, Japan, Bangladesh-which has an annual income per capita of less than $120-and Sri Lanka where problems are most severe. The Far Eastern Economic Review in April 1982 stated:

A substantial proportion of the population, which continues to expand at a rapid pace, is without adequate employment, malnourished, suffers from disease, has no access to safe drinking water and is illiterate. Given the poorly developed institutions, it is clear only by concerted, sustained efforts can meaningful progress be made in these DMCs. Thus poverty will remain a daunting problem in the South Asian countries for the foreseeable future and continued progress there will require additional concessionary lending. This is due to the limited access these countries have to commercial sources as well as the difficulty they have in accumulating foreign exchange and local revenue for urgent development projects and programmes.

It does not mean that all is yet rosy in ASEAN. With the exception of Singapore, income inequalities remain substantial and poverty incidence, particularly in rural areas, remains acute. Employment growth has not been sufficient to absorb the additions to the labour force. Labour productivity has gown slowly and real wages in some areas have stagnated. A bias towards capital intensive industrialisation has done much to aggravate the problem.

In those circumstances, it is pleasing that the Bank has recognised the need for a more flexible approach. It has recognised the value of promoting simpler and cheaper intermediate technology. It has increased its assistance to agriculture, which now comprises its largest share, followed by energy. Without energy little development can take place. Priority has been given to the provision of adequate social infrastructure, which includes water supply, sewerage, housing, education and health facilities. But what is most pleasing is that the Bank has oriented its ADF money towards the extremely poor. In 1981 almost 92 per cent of special funding loans went to developing member countries which had a per capita gross national product of less than $300 in the previous year, 1980. In 1981 Bangladesh received the largest amount of ADF loans, $191m, followed by Pakistan, $155m; Burma, $59.5m; Nepal, $45.2m; Sri Lanka, 35.5m.

According to the 1981 annual report of the Bank, in the three instances in which ADF resources were provided to middle income countries-the Technical Education Project in Papua New Guinea, the Palawan Integrated Area Development Project in the Philippines and the Medium-Scale Irrigation Project in Thailand-' Care has been taken to target these schemes at poor people'. In such circumstances, it appears to me that the Government should be congratulated for upgrading its support for the ADF, particularly in these difficult times. It is obvious that the ADB is conscious of the overall social, economic and political requirements of development and is making a very worthwhile contribution in the region. It is equally obvious that for humanitarian long term economic and strategic reasons it should be supported.

Having said that, it is always necessary to touch upon areas of concern-the problems which those who are interested in this subject will have to reflect upon in the future. One is the position of Vietnam. The ADB's position remains that conditions in the country do not provide a reasonable basis for new lending or for a revival of earlier projects. But if we are genuinely concerned about the region's poor and if assistance is independent of political considerations the problem of Vietnam will require reassessment. Following the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan in 1979, the ADB asked the Afghan Government to cease requests for disbursements of committed loans or to ask for new ones. The policy, which can be justified on safety reasons by the staff of the Bank, conveniently fits American foreign policy. But this may not mean that assistance is going where it is most needed.

India has indicated its intention in the future to resume soft loan borrowings. The ADF could not support aid at the proportion envisaged by India. This could lead to a major crisis within the Bank and for its donors in the not too distant future. There is also the chance of a request from China for funds. Requests for membership by China would have to be viewed against the existing membership of Taiwan and difficulties there can be envisaged. Some commentators argue that the strongest impulse for the establishment of the ADB came from Japan on the basis that it was in Japan's regional interests, particularly its need to secure supplies of raw materials and foodstuffs and to provide an outlet for expanded exports. Whilst that objective is not to be condemned, the ADF is now virtually dependent on Japan. It is in Australia's interests, therefore, to look to a broadening of the base of support. There is the difficult problem touched upon by Brandt when he said:
Multilateral lending agencies could usefully give help for adjustment and institutional reforms associated with programs for agrarian reform.

Can the Bank interfere in the internal running of a country? If so, how far can it go? Clearly there is no point in increasing poor nations' wealth-I think this point was touched upon by Senator Gietzelt-through aid if it is simply going to the few wealthy. There is little dispute that social and political reforms are often as important in the achievement of an equitable form of economic development as the availability of adequate capital resources. As I have indicated, there is evidence that the ADF is generally heading in the right direction. But the matter needs constant review.

If we add to these problems the associated policy of increasing protectionism by the North and the problems associated with large debts and interest servicing it is obvious that, although the Minister said the bank has continued to approach its complex development task with flexibility and vigour, it will require in addition to such qualities wisdom in the years ahead. Australia must accept its responsibility-as was also stated in the Minister's speech-to play its role fully.

speech.speaker: Mason Sen C.V.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The Australian Democrats support the Asian Development Fund Bill 1982. Indeed, we applaud the Government for ensuring that Australia has a continued and increased commitment towards helping some of the world's poorest nations to come to grips with their problems. The Asian Development Bank is a vitally important institution, tending as it does to support increasingly the very basic areas of work such as improved water storage , health and population control projects. This Bill will provide $212m to the Bank this year increasing Australia's share from 5.14 per cent to 7.2 per cent. We are very much preoccupied in this country with our own problems of recession and unemployment. But I think we would all agree that serious though those problems are, they are not as bad as those faced by Third World nations. It is also a fact that as our problems increase so too do the problems of other countries, but theirs to a greater extent than our own.

speech.para: I was very shocked to read a story from an African newspaper some weeks ago about a group of old and infirm people who were among a group of refugees sitting in a camp somewhere in Africa. After due deliberation, thought and consideration they decided that they would voluntarily poison themselves-commit mass suicide-so that a greater share of the miserable food resources would be available for the children so that those children might live. That in itself was a very noble and dignified act carried out by noble and dignified people almost in obscurity. I think that probably a huge proportion of the human race now sees such things happening and that often we do not even know that those things are going on. Indeed, if it is one world and humanity is one people, we have failed very sadly the greater majority of our fellow humans when things of that kind happen.

I believe it would be the most selfish, carping and miserable of opinions that we should cut back on this kind of assistance to people who are less fortunate than ourselves because of our own problems in the knowledge that those cutbacks meant certain death to people who suffer from poverty, famine and disease through no fault of their own. It is a fact that these people, like ourselves, are caught up in the whirlwind of world happenings and they have no control over their fate to the stage where many who are born in those countries die before they are even at the age where they can exert any control over their own affairs whatsoever. It is my opinion that for those kinds of reasons the great majority of Australians support the Government in this allocation of funds. However, I agree with Senator Gietzelt that a careful watch must be kept on how this money is spent. The demonstrated need is so enormous and the resources so small in contrast with that need that every dollar must be spent in the most fully effective way. This is not, unfortunately, always the case. Human nature being what it is, it is a natural and regrettable tendency for money devoted to purposes like this to be concentrated more and more on administration rather than practical efforts. It is easier simply to set up some sort of administrative group, and administration, of course, proliferates on itself.

My own experience in the Asian countries, unfortunately, shows that they are almost better at doing this than we are ourselves, and that is saying something. Still worse, this money can be diverted to people who do not really need it or who find dubious but still legal ways of using it for their own ends. This has been done in many countries of Asia with the greatest possible cynicism. I think it is a reflection of the views of a class of people who find themselves at the top of the heap, but who see their position as precarious and who see their preservation and their children's preservation as being of more importance than the least fortunate people in their own country. That is a tendency we must recognise. We must use our own influence, whenever we can, to overcome it.

I could not agree with Senator Gietzelt-I do not think he said this, but he implied it-that the existence of an authoritarian regime in itself must debar a nation from help by the bank. Indeed, it is probable that those countries are the ones which need it most. The extent to which an outside nation can interfere in how a recipient nation runs its own affairs can, however, be quite effective, even if difficult. This does not have to be overt; it certainly should not be that way. The adage: 'He who pays the piper calls the tune', is always true. We ought not to be too coy in calling the tune in such matters. There again, that is a fine line to be walked.

It is wrong, as happened in India I think from both sides of the zonal conflict , that a country should be punished because of the political view of its government at that time. At the same time, we should not believe that we can safely isolate ourselves, with any conscience, from the vast majority of human beings who are poorer than ourselves. This should be an absolute fundamental of our view of the world. John Donne said: 'No man is an island.' We would be foolish indeed to believe that we could continue to exist and prosper in the midst of a surrounding sea of poverty. Like Senator Hill-I applaud him for his comments-I deplore those statements which we, unfortunately, now see and hear in this community in increasing numbers. It is said that we ought to cut back on foreign aid to the benefit of some domestic cause. In our own interests that has to be resisted.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”in reply-I thank honourable senators for their support of this legislation. That support has come from all quarters of the Senate. There are one or two points to which I would like to refer. Senator Hill drew our attention to the fact-I think Senator Gietzelt mentioned it also-that there has generally been a decrease in the amount of support coming from the, if you like, developed nations for the Asian Development Bank. Certainly in this replenishment there will be a drop in the contribution by the United States of America to the Bank. It should be noted , however, that there is a significant increase in the proportion of funds coming from sources now identified as very well developed countries in this region; I instance Japan. Certainly Japan's proportion compared with the last replenishment has increased from 33.7 per cent to 37.8 per cent. Australia, with a significantly smaller population than that of Japan, has increased its proportion from 5.14 per cent to 7.2 per cent. I think it has to be acknowledged that, while saying that the United States has taken less interest in this activity compared with previous years, certainly the slack, if you like, has been taken up, as it appears, with great alacrity by countries which are part of this region. That is a significant trend in the development of care and assistance for Asian nations as has been well identified by Senator Mason in his remarks.

speech.para: I was fortunate enough last year, as Minister Assisting the Treasurer, to attend the annual general meeting of the Asian Development Bank in Honolulu. I had the opportunity of having discussions with many leaders, not only those whose countries are in need and are borrowers from the Bank, but also those whose countries contribute heavily to programs. The kinds of points that were made by Senator Mason in relation to the poorer nations I think are things that are uppermost in the minds of those who are contributing. There is a genuine spirit of assistance within the Bank as a whole. I commend both staff and directors of the Bank for their altruism and their approach to the development of Asia as a whole.

I conclude these very brief remarks by commending further Australia's commitment to this very fine enterprise. It is a relatively recent one in terms of the development of this area of the world. The total funding provided by the Asian Development Bank I think is of the order of $10,000m. Of that Australia has contributed quite worthily in recent years. The proportion, as I said, which Australia is contributing is growing and has reached a total of 7.2 per cent. This latest replenishment amounting to some $212.33m is a very significant development in this area of the world. I think all Australians recognise the need to assist those nations that are in the poorer categories. It is a very important factor for all of us to recognise that in fact countries which are in the lesser developed areas-those that are generally the poorer nations-are probably those which will be most affected and which are being most affected by the current downturn in world trade.

Of course, there are many factors which mitigate against the development of Asian nations. Those have been canvassed in other debates. I speak of the trading policies of various nations in relation to primary produce and those things which are complimentary to the economic produce of Asian nations. That is another argument. Let us, at this point of time, acknowledge the very significant contribution of Australia to the Asian Development Bank. The Bank consists of a very dedicated group of people who work out of Manila and who are providing significant benefits and development funds for Asia generally.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

debate.title:
DEFENCE FORCE DISCIPLINE BILL 1982
DEFENCE FORCE (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1982

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 25 August, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen G.J.

talk.start.para: â€”In introducing this legislation on 25 August this year, the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, said that the Defence Force Discipline Bill-a 100-page Bill designed to produce a complete new code of military law in this country-was the outcome of a 'prolonged review of the existing law'. That is a masterly understatement. The process of producing a new code of military discipline law in this country began 36 years ago with the report of Mr Justice Reed of the punishment and trial of military offences, which report was completed in 1946.

speech.para: It was not until the Labor Government came to office in 1972 and generated some momentum in this area as in so many other areas that a further report was produced and tabled in this Parliament on 2 April 1974 from a working party which had been established the previous year. We are told that this Bill is based on that report. The report itself was the subject of considerable comment by members of parliament, members of the public and, of course, members of the Defence Force. Following that, there was a conference in November 1978 chaired by the then Minister for Defence. Now, four years later, we have this Bill.

Needless to say, at the end of that process, the Opposition does, in fact, welcome its final appearance. We cannot help but ask ourselves why it has all taken so long. A number of reasons suggest themselves, but I think Senator Durack partly at least gave the game away by revealing in his second reading speech that the Attorney-General's Department was involved in the review of the law in question. We all know what that means. Having the Attorney-General's Department, under the present Attorney's administration, involved in any law reform project is like driving with the brake on.

Be that as it may, it would be churlish to do otherwise than to welcome, unequivocally, the arrival of the Bill. Certainly, the Bill will-as the second reading speech, which it appears was largely written by the then Defence Minister, Sir James Killen, as his swan song in that portfolio, colourfully illustrates-bring the law and the procedure governing discipline of the Defence Force headlong into the twentieth century. That is no mean feat. No longer will there be as part of Australian military law the offence of negligent drum beating. Nor will there be, as part of our military law, offences relating to the exploitation of sutlers. For those who are not in the know about these matters, sutlers, it appears, follow an army and sell provisions to soldiers. With this legislation we are showing signs at last of getting into the area of modern enlightened criminal law.

We do not oppose the Bill, nor do we seek to delay its passage. I do feel obliged to indicate that we are by no means happy with every detail of it although, again, we are realistic enough to acknowledge that perfection in this kind of complex legislation, albeit after 36 years of endeavour, is virtually unattainable and we do not stand too much on the lack of perfection in every respect of this Bill.

Let me quickly, however, point to not only some of the weaknesses of the Bill but also its strengths. I think its primary strengths are that in general terms it does amount to almost a complete codification of the law, thus producing a much greater degree of certainty and uniformity in what has hitherto been very much a dog's breakfast. Secondly, in general terms it does reflect, finally at last, the abolition of our dependence in this respect on United Kingdom legislation-a welcome trend, as this is, representing the legal emancipation of Australia, which grinds slowly on as the Federation now enters its ninth decade. The other useful thing, of course, accomplished by this Bill is that it will provide in very large, if not total, measure uniformity as between the rules applying to each of the three Services.

Some of the particular merits of the Bill seem to me to be the automatic review that is provided for in clauses 151 and 152 of convictions and punishments and also the requirment in clause 70 that Service tribunals are to have regard to articulated sentencing principles. That is not to say we are entirely happy with the formulation of those sentencing principles in that clause, but certainly the appearance of such an attempt to codify, to describe, the appropriate sentencing approach is very much to be welcomed.

As to the weaknesses of the Bill, were it not for the time constraints we are operating under it might have been appropriate to devote some considerable time in the Commitee stage of this Bill to spelling out some of them and, indeed, to moving amendments to endeavour to deal with them. But for the moment let me indicate what some of them appear to the Opposition to be. I will describe the context in which I believe it is appropriate for these weaknesses to be sought to be remedied in a moment. One weakness is, as the Opposition spokesman on defence, Mr Scholes, described in his contribution to the debate on this Bill in the House of Representatives on 17 August, that it does not seem to provide clear or adequate cover to Service personnel when they are engaged in assisting the civil power. There are all sorts of uncertainties about the powers, duties and protections of Service personnel in those situations and this Bill does not do anything really to resolve them.

The second concern relates to clause 10 of the Bill insofar as it refers to the presevation of the principles of the common law with respect to criminal liability. That is a clause of very considerable vagueness and ambiguity, it not being at all clear whether what are there being referred to are the substantive common law criminal offences or merely rather the common law rules relating to the determination and establishment of guilt. It may well be only the latter but there is, nonetheless, a degree of uncertainty which is an unhappy uncertainty in what does purport to be a fairly complete, in itself, military code.

There is a further matter for concern which has been the subject of representations to a number of honourable senators: The absence of protections in relation to certain kinds of behaviour being the subject of disciplinary penalties. I am referring in particular to homosexual behaviour by armed service personnel. That behaviour is not explicitly made the subject of disciplinary process in the explicit test text of this legislation, but it would be covered by clause 61 of the Bill to the extent that that clause makes a military offence anything which constitutes an offence under Australian Capital Territory law for the time being. Since most forms of homosexual activity are in fact, unfortunately, still proscribed by the Australian Capital Territory criminal law , this then is the vehicle through which homosexual behaviour can be the subject of military discipline. This assumes some importance, particularly in the context of what I understand to be the policy being applied within the armed Services, not merely of treating such behaviour when detected as grounds for military discipline but going further than that to treating such behaviour as being grounds for, in fact, expulsion from the armed Services. This is not an especially enlightened view of the world in this day and age. This subject is one which we believe could have been more sensibly and directly addressed in this legislation.

There is a further weakness of the Bill which we perceive in clause 75 insofar as it allows for the determination of various forms of conviction and for a variation in the sentences which can attach to such convictions. But the clause does not allow for the discharge of a person without a conviction in fact being recorded. It is, of course, the case in most jurisdictions under criminal law that people can get away with a first offence or an offence for which there is some ground for leniency. In fact, the offence does not appear on their record. We believe it is appropriate that there be some discretionary power of that kind in relation to these sorts of offences.

We see in clause 137 of the Bill some untoward limitations on the extent to which persons accused of offences under military law can get external legal representation of their own choice. Again I refer to the eleventh report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, which identified a large number of specific matters which troubled that Committee as possibly encroaching to an untoward extent on the liberty of the subject in the context of powers of entry to arrest, powers of detention before trial, powers of arrest, provisions relating to closed courts and so on. The basic question running through all those issues is a question about which reasonable men can differ and relates to the extent to which ordinary civil liberties can be reasonably encroached upon in the special context of discipline in a disciplined service such as the Defence Force.

I mention those matters which could, as I say, be the subject of debate or, indeed, amendment at the Committee stage not in order to attempt to foreshadow any such exercise in the Committee stage but simply to indicicate that there are many matters of detail which are not, on the face of it, totally satisfactory and which could well properly be the subject of review. It is not, however, the Opposition's desire-particularly since the House of Representatives has now adjourned for this year and particularly given the long and unhappy history of the legislation in terms of getting it through the Parliament-to seek in any way to delay the passage of this legislation in its present form. We believe the merits of the Bill far outweigh the specific demerits that I have identified and perhaps some others as well. What that listing of demerits and weaknesses leads me and the Opposition to suggest is that there is, in fact, a strong case to be made for the review of this legislation within a reasonable period. It is with that thought in mind that in respect of the Defence Force Discipline Bill 1982 I now move:
At the end of motion add:

', but the Senate is of the opinion that the Minister should, as soon as practicable after the expiration of 3 years after the proclaimed date, establish a Board, to be known as the Defence Force Discipline Legislation Board of Review consisting of such persons as he determines, which Board shall, within 12 months after it is established, prepare and furnish to the Minister a report relating to-
(a) the operation of this Act and the regulations; and
(b) the operation of any other law of the Commonwealth or of the Australian Capital Territory in so far as that law relates to the discipline of the Defence Force'.

That proposal, I believe, is a responsible one and a necessary one. The very genesis of the Defence Force Discipline Bill shows how important such a review process is and how necessary it is likely to be if appropriate changes to keep pace with identified weaknesses are, in fact, to be made. Three years would appear to be about the minimum period necessary for a proper evaluation to be made of this legislation in practice. I regret to advise the Senate that the former Minister for Defence, Sir James Killen, in the House of Representatives on 18 August, responded to this proposal in a way which demonstrated amply why he is now so universally described as the Minister for Nothing. We had from him a classic mixture of bluster, bonhomie and non-sequitur, characteristics which have become the trade marks of that gentleman and evince a total failure by him to grasp the thrust and merit of this proposal.

It is true, as the Minister said, that flaws may appear in this legislation in the early days of its operation. It is possible, although I believe unlikely given its record, that the government of the day will attend to those flaws. What is and should be evident is that the question of a thorough-going, comprehensive review of the operation of this legislation at the end of three years is an altogether different matter from giving piecemeal attention to particular flaws that may arise, and is perfectly consistent with and complementary to any short term tinkering that may be done.

So I conclude by saying that this is important legislation. It is overdue legislation. It is legislation that ought to be supported by the Senate and will be supported by the Australian Labor Party. But it is not legislation without flaws and it is not the kind of legislation that ought to be put on the statute books and forgotten about for another 36 years. It is the kind of legislation that should be subject to a proper review process and the formula by which we suggest that should take place is contained in our second reading amendment, which I commend to the chamber.

talk.start.para: â€”Senator, did you move your amendment to the first of the Bills, the Defence Force Discipline Bill 1982?
â€”Yes, Mr President.

speech.speaker: Hamer Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I support the Bills, which I believe are a long overdue consolidation and clarification of the disciplinary legal situation in the Services. I do not think that we should, in Services which are very traditional, accept this without examining what the present situation is and what is wrong with what is going on at present. We must realise that our forces are in a high state of discipline. We have no serious legal problems and before we make a change we must be quite clear as to what is wrong with the present situation. The present situation is basically confused-though it can be made to work-but more importantly it is not really Australian at all. The existing legislation for the discipline of the Defence Force consists of three British Acts, two of which have ceased to operate in their country of origin, four sets of British rules or regulations, all of which have ceased to operate in Britain; three Australian Acts; and nine sets of regulations under our Acts.

speech.para: To make the situation even more confusing, the British Acts and regulations do not apply in their original form but have been modified, added to and adjusted by Australian regulations. To put it mildly, this is a very confused situation. A few examples have been given. Senator Evans gave a couple and I will give a couple more. In the case of the Navy and the Air Force some provisions of the United Kingdom legislation apply in parallel with corresponding, but not identical, Australian legislation. Sometimes one prevails and sometimes the other. The basic law for the Navy is contained in a modern United Kingdom statute, the Naval Discipline Act of 1957, whereas Army and Air Force law is based on a superseded British Army Act of 1881. Senator Evans gave a few examples of the absurdities of that particular Act. It refers to such offences as duelling, behaving in a scandalous manner unbecoming the character of an officer and a gentleman, beating the drums negligently occasioning false alarms on the march and conniving at the exaction of any exorbitant price for a house or store let to a sutler.

talk.start.para: â€”That would be very treacherous conduct, Senator, wouldn't it?

â€”Beating drums on the march and causing alarm and confusion? Yes, though it is not perhaps very relevant to the Navy or Air Force and only slightly so to the Army, one would have thought. To go on to relate the absurdities, the Army is provided with two sets of disciplinary laws, one of which applies when members are serving Australia in peacetime and the other when members are serving outside Australia on war service. Their legal system changes when they go overseas.

speech.para: A further example is that Army and Air Force tribunals apply the English rules of evidence but Navy tribunals apply the rules of evidence that are applicable to the Australian Capital Territory. The final example of the difficulties under which we are labouring at the moment is this reliance on British Acts. If they are changed without being noticed in Australia it might render nugatory a trial in Australia. I will give one example of that. There was a case where a naval conviction was quashed because the judge advocate advised the court-martial on the basis of an English decision which had not been followed by the High Court of Australia and he was not aware of that. We had a very clumsy and essentially unworkable situation.

There is no doubt at all in my view that a new single Act for our Defence Force is necessary to clear up these confusions and ambiguities, to codify the disciplinary law as it applies to the Defence Force. This is necessary not only for practical reasons but also as befits our dignity as a nation. It is not proper that our Defence Force should be reliant on the laws and procedures of other parliaments. It is up to this Parliament to provide the disciplinary laws for its own Defence Force.

It has already been pointed out that the present Bill has been many years in gestation. It has been a difficult process. An earlier Bill which was produced-I saw it a decade or so ago-would have been very unsatisfactory. As it was produced then it was a lawyer's dream, but it was a service officer's nightmare and it would have been unworkable in practice. What we have to think about is why we need a Defence Force Discipline Bill at all. Why can we not use the ordinary civil laws? I think that everyone knows the answer. When a man enlists he renounces for necessary reasons some rights he had as a civilian. If he does that it is particularly important that we see that he is fairly treated-treated justly.

The different requirements the Services have, because they are disciplined fighting forces, are quite unlike what is required in ordinary civil administration. Offences must be promptly dealt with. We cannot afford to have a situation in which offences linger on for months. Although there must be proper respect for the rights of the individual, it is at least equally important that there should be certainty of punishment for the guilty because nothing is more damaging to morale and therefore the efficiency of the unit concerned, than if a clearly guilty person gets off, particularly if he gets off on a legal technicality. The code must be simple and clear and there must be certainty of punishment for those who have committed offences. But above all-this is the most difficult one-we must avoid excessive delays. As I have said we must avoid perversions of true justice by excessive legalisms.

This is not always achieved. The matter of producing a new code does not solve all our problems. I mentioned that the earlier version of this code was highly unsatisfactory. After the Second World War the Americans produced a uniform code of military justice for their forces. It was a catastrophe; it was a legal bonanza but it did immense harm for the discipline and efficiency of the American services. It was not a practical way to run the discipline of a fighting service. What we must do as I have pointed out, is balance the problems . We must protect the rights of the individual. We must always have in mind that the purpose of a Defence Force Discipline Bill is to see that the Defence Force is efficient for its primary role. I believe that the present Bill is a fair and workable compromise. There must always be compromise in a Bill such as this. It creates a workable system.

I also support the amendment which has been moved by Senator Evans. One of the great worries in dealing with this Defence Force Discipline Bill has been the inordinate delays in getting it before the Parliament. It will not be a perfect Bill. There will certainly be some difficulties which will emerge through experience. We must see that such amending Bills are promptly enacted by this Parliament. Therefore, we must have a structure which will enable us to bring forward the necessary amendments. If we just left it to the Department of Defence and the Attorney-General's Department I fear, from past experience, that years might pass before such amending legislation would come forward. By setting up a review committee after three years I hope and trust that the legislation will be promptly implemented. These Bills will make a substantial contribution to codifying the disciplinary code of our Defence Force. They will do it in a way which will preserve the efficiency of our Defence Force and provide justice for the individuals in it.

speech.speaker: Mason Sen C.V.J.

talk.start.para: â€”I would be a brave person if I were to attempt to analyse or criticise extensively the Defence Force Discipline Bill which, as far as I can see, has been the subject of a series of intense consultations by expert people for no less a time than 18 years, going back to a working party which I believe was set up in 1965. The report of that working party having been presented, the legislation has been in gestation for the past eight years. It is very complex and constructive legislation. Previous speakers have mentioned some of the strange provisions, such as those concerning duelling and beating drums and things of that kind, which will be eliminated. I do not know whether it has been mentioned but, most importantly, the death penalty will be abolished. These measures are an enlightened move into the twentieth century for the Defence Force disciplinary code.

speech.para: Altogether, this legislation should be applauded. It is something which all parties here should, and do, support. The Australian Democrats support it without significant amendment. However, we do support Senator Evans's amendment. This has been a difficult matter and it has taken a long time for people to get what they think is the best possible result. It is unlikely to turn out to be a perfect result. For that reason alone it is very wise to provide for some sort of legislative board of review which can look at it after it has been operating, as Senator Evans's amendment suggests, for 12 months and then report to the Minister for Defence.

talk.start.para: â€”Three years.
â€”That is right; it has to be established within 12 months. In part , the amendment states:

speech.para: . . . after the expiration of three years after the proclaimed date, establish a Board, to be known as the Defence Force Discipline Legislation Board of Review . . . which Board shall, within 12 months after it is established, prepare and furnish to the Minister a report . . .

I thank Senator Hamer for raising that point. We support that because we believe it is an important and wise provision. Although people have worked very hard to draw up and present this new code, I believe they themselves would not consider themselves infallible; nor should we consider them so. On that basis I think that this is a wise amendment. We shall support it, as we shall also support the Bill.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”In view of the time I will speak only briefly to acknowledge the contributions of honourable senators on all sides in support of the Defence Force Discipline Bill . I take it the amendment moved by Senator Evans at the second reading stage replaces any further action that he might have had in mind in relation to the Committee stages of the Bill. I did see an amendment being circulated earlier.
â€”It is not my intention to proceed with any amendments in the Committee stage.
â€”I thank the honourable senator for that assurance. I am pleased to have it. In view of that, the Government readily accepts the amendment which will be attached to the second reading motion.
â€”Does that mean you will actually do something about it?

â€”Of course; it is a very interesting amendment and one which will receive the fullest consideration by the Government. Senator Evans did mention one aspect of significant interest, the relationship between civil personnel and members of the Defence Force. Perhaps it is not appropriate to discuss that aspect under this head, the disciplinary measures in relation to defence personnel. It very much relates to the Defence Act. It is an area separate from the matters before us in this legislation. Nevertheless, the Government has under active consideration that relationship which no doubt concerns Senator Evans.

speech.para: I thank all honourable senators for their support of the Bill. It is a complex measure; it is certainly a major upgrading of legislation. It is a significant move into the twentieth century. Senator Evans and Senator Hamer both pointed out to us some of the obvious absurdities of the present law. Clearly, they are rightly corrected by this legislation. I wish the Bill a speedy passage.
Amendment (Senator Evans's) in respect of the motion for the second reading of the Defence Force Discipline Bill 1982 agreed to.
Original question in respect of the Defence Force Discipline Bill 1982, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Original question in respect of the Defence Force (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1982 resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

debate.sub1.title: Aircraft Accident at Hobart Airport: Compensation for Mr Geoff Lucas-Mr William Sinclair: Imprisonment in Thailand-Air Force Bases in North West of Western Australia

proctext.para: Aircraft Accident at Hobart Airport: Compensation for Mr Geoff Lucas-Mr William Sinclair: Imprisonment in Thailand-Air Force Bases in North West of Western Australia
Motion (by Senator Messner) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

speech.speaker: Coates Sen J.

talk.start.para: â€”I wish to raise a matter of great concern about a constituent in Tasmania called Geoff Lucas of Risdon Vale, a Hobart suburb. Mr Lucas was one of five passengers on an Aero Commander plane, VH-EXQ, which crashed into Frederick Henry Bay near Hobart Airport on 27 April 1981. The summary report from the investigation of that accident was available only last month. The pilot was engaged in ferrying passengers across Bass Strait while commercial airlines were not flying due to an industrial dispute. The operation was apparently illegal, or at least regulations were not complied with, as I shall show in a moment.

speech.para: Mr Lucas suffered a heart attack while he was in the water awaiting rescue. He suffered severe hypothermia and nearly died as a result of the accident. He is still suffering today and has been invalided out of his job. He has received no compensation whatsoever for his loss of earnings, for his medical expenses, both then and continuing, or for his pain and suffering. The insurance company involved, the insurance company of the company Tasair, has refused to pay, although it has paid for the loss of the aeroplane. It has apparently not paid for the personal injury because it argues that the pilot's licence was not in order. Yet I should like to point out that it was no fault of the injured passenger that regulations were broken. As far as I am aware, all the passengers on the flight thought that it was either a proper private charter or even a proper regular passenger transport arrangement. They did pay individual fares and the aircraft did leave from Trans Australia Airlines' Tullamarine Airport terminal. It was not even the case that it left from Essendon Airport. It was, to all appearances, a proper commercial flight.

There have been many allegations about the flight and the accident-for instance , that there was only one life jacket on board; that the pilot had been drinking in Melbourne, and even during the flight; that he was not qualified for instrument flight rules involved in what turned out to be a night landing or at least an after sunset landing; that there had been no proper safety explanation before take-off and that there was no warning about what emergency action was appropriate as the inevitable impact with the sea approached. So in the light of those sorts of allegations, I believe that Mr Lucas has been very badly treated and has been getting the run-around. I think that he could be forgiven for thinking that there was a giant conspiracy involved in this matter, especially when one considers the connection between the involved parties. I do not intend to mention names tonight, but I shall certainly do so if no action eventuates which provides Mr Lucas with compensation. For instance, the lawyer for the insurance company also represented Tasair at the prosecution of the pilot and of the company in the Hobart Magistrate's Court. That lawyer is also a pilot member of the aero club which has its association with and is a major shareholder of Tasair.

talk.start.para: â€”Is he from out of State?

â€”He is a Tasmanian. His former boss is also a director of Tasair. Another of the passengers, who is now apparently in gaol, has a connection with the insurance company's Hobart agent. The pilot and the departmental investigators are, I am told, members of related lodges. A shareholder of Tasair is even a Liberal member of this chamber.

speech.para: So there are a number of questions to which I would like answers from the Minister. Obviously they are not questions which can be answered in detail tonight, but I think that the matter is important enough for me to raise them and to demand answers. For instance, is the insurance company within its rights to refuse to honour the insurance contract, or is it obliged to pay up under the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act? How come the company has paid for the aeroplane's loss, despite the illegality of the flight, yet not for the personal injury involved? If it is not obliged to pay up, why not? How can it avoid the terms of the Act? In passing I mention that advice has been given that payment is usually made only on death, not injury. Again, I should like the Minister to confirm whether that advice is right or wrong. I do not believe it is any answer to say 'Well, if the insurance company does not pay up, the carrier must pay'. Who is to say that the carrier has enough assets to pay the full and appropriate compensation? Incidentally, Mr Lucas has taken steps to sue the company, the aero club and the pilot.

I would like to know what mechanism can be instituted to ensure that passengers are not hoodwinked into believing that all is well in such a flight and that only properly licensed pilots fly for reward, especially from a normal commercial terminal, regardless of whether there is an industrial dispute at the time. I would like to know how it was that the Hobart and Melbourne towers allowed the flights to depart. Is there no way of checking the identification and licence of pilots in such circumstances?

There are some other minor questions to which I would like to obtain answers. For instance, why does the accident summary report from the then Department of Transport and the now Department of Aviation say that there was nil injury to all of the listed passengers when, plainly, that was no so? Why was the pilot granted a student pilot licence immediately after the crash so that he could keep flying, especially as very serious charges were to be laid against him, charges which led to his being sentenced to gaol, although the sentence was varied on appeal? There is a great absence of full knowledge of the circumstances and many of the allegations because of the pilot's pleading guilty at the prosecution.

I would also like to know why the investigation was stopped. Was the reason simply the razor gang limitations on funds, or was it some other reason? I would also like to know the answer to the allegations that the records of interview by the Australian Federal Police were not passed on to the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office which was responsible for the prosecution. To me the main problem is the lack of control over people wanting to make a fast buck at the expense of and risk to people who are open to exploitation; that is, people who are in a hurry to fly for all sorts of good reasons during a dispute affecting the airlines. We have a cosy club of people who are, apparently, all wanting to protect each other by a veil of silence and non-co-operation.

I want Mr Lucas to be properly compensated for all his dreadful suffering. I want better protection in the future for charter passengers such as he in relation to safety to ensure that such passengers arrive and compensation being in order if they do not. I believe there needs to be a much fuller and more open inquiry into this case than there has been so far. If the answers are not satisfactory in the next couple of months I intend to take the matter further when Parliament resumes. Perhaps this is just an isolated case. Perhaps it is just one example of shady operations in the general aviation industry, and I am worried that it may be the latter.

speech.speaker: Missen Sen A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”Tonight I desire to raise a matter which I have raised before in questions asked in this Parliament. It is a matter which has been the cause of some months of correspondence between the New South Wales Government and me. It concerns an Australian citizen who, I believe, is suffering considerable injustice because of the failure of the officers of the New South Wales Government in particular, including police officers, to make available to him the evidence required for him in connection with an appeal which is to take place in Thailand. The man in question is William Charles Sinclair who was convicted, after he was in a Thai gaol for some years, and who was tried on charges in Thailand for having possession of and attempting to export narcotics. He was charged along with two other persons-Warren Fellows and Paul Cecil Hayward-who have been convicted and who have not appealed. I do not think there is any question of their involvement in the attempt to remove these narcotics from Thailand.

speech.para: William Charles Sinclair has reiterated and confirmed a contention in a book published yesterday, called Kingdom of Illusions: The William Sinclair Story, by Richard Shears and Isabelle Gidley. It relates the result of further proceedings in Thailand in the last three years. After being in gaol for a number of years before trial Sinclair was convicted on 23 July 1981. He subsequently appealed and protested that the evidence against him was false and concocted. Ultimately he was successful in that appeal. His sentence of 33 years and eight months was quashed and on 16 April of this year his appeal was upheld. There was a further appeal to another court, which was due to be heard yesterday but because of his failure to attend court because his health at the moment is in no way such that he can attend and nor does he have available to him the evidence which he needs for that appeal, as has been reported today, he has suffered the loss of his bail money, which is very substantial, and he is under threat of arrest and extradition to Thailand.

I think it is important to realise that great injustice is being done by Australian authorities to this man in his attempt to get justice from a court in Thailand. I came into this matter some time before his appeal was upheld when his son, Gregory Sinclair-who is a constituent of mine in Victoria-approached me as well as the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) to make arrangements for the Australian Government to do the necessary things to enable evidence that had been given in New South Wales, which refuted allegations that had been made against Sinclair, to be certified and used in the Thai court. That was done by the Australian Government. Subsequently, after the successful appeal by Mr Sinclair, other problems developed. I have been endeavouring, quite unsuccessfully, since then to obtain satisfaction on his behalf. His appeal was upheld but he had to face another appeal. It became evident that what he needed to do was obtain evidence which would refute a statement which was alleged to have been made by him and which he has always contended was taken from him by New South Wales police officers in Thailand, accompanied by one police major Virat who is sometimes apparently known as Mad Dog Virat when he goes under that style. It is suggested that the document which they created is not genuine. The document which Sinclair says he signed was a quarto size document but now apparently it is a foolscap document. I do not know how that can be explained. He desires and needs to be able to dispute the original nature of that document. There is no doubt about his signature on it but there is a lot of doubt about the content of the document and whether the original has ever been produced. It has certainly never been tested by any forensic experts.

As a consequence of this on 17 June this year I tried to obtain the assistance of the Commonwealth Attorney-General, Senator Durack. To save time I will seek leave to incorporate in Hansard certain correspondence so that honourable senators will be able to see the course of these events. I will not read the details but I will just comment very briefly on these letters. I seek first to incorporate in Hansard a letter which I wrote to Senator Durack on 17 June 1982 in connection with this matter.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Senator the Hon. Peter Durack, Q.C.,
Attorney-General,
Parliament House,
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
My dear Attorney,
Re: William Charles Sinclair
Since his release on bail by the Thailand Supreme Court, I have had the opportunity of conversations with Mr William Sinclair, who has now returned to Australia.
He is now residing at 57 Guildford Road, Surrey Hills, Victoria, with his son Gregory and family, and is at the moment undertaking medical and dental treatment.

As you are aware, I have been concerned at the evidence which was used against Mr Sinclair through the interposition of Australian police and embassy officials , and which has subsequently been discredited in the further proceedings in the Thailand courts.

As you are probably also aware, there are difficulties at the present time because, under the curious arrangements of Thai law, Mr Sinclair is required to be back in Thailand to hear the reading of an appeal which apparently the prosecution intends to pursue and this requires him to be present in the court on 21 June. He has forwarded to Thailand medical certificates, copies of which I enclose herewith indicating why he will not be able to appear in court on that date, and it is trusted that he will be able to pursue his appeal thereafter despite the fact that it appears that the bail of 1 million baht (or $41,000) will be automatically forfeited.

It is also hoped that when it is ascertained that further evidence that was used against him, is false and defective in many respects, something will be done about this matter, but in the meanwhile I am asked that you exercise your good offices to request the Thai authorities to avoid the forfeiture of bail, if he does not appear for the reading of the appeal.
There are a number of important matters Mr Sinclair has raised with me and also through his solicitors, and in respect to which your urgent intervention is requested.

As you are aware, Detective Sgt. B. W. Dunn of the New South Wales Police Force (Criminal Intelligence Unit), and Detective Sgt. McAfee produced an alleged document from William Sinclair in the criminal proceedings in Thailand being the alleged statement he made to them on 22nd December, 1978 in the Maha-Chai Prison in Thailand. There appears to be grave doubts as to whether the photostat document actually produced in the court was indeed any such statement made by Mr Sinclair, and the court proceedings were in fact adjourned so that the photostat copy which had been produced in the court could be replaced by the original. On the resumption of the hearing I am informed that a document was produced (which was alleged to be the original but which is not so), and in fact that original document has never been produced in any court or to the Woodward Commission to the best of my knowledge.
Mr Sinclair therefore as an Australian citizen requests your assistance in the following respects:

1. To urgently approach the New South Wales Government to arrange for Detective Sgt. Dunn and Detective Sgt. McAfee to produce the original of this alleged statement so that it may be examined for authenticity by competent forensic experts.

2. Upon production of this original, for you to forward it to the Thailand Supreme Court so that Mr Sinclair will have the same basic legal rights as he would have in Australia of facing and refuting such an original document in the appeal proceedings.
3. That the Australian Government investigate and verify that the document now held in the Thailand Supreme Court is only a photostat and not an original document.
4. To obtain from Detective Sgt. Dunn an explanation of why the original document was not left in Thailand in view of the gravity of the charges presented against Mr Sinclair.

5. To produce and provide the necessary evidence to show that these two State policemen had the appropriate authority and relevant clearances from the Commonwealth Government to operate as police in a foreign country, namely Thailand.

6. To give an assurance that the Australian Government will again intercede with the Thai Supreme Court and again attest to the validity of the subsequent New South Wales court findings, as this is a hearing in a completely separate court to the original Appeals Court, and it may be necessary to validate the documents further to ensure that the Supreme Court has all the evidence before it.

Because the obtaining of this material may take some time, I would ask specifically that the Australian Government should approach the Thai authorities to ensure there is a delay of any hearing on the 21st June, which might otherwise lead to the forfeiture of the enormous bail imposed upon this man, particularly, bearing in mind that his appeal has been upheld by the Appeal Court and that he should be enabled to continue with his appeal without being required to attend, not only at great expense but also at the expense of his health at the present time.
I would appreciate an urgent reply.
Yours sincerely, ALAN MISSEN Senator for Victoria Encs.
cc Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: â€”In that letter I set out the facts and I sought the assistance of the Commonwealth in having the original document produced so that it could be studied by forensic experts and produced in the Thai court, where it should have been produced but where it has not been produced, and to endeavour to find out why the original document was not produced in the court. The Attorney-General replied to me on 25 June 1982. I seek leave to have his reply incorporated in Hansard.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Attorney-General Parliament House, Canberra, ACT 2600 25 June 1982
Dear Senator Missen,
I refer to your letter dated 17 June 1982 in which you asked the Government to act in a number of respects on behalf of Mr William Sinclair.

In the first place your asked that the Government approach the Thai authorities to ensure that bail money paid by Mr Sinclair not be forfeited if he failed to appear on 21 June 1982 before the courts in Thailand. You asked specifically that the Government request that the Thai courts delay the hearing scheduled for 21 June 1982. This is a matter for the Minister for Foreign Affairs. However, I am advised that it would not be appropriate for the Government to attempt to intervene in such a case. I understand however that Mr Sinclair's lawyer appeared on his behalf on 21 June 1982 and that bail has not been forfeited.

Secondly, you refer to a document allegedly held by the New South Wales police and to certain alleged conduct of a New South Wales police officer. Mr Sinclair should approach the New South Wales Government regarding these matters.

Thirdly, you mention that Mr Sinclair requests evidence that two officers of the New South Wales police had Commonwealth authority to operate in Thailand. I am not aware that any Commonwealth authority was given or that any such authority is required.

Finally, you request on Mr Sinclair's behalf an assurance that the Australian Government will again intercede with the Thai Supreme Court and attest to the validity of a record of certain proceedings before a New South Wales court. I understand that if this is required by the Thai authorities, and the New South Wales court authorities can provide an authenticated record of the proceedings, the Department of Foreign Affairs is willing to assist by transmitting the record to the Thai authorities in an appropriate form.

I am informed that information provided to the Australian Embassy in Bangkok by Mr Sinclair's lawyers concerning the proceedings is being passed on to Mr Sinclair by the Department of Foreign Affairs in Canberra as it arrives.

In view of the fact that the matters you raise on behalf of Mr Sinclair are not within my area of responsibility, I would be grateful if you would communicate with the responsible Minister and/or Government should your wish to pursue these matters further.
Yours sincerely, PETER DURACK
Senator A. J. Missen,
Senator for Victoria,
Australian Parliament Offices,
400 Flinders Street,
Melbourne, Vic. 3000.

talk.start.para: â€”In that reply, the Attorney-General declined to intervene in the matter, certainly at that stage. He took the view that the argument related to the New South Wales Police and the production of documents which were in New South Wales and he suggested that I should seek the assistance of the New South Wales authorities, which I then did.

speech.para: I wrote to the Premier of New South Wales, the Honourable N. K. Wran, on 30 June 1982. I seek leave to have that letter incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
30th June, 1982 The Hon. N. K. Wran, Q.C., M.P.,
Premier,
State Office Block,
Macquarie Street,
Sydney, NSW 2000.
Dear Mr Premier,
Re: Mr William Sinclair

I enclose copy of a letter dated the 17th June, 1982, which I wrote to the Attorney-General, Senator the Hon. Peter Durack, Q.C., seeking the Australian Government's assistance in a number of matters relating to the arrest and subsequent trial and imprisonment of Mr William Sinclair, in Thailand. I also enclose copy of the Attorney-General's reply dated the 25th June 1982.

You will note from the Minister's letter, that there are a number of these matters which come within the area of responsibility of the New South Wales Government. As he is most anxious to solve many of the discrepancies that exist in his case and to highlight the erroneous allegations presented as facts to the Thai Court (and accepted by them as such), I would on behalf of Mr Sinclair request your assistance in the following respects:

1. To arrange for Detective Sgt Dunn and Detective Sgt McAfee to produce the original of the alleged statement which Mr Sinclair made to them on the 22nd December, 1978, in the Maha-Chai prison in Thailand.

2. Upon production of this original, for you to forward it to the Thailand Supreme Court so that Mr Sinclair will have the same basic legal rights as he would have in Australia of facing and refuting such an original document in the appeal proceedings.
3. To obtain from Detective Sgt Dunn an explanation of why the original document was not left in Thailand in view of the gravity of the charges presented against Mr Sinclair.

4. To give an assurance that the New South Wales court authorities can provide an authenticated record of certain proceedings before a New South Wales court to the Department of Foreign Affairs, if this information is required by the Thai authorities.
In view of the urgency of these matters, I would appreciate an early response.
Yours sincerely, Alan Missen Senator for Victoria Encs.

talk.start.para: â€”With that letter I sent him also a copy of the letter that I had written to the Attorney-General and a copy of the Attorney-General's reply. I sought to ascertain whether the New South Wales Government would make available the original document, which it is contended is not a genuine document, so that it could be inspected by forensic experts and could then be returned, as it should be, to the Thailand Supreme Court and used in the appeal which my constituent was then to undergo. I also sought authentication of documents in New South Wales because in a case in the New South Wales court the original informer-the man who originally gave evidence against Sinclair-in subsequent court proceedings against Sinclair's son and others on conspiracy charges admitted that he had made these statements merely to satisfy the police, and that they were not true. That request was made to the Hon. Neville Wran on 30 June. Never has any satisfaction come from that request despite much more correspondence since. That letter was acknowledged by the Premier's Department on 5 July. I was told by the Premier's secretary:

speech.para: Mr Wran wishes to say that the matter is in hand and that further advice will be forwarded as early as practicable.
Nothing was forwarded. There was no reply to my letter.

Then, on 10 August, on a television program entitled The Reporters on Channel 10 in New South Wales, the New South Wales Minister for Police, Mr Peter Anderson, displayed the original document which he said was the original document that Sinclair had signed. It was shown to the interviewer but, of course, it was not available for inspection by Sinclair's lawyers or put to any study. As a result of that program-I have heard the tape of the program although I did not see it myself-on 17 August 1982 in this chamber, I asked a question of the Attorney-General in which I again sought his good offices to try to aid the production of this information. The Attorney-General was surprised that I had not been able to get anywhere with the New South Wales Government. He said:
. . . which is disappointing, to say the least, and perhaps surprising also.

I did not receive any further assistance in getting the information. I wrote again to the Premier of New South Wales the following week, on 23 August 1982. I seek leave to have that letter incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA-THE SENATE
Commonwealth Parliament Offices 400 Flinders Street, Melbourne 3000 Telegraphic Address: 'COMMEMROOM', MELBOURNE Telephone: 62 2521 23rd August, 1982
The Hon. N. K. Wran, Q.C., M.P.,
Premier of New South Wales,
State Office Block,
Macquarie Street,
SYDNEY, N.S.W. 2000
My dear Premier,
Re: Mr. William Sinclair

I refer to my letter to you of the 30th June, 1982, in which I sought information concerning the documents held by the New South Wales police in respect to the charges against this Australian citizen, that are still pending on appeal in Thailand.
I enclose, for your information, a copy of the question I asked in the Senate last Tuesday of the Attorney-General, and his reply. I trust that he has been in communication with you on this subject.

I want to emphasize that I am particularly concerned that the original document , which is alleged to have been signed by Mr. William Sinclair, be made available for inspection by him and his legal and forensic experts. This document was, according to evidence given in the Thai court, made available to that court after the case was adjourned to enable this to be done but, of course , it now appears from the disclosure made by your Minister of Police on a recent television programme, that the original is still in the possession of the Minister. Apparently, what is in the Thai court is, again, another photostat.

It is, of course, desired that the authenticity of this original document be tested and that subsequently it be made available to the Thai court, so that the interests of this Australian citizen in a foreign court can be preserved and properly tested.
I trust you will let me now have a reply to my earlier correspondence.
Yours sincerely, ALAN MISSEN Senator for Victoria

talk.start.para: â€”In that letter, I pointed out what had happened in respect of the production of the document on television. I pointed out that I still required the information, that it was needed by my constituent and that I was very concerned that it had not been made available as requested. I received a reply on behalf of the Premier from the Honourable Kevin Stewart, M.P., one of Mr Wran's Ministers, dated 7 September 1982. I seek leave to have that letter incorporated in Hansard.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Premier of New South Wales
7 September 1982 Dear Senator Missen,
I refer to your personal representations on behalf of Mr William Charles Sinclair.

Following your approach, I have been in touch with my colleague, the Minister for Police and Emergency Services. He informs me that the original statement made by Mr Sinclair in a Thai prison on 22nd December 1978, was produced by Detective Sergeant Dunn for the Court in Thailand at the hearing of the charge against Mr Sinclair. With the approval of the Presiding Judge, the original document was released to Detective Sergeant Dunn and returned to Australia for production at Court proceedings then under consideration, while a copy was retained by the Thai Court.

In addition, the Minister of Justice has advised that he has been unable to identify any proceedings now before any New South Wales Court involving findings concerning Mr Sinclair, or admitted evidence provided by him. If Mr Sinclair is referring to a Royal Commission, he enjoys the same rights of access to records as any other party to the proceedings, whether such a person is the accused or a witness called to give evidence.

In view of your further representations requesting that the original of the statement made by Mr Sinclair be made available for inspection by him and his legal experts, I have sought further advice from Mr Anderson, and will be in touch with you as soon as practicable.
I trust this information is of some assistance to Mr William Sinclair.
Yours sincerely, KEVIN STEWART for the Premier
Senator Alan Missen,
Commonwealth Parliament Offices,
400 Flinders Street
Melbourne, Vic. 3000.

talk.start.para: â€”There were two interesting points in that reply. We were informed by Mr Stewart that the original document which should, of course, have been in the Thai court and which apparently has never been in the Thai court, had been returned to the police by the presiding judge and returned to Australia . He also complained that he could not identify the proceedings which I was talking about. I had always been talking about proceedings in Thailand. He seemed to be somewhat confused. He could not identify any New South Wales court proceedings in which the document might be required. An extraordinary piece of obfuscation took place at that stage. Following that, I wrote again to the Premier in a letter dated 26 October 1982 to clarify this matter. I seek leave to incorporate that letter in Hansard, Mr President.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
PARLIAMENT OF AUSTRALIA-THE SENATE
Australian Parliament Offices 400 Flinders Street, Melbourne, 3000 Telegraphic Address: 'COMMEMROOM', MELBOURNE Telephone: 62 2521
26 October 1982
The Hon. N. K. Wran, Q.C., M.P.
Premier
State Office Block
Macquarie Street,
Sydney, N.S.W. 2000
My dear Premier,

Re: Mr William Sinclair Having now returned to Australia I have had the opportunity of considering your reply dated 7 September 1982 (under the hand of Hon. Kevin Stewart, M.P.) relating to the representations made by me in my letters to you of the 30 June and 23 August 1982.

The representations concern the documents which are held by the New South Wales police relating to the charges against Mr William Sinclair, that are still pending on appeal in Thailand. The references in your reply to proceedings now before courts in New South Wales or to Royal Commissions are confusing-I have never suggested there is any current litigation save the pending appeal in Thailand.

I am most concerned about the apparent confusion which exists as to why the original document is required. I point out that, ''the original document is required first for for forensic study and then for return to Thailand in connection with the appeal in Thailand'' (not any litigation in New South Wales) .

I said in my earlier correspondence with you on this matter, ''it is desired that the authenticity of this original document be tested and that it be made available to the Thai court, so that the interests of this Australian citizen in a foreign court can be preserved and properly tested''. In the light of additional information, this becomes of even greater relevance.

I note the statement by the New South Wales Minister for Police and Emergency Services that the original statement was produced to the Thai Court and subsequently released by that court to Detective Sergeant Dunn and returned to Australia.

I enclose a photostat of a statutory declaration by Chai Suawansri (Mr William Sinclair's trial attorney in Thailand) dated 11 October 1982, (the original of which can be produced) which confirms that there is ''no evidence in the record of the Criminal Court that the court was ever shown or received the original of said purported document''.

I note that you were seeking further advice in respect to my representations that the original of the statement be produced for forensic inspection and subsequently returned to the Thai Court. I request an urgent reply to those representations.
Yours sincerely,
ALAN MISSEN Senator for Victoria Enc.

talk.start.para: â€”In that letter I pointed out that I was not talking about any New South Wales proceedings, that the document was required for forensic studies here and also for production to the Thai court. I reiterated my demand that an injustice was being done by reason of that. Meanwhile, I had also obtained a telegram from the attorney who had at all stages acted for Mr Sinclair in Thailand. His name is Chai Suawansri. He made a statutory declaration at the Australian Embassy on 11 October 1982. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a photostat copy of that declaration, Mr President.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
TILLEKE & GIBBINS
Registered Ordinary PartnershipAdvocates & Solicitors(Founded A.D. 1902)
Wang Lee Bldg. 297 Suriwongse Road Bangkok-Thailand Cables: ''Lyman'' or '' Brigson'' Bangkok Telephone Nos. 234-5173 Telex: ''82978 LYMAN TH''
Mr Chai Suawansri being duly sworn deposes and says:

1. I am a member in good standing of the Thai Bar and have been so since 1935 ( B.E. 2478). I am also the senior trial attorney for the law firm of Tilleke & Gibbins, R.O.P. of 297 Suriwongse Road, Bangkok, Thailand and in this capacity I and those under my direct supervision presented Mr William Charles Sinclair in the case in which he was prosecuted by the Public Prosecutor of Thailand on charges involving the possession for sale of heroin and attempting to export the same from Thailand which charges were tried before the Criminal Court in Bangkok from 1979 to 1981 under case Number Black 2190/2522, Number Red 477/2524.

2. I am familiar with all the evidence submitted in the case against Mr Sinclair, et al, and have thoroughly reviewed the court file in said case. With respect to a record of interview purportedly made between William Charles Sinclair and an Australian Police Officer Barry Dunn at the Bangkok Special Prison on or about 22 December 1978, there is no evidence in the record of the Criminal Court that the court was ever shown or received the original of said purported document.
Chai Suawansri
Subscribed and sworn to before me at the Australian Embassy this Eleventh day of October, 1982.
A. L. MOORE Consul

talk.start.para: â€”In that document Mr Chai makes it clear that he acted at all times for Mr Sinclair and he was familiar with all of the evidence. With respect to the record of interview which is the subject of challenge, he said:
