speech.para: . . . There is no evidence in the record of the Criminal Court that the court was ever shown or received the original of said purported document.

Of course, that flies entirely in the face of the statements made in the correspondence I have received from the New South Wales authority. The position is that following this Mr Sinclair was advised that he had to return to Thailand . He had to face the trial. Here he was, of course, without the evidence, having been completely stopped from receiving it. I therefore sent a telegram to the Premier of New South Wales in strong terms on 3 December 1982. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a copy of that telegram, Mr President.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Telegram: Sent 4.30 p.m. 3 December, 1982.
Hon. Neville Wran, M.P.,
Premier,
Parliament House,
Sydney, New South Wales

I have written to you several times without a substantive reply seeking that your Government make available for forensic study and then return to the Thai Court of the alleged original statement by Mr William Sinclair which your Minister for Police produced on a television programme recently. William Sinclair is now required to return to Thailand to face the court on the 14 December 1982. Your failure to allow this Australian citizen to test evidence and make it available to the court may lead to his incarceration in Thailand and possibly to the loss of his life. I require an urgent reply to my long standing representations on his behalf.
Alan Missen Senator for Victoria

talk.start.para: â€”I pointed out in that telegram that the original document had been produced on television, yet it was not being made available for study. I pointed out that the man had to face the possibility of returning to a court where he may be incarcerated, that a man of nearly 70 years could face death because of this and because of the neglect to uphold his rights as a citizen. I turn to two interesting documents, both dated 9 December 1982. The New South Wales Ombudsman had been brought into this matter at that stage by the representatives of Mr Sinclair. To my telegram I received from the Premier of New South Wales, the Honourable Neville Wran, a reply dated 9 December 1982. I seek leave to incorporate that document in Hansard, Mr President.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Premier of New South Wales
9 Dec. 1982 Dear Senator Missen,
I refer to your personal represetations on behalf of Mr William Sinclair.

As you know, following your approach, I discussed your representations with my colleague the Minister for Police and Emergency Services. Mr Anderson has now informed me that the original document will be produced upon request by the Thailand Supreme Court, or any other properly constituted Court within Australia , providing a special request is made by the Thai Government through diplomatic channels.
The Minister asked me to mention that the Commissioner of Police views with concern the inferences raised and refutes any suggestion of impropriety involved .
Yours sincerely, NEVILLE WRAN Premier
Senator A. J. Missen,
Australian Parlament Offices,
400 Flinders Steet,
Melbourne 3000

talk.start.para: â€”It is interesting that in that letter the Premier, apart from expressing concern that I was throwing doubts of impropriety on the part of the police officers involved-I certainly was doing so-went on to say:

speech.para: . . . the original document will be produced upon request by the Thailand Supreme Court, or any other properly constituted Court within Australia, providing a special request is made by the Thai Government through diplomatic channels.

That is apparently the arrangement that would have to be made. It was not made. A letter of the same date which was written by the Police Commissioner in New South Wales shows that a completely opposite thing was done. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a copy of a letter dated 9 December 1982 from Commissioner of Police Abbott to the Ombudsman in New South Wales.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Police Department
Police Headquarters

14-24 College Street, Sydney, Box 45, G.P.O. Sydney, N.S.W. 2001 Telegrams and Cables: ''Nemesis'' Sydney JD:BJE Our reference: CC1-55324/3571 Your reference: K/51681 CW:JS Telephone: 339 0277 Extension: 5326 9 December 1982
The Ombudsman
14th Floor,
175 Pitt Street,
Sydney, NSW 2000
Dear Sir,
I refer to your letter, with attached documents, in respect of a complaint made to you by Mr Peter Steer of Greenhouse Publications Pty Ltd, on behalf of Mr William Sinclair.

The original record of interview recorded on 22 December 1978, when Mr Sinclair was interviewed by Detective Sergeants Dunn and McAfee was tendered to the court in Thailand while Detective Sergeant Dunn was actually giving evidence. The presiding judge carefully examined the original document against a copy, and allowed the original to be returned to Detective Sergeant Dunn for production at court in New South Wales, the copy being retained by the judge.

The original record of interview is not in the possession on my Department having been given into the custody of Mr Chamchalerm, the Thai Prosecutor who conducted the trial in Bangkok of Messrs Sinclair, Fellows and Hayward, for attachment to the Thai court papers.
It is open, of course, to Mr Sinclair to make any represent- ation in respect of the original record of interview to the Thai court at the hearing of his Appeal.
When records of interview are conducted between police and members of the public an exact copy of the document is given to the person interviewed, the original being retained for court purposes.
Yours faithfully, C. R. ABBOT Commissioner

talk.start.para: â€”That letter tells us that the original document, which was shown on television, which had apparently been available at all times before that and which I had last demanded on 26 October, has been handed back to somebody and has gone back to Thailand. I am told that it went back to Thailand on about 10 November. In the letter which the Commissioner of Police wrote, he did not say anything about receiving any diplomatic request. He said that a Thai public prosecutor, Mr Chamchalerm, who conducted the trial, had been in Australia and had been handed the original record to take back to Thailand. The document has left the country and it cannot be subject to any proper study in this country now.

speech.para: It does not cease there. The position is confirmed in a telex received from the solicitor acting in Thailand for Mr William Sinclair, Mr Chai Lyman. I seek leave to incorporate that telex of 14 December 1982 in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Attn William Sinclair

With reference to our telephone conversation you asked me to ask Mr Chamchalerm , the Thai Public Prosecutor whether he has received your original statement made to Det. Sgt Dunn from Det. Sgt Dunn on the 12th November 1982.

Please be informed that I was told by Mr Chamchalerm that one closed envelope was handed over to him in Nov. 1982 in Sydney by Det. Sgt Dunn who requested him to hand it over to police Major Virat. Mr Chamchalerm did not open the envelope but sent it to Major Virat through a messenger without any knowledge of what it contained. Mr Chamchalerm advises that major Virat should be asked directly about this matter.
Rgds, Lyman (Chai)

talk.start.para: â€”In that telex, Mr Chai Lyman makes it clear that he has spoken to Mr Chamchalerm. Mr Chamchalerm was not told what this document was. He was handed a sealed envelope which was addressed to Major Virat, the man who it was alleged, among others, conspired to produce this document which is challenged as being a fraudulent document. The document was handed to Mr Chamchalerm to take back to Thailand and he handed it over on his return. He is indignant that he now finds that he was the unknowing medium for delivering the letter not to the Thai Supreme Court but to the man against whom the allegations are made. The document has left Australia. For all I know it may, no longer exist. But there has been an extraordinary record of obfuscation, delay, denial, and inconsistencies between the authorities in the State of New South Wales.

speech.para: I believe that it is important to put these matters on the record. Mr Sinclair is an Australian citizen. He is a man who I think has had a somewhat difficult past. Some authorities may think that he is a man who has not shown a great deal of credibility in the past. They might have even hoped that he would stay in gaol in Thailand and not come back to Australia. This man has rights. At all stages he has protested his innocence. In fact, the courts in Thailand have found that he is not guilty, that he is not part of the charges which have been raised. As the position stands at the moment, his bail is now forfeited. There is a warrant for his arrest. This country may be asked to extradite him. I believe that this is a shocking record, and an indictment of the Government and the authorities of the State of New South Wales, of the police and of the higher officials who have sought, in the last six months, to avoid allowing evidence to be obtained and given. I hope that both the Attorney-General and the Commonwealth Government will feel it necessary now to intervene or at least bring their good offices to bear to ensure that some justice is done in this case. I hope that the people of Australia will be able to appreciate that injustice is being done to a citizen of this country.

speech.speaker: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

talk.start.para: â€”I take this opportunity briefly to raise a matter in connection with the Royal Australian Air Force base at Learmonth and the proposed base at Derby, both in the north-west of Western Australia. The base at Learmonth has been operational for several years now and, as the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) recently pointed out, has been the subject of recent capital works to improve the airfield's capacity for handling aircraft deployments. That work includes extensions to some of the parking aprons, improvement to flight line facilties and upgrading of the fuel storage capacity on the base. I understand that the base now has a fuel storage capacity of some two million litres in semi-buried tanks supplied by road from Port Hedland, some 919 kilometres to the north. I suggest that that is a quite large quantity of fuel and a very considerable distance over which it must be transported.

speech.para: I also point out to the Senate that as the main Air Force installation in Western Australia north of the 26th parallel-indeed, the only installation between Pearce just north of Perth and Darwin in the Northern Territory-it would be extremely important in the event that Australia became involved in some sort of threat or perceived threat. Yet, as I said, Learmonth receives its fuel from Port Hedland by road transport. It is almost the same distance as from Canberra to Brisbane. In the event of hostilities that supply line would be extremely vulnerable. The single road link between the two towns would be a logical primary target, and a successful strike on that road would leave the north-west of Western Australia devoid of air cover except for that which could be provided by using the fuel already on the base. It is a matter about which, in my view, we should all be concerned.

I commend the Government for its initiative so far in increasing the air defence of the north-west of Western Australia by constructing a new air base in the region. Construction of the new $50m project near Derby is expected to commence next year. It will provide the next step in what the Minister recently described as the 'umbrella of forward operating facilities' in the north and north-west of Western Australia which will eventually include the construction of a patrol boat base at Finucane Island off Port Hedland. As I said, I commend the Government for this initiative which will greatly assist in coastal surveillance as well as provide the infrastructure to deal with an attack on this vulnerable portion of the nation's vital coastline. However, it would seem that the same problem has arisen with respect to the new facility at Derby as arose at Learmonth. It is no secret that the harbour at Derby is very shallow and has siltation problems. Recently the State ship Pilbara ran aground at Derby , prompting an investigation of the harbour facilities which concluded that expensive dredging would be necessary to maintain the harbour. Given the small trade through the port, such expenses were deemed not to be necessary. The State ship Pilbara which ran aground at Derby was a vessel of 13,000 tonnes. The average tanker engaged in the Australian coastal trade, the BP Enterprise type, is a vessel of about 26,000 tonnes. There is clearly no prospect that vessels of that size could use Derby and, therefore, no prospect that the airfield at Derby could be supplied with fuel in that way.

There are two alternatives, as I see it. Firstly, coastal tankers of the BP Enterprise type could supply the base through the deep-water port at Broome, though that would once again necessitate a vulnerable road section. In this case the fuel would have to be transported about 220 kilometres from Derby to Broome, once again a costly exercise on what in a time of hostilities would be a very fragile link indeed. The alternative is to use the shallow draft Chinese tankers of about 3,000 tonnes which can use the port of Derby. I simply say to honourable senators that the experience of the company which operates through Derby in that way has not been encouraging. Indeed, I am advised that the company is looking at long term alternatives at present. Given that fact, I would not have thought it a viable proposition for the Royal Australian Air Force to consider supplying fuel to its new base at Derby in that way. As I said , that once again leaves road transport. In fact both RAAF bases in the north- west of Western Australia will be dependent for their fuel on single road links. I say single road links because in the north of Western Australia there is rarely an alternative route.

I hope that in the case of the Derby base, which is not yet built, such a simple thing has not been overlooked by defence planners. If it has not, I would be pleased if the Minister could explain to the Senate how this problem can be overcome. At Learmonth, on the other hand, the existing base has a very real problem. Fuel is rarely taken by road from a port almost 1,000 kilometres away. Therefore, I urge the Government to consider sea-fed storage faclities being developed at the United States Navy base at Exmouth which would have the capacity to take the coastal tankers operating along our coast. From there it would involve a road journey of only 22 kilometres or, if it were thought to be warranted, a buried pipline could be installed from Exmouth to Learmonth. This would guarantee the security of supply of fuel to Learmonth which I believe could be very important if Australia were ever to be involved in hostilities along our western coastline. Even if we are not involved in such conflicts, the advantages of a sea-fed fuel supply to Learmonth are obvious. There are economic advantages-cost savings brought about by bulk transportation of fuel in tankers rather than in several trucks run and maintained by supplying oil companies at the expense of the RAAF. Certainly there is nothing in road transport for the oil companies. Their costs are defrayed by the Government through simply being able to build the extra cost into the cost of the fuel. However, I understand that they too would welcome this initiative because of the greater convenience it would afford them in this trade. The Royal Australian Air Force should also presumably welcome it for the eventual cost savings, the undoubted convenience, greater surety of supply and, above all, for the obvious advantage that supplies would not be so easily placed in jeopardy in a crisis. In conclusion, I therefore seek a response from the Minister for Defence Support (Mr Viner) on the viability of a sea-fed fuel supply line at Learmonth and a clarification of the position at the proposed base at Derby.

speech.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: â€”All three speakers who took part in the adjournment debate tonight have raised matters of considerable complexity. Senator Coates, though his comments were about Mr Lucas , really went to a number of issues which go quite widely on a number of our practices in general aviation. He asked a number of specific questions. His comments, though ex parte, are still important. I want to put them to the Minister for Aviation (Mr Fife) for careful consideration. I believe they are matters which warrant an investigation and they will be referred to Mr Fife.

speech.para: Senator Missen has presented a full account of some problems affecting Mr William Sinclair. If Senator Missen is right, then there may need to be some explanation as to whether this man has had any denial of due process. If that is the case, it is appropriate that it be examined. I agree with Senator Missen that irrespective of what people have said about Mr Sinclair he has the same rights as anyone in getting justice before the courts. I will refer that matter to the Acting Attorney-General (Mr N. A. Brown).

Finally, I am grateful to Senator Crichton-Browne for his comments about the new bases at Learmonth and Derby. He has told us that there is a solution in sight for Learmonth but that the Derby situation is unresolved. He is concerned both on defence and on economic grounds that something needs to be done about this. It is a matter which will be referred to the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) for his careful consideration.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate ajourned at 11.37 p.m.

question.speaker: Grimes Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

question.para: (1) What recent surveys have been undertaken to ascertain the extent of hearing defects in Aboriginal adults and children.
(2) What are the estimates in each State for Aborigines having (a) no hearing defects or (b) serious hearing defects.
(3) What are the estimates in each State in (a) rural and (b) metropolitan areas, of hearing problems of the Aboriginal people.

answer.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) I am advised by the relevant health authorities that the position is as follows:
In New South Wales no recent surveys have been undertaken but Aboriginal children in most parts of the State are regularly screened for hearing defects.

In Victoria Aboriginal adults attending the Aboriginal Health Service, Fitzroy have been surveyed. Aboriginal children in the country regions of Warrnambool, Swan Hill and Shepparton have also been surveyed.

In Queensland a Hearing Conservation and Treatment Program for ear diseases in the State's Aboriginals has been conducted since 1974. In 1981, 17 rural communities were surveyed and during 1982 up to and including May, 14 have been assessed.
In South Australia surveys have been undertaken since 1970 in remote communities and in the north-west of the State, in 1974 and 1980 and yearly since then.

In Western Australia fifteen surveys have been mounted during the last two years to estimate the extent of hearing problems and ear disease in Aboriginal children aged 0-12 years. The principal areas surveyed are Eastern Goldfields, Murchison, Pilbara and Kimberley.
In Tasmania no recent surveys have been undertaken.
In the Northern Territory surveys of hearing defects in Aboriginal children are ongoing. The most recent was in 1981 in the southern region.

In the Australian Capital Territory the main Aboriginal population is located in the Wreck Bay area of the Jervis Bay territory. No surveys of hearing defects are undertaken but routine examination of toddlers, pre-school and primary children are carried out. Secondary school children attend N.S.W. High Schools and are screened in that State's school program.

(2) and (3) New South Wales. Accurate estimates of the number of Aboriginals in the State having hearing defects cannot be made. Limited information would be available for some communities but it would not be possible to extrapolate such information for the State. No accurate estimates are available on the prevalence of hearing problems in either urban or metropolitan areas.

Victoria. The Fitzroy (metropolitan) survey revealed that more than 50% of Aboriginal adults have a significant hearing loss. In country regions, the Warrnambool survey indicated that 33% of Aboriginal children suffer a significant hearing loss. The Swan Hill survey disclosed a figure of 25% and the Shepparton survey 36%. Based on these figures it could be estimated that 30-35% of Aboriginal people in Victoria have a significant hearing problem but it is not possible to separate rural and metropolitan populations.

Queensland. The Hearing Conservation and Treatment Program referred to in (1) aims to identify ear disease and hearing loss in Aboriginal communities, to provide and evaluate treatment and to improve rural health by increasing awareness of ear disease and hearing loss. It is conducted by the Faculty of Medicine, University of Queensland with Commonwealth funds. In 1981 and 1982 the prevalence of hearing loss was as follows:

I am advised that the Queensland Government does not seek or maintain statistics that identify race and that consequently comprehensive statistics related to Aboriginals as a distinct group are not available.

South Australia: The main emphasis on the surveys referred to in (1) has been on detecting the cause of defects viz middle ear infection. A 1971 survey in the Yalata region disclosed that 23% of children examined required treatment for hearing loss. In the remote north-west a survey in 1974 showed 42% of Aboriginal people evidenced ear drum perforation and some hearing loss. In a 1980 survey the incidence of perforation was 21%. A generalist in 1976 and a specialist in 1977 reported a lower incidence of middle ear disease than was found in the 1974 survey. In 1978, almost 350 children under 15 years of age in remote communities , were examined and 27% showed perforation and received specialist treatment. In 1980 about 80% of Aboriginals had no significant hearing defects and it was also estimated that less than 1% would suffer from serious defects. No figures are available to estimate the hearing problems of Aboriginal people in other rural or the metropolitan areas.

Western Australia: Of 1 054 Aboriginal children from the initial surveys, 69% were found to have normal hearing and 31% had a hearing loss in one or both ears . 21% had a mild loss, 9% had a moderate loss and 1% had a severe loss.
No surveys have been carried out on adults. It is estimated that in adult Aboriginals 10% would suffer hearing loss.

Tasmania: No figures are available.

Northern Territory: The 1981 survey showed that 38.6% of Aboriginal children had some degree of hearing impairment in one or both ears. No true comparison between urban and rural Aboriginal hearing defects can be made because urban surveys do not distinguish between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal children. However a survey of all school children in Darwin in 1981 indicated that 12.5% suffered some degree of hearing impairment. No data are available on Aboriginal adults.

Australian Capital Territory: The routine examinations of young children referred to in (1) have revealed 11% suffering hearing defects, none of which were severe. No data are available on Aboriginal adults.

question.speaker: Ryan Sen S.M.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 24 August 1982:

question.para: (1) What airstrip facilities exist at the following Northern Territory communities: (a) Galiwinku; (b) Bathurst Island; (c) Melville Island; and (d) Maningrida.
(2) What sorts of planes can now land at these four communities.
(3) What work has been carried out on airstrips in these four locations.
(4) What has been the cost of any work done at these four communities during the last two years, and from which departmental or authority budget has this expenditure come from.
(5) What was the purpose of any upgrading of airstrips in these four locations.
(6) Will these airstrips be used at all for defence/military requirements; if so, will they represent military targets in any war situation.

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) Galiwinku Aboriginal community is served by a licensed aerodrome known as Elcho Island. The aerodrome consists of a sealed 30 metre wide runway 1,440 metres in length contained within a 90 metre width strip. A sealed taxiway and apron are available for aircraft parking.

(b) Bathurst Island Aerodrome consists of a sealed 30 metre wide runway 1,350 metres in length within a 90 metre width strip. A sealed taxiway and apron are available for aircraft parking together with a terminal building.
Melville Island Aboriginal community is served by two licensed aerodromes: Snake Bay and Garden Point.

Melville Island (Snake Bay) Aerodrome consists of a sealed 30 metre width runway 1,440 metres in length and contained within a 90 metre width strip. A taxiway, apron and terminal facility are available.

Melville Island (Garden Point) Aerodrome consists of a gravelled unsealed 30 metre wide runway 1,138 metres in length and contained within a 90 metre width strip. A taxiway, apron and terminal building are available.
(d) Maningrida Aerodrome consists of a sealed 30 metre width runway 1,530 metres in length and contained within a 90 metre width strip. An apron, terminal and refuelling facilities are available.

(2) (a)-(d) Apart from Melville Island (Garden Point) Aerodrome aircraft up to and including the Fokker F27 Friendship can use the aerodrome. These are classified as aircraft below 23,000 kg maximum take-off weight. In the case of Garden Point Aerodrome the unsealed surface normally restricts use to those aircraft which are below 5,700 kg maximum take-off weight.
(3) (a) Galiwinku (Elcho Island) Aerodrome was upgraded and sealed during 1981.
Works: Construction of sealed runway, taxiway and apron.
(b) Bathurst Island Aerodrome was built on new site during 1976 as an unsealed facility. It was sealed in 1980.
Works: Construction of sealed runway, taxiway and apron and of a terminal building.
(c) Melville Island (Snake Bay) Aerodrome was upgraded and sealed in 1981.
Works: Construction of sealed runway, taxiway and apron and of a small terminal building.

Melville Island (Garden Point) Aerodrome was upgraded by the construction of a new unsealed gravel runway in 1975. The original runway was abandoned at that time due to its unsatisfactory longitudinal profile.
Works: Only routine maintenance works have been carried out to the runway in recent years. A terminal building was completed in mid-1982.
(4) (a)-(d) I cannot provide details sought, as the aerodromes are not owned by the Commonwealth.
(5) (a)-(d) Each of the four aerodromes was upgraded for the introduction of the Swearingen Metroliner (a light commuter aircraft) by the Northern Territory Government.
(6) (a)-(d) The Minister for Defence has provided the following in regard to this part of the honourable senator's question:

During a time of threat to Australia it cannot be discounted that there could be a requirement for the airstrips (and a wide range of other civil resources) to be used by the Australian Defence Force in the defence of Australia. Whether there would be a need for these particular airstrips to be utilised and the nature of defence use, if any, would depend very much upon the circumstances at the time. Exercises for the Australian Defence Force in northern Australia are not restricted only to the use of Commonwealth-owned facilities and some defence use may occur in the future in this context, although none is specifically planned at this stage. There is no threat of military hostilities against northern Australia in the foreseeable future.

If hostilities were to occur these five airstrips along with a wide range of other civil facilities in the north could be potential targets. Defence Force use of any particular facility while perhaps, but not necessarily, increasing its value as a target, also contributes substantially to its defence against attack, as well as contributing to the overall defence of Australia.

question.speaker: Grimes Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 7 September 1982:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister for Health aware of the growing concern about the lack of funding for the care of confused, active elderly people who do not qualify for the frail aged subsidy.

(2) Does the Government have any plans to introduce a subsidy to enable organisations to provide the necessary 24-hour supervision in hostel-type accommodation; if not, is the Minister aware that organisations already providing such care on a limited basis may be forced to discontinue because of the high costs.

answer.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) I am advised that the personal care subsidy payable by the Department of Social Security to hostel residents in receipt of approved personal care services was increased from $80 to $120 per qualified resident per 28 day period with effect from 6 July 1982. This change will give greater financial assistance to organisations providing care within hostels for active, confused elderly persons. A Working Party consisting of representatives of the Australian Affiliation of Voluntary Care Associations, the Australian Council on the Ageing , and the Departments of Social Security and Health has been established to review the present basis for recurrent Commonwealth financial assistance to hostels. One of the matters being considered by the Working Party is whether additional subsidy should be paid in respect of care provided to active, confused elderly persons.

The Ministers for Social Security and Veterans' Affairs and I are currently reviewing the whole question of care for the aged, with the assistance of an Interdepartmental Committee including the Departments of Health, Social Security and Veterans' Affairs and chaired by the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat. I expect that the care of the confused, active elderly people will be considered in this review.

question.speaker: Childs Sen B.K.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 September 1982:

question.para: (1) What action has the Treasurer taken to eliminate the practice of 'cash in hand' payments in the last seven years in relation to the payment (or non- payment) of income tax under the Income Tax Assessment Act.
(2) What knowledge does the Treasurer have of tax avoidance practices amongst employers in the roofing industry in New South Wales.
(3) Is the Treasurer aware that roofing contractors are indulging in the practice of cash in hand payments, pyramid sub-contracting and under-award payments in that industry.

(4) Is the Treasurer also aware that the Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Union of Australia has campaigned against these tax evasion practices and as a result of this campaign the assistant secretary of the Union in New South Wales, Mr Glen Batchelor, has been reliably informed that a contract has been taken out on his life and he is now under police protection.

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: â€”The Treasurer has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) In my 1982-83 Budget Speech, I announced that the Government is to take action against certain tax evasion practices in the so-called 'cash' economy. The new measures-the deduction of tax at source in relation to selected payments for labour and services and associated arrangements for reporting by householders of payments made in connection with certain building and construction projects-are aimed at preventing evasion of tax by failure to declare income consisting of such payments.

The Government's decision to introduce these measures, with effect from 1 July 1983, follows long and careful consideration of the most appropriate and effective means to counter this kind of evasion, which has grown in recent years because persons who have traditionally stood in the relationship of employer and employee are, for various reasons, entering into arrangements under which the former employee assumes the role of an independent contractor providing labour and services who is entitled to be paid without deduction of tax at source.

The Government is also currently reviewing the adequacy of the penalty provisions of the taxation laws with a view to increasing the level of taxpayer compliance with those laws. While I cannot, at this stage, indicate the likely outcome of this review, I can say that significant deterrents to tax evasion practices, whether involving the 'cash' economy or not, are under consideration.

(2) and (3) I am not aware of any particular tax avoidance or other practices that are peculiar to people in the roofing industry in New South Wales. I am, however, aware that some people engaged in the building and other industries do seek cash in hand payments for labour and services free of tax deductions, and that in many cases these people have failed to disclose this income in their tax returns.

(4) I had not been aware that the Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Union had been campaigning as advised by the honourable senator. The Union and its officials have not made any representations to me, or to the Commissioner of Taxation with whom I discussed this aspect, regarding this matter. However, if the Union is able to supply the Taxation Office with information regarding specific cases where tax evasion is suspected to have occurred, these will be fully investigated.

question.speaker: Button Sen J.N.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 14 September 1982:

question.para: (1) Are salaries for engineers in the Australian Public Service (APS) well below those in the State Public Services, and has the Australian Public Service Board admitted that engineer salaries in the APS are too low.
(2) Is the starting salary for a draftsman higher than the starting salary for a qualified professional engineer in the APS.
(3) Was this anomaly created by the Public Service Board over five months ago, and has it since taken no action to remedy the situation.

(4) Has this failure of the Public Service Board to perform its statutory duty led to overwhelming dissatisfaction and frustration amongst engineers in the Australian Public Service, resulting recently in industrial action which may delay some major engineering projects; if so, will the Prime Minister take action to remedy this situation by directing the Public Service Board to perform its duty, or by removing personnel management in technological areas from its ambit.

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) to (4) The Public Service Board has informed me that on 21 October 1982 the Acting Public Service Arbitrator issued a consent determination giving effect to salary increases offered to engineer or related groups by the Board on 24 September 1982.

It is the view of the Board that the salaries of engineers employed by the Australian Public Service are now broadly comparable with those of engineers in the New South Wales Public Service. Any anomalies that it is claimed existed between graduate engineers and drafting grades prior to the increases were largely the result of the different timing of pay reviews concerning those groups. The salary of a graduate engineer is now higher than the starting salary of a draftsman.

In addition the Public Service Board also considers that these increases should largely, if not totally, remove situations where the maximum salary of a subordinate technical officer/draftsman exceeds that of his professional supervisor. A process for dealing with any remaining situations of this nature was included in the offer that was accepted by the relevant organisations.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General, upon notice, on 22 September 1982:

question.speaker: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 12 October 1982:

question.para: (1) Are clitoridectomies performed in Australia; if so, could the Minister indicate how many such operations are performed annually and the age distribution of the females involved.

(2) Could the Minister indicate the reasons for such a procedure to be carried out, and, in particular, is the Minister aware of any such operation being performed for ritualistic rather than medical reasons.
(3) Does the Minister have any evidence of backyard ritual circumcision of young girls, if so, what action does the Government intend to take.
(4) Is the Minister aware of any other medical procedures based primarily on ritualistic grounds which are practised on migrants in Australia.

answer.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes, although precise figures on the number of these operations are not available. Based on claims under Item 6299 of the Medical Benefits Schedule-' Amputation of the Clitoris' (the only item covering operations on the clitoris), my Department estimates that there were 23 cases in 1979-80 and 12 cases in 1980 -81. These are the most recent years for which estimates are available. Age breakdown is not available and the data may be incomplete as they do not include operations for which no claims have been made.

(2) I am not aware that any of these operations are carried out for ritual rather than for medical reasons. Previous investigations by my Department revealed that most operations were carried out in cases of indeterminate sex of children due to congenital or genetic disorders.

(3) No. However, traditionally such ritual circumcision operations are carried out by tribal women in secrecy and not by doctors. Such operations would only come to notice should complications arise or during gynaecological examination in later life. Appeals for information on this matter were made in 1979-80 through the Maternal Health and Reproduction (Standing) Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council to the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners and the Royal Australian College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists. A similar appeal was published in the Australian Medical Association 'Monthly Bulletin'. While no confirmation of Australian cases was obtained from any of these sources, my Department continues to keep the matter under review.
In any event, legislative control of such operations is a State responsibility and is covered by common law or the Criminal Code in each State.

(4) Two procedures which, broadly, may be regarded as ritual operations are performed on both migrants and non-migrants. One is circumcision of male infants ; the other is ear-piercing, which is often carried out by non-medical personnel .

question.speaker: Colston Sen M.A.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications , upon notice, on 13 October 1982:

question.para: What plans does Telecom have for the upgrading of telephone facilities on Thursday Island.

answer.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice from the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

answer.para: Telecom proposes to upgrade telephone facilities on Thursday Island in the following way:
(i) By the installation of an automatic exchange;

(ii) By the provision of additional trunk line circuits between Thursday Island and Cairns to improve traffic handling and to enable Island subscribers to be given direct access to the national STD network.

It is presently expected that work on the new automatic exchange should be completed during September 1983. Concurrently at least 12 additional trunk lines will be provided to Thursday Island. A manual trunk exchange will be retained on the Island at this stage to handle subscriber traffic requiring operator assistance.

The next stage planned is the extension of the Cairns-Coen broadband trunk route to Bamaga/Thursday Island. This will cost about $2.5m and is programmed for completion during 1986. Sufficient trunk lines will be obtained from this installation to enable the connection of the Thursday Island exchange to the national STD grid.

question.speaker: Jones Sen G.N.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 20 October 1982:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware that the American incinerator ship Vulcanus has been invited to Victoria to dispose of about ten years' supply of highly dangerous toxic wastes including polychlorinated biphenyls.
(2) Will the Minister grant permission for the visit.

(3) Will the Minister ensure that the ship is able, and encouraged to visit any other states that have stockpiles of toxic waste material as the cost of hiring the Vulcanus limits the number of visits it will be making to Australia, and there is no other method of disposing of highly dangerous toxic waste material available in this country.
(4) Will the Minister ensure that all toxic waste material currently stored by Federal Government departments will be disposed of by the Vulcanus while it is in Australia.

answer.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) ICI Australia Operations Pty Ltd Sydney and B. F. Goodrich Chemical Limited Melbourne have made arrangements for the incinerator ship Vulcanus to come to Australia in December to incinerate at sea stockpiles of wastes from vinyl chloride manufacture. The Brambles subsidiary Cleanaway has proposed that, following the ICI and B. F. Goodrich burns of waste, the Vulcanus incinerate waste polychlorinated biphenyls (PCB's).

(2) The proposals to incinerate at sea wastes from vinyl chloride manufacture were discussed with relevant Commonwealth and State Government organisations and unions. No objections were raised on environmental grounds. The incineration of the ICI waste is planned to commence on 7 December 1982 with the B. F. Goodrich burn to follow. Cleanaways are currently assembling information necessary for assessment of the proposal to incinerate PCB's.

(3) In disposing of wastes from vinyl chloride manufacture the vessel will visit Sydney and Melbourne. With regard to the proposal to incinerate waste PCB' s Cleanaway is investigating the feasibility of collecting material from several States.

question.speaker: Bolkus Sen N.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 21 October 1982:

question.para: (1) Did the Asprey Committee make recommendations in respect of taxation agents certification suggesting that the current practice be reviewed by the Commissioner of Taxation in consultation with members of the accounting profession and organisations representing tax agents, in order 'to develop a question or series of questions that would go further towards securing a statement from the tax agent recording the steps he has taken to ensure the accuracy of the returns covered by his certificate'.
(2) What action has the Government taken to implement this recommendation.

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: â€”The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) This is a matter of administration and, therefore, the responsibility of the Commissioner of Taxation. The Commissioner has advised me that income tax return forms are reviewed each year in the light of Taxation Office experience and suggestions from the accounting profession and other interested organisations and individuals. In the absence of any significant dissatisfaction with the present certificate it has not been considered necessary to follow up the Asprey Committee recommendation. The matter will be kept under annual review .

question.speaker: Bolkus Sen N.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 21 October 1982:

question.para: (1) Did the Asprey committee recommend a general review of the penalty structure under the taxation Act and inter alia;
(a) That where a taxpayer has overpaid tax and is due for a refund, he should receive that refund with interest; and
(b) The need to allow for extensions of time to pay pecuniary penalties.
(2) What action has the Government taken to implement such recommendations.

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: â€”The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1)Yes, but in relation to (1) (a) only where the refund of tax arises out of a successful objection or appeal by the taxpayer. The Asprey Committee did not favour payment of interest on refunds as a general rule.
(2) On 30 May 1982 I announced that the Government would undertake a review of the level of penalties imposed for breaches of the taxation laws.

On 10 August 1982 I made public the results of part of that review, namely, the Government's decision to increase from 10 per cent per annum to 20 per cent per annum the rate of penalty tax for late payment of income tax and other taxes.
At that time I gave details of the Government's intention to introduce a system for payment of interest on refunds of tax that occur as a result of a successful objection or appeal by a taxpayer.

With certain limitations, the present income tax law allows a court which imposes a pecuniary penalty to extend the time for payment or to permit payment of the fine by instalments. However, I recognise that the limitations prescribed may not, in today's society, be ragarded as entirely appropriate and that there is an absence of alternatives to imprisonment for non-payment of court-imposed taxation fines by persons who cannot pay or would experience severe hardship in paying.
A review of these aspects of the taxation laws is being undertaken as part of the general review of penalties and I hope to be in a position to announce the results of the review shortly.

Time for payment of penalties for late lodgment or non-lodgment of taxation returns, for incorrect returns or for late payment of tax which are imposed by statute can, in appropriate circumstances, be extended, or made the subject of payment by instalments, by the Commissioner of Taxation.

question.speaker: Watson Sen J.O.W.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 21 October 1982:

question.para: What steps are being taken by the Department of Health in light of the recent Tylenol disaster in the United States, to ensure that similar interference with drugs does not occur in Australia.

answer.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: My Department is co-operating with the pharmaceutical industry in establishing as early as practicable a working party to examine all aspects of safety packaging of pharmaceuticals. Membership will include an officer of my Department.

question.speaker: Macklin Sen M.J.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 November 1982:

question.para: (1) Did the following long service awards exist for members of the Army prior to 1975: (a) for Australian Regular Army Other Ranks-the Long Service and Good Conduct Medal and the Meritorious Service Medal; (b) for Army Reserve ( previously CMF) Officers-the Efficiency Decoration; (c) for Army Reserve ( previously CMF) Other Ranks-the Efficiency Medal.
(2) Was it recognised, around 1970, that Australian Regular Army Officers were the only category not covered by a Long Service award, and was a decision taken to issue such an award.
(3) Was progress on this decision reported regularly in the Service newspaper Army and did one report state, inter alia, 'the award when issued would carry no post-nominal initials'.
(4) Was the issue of such an award deferred, after 1972, because it was intended to replace it with an equivalent award under the new Australian system of honours.

(5) Did the deferment of the introduction of the Australian system of honours until 14 February 1975 have the effect of rendering ineligible, through retirement, many officers with upwards of thirty years service (including war service) who otherwise could have qualified for the Imperial Long Service award had it been instituted in the early 1970's.

(6) Does the Minister for Defence still consider, as he stated in his reply to my Question No. 1872 (Hansard, page 844, 16 March 1982) that 'Until 14 February 1975, permanent officers in the Defence Force had no expectation of receiving a Long Service Award'.

(7) Does the service given by Australian Regular Army Officers in the period 1945-1975 deserve to be recognised; if so, can steps be taken to make them eligible either for the Australian or Imperial Long Service Award.

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

(2) Until 1975, there was no long service award for which officers of the Permanent Forces were eligible. During the period 1967 to 1972, the Defence Group of Departments examined the general question of awards for the recognition of long service in the Defence Force. A long service award for permanent officers, including Australian Regular Army Officers, was one of a number of options considered. No final decisions were made.
(3) See (2) above. The option of a long service award for permanent officers was the subject of a number of letters to the Editor of the Army newspaper. In reply to one such letter, it was stated:
'. . . that such an award . . . should not carry any entitlement to post- nominal initials.'

(4) See (2) above. Consideration of the matter fell into abeyance in December 1972, when the Prime Minister called for a review of honours and awards practices with a view to establishing an Australian system.
(5) See (2) above. Permanent officers who retired before 14 February 1975 cannot be regarded as having been 'rendered ineligible' for an award which did not exist whilst they were serving.
(6) Yes.

(7) See (5) above. While respecting the significant contribution of Australian Regular Army Officers in the period 1945-1975, there is no intention of extending eligibility for Australian long service awards to Australian Regular Army Officers who retired before 14 February 1975, the date the Australian system of honours and awards was introduced.

question.speaker: Keeffe Sen J.B.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 November 1982:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister for Defence aware that the Navy at Cairns dumped a large number of chairs, apparently in good order and covered either with leather or good quality vinyl upholstery, at the local council tip.
(2) Were a very large number, possibly about 100, single and double inner spring mattresses and foam mattresses and some refrigerators dumped at the same time.

(3) Is the particular dump an area where scavenging is not allowed; if so, is the Minister aware that as soon as the Navy trucks departed the area two vehicles came into the tip, loaded all the material, with the exception of three or four articles and took the furniture away.

(4) Was a very large order placed by the Navy with a local furnishing firm for furnishings to replace the material dumped; if so, was the order placed with the furnishing firm in the vicinity of $70,000 in value.

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1), (2), (3) and (4) Early in August and September 1982 surveys of furniture in married quarters administered by HMAS Cairns were carried out by a Board of Inspectors. Items surveyed included washing machines, clothes dryers and refrigerators.

Those items classified as unserviceable but of some residual value were transferred to the Department of Administrative Services for disposal by auction . Items classified as beyond economical repair were sentenced to disposal by dumping.

Dumping was carried out at the Cairns Municipal Tip by the Navy establishment HMAS Cairns on two occasions, that is, after each survey. Items recorded as having been dumped were: 8 washing machines, 10 clothes dryers, 12 refrigerators , 46 mattresses (single and double), 10 lounge suites, 8 tables (of various types), 37 chairs (lounge, dining and baby), 1 cot, 4 ironing boards.

Before dumping was carried out the Commanding Officer, HMAS Cairns, gave consideration to seeking approval to give the furniture to charity but did not proceed when the local Branch of the Society of St Vincent de Paul assessed the items as being of no use. Any suggestion that some of the items were in good order is therefore incorrect.

Scavenging at the tip is known to be a common practice and no evidence has been found that would suggest collusion between personnel involved in the disposals and other persons who may have illegally removed material from the tip. In any event the surveys and disposals were carried out in accordance with Departmental procedures under Finance Regulations and Directions.

Since June 1981 replacement furniture to the value of $72,807 has been purchased for HMAS Cairns married quarters. In the same period $10,153 has been expended on furniture for new married quarters. These purchases have been made from a number of firms in Cairns.

question.speaker: Ryan Sen S.M.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 17 November 1982:

question.para: (1) Will the Government honour its commitment to ensure that the integrity of Aboriginal reserve boundaries will be maintained by the Queensland State Government when it makes deals of grant in trust to Aboriginal communities.
(2) From what date will the reserve boundaries that are to be maintained, be taken.

(3) Has the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs maintained close contact with the Queensland State Government to ensure that plans for granting deeds of grant in trust respect the Commonwealth's commitment on maintaining the integrity of reserve boundaries.
(4) Can the Minister provide the following information:

(a) will the Palm Island Community be given a deed of grant in trust over Great Palm Island, Curacoa, Esk, Falcon, Eclipse, Brisk and Havannah Islands thereby preserving the integrity of that reserve community area which measures 6252.232 hectares;

(b) will the Weipa South Aboriginal Community be given a deed of grant in trust over the 354835.685 ha (876800 acres) which has been described as that Community 's land in the Queensland Parliament for the last twenty years, or will the deed of grant in trust only cover that 119 ha of the reserve which has not yet been degazetted;
(c) will the 1000 square miles of the Comalco lease (formerly Aboriginal reserve) surrendered back to the Crown five years ago be included in the deed of grant in trust for the Weipa South Community;

(d) will the Cherbourg Aboriginal Community be given a deed of grant in trust over the 12735.064 ha (31469 acres) which has been described as the area of the Cherbourg reserve in the Department of Aboriginal and Islander Advancement Annual Reports to the Queensland Parliament in recent years, or will the deed of grant in trust cover only a quarter of that area;
(e) will the Doomadgee Community be given a deed of grant in trust over the Bayley Point (Old Doomadgee) Reserve; if not, what will become of that reserve;
(f) will the Hopevale Aboriginal Community be given a deed of grant in trust over Reserves 1 and 157 in the County of Banks;

(g) will the community at Lockhart be given a deed of grant in trust over the 313388.838 ha which the Queensland Parliament has been informed is the whole of that community reserve area thereby including reserve numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 6 and 7 in the County of Weymouth;
(h) will the community at Wujal Wujal be given a deed of grant in trust over reserves 124 and 125 in the County of Solander;

(i) will the size of the Cherbourg reserve be increased before issuing the deed of grant in trust for that community so as to compensate the community for the land which will be resumed by the proposed dam shown on Map K2-57774 of the Water Resources Commission;
(j) will the old residents of Mapoon, now New Mapoon, be issued a deed of grant in trust over the Mapoon reserve number 11;
(k) will reserve numbers 2, 8, 9, 10, 12, 13, 15, 18 and 19 in the Bamaga area all be subjects of deeds of grant in trust for the five communities in that area ;

(l) will the cattle properties at Foleyvale, Duaringa, Sorrel Hills and Zamia Creek be the subjects of deeds of grant in trust; will these properties be maintained for Aboriginal cattle operations in view of the fact that they are used by a number of Aboriginal communities for their stock.

(5) Will the Minister initiate a joint Federal/State tribunal or judicial body to determine the areas of reserve land to be the subjects of deeds of grant in trust in view of the discrepancy of more than a quarter of a million hectares between the area of Aboriginal reserves as stated by the Queensland Land Administration Commission and the Queensland Department of Aboriginal and Islander Advancement in their reports to the Queensland Parliament in recent years.

answer.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) and (2) I refer the honourable senator to my statement of 1 April and the present Minister's reaffirmation of it of 27 August, this year. I refer also to my answer to a question from Senator Macklin as recorded at page 2399 of the Hansard of 17 November.
(3) The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is continuing to maintain close contact with Queensland Ministers in relation to plans for Deeds of Grant in Trust.

(4) and (5) Whether particular areas are for inclusion within any proposed Deed of Grant in Trust will be considered when the Queensland Government's proposals are put before Community Councils. The honourable senator might note that the Queensland Minister for Water Resources and Aboriginal and Island Affairs said in Queensland Parliament on 23 November: 'It is confirmed that the Deeds of Grant in Trust will be principally based upon the existing Aboriginal reserve boundaries, and that careful consideration will be given to special circumstances existing for those few communities where lands other than gazetted Aboriginal reserves are involved.'

The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, in a letter to Senator Bonner dated 4 October (see Senate Hansard of 14 October, page 1446) made it clear that the Commonwealth would ensure that legal aid was available so that the precise details of the areas to be included within each Deed of Grant were able to be checked to the satisfaction of the communities.

question.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 November 1982:

question.para: (1) Has the air-to-air missile to equip the RAAF's FA18s been selected.
(2) Have competing missiles such as the AMRAAM, Skyflash, Super R530 and any others been evaluated; is so, has the evaluation process been reached:
(a) the Force Structure Committee (FSC);
(b) the Defence Operational Requirements Committee (DORC);
(c) the Defence Source Definition Committee (DSDC); or
(d) the Defence Force Development Committee (DFDC).
(3) What progress has been made in the R530 replacement program.

(4) When can an order for advanced, medium range, presumably semi-active radar- guided, air-to-air missiles be expected, and will they be ordered in time to equip FA18s when this aircraft type enters service with the RAAF in 1986-87.
(5) What is the lead time for modern air-to-air missiles.
(6) What degree of Australian industrial participation in such a program can be expected.

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The short range air-to-air missile has been selected, and a provisional selection of a medium range air-to-air missile has been made.

(2) Yes. Air-to-air missiles for the FA18 were considered by the Government in the context of its deliberations on the aircraft selection. A proposal for the acquisition of a medium range air-to-air missile is currently under examination in the Department.
(3) There is no program to replace the R530 missile for Mirage use, however a refurbishment program to extend its life of type is progressing.
(4) Expectations are that an order will be placed for medium range air-to-air missiles for delivery in time to be available as each operational FA18 squadron is activated.
(5) Three years.
(6) Negotiations are currently in progress with contending missile contractors. Details of Australian industrial participation have not yet been finalized.

question.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 November 1982:

question.para: (1) Is there any staff requirement, staff target or staff objective for modern self-propelled or towed anti-aircraft artillery for the defence of the Field Force, rear or support areas and airfields.

(2) Has the purchase of Gepard or similar self-propelled anti-aircraft guns been considered by any of the following committees: the Force Structure Committee, the Defence Operational Requirements Committee, the Defence Source Definition Committee or the Defence Force Development Committee.
(3) What radar-guided or directed anti-aircraft guns are not available to the Field Force, or to defend airfields, in wartime.
(4) Does the Government assume that wherever Australian forces are deployed Australia would have such overwhelming air superiority that modern anti-aircraft guns are not necessary.

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes, an Army Staff Objective has been raised.
(2) The purchase of a self propelled gun such as Gepard was considered by the Department in the context of the proposal to replace the Redeye man-portable surface-to-air missile.
(3) Nil. Army has Rapier and Redeye surface-to-air missile systems for air defence.

(4) The Government does not assume that even with overall air superiority that the requirement for guns would be negated. However, Australia's ground launched air defence requirements are being met by missile systems which studies indicate are the more effective systems.

question.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 November 1982:

question.para: (1) Has the acquisition of such a mobile air defence system as Tracked Rapier been considered for any branch of the Australian Defence Force.
(2) Is there any staff requirement, staff target or staff objective for a self propelled surface-to-air missile system as Tracked Rapier.

(3) What measures have been taken to ensure Australian Rapier systems are modified to the same standards as British systems when they were modified to incorporate Falklands experience, given the technical deficiencies in the Rapier system brought to light by experience in the Falklands, especially those experienced with the Blindfire radar unit due to rough handling and problems in identifying friendly and enemy aircraft.

(4) Will any steps be taken to make Australian Blindfire radars more rugged, or does the Army regard them as sufficiently tough to withstand possibly rough treatment such as might be encountered in loading and unloading from amphibious warfare ships.

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) To date the acquisition of Tracked Rapier has not been considered within any branch of the Australian Defence Force.
(2) There is an Army Staff Objective which incorporates a requirement for a self propelled air defence system either gun or missile.

(3) The British Rapier systems are being upgraded to overcome technical deficiencies which were apparent prior to and confirmed by Falklands experience. Plans to modify the Australian Rapier systems to the same standards as the British systems are proceeding.
(4) No adverse reports on the performance of Blindfire radars in the Falklands have been received. It is considered that Blindfire is rugged enough to withstand normal in service use.

question.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 25 November 1982:

question.para: (1) Is there any staff requirement, staff target or staff objective for a man portable surface-to-air missile system to replace Redeye.
(2) Have competing missile systems such as Stinger, Blowpipe, and others been evaluated.

(3) Has the Redeye replacement program reached the Force Structure Committee, the Defence Operational Requirements Committee, the Defence Source Definition Committee or the Defence Force Development Committee.
(4) When can an order for modern man portable surface-to-air missiles be expected.
(5) What degree of Australian participation in such a program can be expected.

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) There is an Army Staff Requirement (ASR) for an air force defence system to replace Redeye.
(2) Evaluation of competing missile systems is progressing.
(3) The Redeye replacement Project has been considered by the appropriate Defence Committees.
(4) There is provision in the 1983-88 Five Year Defence Program for procurement of modern man portable surface-to-air missiles.
(5) The degree of Australian participation will depend on the particular system selected; however, in any event every effort will be made to achieve at least 30 per cent local participation.

question.speaker: Grimes Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 24 November 1982:

question.para: What is the Minister for Social Security's latest estimate of the most likely cost of unemployment benefits in 1982-83.

talk.start.para: â€”On 18 March 1982 (Hansard, page 925) Senator Elstob asked me a question without notice concerning setting up experiments in Australia similar to those being conducted in Japan and America on sailing ships using fully computerised sails and, in conjunction with the Minister for Transport, to consider granting funds to the Australian National Line for a feasibility study on the use of computerised sailing ships. I undertook to get further information on the matter and to direct the content of the question to both NERDDC and the Minister for Transport. I am now able to provide some additional information as follows:

answer.para: In the past decade there has been extensive world-wide research carried out into the application of sailing ship techniques to modern cargo vessels. In addition to the work at Monash University to which Senator Elstob has referred, work has been carried out in Australia by at least one commercial naval architect, Mr W. J. Hood. The British Ship Building Research Association conducted a symposium in London during 1980 on 'Wind Propulsion of Commercial Ships' and the proceedings of this symposium have been published. Experimental work on prototype applications has also been carried out by Japanese interests and others, and these have resulted in useful economies in certain highly specialised applications.

In Japan a 1,600 tonne sail assisted motor tanker 'Aitoku Maru' has been constructed and is undergoing trials. Use of the sails reduces fuel consumption by about 13 per cent. This study indicates that the capital cost of wind assisted vessels would be higher than that of conventional vessels.

In America current interest in sail power is directed towards the fishing industry and the merchant marine. Preliminary results in the fishing industry indicate that overall fuel savings of between 25 and 40 per cent would be possible under normal operating conditions. In regard to merchant shipping, the general consensus appears to be that sail power would be most viable for smaller vessels operating over relatively short routes. However the economics would depend on the particular application and the effects that the addition of sails would have on capital and operating costs including maintenance and manning levels.

In addition to this work, the fuel supply problems during the 1970s also focussed attention on a number of other promising approaches to fuel economy for marine transport. These include the use of larger propellers matched to slow running engines resulting in considerable oil consumption savings and the use of improved navigational aids such as the Omega and Navstar navigation systems which allow for more accurate position-fixing than astro-navigation. Coal-fired ships are also being introduced by Australian ship owners and at least one bulk carrier is operating on CNG.

In terms of commercial ship building and ship design work, Australia does not have a sufficiently large industrial base to support the substantial research effort which is traditionally carried out by the major ship building nations. However, it is clear from work to date that there is no shortage of information available to enable Australia's commercial ship owners to form appropriate judgements concerning the most economical approach to particular ship operations. In these circumstances I do not consider that it would be appropriate for special arrangements to be made to fund the Australian National Line to undertake feasibility studies in this field, particularly at a time of general restraint in Government spending. The adoption of particular technical options for carrying out its commercial activities is, of course, a matter for the judgement of ANL management.

The National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council (NERDDC) has considered two applications for support of R&D into sailing ships. The two applications were not recommended for funding because it was considered that research in the area is of relatively low priority for Australia.

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.
