talk.start.para: â€”On 9 September 1982 (Hansard, page 771) Senator Lajovic asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice regarding an item in the Sydney Morning Herald of 24 August 1982 concerning a recent study of the health of some 2,500 school children in New South Wales.

answer.para: The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The study referred to by the honourable senator was reported in the Medical Journal of Australia 1982; 2:178-183 and was entitled 'Health attitudes and knowledge, and coronary risk factors in high-school children, Sydney and Inverell'.

The results of this study indicated that 20 to 30 per cent of children (aged 11-16 years) surveyed were smoking cigarettes; 30 per cent were overweight or obese; 9 per cent had high blood cholesterol; and 8 to 15 per cent of boys and 2 to 7 per cent of girls had high blood pressure.

To date, no national study has been carried out on the health status of a statistically representative sample of Australian children. Consequently, information is not available as regards the 'real position' of the health conditions of young people. However, within recent years a number of studies have been conducted into both the life-style patterns and health parameters of selected groups of Australian children. These studies have consistently yielded results similar to those reported in the subject article.

Just as health services are mainly provided by State and Territory Governments , so too health education is primarily the responsibility of those authorities. They and various voluntary organisations are conducting a wide range of health promotion and intervention programs, many of which are directed to parents and young people. These bodies are considered the most appropriate avenues of disseminating-direct to parents, as part of the programs they conduct-the results of studies such as that reported in the subject article.

However, my Department is providing to health professionals, educators and voluntary organisations throughout Australia, information on the relationship between life-style factors, such as activity patterns and over-eating, and health and disease. Along with the National Health and Medical Research Council , my Department is responsible for the development of nutrition education standards or references. It has recently drawn up a set of dietary guidelines, published in a booklet 'Dietary Guidelines for Australians', to assist Australians to make decisions about the selection of a nutritious diet. The booklet points out the risk factors for a number of diseases associated with obesity and excessive intakes of fat, sugar, alcohol and salt and provides practical information on ways to reduce these risk factors by a wise choice of food. This booklet is freely available from my Department and, together with other nutrition education publications of the Department, is being widely used in schools.

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: â€”On 14 September 1982 (Hansard, page 866) Senator Tate asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice:

answer.para: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is it a fact that no instructions or requests to prosecute under the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980 have been made by the Australian Taxation Office to the Crown Solicitor's Office? Did the Crown Solicitor, in evidence before Estimates Committee A yesterday, claim that he had had to phone the Taxation Office during the last few weeks concerning this matter and had received contradictory statements as to the number of cases being ready for prosecution-at one time five and at another time nine? Has there been a deliberate cover-up in the Taxation Office in order to sustain the Treasurer's oft-quoted assertion that the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act stopped the entering into of the schemes covered by that Act? If not, what is the explanation for the failure of the Taxation Office to seek prosecutions after nearly two years of operation of the Act?
The Treasurer has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

No prosecution proceedings have yet been instituted under the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act. That Act came into operation on 4 December 1980 and applies to arrangements or transactions entered into on or after that date for a purpose of securing that a company (or trustee) will be unable to pay its tax. It follows that, before it can be said that a possible breach of the Act is apparent, it is necessary for preliminary investigations to have been carried out, for an assessment to have been made for the year of income in question and for the tax assessed to have remained unpaid after the due date. The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that those processes have been completed in seven cases in which breaches of the Act are suspected to have occurred during the year ended 30 June 1981. On 10 September 1982 information in respect of those cases was referred to the Australian Federal Police for formal investigation. The Commissioner understands that these cases have now been referred to the Special Prosecutor (Mr R. V. Gyles, Q.C.) by the Federal Police .

answer.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: â€”On 21 September 1982 (Hansard, page 1042) Senator Mason asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice regarding salt and its effect on health.

answer.para: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

The study, of which Dr Beard was the principal investigator and to which the honourable senator referred, found that 4 out of 5 cases of hypertension were able to either discontinue all medication or reduce the dose, following the use of a low sodium-not a salt-free-diet. The proportion of patients who could be treated effectively solely through the use of a low sodium diet, was 1 in 3.

The National Heart Foundation's Risk Factor Prevalence Study, of which I am aware, was carried out on a sample of Australian adults aged 25-64 years and living in the State capital cities. It found that approximately 20 per cent of people included in the study were hypertensive and, of this group, 33 per cent of men and 61 per cent of women were under treatment for raised blood pressure.

It is the total sodium content of the diet that is related to the development of hypertension. Salt (sodium chloride) is only one of twenty sodium compounds that may be used in food manufacturing. Therefore, it is important that consumers be informed of the amount of sodium-not salt-that is contained in packaged foods, and that legislation be based on total sodium content.

The matter of the declaration of sodium content on the labels of packaged foods is currently under consideration by expert committees of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH and MRC); these include State representation. The Council has already recommended that food ingredients, including added salt and monosodium glutamate, be declared on labels.

While the content of sodium of many prepared baby foods is not specified on the label, the content of sodium in canned baby foods is so specified under legislation in the States of Victoria and Queensland. An expert committee of the NH and MRC is now preparing detailed standards, including sodium limits, for all baby foods and the major manufacturers of these foods are represented on this committee.

Existing State legislation limits the sodium content of canned baby foods to 1 gram per kilogram-half the recommended limit of the Codex Alimentarius Commission of the Food and Agriculture Organization. I understand that manufacturers of baby foods are conforming nationally to this legislation.

Under these circumstances, where measures are already in place or under consideration to limit the sodium content in prepared baby foods, I do not consider there is a need for a study as proposed by the honourable senator.

However, the sodium content (provided mainly through added salt) of home- prepared foods and other family foods that are introduced into the diets of infants remains a problem. A recent study in Canada showed that home-prepared foods, compared to milk foods and commercial baby foods, were the major source of sodium in the diets of infants over six months of age. Nutrition education material prepared by my Department advises parents to limit the use of salty foods in the diets of young children. With increasing public awareness of the effect of salt on health, parents will hopefully become more discerning in their use of salt, particularly when preparing infants' meals.

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: â€”On 12 October 1982 (Hansard, page 1301) Senator MacGibbon asked me a question without notice concerning quality control standards used by Australian refiners in the production of automotive diesel oil. talk.start.para: â€”On 14 October 1982 (Hansard, page 1434) Senator Walters asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the operations of Medibank Private.

answer.para: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

The article in the Institute of Public Affairs' journal was based on financial data relating to Medibank Private's operations up to 30 June 1981. The Health Insurance Commission's 1981-82 annual report was tabled in the Parliament on 27 October 1982. In the year to 30 June 1982, Medibank Private recorded surpluses totalling $16.9m in four States and losses totalling $2.4m in two States. As at 30 June 1982 Medibank Private had total reserves of $40m or $20.3m higher than at 30 June 1981. I hope that this favourable trend will continue. answer.to.qwn.title: Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union Health Fund

answer.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: â€”On 20th October 1982 (Hansard, page 1619) Senator Lewis asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the financial position of the Health Insurance Commission ( Medibank Private) and an agency agreement between AMWSU Health Care Limited and Medibank Private.

answer.para: The Minister for Health has provided the following answer:

The Government's policy on reserves held by organisations registered under the National Health Act applies equally to Medibank Private. There is no legislative requirement in relation to reserves held by the organisations. Medibank Private is pursuing a policy of building up its reserves as competitive circumstances permit. Similar policies have been adopted by other funds.

Medibank Private's accumulated losses on trading to June 1981 were as indicated in the IPA Review article referred to by the honourable senator except that the figure for New South Wales should be $6.5 million and that in Western Australia Medibank Private accumulated losses of $0.6 million in the five years to 30 June 1981. However, since the article appeared, the 1981-82 Annual Report of the Health Insurance Commission has been tabled in Parliament. This report shows that, on an overall basis, Medibank Private made a surplus of $14.5 million for the year. Losses were incurred in only two States: South Australia and Western Australia. As at 30 June 1982, total reserves stood at about $40 million, $20.3 million higher than a year earlier.

It is a fact that over the five years to 30 June 1981 Medibank Private's management expenses, when related to contribution income, were well in excess of the average for the industry. However, in 1981-82 Medibank Private's management expense ratios varied from 11.0 per cent to 15.0 per cent and are now much less above the industry average than they used to be.

As to whether Medibank Private will charge the AMWSU the full management costs for handling its business, as mentioned in an earlier answer to a question from the honourable senator (Hansard, 26 October 1982, page 1795), Medibank Private regards the arrangements as being a purely commercial transaction and has informed me that the transaction would be profitable and in the interests of contributors.

Concerning Medibank Private's superannuation liability, it is the policy of the Health Insurance Commission to meet its commitments on an emerging costs basis. These commitments are reflected in Medibank Private's management expenses.
There is no sound basis for suggesting that Medibank Private will need regular injections of taxpayers' funds to enable it to survive.

answer.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: â€”On 9 November 1982 (Hansard, page 2040) Senator Georges asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the compilation of data and statistics on Aboriginal health.

answer.para: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

The collection of basic data and statistics relating to Aboriginal health is mainly a matter for the States and Territories in the first instance. However, the States, and to a lesser extent the Northern Territory, do not uniformly identify Aboriginals in their collections and this has limited the flow of data concerning Aboriginal health that is available for compilation and analysis by my Department.

Until such time as there is an increased flow of basic details from these sources, my Department can do little but maintain the existing level of statistics as published in the Annual Reports of the Director-General of Health . These data are prepared under the supervision of a Medical Officer Class 3 with assistance from an officer at Class 8 level. In addition, Dr L. R. Smith, B.A., Ph.D., a medical demographer who prepared the Aboriginal Health Bulletin Number 1-'Aboriginal Vital Statistics: An Analysis of Trends', has acted as a part-time consultant to my Department without renumeration.

My Department's resources allocated to this task are to be strengthened by the imminent appointment of an experienced statistical officer. Provided there follows increased consultation with relevant State/Northern Territory Departments resulting in an increase in the flow of data from them, I would expect a marked improvement in the quality of statistics.

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: â€”On 10 November 1982 (Hansard, page 2108), Senator Lajovic asked me a question without notice as to whether my Department had studied the generation of energy from waste. I said I would look into the matter and examine the need for research.

answer.para: I am advised by my Department that a number of studies on the possible use of household waste as an energy source has been undertaken in Australia by or on behalf of State and Local Government bodies concerned with energy and waste disposal. I am including details of several of the representative studies for information:
Kambah/Weston Creek Householders' Facilities Solid Waste Strategy Review: L. T . Frazer and Associates Pty Ltd for National Capital Development Commission, 1982 (ACT)
Mildura Incinerator Working Party Report: Department of Mineral and Energy Victoria, 1982
Energy Recovery from Refuse: Australian Mineral Development Laboratories Report No. 1331 for South Australian Department of Mines and Energy, 1980
Resource Recovery and Sydney's Waste Potential: Metropolitan Waste Disposal Authority, Sydney, NSW, 1979
Waste Disposal Alternatives for the Western Refuse Disposal Zone: Western Refuse Disposal Zone Steering Committee Report, 1982 (W.A.).
In the main these studies have concluded that the utilisation of household waste as an energy source is technically feasible but not economically viable.
My Department is monitoring developments in this field. I do not believe it necessary to initiate a further research project at this stage.

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”On 11 November 1982 (Hansard, page 2299) Senator Sibraa asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice, a question concerning work performed by a Singaporean firm called Autoblast Singapore Pty Ltd in sandblasting and painting work on several Australian Navy craft in particular HMAS Stalwart and HMAS Parramatta. The issue was raised on behalf of Senator Mulvihill.

answer.para: The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Each year, an amount is included in Defence Estimates under Division 235, Equipment Repair, for very limited ship repair in overseas ports. The work undertaken is to remedy urgent defects which cannot be left until the ship returns to Australia, and preventative maintenance which is declared essential by the Fleet Commander. The 1982-83 Estimates include $100,000 for overseas expenditure on these aspects, $75,000 for repair of urgent defects and $25,000 for preventative maintenance. These amounts are consistent with provision made in previous years.

In May 1982, whilst Stalwart and Parramatta were in Singapore, it was necessary for operational reasons associated with the Fleet Program and the need to complete basic ship husbandry activities within that program, to perform some ship's side gritblasting and repainting. The work was performed alongside a wharf.

The order for work was placed upon Autoblast Pty Ltd when that firm was the only company to respond to a call for tenders. Autoblast has not been given any indication that further work will be placed with it by the RAN.
It has always been Navy policy to fully occupy the local naval ship repair facilities and Navy can give assurance that major repair work will not normally be conducted abroad.

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: â€”On 16 November 1982 (Hansard, page 2317) Senator Coates asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer the following question, without notice:

answer.para: I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer how the figure of $700m-which was announced by the Government as the saving which will be spent on other projects instead of pay rises-was calculated? Is it net of income tax drawback? If not, how much actually will be available? If this wages freeze were to be extended across the board-as Senator Carrick keeps suggesting-and the private sector followed suit, what would be the amount involved in loss of income tax from those wages?
The Treasurer has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In calculating the figure of $700m, no allowance has been made for the loss of income tax revenue which would occur from the implementation of a pause in public sector wages. If, as the Government intends, the wage pause were extended to the private sector, income tax revenue would be lower, because of that factor, than would otherwise be the case. Until the precise form of the wage pause is agreed , however, it is not possible to calculate the further revenue loss which might be involved.

answer.to.qwn.title: Tax Exempt Status: Right to Life Organisation

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: â€”On 18 November 1982 (Hansard, page 2477) Senator Giles asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice:

answer.para: I direct my question to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle either in her capacity as Minister for Finance or as the Minister representing the Treasurer. Under what conditions do associations obtain tax exempt status for donations to their funds? Has there been an application by the organisation known as Right to Life for such status? If so, what was the result? Did that organisation have reason to believe that donations to its funds were in the course of being approved as a tax deduction, as indicated in a fund raising letter to Sydney lawyers dated 7 October 1982?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that an application was made on behalf of the organisation Right to Life Association for gifts to it to be tax deductible in accordance with section 78 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Because the organisation did not come within the scope of any of the provisions of section 78 the application was not granted.

The possibility of amending the law to include the Right to Life Association in the list of those specifically named in section 78 was also considered during the 1982-83 pre-Budget deliberations along with the many other requests received by the Government for new or extended taxation concessions. However, given the Government's desire to introduce broad measures of tax relief for the benefit of Australian families generally and a program of social security and welfare benefit increases, it was not found possible on this occasion to amend the law in the particular manner sought.

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: â€”On 19 November 1982 (Hansard, page 2568) Senator Martyr asked the Leader of the Government in the Senate, without notice, the following question:

answer.para: (1) Is it a fact that there is an interchange of Russian mercantile ship's officers with naval officers?
(2) Is it a fact that all Russian mercantile officers are naval reservists?
(3) Is it a fact that all Soviet mercantile vessels and crews are engaged in gathering intelligence for the Russian Navy?

(4) Is it not standard practice for the Russians always to deny such claims, as their local representative has done in this article, with the words that the charges are so ridiculous that they do not deserve comment?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
(1) It is believed that some merchant ships have naval officers among their complement.
(2) It is believed that most, if not all, Russian mercantile officers hold commissions in the naval reserve.

(3) I cannot confirm that all Russian mercantile ships and their crews are engaged in intelligence gathering for the Russian Navy. All ships probably report significant information on shipping movements, including those of foreign naval units.
(4) To the best of my knowledge, no Soviet spokesman has ever done other than deny such claims.

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”On 25 November 1982 (Hansard, page 2790) Senator Sibraa asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

answer.para: (1) Can the Minister advise the Senate whether the FA18 program will proceed.

(2) Can the Minister indicate whether the contract for the purchase of the FA18 includes provisions for Australian withdrawal if the aircraft does not meet the requirements specified at the time of contract.
(3) Does the Government intend to continue current expenditure and preparation for the manufacture of the FA18 while the future production of the aircraft is in doubt.

(4) Does the present contract provide for compensation payments to the Australian Government and private firms involved in the Australian industry participation program for accrued costs arising from the production contracts should production of the aircraft not be approved by the Congress of the United States of America.
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) The Government is confident that the FA18 program will proceed. The United States Defence Systems Review Committee (DSARC) has already cleared the FA18 for full production in the fighter role. We are confident that the DSARC will clear the FA18 for full production in the attack role in the near future.

(2) The Memorandum of Arrangements between the United States Government and the Australian Government relating to the procurement and co-production of a New Tactical Fighter Aircraft as presented to the Parliament by the then Minister for Defence on 18 November 1981 states at paragraph 24:

'Should the United States aircraft production program be suspended or significantly reduced, or there be a significant change in cost factors or substantial delay or other default by the prime contractor, or performance resulting from trials of the aircraft and its weapons indicate to Australia that the aircraft and its weapons will not meet the basic characteristics or the performance requirements agreed to at the time of the acceptance of the Letter of Offer and Acceptance, or the national interests so require, the Australian Government may wish to cancel, suspend, or significantly reduce its purchases. To the extent practicable and subject to authorization and appropriation of funds by the United States Congress, the United States Department of Defence will endeavour to apply any material cancelled by the Australian Government toward the satisfaction of its own approved requirements in order to minimize cancellation costs to the Australian Government. This undertaking shall not relieve the Australian Government of its responsibility for net cancellation costs under the terms of the Letters of Offer and Acceptance.'

This provision is also included in the Letter of Offer and Acceptance relating to Australia's 75 FA18 aircraft. Recognising the possibility of reduction in the production rate of FA18 aircraft in the early years of the program and the attendant possibility of increased costs, to contain such cost growth there are also provisions in the Letter of Offer and Acceptance which stipulate that the manufacture of the first of our aircraft should not precede a specified number of aircraft in the US program unless we decide otherwise.
(3) Yes. The Government has no advice to the effect that the future production of the FA18 is in doubt.

(4) If the sub contracts on Australian industry involved in the FA18 Australian Industry Participation Program are cancelled as a result of the US FA18 not being approved, Australian industry would have the right to recover accrued costs under the terms of the sub contracts negotiated between Australian industry and their US suppliers. As to the Australian Government's position in that event, the provisions of paragraph 24 of the Memorandum of Arrangements would generally apply.

question.speaker: Evans Sen G.J.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

question.para: Where, when, how and with what result has Australia participated in negotiations for a Sixth International Tin Agreement?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: Four negotiating meetings for the Sixth International Tin Agreement were held in Geneva, namely, 14 April-14 May 1980, 1-18 December 1980, 9-26 March 1981 and 9-26 June 1981. Australia participated in all the negotiating sessions which succeeded in establishing the text of the current Agreement. The Australian Delegation to the negotiations comprised senior officials of the Department of Trade and Resources and representatives of the Australian tin industry.

The Governor-General in Council on 22 January 1982 approved Australia's signature and provisional application of the Sixth International Tin Agreement. Australia signed the Agreement on 4 February 1982.

Countries representing 50.31 per cent of total consumption percentage and 82 per cent of total production percentage notified by the due date, 30 April 1982, their intention to deposit instruments or had deposited instruments to participate in the Sixth Agreement. The United States declined to join and therefore the required percentage of total consumption (65 per cent) represented by consuming countries to enable the Agreement to enter into force provisionally was not met.

However as provided for in the Agreement, governments of those countries which had, by 30 April 1982, notified of their intention to deposit instruments or had deposited instruments of ratification, acceptance, approval or accession met in Geneva on 10, 11 and 23 June 1982 and decided to bring the Sixth Agreement into force provisionally among themselves from 1 July 1982.

question.speaker: Grimes Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 25 August 1982:

question.speaker: Bolkus Sen N.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 7 September 1982:

question.para: (1) Is the Government aware that in the 'Wilson tapes' as presented to the Royal Commissioner, Mr Justice Stewart, Douglas Wilson claims that a senior officer of the now disbanded Customs Narcotics squad in Sydney was receiving $25 ,000 per year from the Mr Asia Organisation.
(2) What internal investigation has the Government taken in respect to these allegations as well as others that have been made to the Royal Commission.
(3) What officers of the now disbanded Customs Narcotics Bureau, and what other officers, have been prosecuted because of such allegations; if no prosecutions have been launched, then why not.

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) I am aware of the allegations by Douglas and Isobel Wilson concerning a link between an officer or officers of the now disbanded Federal Narcotics Bureau and the Terrence Clark drug trafficking group.

(2) and (3) A joint Police Group comprising members of the Commonwealth, Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland police, led by then Assistant Commissioner Hall of the Victoria Police, was established in June 1979 by the Commonwealth Government to investigate those allegations.

As a result of the Joint Police Group's inquiries, two officers of the former Federal Narcotics Bureau and a Sydney law clerk were charged (see answer to Question No. 2905 direct to the Attorney-General).

The allegations made by Douglas and Isobel Wilson are also within the terms of reference of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking, established by the Commonwealth Government, in conjunction with the State governments of New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland, in June 1981. The Commission is to provide its final report on its investigations regarding the Terrence Clark drug trafficking syndicate by 28 February 1983.

question.speaker: Keeffe Sen J.B.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 23 September 1982:

question.para: (1) Do export controls on tin under the Sixth International Tin Agreement actually apply to tin production which includes tin consumed in Australia as well as tin exported.
(2) Could those controls be called production controls rather than export controls; if so, could future agreements be negotiated so that controls apply to export tin only, and not on production.
(3) Which tin mining companies in Australia benefit from controls placed on production and not on exports alone.

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: â€”The Acting Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) to (3) The International Tin Agreement defines exports for the purpose of export controls applied under the Agreement. The definition for Australia includes tin consumed in Australia as well as tin exported. It is the clear intention of the Agreement that export controls should have the effect of reducing production so as to help correct the market imbalance that led to the imposition of the control.

question.speaker: Keeffe Sen J.B.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 23 September 1982:

question.para: (1) Does Australia's contribution to the world tin industry constitute only about 7 per cent of world tin production.
(2) What is the necessity for Australia to be a member country of the International Tin Agreement (ITA) when its production constitutes such a small percentage of total world tin production.
(3) What would be the benefits for Australia if it withdrew from ITA and sold its tin on the free market.
(4) What likely damage would the industry suffer if Australia withdrew from ITA immediately.

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Australia produced about 6 per cent of western world mine output of tin as recorded in 1981 by the International Tin Council.

(2) Membership of the International Tin Agreement is consistent with Australia' s longstanding policy of support for international co-operation aimed at bringing greater stability into international commodity trade and expanding and improving the market for commodities. Australian membership is considered important to the success and continued viability of the Agreement and to protecting Australia's trade and economic interests through the only specialised international forum on world trade in tin. In this regard, representatives of the tin industry have recently confirmed the previously expressed view that, on balance, it was to Australia's advantage to be a member of the International Tin Agreement. In addition, there are broad trade and foreign policy reasons for adhering to the Agreement because it covers a commodity of particular concern to developing producing countries, including the ASEAN countries, and because it helps to promote the mutual interests of tin producing and consuming countries generally.

(3) and (4) Australia could not withdraw immediately from the International Tin Agreement without incurring a severe penalty. If Australia were to decide to withdraw, it would have to give 12 months notice after 1 July 1983 of its intention, in order to be entitled to a share of the proceeds of the liquidation of the buffer stock on the termination of the Agreement. In this regard, Australia has contributed $10.8m to the buffer stock under the Sixth International Tin Agreement. Until Australia's withdrawal became effective, Australia would be obliged to observe the provisions of the Agreement including export controls. A declaration of intention to withdraw could be expected to have serious repercussions for Australia's relations in tin matters with the remaining members of the Agreement, for the future of the Agreement itself and thus for the stability of the world tin market for some considerable time.

question.speaker: Keeffe Sen J.B.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 23 September 1982:

question.para: (1) How many large Australian companies are involved in tin mining in the Asian area?
(2) Are the activities of these companies indirectly reducing Australian production of tin?

(3) Does the Australian company CSR Ltd operate one of the biggest tin mines in Indonesia with a quota of eight to ten times that for the North of Queensland; if the quota is not of this magnitude, what quota does CSR have in Indonesia?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Four large Australian companies are involved in tin mining in Asia (Broken Hill Proprietary Limited, BMI Ltd, CRA Ltd and CSR Ltd).

(2) These activities do not affect Australian production of tin. Tin quotas are allocated by the International Tin Council on a country by country basis based on past export performance. It is the responsibility of each Government to make an appropriate allocation to producers within its country.

(3) The Australian based company, Kajuara Mining Corporation is owned 50 per cent by CSR Ltd and 50 per cent by BMI Ltd. Kajuara in turn, owns 75 per cent of the Indonesian tin company PT Koba Tin, which is allocated a quota by the Indonesian Government.

Indonesia is the fourth largest tin producing nation in the world with an export quota in the current calendar quarter of 5,816 tonnes, of which Koba Tin' s allocation from the Indonesian Government is 1,086 tonnes. This quota is held by the Indonesian operating company and cannot be attributed to the indirect Australian shareholders.

question.speaker: Jones Sen G.N.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry , upon notice, on 12 November 1982:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware of the high level of activity by Japanese companies investing in Australian beef cattle grazing properties and the restocking of those properties with increased herds.
(2) Are Japanese investors attempting to gain control of the source of their beef imports as they have done in the case of other commodities such as coal and iron ore.

(3) Will this intrusion into Australia's ailing beef industry by foreign interests further aggravate an industry beset by problems of drought and sluggish markets to the extent that it may not recover its international viability.
(4) Will this type of foreign investment have an adverse effect on Australia's balance of payments.
(5) What measure is the Government considering to limit Japanese involvement in the Australian beef export industry.

answer.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: â€”The Acting Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following reply to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1), (2) and (3) The experience of the Foreign Investment Review Board is that there is not a high level of investment in beef cattle grazing properties on the part of Japanese investors. On the contrary, there has been relatively little interest shown by these investors in beef cattle grazing properties since the Board was established in 1976.

(4) There is no evidence to suggest that this type of investment should have an adverse effect on Australia's balance of payments. It is apparent that the level of Japanese investment in beef cattle grazing properties is very low in relation to Australia's beef industry and beef exports as a whole. The Government's policy requires that all foreign investment proposals be consistent with Australia's national interests, including in respect of such matters as the development of, or access to, new export markets; taxation considerations; and industry circumstances.

Proposed investments in beef cattle properties are assessed on their merits on the basis of the approach announced by the Treasurer on 20 January 1982 and outlined in Hansard on 9 September 1982 in response to the honourable senator's Question No. 1520.

(5) The Government is not considering measures to limit investment in the Australian beef industry by investors from Japan or any other country. The administration of the foreign investment policy is non-discriminatory as to the country of origin of investors.

question.speaker: Jones Sen G.N.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry , upon notice, on 21 October 1982:

question.para: (1) Has the Minister for Primary Industry seen a report in the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation journal, Ecos, which reveals that cattle are among the fastest-growing sources of methane gas that is warming up the earth's atmosphere.

(2) Is the Minister aware that the same report estimates that there are about 1 ,210 million cattle on earth and that each cow belches up about 300 litres of methane gas each day, an international total of a daily 363 billion litre bovine burp.
(3) Has the Department of Primary Industry ever considered encouraging the harnessing of this hitherto untapped and unlimited source of energy together with other contributions from the rural rump.

(4) Does the Minister envisage a future for cow-power in an energy-starved world, considering some of the amazing technological and scientific advances of the past few years; if so, will he consult with his colleague, the Minister for Science and Technology, to effect a joint feasibility study.

answer.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: â€”The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.

(4) No. There is no known practical way of collecting methane from such sources which could conceivably result in a net energy gain. Priorities for energy research lie elsewhere in proposals offering real potential.

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”On 9 November 1982 (Hansard, page 2036) Senator Townley asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory, a question without notice seeking the Minister to extend the period of daylight saving to six months in future summers.

answer.para: The Minister for the Capital Territory has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

While I personally favour the extension of daylight saving, it is desirable for obvious reasons that the period applying in the Australian Capital Territory should be uniform with that of New South Wales.

The New South Wales Government does not propose to extend the daylight saving period this summer. Consequently, it would be inappropriate for the Australian Capital Territory to act alone as inconvenience would be created to transport, commerce and communication links to the Territory.

However, if any new initiatives are forthcoming on the part of the New South Wales Government in the future, I would seriously consider the extension of the daylight saving period in the Australian Capital Territory.

answer.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: â€”On 10 November 1982 (Hansard, page 2114) Senator Button asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications the following question without notice:

answer.para: In view of the widespread disquiet in regional areas about big increases in telephone costs if the Government accepts the recommendations of the Davidson Committee of Inquiry into Telecommunications Services in Australia, will the Minister give an assurance that there will be no increases in the cost of communications in rural areas and outlying city areas as a result of any Government decision in this matter?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Government decisions on the recommendations of the Davidson Committee of Inquiry into Telecommunications Services will be made only after all relevant aspects have been fully examined. It is for this reason that the Government has invited comments on the recommendations from the public. I would expect that people in rural areas and outlying city areas will put their views forward and of course we would welcome those views.

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”On 2 December 1982 (Hansard, page 3044) Senator Coleman asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, a question without notice concerning the explosion of nuclear devices, whether the Minister for Defence had authorised any research into the effects of such explosions on Australian cities.

answer.para: The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

On 21 September 1982, the Minister for Defence, in response to Question Nos 4686 and 4687, informed the House of Representatives of Commonwealth-State responsibilities for civil defence and detailed action taken by the Commonwealth to fulfil its responsibilities.
From those statements the honourable senator would be aware that civil defence is primarily a State responsibility, but with Commonwealth support.

Some State authorities have undertaken an analysis of the effects of a large disaster, including nuclear explosions on a major Australian city, for use in their counter disaster and civil defence planning. The general effects are well known. Effects specific to a city require detailed knowledge of that city including geographic and demographic factors.

The Commonwealth has provided support over recent years by organising a number of national studies and reviews at the Australian Counter Disaster College on subjects related to the effects on communities of major disasters. These have included a Mass Burns Casualty Management Study, a Port Disaster Seminar and a study on the Protection of the Public from Ionising Radiation.

The Government rejects out of hand the suggestion that it does not support research on this subject. Equally, any suggestion that large additional resources should be poured into civil defence should be viewed most critically given the continuing assessments that attack is most unlikely, and other pressing demands for resources.

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: â€”On 8 December 1982 (Hansard, page 3216) Senator Peter Rae asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice:

answer.para: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is it a fact that in a television program produced by a Norwegian team and shown recently in a number of countries, visual and oral evidence was produced in relation to the huge number of people held in detention, without trial in Vietnam? Is it a fact that the number is not less than 15,000 and could be as high as 200,000 people? Since the war in Vietnam finished seven years ago, is it not a gross infringement of basic human rights that any of these people should continue to be held without trial? Will the Australian Government raise the matter in the United Nations and all other appropriate places to muster international pressure to force the Vietnamese Government to observe fundamental human rights?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following supplementary answer to the honourable senator's question:

On 24 September this year Vietnam acceded to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. Vietnam has therefore now acknowledged the legitimacy of international scrutiny of its human rights record. As senators will be aware, the Covenant specifically proscribes detention without trial and maltreatment of detainees. Australia has been a consistent supporter of the Human Rights Committee, the body which supervises the implementation of the Covenant. Our Missions in New York and Geneva and our representatives to bodies such as the United Nations Commission on Human Rights will be instructed to note Vietnamese violations at an appropriate opportunity.

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: â€”On 25 November 1982 (Hansard, page 2789) Senator Button asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

answer.para: Is it a fact that 13 of the Royal Australian Navy's 19 Tracker aircraft at Nowra in New South Wales are in mothballs? Is it also a fact that while these planes and their highly trained crews are idle the Government is hiring private aircraft for naval duties? Were two Piper Aztec aircraft hired last month from a Melbourne company which has been in receivership since August? Did Royal Australian Navy personnel have to repair faults in door locks, radio equipment and other parts of these hired planes before they could fly?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The following is a breakdown of the disposition of the 19 Trackers in the Royal Australian Navy's aircraft inventory:
Aircraft held by the squadron 5 Aircraft at Hawker de Havilland for overhaul 2 Aircraft in storage 11 Aircraft reduced to spares 1
Total 19

The Royal Australian Navy routinely uses charter aircraft under contract for specialised tasks such as target towing and for simple tasks such as radar tracking. In the case in question aircraft were required for anti-submarine air controller (ASAC) training. While Trackers would have been the preferred aircraft, insufficient Tracker hours remained available and pending revision of the FY 1982-83 estimates for this task, charter aircraft manned with naval Observers were used. Since that time Tracker hours for FY 1982-83 have been increased and further increases are being considered.

The Piper Aztec aircraft used for the ASAC training were provided by Phoenix Airways, a Melbourne based company which currently holds the contracts for this particular type of aircraft and service. The RAN was advised recently by the Department of Defence Support that Phoenix Airways had gone into receivership but would continue to provide aircraft services under the terms of the contract while they attempted to trade themselves out of difficulty.

The aircraft did suffer several minor routine unserviceabilities while operating out of NAS Nowra. The RAN did provide limited assistance in the rectification of several of these defects in preference to wasting valuable ship operating time due to cancelled or delayed sorties.
